name: ENVS-134
title: Environmental Geology
desc: Just as the physical environment impacts human activities, so too do our actions influence our surroundings. In this course we will seek to understand geologic processes and the ways in which humans interact with them. We will also explore the unique geology and physical geography of northeast Iowa during labs and field trips.

name: ENG-361
title: Chaucer and Medieval Literature
desc: From heroes fighting monsters to Arthurian romances, medieval literature is best known for its stories of chivalry.  Less well-known but equally wonderful are the comic tales of sex in trees and greedy friars dividing a fart.  We will read Beowulf, narrative poems about love and adventure by Marie de France, the tale of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, and much more, with in-depth attention to Chaucer's Canterbury Tales.(Same as WGST 361)

name: PE-250
title: Coaching of Sports:Softball
desc: Theory and technique of coaching softball. Taught in 2 credit hour units.  A maximum of 4 such credit hours may be counted toward the 128 required for graduation.  Some sports are offered alternate years.  For sophmores, juniors and seniors.

name: ENG-362
title: Renaissance Literature
desc: English literature came into its own during the Renaissance, as Sidney, Spenser, and Raleigh courted Queen Elizabeth's favor through love poetry, and sonnets were all the vogue. The period also produced the counter-cultural poetry of Donne and Marvell, and profound religious lyrics of Herbert, and the golden age of Engish drama with the plays of Marlowe, Shakespeare, and Jonson. The course will explore this rich body of literature through both literary and cultural analysis, with options for a range of student writing. Offered alternate years.

name: CHEM-490L
title: Senior Project Lab
desc: A semester-long laboratory experience in which students work as a group (minimum of 6 hours per week) on a project defined by the chemistry faculty.  This course requirement for majors may be waived for students who have an approved summer research experience in chemistry or a related area, or who have done research in chemistry or a related area at Luther for the equivalent of 2 semester hours. This course is grade credit/no credit.

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topic:panorama of MexicanyCivilization and Culture
desc: A study of the development of cultural and social institutions that have defined Mexico from pre-Colombian times to the present day.  Major themes and figures from politics, art, music, and literature will be presented and discussed to highlight the country's socio-cultural evolution.

name: PE-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: An opportunity to pursue a specialized area of the discipline for which course offerings are limited by following a prescribed reading list under the direction of a faculty member.

name: GS-98
title: HS Lang (other) - Semester 1
desc: Semester 1 of a high school language we do not offer at Luther. To be used to record that a student has completed a year of a language in high school.

name: GS-99
title: HS Lang (other) - Semester 2
desc: Semester 2 of a high school language we do not offer.

name: SPAN-499
title: Spanish Proficiency Exam
desc: Oral proficiency exam

name: ENG-363
title: Milton
desc: How could angels in Heaven and humans in Paradise rebel against the God who created the world and made it good?  Is it better to rule in Hell than serve in heaven?  What would it be like to live in Edenic bliss, anyway?  John Milton sought to answer those questions in Paradise Lost.  Second only to Shakespeare in its influence on later writers, Milton's work probes religion, politics, and gender in a remarkable melding of classical and Christian traditions.  We will read this epic, as well as other poems and prose in which Milton engaged the tumultuous events of the English civil wars and its aftermath.

name: PE-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Involvement in research project under supervision of department faculty. Recommended for students who expect to attend graduate school.

name: IS-135
title: Exploring Britain
desc: A year-long course in which Nottingham students travel to a variety of historical and cultural sites. Trips include approximately six weekend field trips to sites that may include London, Stratford-upon-Avon, the Lake District, Northern Ireland, Scotland, and Wales. Course work will also include research, reading, presentations, and discussion pertaining to each trip.

name: RUS-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the Registrar's Office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar.  Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects.  The completed project is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department.  All projects must be presented publicly.  Only projects awarded an "A- or A" qualify for "department honors" designation.  The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: ANTH-221
title: Anthropology in East Africa:yCulture Change Among the Maasai
desc: The Maasai pastoralists of Tanzania and Kenya are experiencing rapid culture change in response to global, national, and local forces.  In this course we will study "traditional" Maasai culture and examine the ways in which the Maasai of northern Tanzania are adapting to changing social, political, economic, and environmental conditions. Topics to be explored include the shift from herding to agropastoralism; the tension between traditional and formal modes of education; the adoption of Christianity in place of or alongside traditional religion; changes in coming-of-age rituals; cultural dimensions of health, illness and healing; challenges to traditional gender ideology; the Maasai relationship to their environment; and the impacts of ecotourism, cultural tourism, and wildlife conservation programs on the pastoral way of life.  From bases near the city of Arusha and the small town of Monduli students will interact with Maasai people in urban and rural marketplaces; in schools, medical facilities, and places of worship; and at Maasai bomas (family compounds) in the bush.  We will also visit the Ngorongoro Crater Conservation area and the Oldoinyo Lengai volcano and pilgrimage routes in in order to explore the tension between pastoralism, wildlife conservation programs, and tourism.  Offered January term. (Same as AFRS 221)

name: AFRS-221
title: Anthropology in East Africa: Forces ofyCulture Change Among the Massai
desc: The Maasai pastoralists of Tanzania and Kenya are experiencing rapid culture change in response to global, national, and local forces.  In this course we will study "traditional" Maasai culture and examine the ways in which the Maasai of northern Tanzania are adapting to changing social, political, economic, and environmental conditions. Topics to be explored include the shift from herding to agropastoralism; the tension between traditional and formal modes of education; the adoption of Christianity in place of or alongside traditional religion; changes in coming-of-age rituals; cultural dimensions of health, illness and healing; challenges to traditional gender ideology; the Maasai relationship to their environment; and the impacts of ecotourism, cultural tourism, and wildlife conservation programs on the pastoral way of life.  From bases near the city of Arusha and the small town of Monduli students will interact with Maasai people in urban and rural marketplaces; in schools, medical facilities, and places of worship; and at Maasai bomas (family compounds) in the bush.  We will also visit the Ngorongoro Crater Conservation area and the Oldoinyo Lengai volcano and pilgrimage routes in in order to explore the tension between pastoralism, wildlife conservation programs, and tourism.  Offered January term. (Same as ANTH 221)

name: HIST-139
title: ST:History of the Modern SouthernyCivil Rights Movement, 1954-1965

name: REL-339
title: Religion and Media: God and InformationyTechnologies From Papyrus to Cyberspace
desc: Religion and Media: God and Information Technologies from Papyrus to Cyberspace. This course provides a broad historical and comparative survey of the relation between religion and the various forms of mass media. Looking to the past for comparative resources that help to orient current questions about religion and new forms of mediated communication, it surveys a broad range of Western religious and philosophical writings (drawn from Plato, the Bible and other early Christian texts, Augustine, Luther, Nietzsche, Hegel and others). Selections are read closely for clues about the media environments in which they were first produced and also in conjunction with contemporary reflections on the history of media and religion. Topics include the way depictions of divine revelation consistently have been influenced by new types of information storage materials like the stone tablet, papyrus scroll, codex, or, more recently, the silicon computer chip; the influence of postal and other

name: ENG-364
title: Restoration and Eighteenth-CenturyyBritish Literature
desc: This course explores the range and variety of British literature written after the restoration of the British monarchy in 1660, and before the revolution in France in 1789.  Literary artists in this era produced innovative writing in several new genres, including journalism, travel writing, biography, satire, and the novel.  The literature of the 18th century was also a crucible for modern understandings of gender, race, and class identities.  In this course, we explore these literary developments within their historical contexts, aiming for a broad coverage of canonical and not-so-canonical texts.  Representative authors may include Dryden, Congreve, Behn, Swift, Pope, Johnson, Fielding, Burney, and Haywood. Offered alternate years.

name: REL-239
title: ST:Life After 9/11: Unity and DiversityyIn Contemporary Islam
desc: Life after 9/11: Unity and Diversity in Contemporary Islam. Due to the events of Sept. 11, 2001 Islam has become a pervasive topic in American public discourse, and it has become clear that Islam is a phenomenon that must be understood in order to comprehend life in the twenty-first century. But what role does Islam play in the contemporary world, especially if there is not a single Islam about which this question can be asked?  What is the range of Islamic diversity, and how do these diverse viewpoints answer differently the question of Islam's role in the world?  Are there any common themes uniting the diversity of Islamic voices?  Topics to be covered will include Islamic revival movements in Egypt and Turkey, the history and legacy of the Shi"ite revolution in Iran, the role of women in Muslim society including the development of Islamic feminism, and the development of a progressive Islam movement growing in reaction to the so-called fundamentalist Islam. Because of the rapid

name: REL-339
title: ST:Church and Society: The LiberatingyRole of Religion in Brazil

name: POLS-239
title: Special Topic:Politics of Rock and RollyMusic
desc: This course is an exploration of the political character of rock and roll music from its appearance in the 1950's to contemporary performers. Students will examine the themes of freedom, liberation, empowerment, pluralism, change and public action as interpreted by various musicians, and analyze the challenges posed to the spirit of rock and roll (and, by extension, the spirit of politics,) by mass mentalities and private interest. Optional, non-required films will be shown after class. Course feeL Approx. $25.00 to attend a theater performance in St. Paul.

name: GS-139
title: Special Topic:Discovering Identities:ySelf, Vocation and Balance

name: AFRS-185
title: Blaxploitation:It's Birth and EvolutionyEvolution
desc: This course will explore the development of the film genre commonly referred to as blaxploitation. Beginning in the late 60s and lasting through the 70s, this body of movies starred African-American actors who would become icons in black American culture. Our study will focus on the social and political forces that gave birth to this wave of art, noting how the films challenged, resisted, transformed, or confirmed public perception about African-Americans, both within the black and white communities. Thus the films' political content, as it relates to racial discourse, class realities, and gender norms, will serve as the focus of the class conversation. We will view films such as Cotton Comes to Harlem, Superfly, Foxy Brown, and Shaft.  (Same as Eng 185 and Wgst 185)

name: ENG-185
title: Blaxploitation:It's Birth and Evolution
desc: This course will explore the development of the film genre commonly referred to as "blaxploitation."  Beginning in the late 60s and lasting through the 70s, this body of movies starred African-American actors who would become icons in black American culture.  Our study will focus on the social and political forces that gave birth to this wave of art, noting how the films challenged, resisted, transformed, or confirmed public perception about African-Americans, both within the black and white communities.  Thus the films' political content, as it relates to racial discourse, class realities, and gender norms, will serve as the focus of the class conversation.  We will view films such as Cotton Comes to Harlem, Superfly, Foxy Brown, and Shaft. (Same as Afrs 185 and WGST 185).

name: ENG-139
title: ST:Home & Away: Mapping GenderyAnd Space in Modern AmericanyLiterature

name: ENG-139
title: ST:Literature of the Apocalypse
desc: Literature of the Apocalypse. This course will focus on literary and filmic narratives produced during moments of perceived and real crisis. The kinds of crisis range from the end of the world to the end of culture and/or the collapse of individual identity.  We will examine the variety of ways writers and filmmakers respond to these "deaths" with narratives which sometimes merely document the world lost, sometimes rage against that loss, and still other times reassert an imaginative order to replace the one that is disappearing. Some texts we will examine include Shakespeare's King Lear, Mary Shelley's The Last Man, Thomas Pynchon's The Crying of Lot 49, John Williams' Sons of Darkness, Sons of Light, Flannery O'Connor's "Revelation," Julio Cortazar's "Apocalypse at Solentiname," and Suzy McKee Charnas' Walk to the End of the World. Films will include Fight Club, Dr. Strangelove, and The Quiet Earth.

name: MATH-258
title: Chaotic Dynamical Systems
desc: Why is it so difficult to make accurate predictions about seemingly chaotic physical systems like weather? This course explores the behavior of nonlinear dynamical systems described by iterated functions. A variety of mathematical methods, including computer modeling, is used to show how small changes in initial conditions can drastically change the future behavior of the system. Topics will include periodic orbits, phase portraits, bifurcations, chaos, symbolic dynamics, fractals, Julia sets, and the Madelbrot set. Offered alternate years.

name: PSYC-139
title: ST:Psychology of Language Dev
desc: Special Topic: Psychology of Language Development. The goal of this course will be to understand how spoken language can be used to solve problems. To understand the basis of language use, we will first examine how infants acquire and manipulate language.  Then, we will investigate the many choices speakers make when trying to communicate clearly. Finally, we will explore the cues listeners use when trying to understand spoken language. Through readings, discussions, and in-class demonstrations, we will develop a model of spoken language use as a tool.  Prereq: psych 130.

name: PSYC-439
title: St:an Introduction to Behavior Genetics:yStudying Twins and Adoptees

name: BIO-249
title: Winter Biology
desc: A field study of the natural history of the southern boreal forest ecosystem in northern Minnesota, including the physiological and behavioral adaptations of organisms to extreme cold. Course activities will include skiing and snowshoeing excursions in remote natural areas, assigned readings, observations of natural history, and research projects. Students who earn credit for 249 may not earn credit for 149.

name: GS-185
title: Latino Literature of the United States

name: EDUC-222
title: Instructional Strategies With ComputeryApplications: Elementary
desc: This course examines the use of behavioral objectives, lesson planning, testing, evaluation, classroom management, instructional techniques, learning theory applications, and instructional media in elementary education.  Course objectives are achieved through writing instruction and practice using conventional writing tools and computer applications. Requires sophomore standing.

name: PAID2-450
title: Health Care Ethics
desc: This course provides a case-study approach to contemporary ethical issues in U.S. health care. Utilizing resources derived from Christianity and Western moral traditions, students develop their own moral framework to respond to issues like abortion, genetic engineering, and the allocation of scarce resources. Attention is given to the communal dimension of moral deliberation and to the social, political, economic, legal, religious and technological forces that impact health care practice today.

name: PAID2-450D
title: Health Care Ethics Dis
desc: A case-study approach to contemporary ethical issues in U.S. health care and its global implications.  Utilizing resources derived from Christianity and Western moral traditions, students will develop their own moral framework to respond to issues like abortion, genetic engineering, and the allocaiton of scarce resources.  Attention is given to the communal dimesion of moral deliberation and to the social, political, economic, legal, religious, and technological forces that impact health care practice today.  A local field trip may be included as well as several day long seminars with guest speakers.

name: SW-139
title: Special Topic:US Mexico ImmigrationyIssues in Context

name: EDUC-330
title: Introduction to Early ChildhoodyEducation
pre_req: Admission to Teacher Educ Program and EDUC 222. It is recommended that the student has completed or is taking EDUC 226 concurrently.
desc: This course is an introduction to early childhood education: the history of the field; educational philosophies for the pre-kindergarten/kindergarten learner; and the developmentally appropriate curriculum in language arts, sciences, social sciences, and mathemathics.  Also included are assessment, and parent involvement programs. Recommended for all elementary education majors and required for all students for certification in kindergarten and early childhood education. It is recommended that the student has completed, or is taking, EDUC 226 concurrently.

name: SPAN-239
title: Special Topic: Culture and Society inyMexico
desc: Culture and Society in Mexico. Course is designed primarily for Spanish minors and will be based in Puebla.  It includes homestays, intensive Spanish language classes in the mornings at a language school, and experiential learning opportunities with a social service institution or in a future employment related area 3 days/week while in Puebla. Afternoon and weekend excursions include Cholula, Cuetzalan (where students will stay in a hotel run by a cooperative of indigenous women and travel each day to the Nahua village of San Miguel Tzinacapan); and to another major city such as Veracruz, Oaxaca, or Acapulco.  The program will end in Mexico City, with excursions including the Zocalo area, Bellas Artes, the Museum of Anthropology, and the archaeological site of Teotihuacan.  Prereq:  Spanish 202 and consent of instructor.

name: SOC-139
title: Special Topic: Sociology of Work andyOccupations

name: COMS-342
title: Feminist Rhetorical Theories
desc: This course is a study of feminist rhetorical theories and expression. The class reads texts by feminist rhetorical theorists and rhetors. Special emphasis is placed on the intersection between social, cultural and economic contexts, political influences, and rhetorical strategies of women rhetors challenging Western patriarchy. This course applies toward the theory requirement for the WGST major. Offered alternate years. (Same as WGST 342)

name: REL-339
title: ST: Wo/men and the Pauline Tradition
desc: This course examines the literary, historical, and theological interpretation of the New Testament letters attributed to Paul from the perspectives of feminist, liberationist, and post-colonial theories and theologies as well as the voices of traditionally marginalized groups. We will trace the impact of the Pauline tradition on issues of slavery, poverty, sexuality, and women's equality from early Christianity to contemporary debates. By using the feminist category "wo/men," we will approach the Pauline tradition from a variety of women's perspectives as well as from the perspectives of subjugated men.

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar:Ecological Design
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: This course will be an interdisciplinary seminar for students completing the environmental studies minor. It will be topical in nature and will combine lecture and seminar approaches to the exploration of environmental issues and policies. Prerequisites: completion of all other courses for the minor, or consent of instructor.

name: FREN-339
title: Special Topic:Slavic, Romance, GermanicyAnd Classical Languages in Space andyTime

name: FCUL-339
title: Special Topic:Slavic, Romance, GermanicyAnd Classical Languages in Space andyTime

name: RUS-339
title: Special Topic:Slavic, Romance, GermanicyAnd Classical Languages in Space andyTime

name: SCST-339
title: Special Topic:Slavic, Romance, GermanicyAnd Classical Languages in Space andyTime

name: SCST-363
title: Norway's Nobel Prize-Winning Authors
desc: Through the lives and literature of Nobel Prize-winning authors, Bjornstjerne Bjornson, Knut Hamsun, and Sigrid Undset, the history of Norway unfolds with its struggles and triumphs from the Middle Ages through Norway's World War II occupation by Hitler's forces. Reading selected works and viewing films based on them, as well as researching the authors' lives and times, students will gain an understanding of the highlights of Norway's history and literary production. All readings and discussion are in English.  Advanced Norwegian language students may elect to enroll in this course for additional coursework in Norwegian. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topic:Slavic, Romance, GermanicyAnd Classical Languages in Space andyTime

name: EDUC-344
title: Methods and Strategies for TeachingyStudents With Learning Disabilities andyBehavioral Issues
pre_req: EDUC 242, 366 (or 321 and 322), Admission to Teacher Educ Program, and junior standing
desc: This course provides an exploration of various methods, techniques, and materials that are used in the education of students who have learning disabilities and behavioral issues in a variety of different settings including the general education classroom.  Methods and materials for instruction in mathematics, reading, written language, spoken language, social skills, listening skills, organizational skills, and skills to enhance life/career choices will be addressed. Must be taken during the junior-level methods course sequence.

name: BIO-357
title: Immunology
desc: This course examines how the cells and molecules of the human immune system develop and how they work together in providing defenses against invading microorganisms.  A portion of the course will emphasize reading, evaluation, and presentation of primary and secondary immunological literature. A non-lab course.

name: PSYC-356L
title: Stress, Coping and Well- Being Lab

name: SPAN-239
title: ST: Conversation & Culture (Chile)
desc: Conversation and Culture (Valparaiso, Chile.  This course is designed primarily for Spanish minors and is based in Valparaiso, Chile.  It includes home stays (one student per Chilean family) intensive language classes (with faculty from the Catholic University of Valparaiso) and experiential learning opportunities.  They include daily cultural excursions and weekend travel to Isla Negra, La Serena, and Santiago.  Students will also visit the small fishing villages of Horcon, Zapallar, and Papudo on the ocean. Prereq: Spanish 202 and consent of instructor.

name: SPAN-339
title: ST: Conversation & Culture (Chile)
desc: Conversation and Culture (Valparaiso, Chile.  This course is designed primarily for Spanish minors and is based in Valparaiso, Chile.  It includes home stays (one student per Chilean family) intensive language classes (with faculty from the Catholic University of Valparaiso) and experiential learning opportunities.  They include daily cultural excursions and weekend travel to Isla Negra, La Serena, and Santiago.  Students will also visit the small fishing villages of Horcon, Zapallar, and Papudo on the ocean. Prereq: Spanish 202 and consent of instructor.

name: ACCTG-380
title: Internship
desc: On-the-job learning experience in government or industry. The plan must be presented for departmental approval before the experience begins. (Note: Those students with less than a 2.50 GPA in the major must have departmental approval before interviewing.)

name: MUS-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: Students who develop an interest in a specialized area of the discipline for which course offerings are limited may follow a prescribed reading list under the direction of a member of the faculty with expertise in that area.

name: BIO-139
title: Special Topics:Wildlife Survey-Wolf andyLynx Ecology Experiences

name: PHYS-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Directed research involves students in research projects under the supervision of department faculty. Recommended for students who expect to attend graduate school in physics or engineering. With the approval of the department, students may register for more than one semester (cumulative total may not exceed 4 semester hours). Prerequisite: approval of the research director and the department head. Normally 12 hours of physics above 150 will be required.

name: PHYS-491
title: Senior Project
desc: Students will write a research paper reporting the nature, outcomes, and significance of the project undertaken in PHYS 490.

name: CHEM-201
title: Advanced Chemical Principles
desc: A faster paced introduction to Chemistry than CHEM 151 and 152.  Material from both CHEM 151 and 152 will be included, but basic chemical knowledge and competence in algebra will be assumed.  Lab will emphasize an introduction to several instruments and to data-handling with spreadsheets. Prerequisite: a good high school chemistry course and testing into at least MATH 151 on mathematics placement test. In order to have a full year of chemistry as required by many professional schools students must take CHEM 202 in addition to this course. (Student who earn credit for 201 may not earn credit for CHEM 114 or 116).

name: CHEM-365
title: Spectroscopy and Separations Lab
desc: A laboratory introduction to various types of spectroscopy and separation techniques and how they are used in the chemistry laboratory. Techniques will include UV/VIS, IR, fluorescence, and NMR spectroscopy, and liquid and gas phase chromatography.

name: CHEM-366
title: Thermodynamics and Kinetics Laboratory
desc: A laboratory introduction to the study of the energetics and rates of chemical reactions.

name: CHEM-344
title: Instrumental Methods:ySpectroscopic Techniques
desc: A detailed look at the instrumentation and applications of optical spectroscopy associated with chemical analyses. Topics will include molecular and atomic absorption, fluorescence, NMR, and IR spectrometries, as well as selected advanced spectroscopic techniques.

name: SCST-499
title: Scandinavian Studies Proficiency Exam
desc: Language proficiency exam required for the major.

name: ENG-365
title: British Romanticism: Revolution, Nature,yAnd the Imagination
desc: The era of the American and French revolutions profoundly affected England, inspiring cultural debates about slavery and women's roles, as well as new ways of looking at the natural world, human perception, imaginative creation, and the Gothic past.  We will study the cultural milieu and read such writers as Blake, Equiano, Burke, Wollstonecraft, Austen, William and Dorothy Wordsworth, Coleridge, Percy and Mary Shelley, Byron, and Keats.  Offered alternate years.

name: CS-330
title: Internet Programming
desc: In this course we examine three-tier Internet application architectures. Applications developed for the internet typically have a database back end, an application server in the middle and a web server on the front end. We will examine application programming frameworks from CGI to Servlets, and other modern application programming frameworks such as Ruby on Rails. Other topics include XML-based architectures such as RSS and web services, data transformation using XSL and XSLT. The course is largely project driven, students will implement a complete web based application. HCI is addressed.

name: BIO-362
title: Neuroscience
desc: The course explores the means by which neurons function and how they form circuitry related to sensory input, motor control and higher cognitive functions.  A second component of the course is devoted to the role of primary literature within the field of neuroscience, including how hypotheses are formulated, tested and the results conveyed to the scientific community.  A non-lab course. (Same as NEUR 362)

name: MGT-339
title: Special Topic: Creativity and Innovation
desc: The course provides students with creativity and innovation methodologies used to inspire, create, and innovate.  Students will develop an understanding of the dynamics, some of which are counter intuitive, associated with developing and sustaining organizational cultures that foster innovation and make ideas a central part of work. In addition, students will learn how to create sustainable competitive advantage through entrepreneurial and intrapreneurial innovation. When possible, creativity and innovation experts will be invited to share insights and experiences with the class.  Prereq: Junior standing or above.

name: REL-339
title: ST: Vocation as a Call to Citizenship
desc: This course will examine the thoughts of Martin Luther on the topic of vocation and social responsibility, provide an overview of the theological development in Luther's thoughts, establish a connection with the contemporary debates on citizenship, and explore some of the ethical consequences of such reflection on vocation as a call to citizenship from a Lutheran standpoint. Prerequisite: Rel 101, 111, or 112.

name: REL-339
title: ST: Zen Buddahism & Japanese Culture
desc: This course will explore the history and development of Zen Buddhism in China and Japan and its influences on Japanese culture. In particular, the course will focus on the beginnings of the Zen Buddist tradition during the Tang dynasty, the formation of its institutions and its canon in Sung China, its impact on the Samurai culture of Tokugawa, Japan, and its influence on contemporary Japanese culture. In this process, the course will address the sectarian politics inherent in the process of canon formation, the scriptural tradition of Zen Buddhism the way the religious ideal of Zen Buddism sought its expression in tea ceremony and martial arts during the Tokugawa period, its influence on the philosophies and politics of pre-war Japan, and its multiple faces in Japan today. Prerequisite: Rel 101,111,or 112.

name: PHYS-339
title: Special Topic:Numerical Physics
desc: Special Topic:Numerical Physics. The formulation and numerical solution of physics problems.  Focus on approaches to complex physical situations that are not practically solvable using analytical methods.  Problems applicable to several branches of physics including astrophysics, atomic physics, fluid mechanics, thermal physics and condensed matter physics. Prerequisite:  Physics 203. Corequisite: Math 240.

name: SW-239
title: Special Topic:cross-Cultural Social WorkyA Navajo Perspective
desc: Special Topic:Cross-Cultural Social Work:A Navajo Perspective.  This immersion course provides an introduction to contemporary social welfare networks serving the Navajo Nation.  Topics include the particular cultural, historical and socioeconomic factors impacting the health and welfare of people living in Rock Point, Arizona; cross-cultural competence through understanding and appreciating the strengths, adaptive capacities, worldview, and traditional values of the Navajo; specific challenges to community life and individual well-being; processes of cultural and community change; and the roles of different tribal, state, and federal social welfare agencies and programs.  Includes a service-learning project at the Navajo Evangelical Lutheran Mission School, and visits to area social welfare agencies. Prerequisites:SW 201 or Anth 201; consent of instructor required.

name: ENVS-139
title: ST:Politics of Local Land Use
desc: This course will determine the nuts and bolts of land use regulation with theoretical inquiries about community democracy and citizen involvement at the local level.  The course will pay special attention to reading case studies of land use practices throughout the United States, the course will use Winneshiek County as a laboratory for  studying the development and implementation of  land use policies.

name: COMS-130
title: Interpersonal Communication
desc: A course dealing with the basic concepts of person-to-person communication, such as the relationship between verbal and nonverbal language, the intent and result of message sharing, the variables in communicative efforts.

name: COMS-132
title: Public Address
desc: A study of the principles of speech composition, organization, and delivery; emphasis on the role of public address in a democratic society. Each student gives a series of speeches.

name: COMS-463
title: Communciation and Public Relations
desc: This course examines concepts of public relations practice in organizational systems with emphasis on communication theory and development of a problem-solving perspective. Students apply theory directly to practical public relations problems. Requires junior or senior status.

name: COMS-133
title: Mass Media
desc: This course studies the evolution of mass media and its relationship with our culture.  In addition to gaining an understanding of mass media, students will critque various forms of media, and explore basic writing skills necessary for media production.

name: COMS-357
title: Research Methods
desc: Students are introduced to communication and rhetorical methods including design of experimental, survey, textual, rhetorical, and ethnographic research.

name: COMS-236
title: Small Group Communication
desc: A study of the purposes, types, processes, and behavioral dynamics of small group interaction. Covers theory and research with special attention to the dynamics, leadership, and the task dimensions of groups. Each student participates in several groups.

name: ENG-366
title: The Victorians
desc: The Victorians experienced cataclysmic changes in science, economics and industry, national identity, gender roles, and faith.  Novelists wrestled with these changes, chronicling the broad social world and the schisms that divided it. Poets of the period registered extremes of doubt, or returned to an idealized past, or looked forward to developments like the liberation of women.  Representative authors may include the Brontes, Dickens, George Eliot, Hardy, Tennyson, and Barrett Browning.  Offered alternate years.

name: COMS-353
title: Argumentation
desc: The course takes a rhetorical perspective on argument. Basic principles of argumentation are explored: problem solving through evidence, reasoning, and persuasion. Analysis and criticism of various types of contemporary speech-making based on principles, models, and theories of argumentation. Offered alternate years.

name: COMS-359
title: Media and Popular Culture
desc: An in-depth exploration of the relationship between mass media and culture with particular emphasis on the relationship between the media of mass communication and particular fundamental institutions, such as family, government, religious institutions, and the commercial sphere.  The course will also offer opportunities for student research concerning how media influence language, values, and social norms.

name: COMS-350
title: Intercultural Communication
desc: Communication theory and research are  used to examine the processes involved in communicating with those who are not members of one's particular cultural, ethnic, racial, religious, gender, ability, and socioeconomic group. Discussion, group activities, and papers will focus on the issues of awareness and competence in increasing one's communicative effectiveness.

name: COMS-239
title: Special Topic: Media and ChristianityyIn America

name: COMS-339
title: Special Topic: the Rhetoric of EverydayyLife

name: LING-131
title: Introduction to Linguistics
desc: Every time we utter a word, no matter how mundane, we engage in a remarkable and, to the best of our knowledge, uniquely human behavior.  This course explores the human capacity to acquire and use language.  Topics include the nature of dialectal differences and the sociolinguistic factors which determine them, the ways in which languages vary and the importance of linguistic diversity, and the nature of the knowledge of language and how it relates to child language acquisition and other aspects of human cognition.

name: BIO-139
title: Special Topic: Genes and Genomes
desc: This non-majors, non-lab course introduces fundamental concepts and applications of genetics. Inheritance patterns, mutations, and evolutionary mechanisms will comprise the first part of the course.  The second portion will focus on genome-level information and its potential use(s).

name: MUS-338
title: Composition: Private Lesson
desc: Individual composition lessons designed to develop compositional facility in a variety of styles and media. Students also participate in a weekly composition seminar and interact with guest composers.  May be repeated for credit.  May be taken for 1 or 2 credits as directed by instructor.

name: COMS-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the " Honors Progarm" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar.  Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed project is evaluated by a review committtee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, another faculty member from outside the major department.  All projects must be presented publicly.  Only projects awarded an "A or A-" qualify for "department honors" designation.  The honors project fulfill the all-college senior project requirement.

name: ART-139
title: Special Topic:Capital Landmark in Artyand Architecture (Washington Consortium

name: COMS-380
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on-campus or off-campus work experience in some area of public communication. No more than four hours may be counted toward the communication major.

name: ENG-367
title: Twentieth-Century British Literature
desc: Many Europeans braced themselves for the start of the 20th century, firm in their belief that it might augur the end of the world.  For thousands of soldiers slaughtered during the "war to end all wars," it was.  Between World War I and II, British writers and Irish nationalists transformed the literary landscape with a radically new approach to language, form, and style.  Women writers explored new freedoms in sexuality and in their literary subjects.  In the second half of the century, novelists and poets confronted the legacy of economic reform, urbanism, and the remnants of British colonialism around the globe.  Readings might include writers such as Yeats, T.S. Eliot, Woolf, Forster, Katherine Mansfield, Jean Rhys, Ted Hughes, and Graham Greene.  Offered alternate years.

name: ENVS-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A yearlong independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar. Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed project is evaluated by a review commitee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department. All projects must be presented publicly. Only projects awarded an "A-" or "A" qualify for "department honors" designation. The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: COMS-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Directed research involves students in research projects conducted under supervision of department faculty. With the approval of the department, students may register for more than one semester (but the cumulative total may not exceed four credit hours.) Requires approval of the department head.

name: COMS-395
title: Independent Study
desc: Used by the student who wishes to design a course of independent study not otherwise available in the curriculum. Requires a detailed proposal of study written in consultation with the instructor. Prerequisite of 12 semester hours in the department of study.

name: EDUC-223
title: Children's Literature
pre_req: EDUC 185/215,  PAID 112D (or equivalent) and sophomore standing
desc: This course introduces the study of children's literature including promoting child development through literature and analyses of books in each genre. Requires sophomore standing.

name: GS-339
title: Introduction to the History andyPhilosophy of Education in the U.S.
desc: A brief survey of the history and philosophy of education in the United States.  Students will study the history and philosophy of  education as it has developed in the U.S. and  draft a personal philosophy of education in  preparation for January travel course to Hawaii.

name: HIST-139
title: Special Topic:Reading Local History inyIndia
desc: Special Topic:Reading Local History in India. This course examines Indian history from the ground up, using local narratives to think about historical figures and processes operating at a larger scale.  Traveling to ordinary and well-known historical sites in northern and western India shows how people used the past to engage in current dialogues and how material life affects the construction of history.  Guest lectures and student interviews with a variety of locals will encourage students to consider the many different ways individuals' memory of historical events interact with more fundamental constructions of historical narratives. Prereq:Consent of instructor.

name: SOC-139
title: Special Topic:Methamphetamine:EthicalyConsiderations Corrections
desc: Special Topic: Methamphetamine:Ethical Considerations and Corrections.  This course will allow students to investigate, in the field, ethical and sociological considerations in methamphetamine-related convictions and sentencing in Iowa.  Students will interview meth offenders at a state facility, using a rigorous student-developed instrument.  The interview results, along with Social Networks theory and public policy ethics literature will be used to examine the possibility of more ethical outcomes for the offenders and for society.

name: ENG-368
title: The British Novel
desc: In Northanger Abbey, Jane Austen's heroine remarks, "The person, be it gentleman or lady, who has not pleasure in a good novel, must be intolerably stupid." In this course, we defy stupidity by enjoying a variety of good British novels, beginning with the eighteenth-century, and arriving, after many pages and multiple plot twists, in the modern era. We consider the history of the genre, the social and political context of the texts, and the development of the British literary tradition. Representative authors may include Burney, Fielding, Austen, Dickens, George Eliot, Thackeray, Conrad, and Woolf.

name: COMS-239
title: Special Topic:Hyperspace,Hobbits, andyThe Hellmouth:Science Fiction andyFantasy as Equipment for Living
desc: This course explores how science fiction and fantasy film and television contribute to an understanding of contemporary human life. Embracing the futuristic, the magical, and the spectacular, science fiction and fantasy tesxts engage the popular imagination, encourage viewers to juxtapose the world as it is with the possibilites of a world that could be and, in doing so, call on viewers to enter a public dialogue concerning issues of public importance and consequence (e.g. science, sexuality, ethics, politics, and spirituality).  Utilizing techniques of close textual analysis via participatory reading/viewing, individual critical reflection, and engaged classroom dialogue, students will interrogate how such popular rhetorical texts such as Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, and Buffy the Vampire Slayer participate in the constitution of cultural apprehensions and aspirations, the negotiation of public controversies, and the transformation of human knowledge, action, and community.

name: COMS-239
title: Special Topic:intro to Religion & Media:yGod and Information Technologies FromyPapyrus to Cyberspace
desc: Special Topic:Intro to Religion and Media:God and Information Technologies from Papyrus to Cyberspace.  This course will investigate depictions of the divine and the supernatural in various media:print, cinema, video/TV and on the internet.  Students will analyze these representations and interrogate their meanings for the students' own religious understanding and expression.  Students will be encouraged to examine how technology influences the religious imagination, and how the students themselves participate in these representations and interact with them, or how these representations of the divine shape their own religious, moral and ethical perceptions. Note: Students who take this course for Religion credit must have completed an introductory Bible course (Rel 101,111 or 112). Student must register for the course as religion 239 in order for it to apply toward the rel/phil requirement.

name: PHIL-339
title: Special Topic:Philosophy in the Wake ofyThe Holocaust
desc: Special Topic:Philosophy in the Wake of the Holocaust.  For many philosophers the Nazi genocide provoked a crisis in Western philosophical consciousness that led to a radical re-evaluation of traditional moral and political categories.  This course will explore the reasons for this re-evaluation and consider the status and possibility of philosophy after Auschwitz.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topic:Intro to Religion & MediayGod and Information Technologies FromyPapyrus to Cyberspace
desc: Special Topic:Intro to Religion and Media:God and Information Technologies from Papyrus to Cyberspace.  This course will investigate depictions of the divine and the supernatural in various media:print, cinema, video/TV and on the internet.  Students will analyze these representations and interrogate their meanings for the students' own religious understanding and expression.  Students will be encouraged to examine how technology influences the religious imagination, and how the students themselves participate in these representations and interact with them, or how these representations of the divine shape their own religious, moral and ethical perceptions. Note: Students who take this course for Religion credit must have completed an introductory Bible course (Rel 101,111 or 112). Students must register for the course as rel 239 in order to apply it toward the rel/phil requirement.

name: REL-239
title: ST:Violence and the Bible
desc: Special Topic:Violence and the Bible.  This course will focus on biblical texts that have been used to justify violence and oppression.  The course has three goals:  First, to understand these ancient texts in their own particular contexts. Second, to critically examine the way these texts have been appropriated in the past.  Third, to reflect on appropriate interpretation of these biblical texts today.

name: GS-185
title: First-Year Seminar:Beyond Google andyInto the Invisible Web
desc: Beyond Google and Into the Invisible Web.  This course will cover research strategies across all disciplines, focusing on the following topics: Internet and database search tools, information search techniques and strategies, textual database structure, search engine architecture, and the invisible web.  The course, through exercises, discussions, lectures, projects and presentations, will provide an in-depth overview of the strengths and limitations of information search strategies.

name: CHEM-185
title: Sem:Scientific Frauds & Hoaxes
desc: Students in this seminar will investigate scientific frauds and hoaxes which have occurred over the years.  These range from well known hoaxes (the Piltdown man, the Cardiff giant, and man-bats on the moon) to pseudoscience (perpetual motion machines, polywater, and cold fusion) and modern frauds (magnetic water softeners).  Each student will select one or more topics to investigate in depth.  For 1st-year students only.

name: CHEM-139
title: Special Topic:Environment, Chemistry,yand SocietyyAnd Society
desc: Special Topic:The Environment, Chemistry, and Society.  A study of the environment with emphasis on the relationship between science, our surroundings, and society.  Laboratory activities will demonstrate the relationship between human activities and environment.  The course is designed for non-science majors with little or no science background.  No prerequisite.  Fulfills the laboratory science requirement.  Students may not receive credit for both Chem 114 and Chem 139.

name: CHEM-139L
title: Special Topic:Environment, Chemistry,yand Society LabyAnd Society

name: GS-139
title: Special Topic:Recording Original Music
desc: Special Topic:Recording Original Music.  A project-based course designed for students (songwriters, bands, a cappella groups, etc.) wishing to record original music (any style). Students may work independently or collaborate with others.  Recording options for the final project include a digital audio workstation (DAW) or a professional recording studio.  Students using a professional studio will pay an additional fee; studios with different pricing options will be provided.  While there is no prerequisite, it is recommmended that students speak with the instructor before registering.  Graded credit/no credit.

name: ECON-139
title: Special Topic:Hunger, Public Action andythe Global Economy
desc: Hunger, Public Action, and the Global Economy.  Many people in the world are starving, while others eagerly pursue new methods to lose weight.  This stark contrast raises intriguing and important questions about the causes of world hunger and the global community's ability to address it.  In this course, we will discuss the nature of world hunger and explore the role of economic, political and social institutions in the creation and prevention of hunger.  We will also examine the increasingly widespread claim that world hunger can be eliminated in our lifetime.  Prerequisite:Econ 130.

name: MGT-139
title: Special Topic:Sports Marketing andyManagement in Australia
desc: Special Topic:Sports Marketing and Management in Australia.  This course will study interplay between product and service marketing with professional and amateur sports marketing and management.  A comparison of the practices in the United States with those of Australia will be the focus of the course.  Topics including the economics of the sports, the role of athletes as celebrity spokespersons, the use of sports as a means to market other products, the role of higher education in amateur sporting events, and other related topics will be the emphasis of the course. Students will visit sporting venues, engage as spectators at a variety of professional and amateur sporting events, meet with professionals from the marketing and sporting industries, and compare the use of sports marketing in media, point of sale, and other marketing channels. Students will have reading and discussion responsibility during the course.  Prereq:Consent of instructor.

name: MGT-339
title: Special Topic:Sports Marketing andyManagement in Australia
desc: See course description under Mgt 139A. Prereq: completion of foundation courses in Econ & Business.

name: ENG-239
title: Special Topic:Chinese Journeys andyEncounters
desc: Special Topic:Chinese Journeys and Encounters. Students will travel to the Peoples Republic of China, encountering the life of the rapidly developing and changing cities as well as the ancient monuments of early dynasties and monuments of Chinese civilization.  Students will explore major cities, take local excursions, and interact with Chinese students.  There will be guest lecturers on Chinese culture and society and some survival Chinese lessons.  Students will read about famous and not-so-famous journeys and encounters of others.  Students will keep journals and write a piece on their journey or encounters within China as a culminating project. Prereq: Consent of instructor.

name: ENG-139
title: Special Topic:Environmental Writing
desc: Special Topic:Environmental Writing.  A writing course for students interested in exploring the environment.   Writing will include journals, essays, and responses to other peoples' writing. The course will involve regular workshops, reading discussions, and field trips to local sites.

name: EDUC-252
title: Introduction to Middle and High Schooly5-12 Methods
desc: An introduction to the general methods of secondary teaching. Such topics as objectives, planning, testing, evaluation, classroom management, instructional techniques, educational technology, media, and the inclusion of special education students in the regular classroom will be considered. Should be taken as close to EDUC 352 as possible.  Required for certification in K-12 health and 5-12 secondary education areas. Not required of K-12 art, K-12 physical education, and K-12 music majors.

name: ATHTR-367
title: General Medical and Pharmacology
desc: Designed to expose athletic training students to didactic and clinical education related to general medical conditions and pharmacology.  Each student completes a series of observation experiences with local physicians, registered nurse practitioners, and physical therapists.  There is one daily lecture in addition to the observation schedule. Requires junior standing.

name: POLS-185
title: First-Year Seminar: War and Vocation:yMaking Judgments
desc: War and Vocation:Making Judgments. A study of war (with a focus on America's war against Iraq) from three perspectives: Nonviolence, Just War, and Realpolitik.  Through readings, lectures, discussions, speakers and films, the key ideas of each perspective will be examined and evaluated. Evaluation of each perspective will be based upon both moral arguments and empirical evidence. Additional topics will include the relationship between human nature and violence and the future of war.

name: FCUL-241
title: Russian Culture Through Film
desc: This course will cover 20th-century Russian/Soviet culture and history through the medium of film. We will begin with classics of early Soviet film (including Eisenstein, Vertov, Pudovkin) and then view and discuss classic films of the Stalinist era and World War II (1930's-50's).  We will continue with classic films and comedies of the 60's and 70's (including Ryazanov, Gaidai, Tarkovsky).  The later 1980's-90's (glasnost', perestroida, and the post-Soviet era) witnessed the emergence of films that revealed difficult social and historical themes (for example, Little Vera, Burnt by the Sun, Prisoner of the Caucasus, Brother I). The course will conclude with discussion of film and society in present-day Russia. Films are in Russian (with English subtitles). Readings and discussions are in English. Advanced Russian language students who have completed RUS 202 may elect to enroll in RUS 241 for supplementary assignments in Russian. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: ENVS-185
title: First-Year Seminar: Natural Disasters
desc: Seminar:Natural Disasters.  From space Earth looks like an idyllic world, but it can often be a hostile environment.  This course will provide an in-depth, hands-on study of natural hazards, their geography, and their impact on societies worldwide.  Students will explore the causes, effects, and societal response to disasters.  A variety of natural hazards will be reviewed including flooding, volcanoes, landslides, earthquakes, hurricanes, and tsunamis.

name: BIO-185
title: Cancer - Its Causes and Treatment
desc: Cancer-Its Causes and Treatment.  This course will explore the cellular basis for oncogenesis and the various medical approaches that are used to deal with cancer.  It will also include discussion of cancer patients; reflection of their experiences.  For 1st-year students only.

name: ART-239
title: Special Topic:Alternative PhotoyWorkshop
desc: Special Topic:Alternative Photo Workshop.  This course is designed to expose students to conceptual ideas and alternative forms to 35mm photography.  Classes will explore these ideas via slide lectures, experimenting with different processes through Holga and pinhole cameras, as well as discussions.  Students will work with various photographic processes and will be able to choose different techniques to create a portfolio of prints.  The darkroom, digital technology, and cyanotypes will be used.  The goal will be to creatively use photography to produce a body of work.  Prereq: Art 120 or 230 or 260. Course fee: $75.

name: PSYC-339
title: Special Topic:Evolutionary Psychology
desc: Special Topic:Evolutionary Psychology.  This course will provide an introduction to the emerging field of evolutionary psychology.  The central assumption of evolutionary psychology is that the mind consists of a large number of specialized computational mechanisms designed by natural and sexual selection to solve the recurrent problems faced by our remote ancestors. Selected topics within evolutionary psychology will be examined and critically evaluated. Prerequisites:  Psychology 130 and Psychology 350.

name: MUS-245
title: Choral Singing in Namibia and SouthyAfrica
desc: Choral Singing in Namibia and South Africa is a travel course that promotes intercultural exchange through music. Music from the western tradition is learned and presented along with learning and presenting traditional Namibian and South African music in local languages. This takes place in church services, through choral exchanges and concerts, and in schools, hospitals and informal settings. Students also learn about the history of Namibia, its fight for independence and the anti-apartheid movement in South Africa through visits to sites of cultural and historic importance. Offered every four years during January term.

name: CHEM-373
title: Solid State Chemistry
desc: An examination of the synthesis and characterization of solids, especially those with crystalline structures.  Emphasis is placed upon the electrochemical, magnetic, optical, and conductive properties of these materials, as well as their applications in batteries, semiconductors, superconductors, and light-emitting devices.  Materials of interest include zeolites, metal-organic frameworks, and nanotubes.    Offered alternate years.

name: FREN-339
title: Special Topic:Arts and Public Spaces inyFrance
desc: See course description under Foreign Culture 339. Prereq: consent of instructor.

name: FCUL-339
title: Special Topic:Arts and Public Spaces inyFrance
desc: Special Topic: Arts and Public Space in France. We will explore the significance of the arts in public spaces of three important cultural centers in France.  We will visit Strasbourg in Alsace, home of one of France's most beloved cathedrals, a national French theatre, and a distinctive Alsatian theatre.  Next, we will travel to Lyon. Established by the Romans, who built an amphitheatre still used for concerts today, it is also the birthplace of the Guignol puppet theatre and is famous for its outdoor murals and silk production.  A side trip to Avignon, host to a well known theatre festival, will provide a taste of Provence.  The course ends in Paris, with its wealth of museums, theatrical, and musical offerings.  Prereq: Consent of instructor.

name: CLAS-300
title: Classics and Culture
desc: Using texts in translation, this course explores select aspects or themes from the cultures of ancient Greece and Rome. Topics range from consideration of a particular literary genre to the in-depth study of a particular place and time, and its broader explorations of Greco-Roman culture in comparison with other cultures. This course is writing intensive and fulfills the writing requirements for all majors in the classics department. Offered alternate years.

name: CLAS-240
title: Classical Mythology
desc: A survey of the major myths and legends of ancient Greece and Rome by reading such authors as Homer, Hesiod, Aeschylus, Euripides, and Ovid. The course also addresses the problem of interpreting myths and, when possible, introduces parallels from non-Greco-Roman traditions.

name: MATH-328
title: Applied Statistics II
desc: Design and analysis of experiments; analysis of variance techniques; fixed, random, and mixed models; repeated measures.

name: SW-139
title: Special Topic: Alcohol: Issues,yTreatment and Prevention
desc: Special Topic: Alcohol:Issues, Treatment and Prevention.  This course is designed to provide students with knowledge about a wide range of content dealing with alcohol.  This course will cover five main areas 1) diagnosis of pathological use, 2) epidemiology, 3) consequences of use (including health effects), 4) treatment, and 5) prevention and advocacy.  Students may not receive credit for both SW 139 and PCAP 450 Alcohol.

name: EDUC-240
title: Home, School, and Community
desc: This pre-K to 12 course examines the dynamic relationship between families, school, and the community. Evaluation, legal aspects, and services to preschool students with disabilities including the Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP) will be explored. The course offers continued focus on collaborative team efforts and the importance of establishing strong links between home, school, and other service providers so the learning experiences of students from preschool through transition to the adult life are maximized.

name: POLS-258
title: Environmental Politics and Policy
desc: In this course, students will identify and examine environmental issues confronting the United States, as well as the larger world. Students will identify and evaluate both current and proposed policies for addressing those issues. We will pay particular attention to the range of actors involved in the making of environmental policy and will emphasize the relationship among politics, economics, ethics, and science in the making of environmental policies in the United States and internationally.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic:Modern Empires in Asia
desc: Special Topic:Modern Empires in Asia.  This course introduces students to the history of modern empires in Asia, from the 16th to the 20th centuries.  Student will learn to recognize the practices and rhetoric of imperial centers, including Portugal, Holland, France, England, Japan and the United States: students will also explore the wide variety of responses of imperial subjects to their governors.  The course will encourage students to think about the linkages between political and cultural power on the one hand and social and economic production on the other hand.

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topic: Spanish for MedicalyProfessionals
desc: This course is designed for students studying to become medical professionals and who require training in Spanish to serve Spanish-speaking clients in a hospital, clinical or office setting. In addition to exploring medical terminology related to the human body, illnesses and treatments, we will also study interview techniques for Latino patients and interpretation/translation in medical settings. Students will work with medical documents in Spanish, perform writing assignments and class presentations.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topic:Prophets and Prophecy
desc: Special Topic: Prophets and Prophecy.  This course will examine prophetic literature in the Bible, in particular Isaiah, Jeremiah, Joel, Amos, Exekiel and Hosea.  Through group discussion students will practice reading and understanding biblical texts with an emphasis on their historical and literary contexts.  Textual material from extra-biblical sources will also be studied.  The main focus will be on understanding the prophets in their own time.  There will, however, also be discussion about the contemporary relevance of these texts. Prereq: Rel 101, 111 or 112.

name: AFRS-139
title: Special Topic:History of AfricanyNationalismySpecial Topic: Nationalism in Sub-
desc: Special Topic: History of African Nationalism. This course is designed to introduce students with no previous knowledge of the subject to the history of Nationalism in Africa.  This course will trace the history of African nations beginning with the establishment of colonial rule until the independence of South Africa in 1994. Topics will include colonial administrative systems, early resistance movements, the emergence of political parties, Pan Africanism, the role of the US and Soviet Bloc, the struggle for national liberation and the implications of national independence.

name: HIST-139
title: Special Topic:History of AfricanyNationalism
desc: Special Topic: History of African Nationalism. This course is designed to introduce students with no previous knowledge of the subject to the history of Nationalism in Africa.  This course will trace the history of African nations beginning with the establishment of colonial rule until the independence of South Africa in 1994. Topics will include colonial administrative systems, early resistance movements, the emergence of political parties, Pan Africanism, the role of the US and Soviet Bloc, the struggle for national liberation and the implications of national independence.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topic:Hunger for Justice:yChristian Ethics and Globalization
desc: Special Topic:Hunger for Justice:Christian Ethics and Globalization.  This discussion-intensive course focuses on the phenomenon of globalization and examines the extent to which it is the cause or cure for hunger and poverty in the world.  The course attempts to equip students with skills to engage in normative Christian ethical assessment of globalization.  The course examines four theories of globalization and explores resources in Christian traditions for grappling with this phenomenon.  The course concludes by applying these analytical and ethical resources to proposals for ending the worst cases of poverty and hunger in our lifetimes.  Prerequisite: Rel 101, 111 or 112.

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar: Cultural Collapse: QuestionsyOf Sustainability
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134 Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: Human societies rely on natural resources for survival. When access to these resources are restricted either naturally or by socio-political upheaval, a society can undergo extreme stress and in some cases collapse. This course will focus on the use of natural resources by human societies both past and present to study the question of whether modern developed societies are sustainable over the long term. Prerequisite: Senior status and Environmental Studies minor or consent of intstrutor.

name: ENVS-320
title: Soil Genesis, Morphology andyClassification
desc: Simply put, life depends on soil. Soils effectively link the physical, biological and chemical environments and the study of soils is paramount to understanding and integrating concepts in archaeology, biology, chemistry, geology, and environmental science. Students will gain a basic understanding of soil formation processes and the relationships between soils and other Earth systems as well as conducting basic field description of soils and interpreting the environmental history recorded in soil profiles. Offered alternate years.

name: ENVS-130
title: Environmental Forays
desc: In this course students will explore the relationship between humans and the physical environment by 1) reading seminal texts that address this relationship, such as "A Sand County Almanac" and "Silent Spring", 2) studying basic ideas and concepts central to environmental studies and, 3) using the prairie-forest border region of Northeast Iowa as a laboratory for investigating how humans interact with the natural world.

name: ATHTR-265
title: Clinical I: Introduction to AthleticyTraining
desc: This course will provide instruction, practice, and testing of selected athletic training clinical proficiencies.  The primary focus will be on injury prevention and acute care skills.  Students are required to complete 125 field experience hours supervised by Approved Clinical Instructor. Requires sophomore standing.

name: ATHTR-268
title: Clinical II: Head, Neck, Thorax,yAbdomen, and Upper Extremity Assessment
desc: An in-depth study of the assessment of common injuries in athletics.  Injuries to the head, cervical spine, thorax, and upper extremity will be covered.  Students are also required to complete 125 field experience hours supervised by Approved Clinical Instructor. Requires sophomore standing.

name: ATHTR-365
title: Clinical III: Spine, Lower Extremity,yand Posture Assessment
desc: An in-depth study of the assessment of common injuries in athletics.  Injuries to the abdomen, lumbar spine, and lower extremities will be covered.  Students are also required to complete 125 field experience hours supervised by Approved Clinical Instructor.  Requires junior standing.

name: ATHTR-368
title: Clinical IV:Therapeutic Modalities andyExercise
desc: This course will provide instruction, practice, and testing of selected athletic training clinical proficiencies.  The primary focus will be on the use of modalities and therapeutic exercise for recovery from injuries.  Students are also required to complete 125 field experience hours supervised by Approved Clinical Instructor. Requires junior standing.

name: ATHTR-370
title: Therapeutic Modalities inyAthletic Training
desc: Designed to introduce students to the concepts and principles of therapeutic modalities and their applications in athletic training.  Treatment effects, safety considerations, indications and contraindications for each modality will be presented. Class meets first seven weeks. Requires junior standing.

name: EDUC-242
title: Introduction to Learning Disabilitiesyand Behavioral Issues
desc: This K-12 introductory course includes a historical perspective to the field of learning disabilities and behavioral disorders. This course covers characteristics and etiology, definitions and identification procedures, treatment and intervention, instructional and behavioral methodologies, impact of the disability throughout the lifespan, and current issues in the field.

name: ATHTR-372
title: Therapeutic Exercise in AthleticyTraining
desc: This course is designed to introduce students to rehabilitation techniques in athletic training and to basic principles of design, implementation, and supervision of rehabilitation protocols.  The course is divided into two sections: the first focuses on design, goals, and techniques of therapeutic exercise; the second addresses rehabilitation protocols for specific regions of the body. Class meets second seven weeks. Requires junior standing.

name: ATHTR-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: Students who develop an interest in a specialized area of the discipline for which course offerings are limited may follow a prescribed reading list under the direction of a member of the faculty with expertise in that area.

name: ATHTR-380
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on- or off-campus work situations in public or private organizations. Graded credit/no credit.

name: ENVS-185
title: Climate Change
desc: The phrase "climate change" conjures images of environmental apocalypse in the minds of some, and the threat of a massive global hoax in the minds of others. How has the issue of climate change become so divisive within our society, and how can we reconcile competing environmental and economic values to best respond to the challenges that climate change poses? We will examine climate change through multiple lenses, including scientific, economic, political, technological, cultural, and ethical, in order to understand the landscape of public debate over climate change and to envision and evaluate potential pathways toward a sustainable future.

name: ATHTR-465
title: Clinical V:Health Care Administration
desc: This course will provide instruction, practice, and testing of selected athletic training clinical proficiencies.  The primary focus will be in the area of health care administration.  Students are also required to complete 125 field experience hours supervised by Approved Clinical Instructor. Requires senior standing.

name: ATHTR-468
title: Clinical VI: Advanced Health Care
desc: This course will provide instruction, practice, and testing of advanced assessment/acute care skills. The course is setup to prepare students to take the BOC exam.  Students are also required to complete 125 field experience hours supervised by an Approved Clinical Instructor. Requires senior standing.

name: ATHTR-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar.  Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects.  The completed project is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department.  All projects must be presented publicly.  Only projects awarded an "A- or A" qualify for "department honors" designation.  The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: GRK-301
title: Advanced Greek Prose
desc: Prose readings chosen from a single Greek author or from a variety of authors within a particular genre. Authors and works may include Herodotus, Xenophon, Lysias, Plato, the New Testament, the Septuagint, or others.  May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

name: GRK-302
title: Advanced Greek Poetry
desc: Poetry readings chosen from a single Greek author or from a variety of authors within a particular genre.  Authors and works may include Homer, Hesiod, Sappho, Sophocles, Euripides, or others. May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

name: EDUC-245
title: Career/Vocational Assessment andyVocational Planning
desc: This K-12 course covers the assessment of career/vocational skills and interests, aspects of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEIA) which specifically address transition, transition meetings, Individualized Education Programs (IEP), community-based instruction, and the school/community services and service providers who would be involved in student transition.

name: POLS-367
title: Political Leadership
desc: Political leadership is different than other forms of leadership because politics is a unique activity. We will use biography, fiction, classical political theory, speeches, and contemporary social science writings to study the nature of political leadership.  The course will pay special attention to the tension between being a good person and a good leader and will explore the idea of politics as a vocation.

name: PE-110
title: Team Sports - Flag Football, Basketball,yVolleyball
desc: Includes flag football, basketball and volleyball

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures
desc: An introductory literature course, with specific focus and readings announced each semester. This course is both an introduction to the pleasures of reading and interpretation and also an opportunity for student writing in a range of analytic and creative forms.  Open to all students in all majors.  Students may enroll in more than one version of the course. Sample topics: Carribean Women Writers, Literature of the Apocalypse, Multiple Hamlets, Poems for Life.

name: HIST-162
title: South Asian History
desc: An introduction to the basic themes and content of South Asian history from the earliest times to the present.  Students will explore the lives of both great and ordinary people who lived in what are now Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal.  Students will consider how empire, international trade, relations of production, and ideologies affected the construction and reproduction of social and cultural groups. Offered alternate years.

name: ENG-380
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on-campus or off-campus work experience that builds on the strengths of an English major. Must have signature of department head. Open to sophomores (those who have completed PAID 111, 112 or transfer equivalents), juniors, and seniors. One 4-credit internship may be used as one of the three electives for the Plan I major, but not as one of the three writing courses required for the Plan II (writing emphasis) major, nor to satisfy requirements for the English minor or writing minor.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topics: Life and Letters ofyPaul
desc: This course will consider the life and teaching of Paul, as well as the diverse religious and political contexts within which his unique work emerged. Primary readings will come from the Hebrew Bible and New Testament, which we will consider in conjunction with texts from pagan and early Jewish and Christian sources. Topics will include discussions of the ancient politics of ethnicity, Paul's stridently anti-imperial rhetoric, his relation to first century messianism and ancient utopian thought, and his creative interaction with first century philosophy.

name: MUS-363
title: Opera Workshop: Production
pre_req: MUS 130 (private voice instruction) and consent of voice instructor
