This course will present current best-practice, research-based instructional methods in mathematical processes, the use of technology in teaching/student learning and classroom management as it applies to mathematics.

name: EDUC-326
title: Elementary Language Arts Methods
desc: This course is an introduction to oral and written communication for the twenty-first century, the curriculum and pedagogy of a language arts program based on standards established by the International Reading Association and the National Council of Teachers of English, and the eight components of the language arts in the elementary classroom. It will include integration of the language arts (to include reading/literature, writing/grammar, speaking, viewing, listening and spelling), the use of technology in teaching language arts, and classroom management as it applies to language arts instruction.  The course utilizes a comprehensive approach that examines language acquisition and development.  It is also the writing-intensive course in the major.

name: GER-339
title: Special Topic:Contemporary Germany
desc: Contemporary Germany.  This course introduces post-war East and West German culture and literature.  We will study a variety of texts which treat central, recurring issues that have defined both Germanys since 1945; such as the problems of history and memory, both in the public realm of politics and mass movements as well as individual life experiences.  Students will explore topics of particular interest to them in greater depth in individual assignments and group projects.

name: EDUC-460
title: Middle and HS Vocal Methods
desc: Students learn physiology and pedagogy of the adolescent voice. Included in the curricula are planning, assessment, literature, music literacy and grading. Prerequisite: admission to the teacher education program and 361.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topic:Religious and EthicalyFoundations of Nursing
desc: This course brings religious resources into dialogue with different dimensions of the ethics of professional nursing: the history of nursing practice and ethics, foundational ethical concepts in nursing, and current ethical issues in nursing. Modern American nursing has its historical roots in religious commitment and motivation. Selections from the Bible and the works of major theologians will ground our discussion of nursing history, ethics, and nursing as vocation. Next, we will reflect on core values of the profession by placing them within the context of ongoing theoretical conversations in theology and ethics. That groundwork will prepare us to examine contemporary issues like the nurse's role in futile treatments or abortion procedures and consider specific religious responses to those issues. Prerequisite: Rel 101, 111, or 112. Taught in Rochester for Luther nursing students.

name: FREN-346
title: Introduction to French Literature I
desc: Historical survey of French literature from the earliest texts to the end of the 17th century. Emphasis on the development of literary forms, including the epic, drama, lyrical poetry and narrative literature. Fundamental concepts of analysis and criticism are presented. Attention will be paid to increasing the student's fluency in writing. Offered alternate years.

name: EDUC-329
title: Elementary Science Methods
pre_req: EDUC 321, 322, 325, and 326, and admission to Teacher Education Program
desc: This course is an introduction to the curriculum and pedagogy of a standards-based science program in the elementary school.  This course includes hands-on opportunities with the activities that support the inquiry of science as practiced in the elementary school classroom.

name: EDUC-328
title: Elementary Social Studies Methods
pre_req: EDUC 321, 322, 325, and 326, and admission to Teacher Education Program
desc: This course is an introduction to the curriculum and pedagogy for social studies instruction based on the National Council of Social Studies Standards.  Ten thematic strands frame the instructional planning for elementary and middle level curriculum.  Students will develop competencies in specific social studies related skills and become acquainted with current directions and research in elementary social studies including instructional technology.  This course is designed to assist pre-service teachers in developing appropriate tools for teaching social studies using an interdisciplinary approach.

name: WGST-339
title: ST: Women and Politics
desc: This course will provide students with a critical examination of women as actors in various forms of political participation with keen attention to how the intersection of gender, race, class, sexuality, and religion influence women's participation and activism. In examining how women are galvanized into politics, we will focus not only on women's participation in the conventional spheres of what is considered politics-women as citizens, party activists, candidates, and elected officials but we will also focus on unconventional spheres of political activism especially community -based struggles where women's political participation has always been apparent but not recognized as political.

name: MUST-380
title: Internship
desc: Provides students with hands-on experience that stresses the kind of museum work relevant to their major disciplinary field including, but not limited to: research, exhibition, education, collections management, preservation, and administration.  The end-result being a tangible representation of their experience, whether it be a research document, portfolio, website, exhibit, or other product approved by their internship coordinator. This end product must be exclusively the student's own work.  The internship must be completed at a nationally or regionally recognized, reputable museum or cultural institution and is subject to the approval of the program director.  Students taking 2 credits must work a minimum of 75 hours and those taking 4 credits - a minimum of 150 hours in the semester.

name: WGST-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A yearlong independent research project. Applications are completed on the Honors Program form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director and the registrar. Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed project is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisors, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department. All projects must be presented publicly. Only projects awarded an "A-" or "A" qualify for "department honors" designation. The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: WGST-380
title: Internship
desc: Each Women's and Gender Studies major will complete a 2 credit hour internship. Students must have had at least two WGST courses before completing an internship. Internship opportunities will be approved for Women's and Gender Studies credit by the WGST board. Internships will be administered through the Career Center with each intern having a faculty adviser chosen from the WGST board or WGST faculty.

name: FREN-380
title: Internship
desc: Registration in a French-speaking internship is only by permission of the French section of the Modern Languages and Literatures department and the cooperating institution.

name: GS-185
title: First-Year Seminar: Burn That Book!yCensorship and Society
desc: Burn That Book! Censorship and Society. Throughout history, nations and cultures have sought to destroy or suppress knowledge through genocide, book burning, and cultural destruction. Books have been burned or banned, libraries and museums destroyed, and peoples persecuted for what they know in the name of protecting society from harmful information.  We will discuss the role of libraries and museums in preserving knowledge, historical instances, of censorship and cultural preservation, indigenous knowledge, and how it relates to the information age.  Student will read Fahrenheit 451 and The Camel Bookmobile, poetry, short stories, and children's literature.  Class discussion and presentations will allow students to examine these issues in-depth. (HE)

name: FCUL-185
title: German Culture Through Film
desc: Film is a powerful art form and means of communication.  The messages embedded in the mesmerizing images often escape us, and we miss the opportunity to understand something about the culture that produced it.  The study of a culture by examining its films provides direct, fascinating perspectives, both of the "other" cultures and our own.  This course offers an introduction to German culture and history through the medium of film.  No knowledge of German is required.  The course covers German films from the 1920 to 2006 and offers a chronological overview of German cinema.  Students will be introduced to major political, social and aesthetic movements that characterize distinct periods in German film history:  Weimar cinema, entertainment and propaganda film in the Nazi era, post-war film, New German Cinema, and post-wall German film.  We will pay close attention to the ways in which cinema -- as a medium of mass communication capable of moving masses reflected and influenced historical developments in the German-speaking world.

name: WGST-185
title: First-Year Seminar:Introduction toyMasculinities
desc: Introduction to Masculinities.  Designed for both men and women, this course will examine what it means to be a man in American society.  Through discussions of scholarly books, articles, popular fiction, film and music, the course will focus on the social and cultural factors that underlie and shape our beliefs about manhood and masculinities. Topics will include gender roles and socialization, sexuality, violence, boyhood, relationships, work, sports and leisure.

name: RUS-345
title: Conversation and Composition
desc: Emphasis on the development of written and oral expression and mastery of grammar.  Reading and listening comprehension will be developed through use of authentic texts (literary and popular press), films, video (news and popular media), and song texts.  Speaking and writing skills will be developed within this context of authentic materials.

name: EDUC-331
title: Early Childhood Education II
pre_req: Admission to Teacher Educ Program and EDUC 330
desc: A review of the current research on curricular models, materials, and methodology in early childhood education. Particular attention given to research translation and implementation for working with infants and toddlers.

name: SOC-339
title: Special Topic:Morocco:Women in Islam
desc: Morocco:Women in Islam.  This course will explore the history and modern day experience of Muslim women in Morocco.  Topics include:  women's roles in Muslim society, gender relations, the history of the women's movement, and family la reforms. (HB)

name: WGST-339
title: Special Topic:Morocco:Women in Islam
desc: Morocco:Women in Islam.  This course will explore the history and modern day experience of Muslim women in Morocco.  Topics include:  women's roles in Muslim society, gender relations, the history of the women's movement, and family la reforms. (HB)

name: ANTH-339
title: Special Topic: Confronting the Border:yGeography, Identity, and Global FeministyTheory
desc: Confronting the Border:Geography, Identity, and Global Feminist Theory.  This course will utilize global feminist theory to understand how people and cultures deal with borders--both geographical and conceptual.  Using Gloria Anzaldua's concept of "borderlands" as a point of departure, we will set out to understand how identities are constituted in bordered areas, the way gender can shape bordered experiences, and how geographical and conceptual borders are given meaning, reinforced and challenged.  Since gender assumes very different shapes as it combines with race, class, sexuality, religion, ethnicity, and various cultural identities, this course will conceptualize gender as it intersects with other identities and examine how such identities are constituted in borderlands. Prerequisite:WGST 130. (HB, INTCL)

name: WGST-339
title: Special Topic:Confronting the Border:yGeography, Identity, and Global FeministyTheory
desc: Confronting the Border:Geography, Identity, and Global Feminist Theory.  This course will utilize global feminist theory to understand how people and cultures deal with borders--both geographical and conceptual.  Using Gloria Anzaldua's concept of "borderlands" as a point of departure, we will set out to understand how identities are constituted in bordered areas, the way gender can shape bordered experiences, and how geographical and conceptual borders are given meaning, reinforced and challenged.  Since gender assumes very different shapes as it combines with race, class, sexuality, religion, ethnicity, and various cultural identities, this course will conceptualize gender as it intersects with other identities and examine how such identities are constituted in borderlands.  Prerequisite:WGST 130. (HB, INTCL).

name: CS-185
title: First-Year Seminar:Godel,Escher,Bach
desc: Godel, Escher, Bach. In 1931, the German logician Kurt Godel proved that any attempt to formalize logical reasoning would fall short in that there would always be unprovable yet true statements. Douglas R. Hofstadter's 1979 book "Godel Escher Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid" explores Godel's result with wit, ingenuity, and insight. Deciphering Godel's Incompleteness Theorem is a fantastic experience with no prerequisites except a willingness to learn and be surprised. Illustrated by M.C. Escher and scored by J.S. Bach, our adventure will pass through the philosophical worlds of Lewis Carroll, artificial intelligence, non-Euclidean geometry, Zeno and Zen Buddhism.  (QUANT)

name: FCUL-185
title: Dante's Divine Comedy
desc: Reading only the "Inferno" is like hearing one movement of a symphony or reading only the first chapters of a novel.  In this first year seminar, taught in English, we will read the entire "Comedy", and discuss the many aspects of the work: historical, literary, artistic, political, philosophical, scientific, and religious. Students will be responsible for oral and written presentations based on a close reading of the text and critical studies. (HEPT)

name: MGT-185
title: First-Year Seminar: UnderstandingyBusiness in a Legal, Social, andyEconomic Context
desc: Understanding Business in a Legal, Social, and Economic Context.  A January first year seminar designed to introduce the relationships of business, society, and public policies.  The course examines economic, regulatory, environmental, and global influences and the impact of business decisions.  Readings, case studies, and varied learning activities introduce students to socially responsible expectations of business.

name: PHIL-185
title: First-Year Seminar:The Consent of theyGoverned? Leviathan on Trial

name: REL-185
title: First-Year Seminar:Responses toySuffering and Evil in the WesternyTradition
desc: Responses to Suffering and Evil in the Western Tradition.  If God is omnipotent, omniscient, and benevolent, how shall we account for the horrendous evils that assault.  This course will explore representative responses to suffering and evil from the Jewish and Christian tradition. Attention will be given to the Hebrew Bible, the New Testament, a selection of apocryphal and pseudepigraph writings, as well as a wide array of texts (philosophical; theological; literary) from the modern and postmodern periods.  Students will also examine classic apologies for and critiques of the traditional portrayal of God. (HEPT)

name: AFRS-239
title: Special Topic: South Africa:Women'syStories, Women's Lives
desc: South Africa: Women's Stories, Women's Lives.  In this course we will look at the challenges facing contemporary women in South Africa and the individual and communal means by which South African women survive and thrive.  In particular we will examine how the double burden of patriarchy and apartheid has limited the life opportunities of women and girls, creating enormous challenges to their social, material, and spiritual well-being.  We will pay particular attention to the way sexual violence and the rapid spread of HIV/AIDS have affected women's lives. We will speak with political activists, community organizers, educators, social workers, nurses, artists, and others who are working to create better, safer, and more independent lives for women.  The course will include a service learning component in Cape Town.  Course locations will include Johannesburg and Cape Town as well as a visit to a rural area.  Sophomore standing. (HB, Intcl)

name: WGST-239
title: Special Topic:South Africa:Women'syStories, Women's Lives
desc: South Africa: Women's Stories, Women's Lives.  In this course we will look at the challenges facing contemporary women in South Africa and the individual and communal means by which South African women survive and thrive.  In particular we will examine how the double burden of patriarchy and apartheid has limited the life opportunities of women and girls, creating enormous challenges to their social, material, and spiritual well-being.  We will pay particular attention to the way sexual violence and the rapid spread of HIV/AIDS have affected women's lives. We will speak with political activists, community organizers, educators, social workers, nurses, artists, and others who are working to create better, safer, and more independent lives for women.  The course will include a service learning component in Cape Town.  Course locations will include Johannesburg and Cape Town as well as a visit to a rural area.  Prereq: sophomore standing and consent of instructor.

name: ANTH-139
title: Special Topic:Street Culture
desc: This course will explore the unique features of street cultures worldwide emphasizing the ways in which those who participate in what may be termed deviant illegal activities normalize and articulate these practices as rational and moral. In particular, we will examine the tension between elements of street life with the dominant culture, focusing on how music, fashion, and linguistic street styles become incorporated, valorized, and demonized by society at large.  The course will investigate four types of street cultures: drug consumption and trafficking, homelessness, prositution and gang life.  What features do these subcultures share?  Is there a relationship between street identity and risk behaviors?  As social scientists, how do we utilize street knowledge to effect positive community and individual change? (HB)

name: ANTH-239
title: Special Topic:Readings in LatinyAmerican Ethnography
desc: Readings in Latin America Ethnography.  This course will explore current social issues in Latin America through reading ethnographies, or descriptions of social and cultural practices. Ethnographies provide us with the ability to look in-depth at a particular issue or theme in society and examine the ways in which individuals express themselves through cultural practices.  Readings will cover a broad spectrum of topics including social movements and political participation, gender relations, sexual identity, indigenous rights, economic development, and violence. (HB, INTCL, GL)

name: MGT-139
title: Special Topic:Australia As Brand
desc: Australia As Brand.  Australia has evolved from being a remote member of the British Commonwealth used as a penal colony to a modern and vibrant country.  However, Australia faces considerable economic limitations including distance from international markets, limited exportable natural resources or manufactured goods, and a relatively small population.  To offset these limitations Australia has developed great capabilities in using tourism, sport, and culture as a means of generating economic development and raising the visibility and stature of the country in the global economy.  This course will study the history of how the deliberate role of government and industry have affected the evolving process of developing Australia as a brand identity and message.  Study will include meeting with business and government representatives, case analysis, and exposure to the eco-tourism and sports industry as well as how music and the arts have all been used as a means of building brand identity.

name: MGT-339
title: Special Topic:Australia As Brand
desc: Australia As Brand.  Australia has evolved from being a remote member of the British Commonwealth used as a penal colony to a modern and vibrant country.  However, Australia faces considerable economic limitations including distance from international markets, limited exportable natural resources or manufactured goods, and a relatively small population.  To offset these limitations Australia has developed great capabilities in using tourism, sport, and culture as a means of generating economic development and raising the visibility and stature of the country in the global economy.  This course will study the history of how the deliberate role of government and industry have affected the evolving process of developing Australia as a brand identity and message.  Study will include meeting with business and government representatives, case analysis, and exposure to the eco-tourism and sports industry as well as how music and the arts have all been used as a means of building brand identity. Prerequisite: Mgt 351.

name: MGT-239
title: Special Topic:International BusinessyAnd the Entrepreneur
desc: International Business and the Entrepreneur.  The risks and potential rewards of conducting business abroad are considerable, but technology and market forces are enabling or even driving small businesses to "go global".  The added complexity of negotiating cross-culturally in foreign environments is especially challenging for the entrepreneur.  This course gives students an overview of the various legal, financial, marketing and operational aspects of international business entrepreneurship in four different environments.  Experienced Luther College alumni, who have taken their businesses abroad to countries in Europe and Asia, will serve as guest lecturers to illustrate and discuss the topics presented.  This course will include cultural and historical perspectives on China, Belgium, Japan and Sweden.  Two field trips to entrepreneurs selling local production internationally, will also be included.  Sophomore standing.

name: CHEM-475
title: Advanced Topics in Chemistry
desc: Faculty will select an advanced topic of interest to students.  Examples include:  Advanced NMR Spectrometry, Environmental Chemistry, and Molecular Modeling. Offered alternate years.

name: CHEM-474
title: Physical Inorganic Chemistry
desc: An introduction to the use of symmetry for qualitative predictions of energy levels, molecular orbitals, and spectra of molecules. Offered alternate years.

name: PHIL-400
title: Advanced Topics:The Woman Questions
desc: Advanced Topics: The Woman Question.  There is a popular issue in the history of philosophy that has been all but ignored in the canons of thought; namely, the debate about the condition of women. some of the greatest philosophers had mostly unflattering opinions about women, such as Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, and Jean-Jacques Rousseau. But there were also philosophers who were defending women against these thinkers, yet who remain relatively unknown.  Although the debate about the nature of women stretches as far back as human history, it received special formatulation in 14th century France when philosophers referred to it as the querelle des femmes, or "the woman question."  This course will trace the debate from the 14th-19th centuries by looking at the thought of some of the greatest philosophical defenders and detractors of women.  We will see how many of these thinkers defend women on the basis not of rights, but rather women's duty and vocation. Through an analysis of primary texts, students will gain insight not only into important modern philosophers, but also into the origins of modern feminist thought.

name: BIO-485
title: Seminar:The Life of Birds
desc: The Life of Birds.  This seminar is based on the acclaimed 10 part BBC television series by David Attenborough titled "The Life of Birds".

name: CLAS-265
title: Greece and Rome on Film
desc: This course explores the ways in which various events and episodes from Greek and Roman myth and history have been adapted for modern film and television.  We will examine a selection of films alongside their original ancient sources, and pay close attention to how these films interpret their sources, as well as how they reflect the cultural values and concerns of their audiences.  What is lost or gained in the transition from page to screen?  To what extent are films shaped by contemporary modes of production and reception? Are films convenient (yet inadequate) substitutes for reading, or do they allow us a valuable, continuing engagement with their original sources? Offered alternate years.

name: ART-290
title: Art in Cultural Perspective: PrehistoricyThrough Contemporary Art in BritainyAnd Ireland
desc: Art in Cultural Perspective: Prehistoric Through Contemporary Art in Britain and Ireland. This course provides opportunity to experience historic and contemporary human visual expression through the study of art works, architectural examples and other objects of intentional design that originated in England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.  Students will work on analysis of objects or sites in order to better understand both artistic expression and the role of the makers and their art in past societies. Discussions, papers, readings and presentations are designed to correspond with visits to major museums and historic and artistic sites.  Material covered will range from Prehistoric to Post-Modern. Prereq:consent of instructor.

name: ART-114
title: Sequential Art, Animation and theyGraphic Novel
desc: This studio course introduces students to the history, techniques and practice of sequential story telling from its beginnings to the contemporary graphic novel.  Students will produce short animations, sequential art, and graphic novelettes.  No prerequisite but ART 108 strongly encouraged.

name: WGST-351
title: Gender and Crime
desc: Examines how gender affects individuals' experiences as both victims and perpetrators of crime and deviance. Analyzes the history and theory of gender and crime in the U.S. and internationally, the social construction of victimization, and the impact of culture, structure, and inequality on criminal behavior. (Same as SOC 351)

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar: Modernism: Salon Culture
desc: Seminar: Modernism: Salon Culture. Modernists are often celebrated for their singular creative genius, yet many moved in circles of other artists and writers who shaped their ideas about art in significant ways. The salon, a regular meeting of artists for the purpose of discussing, developing, and critiquing their own and others' work, was a prominent feature of the culture of literary modernism. This seminar will focus on Paris' famous salon at 27 Rue de Fleurus, the home of Gertrude Stein. Primary texts will include Stein's "Three Lives" and "Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas", and Ernest Hamingway's "In Our Time" and "A Moveable Feast; we will also study works by Pablo Picasso and other visual artists of the post-impressionist movement.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures: The Modern KingyArthur
desc: The Modern King Arthur. After introducing students to the medieval period's definitive telling of the King Arthur story, Thomas Malory's Le Morte D'Arthur, this course focuses on modern retellings of the Arthurian myth in literature and in film. We will explore the political, cultural, and spiritual dimensions of this enduring myth as well as the myth's characteristic forms and ideas:  the errant knight's adventures, the grail quest, courtly love, chivalry, and Camelot.  Readings will include Tennyson's "Idylls of the King", Twain's "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court", and Marion Zimmer Bradley's "Mists of Avalon". (HEPT)

name: HIST-299
title: Topics in History: Vikings inyScandanavia and Ireland
desc: Topics in History: Viking Life in Scandinavia and Ireland. This course examines the "Viking Era" approximately 750 to 1100 CE, with special emphasis on Scandinavia and Ireland. It will cover the essential elements of Viking society and culture, and the technological developments that led to the spread of the Viking World. Topics will include:ships and navigation; art; daily life; military techniques; mythology and religion; and literature. Lectures and readings will be supplemented by visits to museums and historical/archeological sites in the following areas: Copenhagen and Roskilde, Denmark; Dublin and Cork, Ireland; and Oslo, Norway.

name: WGST-361
title: Chaucer and Medieval Literature
desc: From heroes fighting monsters to Arthurian romances, medieval literature is best known for its stories of chivalry.  Less well-known but equally wonderful are the comic tales of sex in trees and greedy friars dividing a fart.  We will read Beowulf, narrative poems about love and adventure by Marie de France, the tale of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, and much more, with in-depth attention to Chaucer's Canterbury Tale.  Same as ENG 361)

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar:Ralph Ellison and "InvisibleyMan"
pre_req: Take 2 courses; From courses ENG-352 ENG-353 ENG-354 ENG-361 ENG-362 ENG-363 ENG-364 ENG-365 ENG-366 ENG-367 ENG-368
desc: Ralph Ellison and "Invisible Man".  This course will take a semester to explore and appreciate one of the most celebrated and powerful novels in American literature, "Invisible Man".  We will look at some of the literary influences that shaped Ralph Ellison's work, such as Richard Wright's novella, "The Man Who Lived Underground", as well as Fyodor Dostoevsky's "Notes from Underground".  Central to a discussion of the novel will be its surrounding literary criticism, that which followed closely the novel's publication in 1952, as well as the criticism that emerged during the sixties with the Black Arts movement.  Ellison's collection of critical essays in "Shadow and Act" and "Going to the Territory" will also serve as useful companions in our assessment of "Invisible Man".

name: AFRS-485
title: Seminar:Ralph Ellison and "InvisibleyMan"
pre_req: Take 2 courses; From courses ENG-352 ENG-353 ENG-354 ENG-361 ENG-362 ENG-363 ENG-364 ENG-365 ENG-366 ENG-367 ENG-368
desc: Ralph Ellison and "Invisible Man".  This course will take a semester to explore and appreciate one of the most celebrated and powerful novels in American literature, "Invisible Man".  We will look at some of the literary influences that shaped Ralph Ellison's work, such as Richard Wright's novella, "The Man Who Lived Underground", as well as Fyodor Dostoevsky's "Notes from Underground".  Central to a discussion of the novel will be its surrounding literary criticism, that which followed closely the novel's publication in 1952, as well as the criticism that emerged during the sixties with the Black Arts movement.  Ellison's collection of critical essays in "Shadow and Act" and "Going to the Territory" will also serve as useful companions in our assessment of "Invisible Man".

name: WGST-138
title: Human Sexuality
desc: A study of the field of human sexuality. The origins of sex roles, myths, stereotypes, and realities of this important aspect of life will be presented. The complexity of the sociological, psychological, biological, and legal components of the sexual being will also be included. The classis open to all students on campus.  (Same as NURS 138)

name: ENG-185
title: The Grail Quest
desc: The idea of the Grail, a mysterious and haunting image, which over time has evolved from a simple platter, or sometimes a stone, into a holy relic, has fascinated us for over eight centuries. In this seminar we will consider the interconnection of the grail myth with the medieval legend of King Arthur, and we will pursue the Grail story from its birth in medieval literature to its recent incarnations in modern fiction and popular culture.  We will supplement our reading of texts with the viewing of films.

name: WGST-339
title: ST: Gender and Communication
desc: Gender and Communication.  This course is an in depth exploration of the relationship between the gender identity, culture, and communication theories with particular emphasis on the how our gendered identities influence both personal and public communication.  In this course we challenge the innate "naturalness" of gender identity in many phases of public and private life and its relationship with particular fundamental institutions, such as family, government, religious institutions, and the commercial sphere. The course will also offer opportunities for student research concerning how gender influences language, values and social norms. (HB)

name: ENG-185
title: Stories of FamilyyAnd Struggle in Apartheid South Africa
desc: Stories of Family and Struggle in Apartheid South Africa. This seminar will use story, memoir, and film to ask how apartheid affected family life in South Africa from the 1950s to the 1990s. Was it possible during apartheid to carry out one's deepest political commitments without compromising one's family relationships151husband and wife, parent and child, sister and brother? To explore this question we'll look at various families -- black, "coloured" (mixed-race), and white, both those who supported apartheid and those who opposed it. Readings will include memoirs of actual families and novels by such writers as Nadine Gordimer, Sindiwe Magona, and others. (HEPT, INTCL)

name: WGST-485
title: Seminar: Topics in Women and GenderyStudies
desc: An interdisciplinary seminar on women's social action and social change as it is understood and guided by feminist theories. The conflicts and contradictions among feminisms will be discussed and critically examined in terms of implications for the future of gender relations. Students will develop projects related to course materials.  Offered alternate spring semesters.

name: ENG-239
title: Special Topic: Modern Arabic Literature
desc: This course is a study in Arabic novels, short stories, and poetry written by men and women from countries in the Middle East and Africa. To paraphrase Aristotle, if you want to know a people, read their poets, not just their historians, because the poets, behind the mask of fiction, reveal truths both objective and subjective. They tackle both experiences and feelings.In addition to literature we will study several films reflecting conflicts between reality and promise or hope. One of the major goals of this course will be to find new perspectives or ways of knowing about these countries and cultures mostly outside our purview and to find common ground.

name: ENG-239
title: Special Topic: Ole E. Rolvaag: AmericanyWriter
desc: This course will study the work of Ole E. Rolvaag (1876-1931), who emigrated from Norway in 1896 and became an American writer. We will read his trilogy, beginning with GIANTS IN THE EARTH (1927), one of his earlier novels, and a few essays. Rolvaag's texts will be discussed as central contributions to Norwegian-American written culture and also in the context of American immigrant and regional literature and history. Students who take the course for Scandinavian Studies credit will be required to read excerpts of the novels in Norwegian. (HEPT)

name: HIST-185
title: Films of the Depression Era,y1929-1942
desc: This course utilizes a selection of films made between 1929 and 1942 as a lens by which to examine issues confronting American society during the Great Depression. The efforts of film-makers as self-designated shapers of culture, the concerns, visions and restrictions of government agencies and censors, the movie-going public's own awareness of current events mixed with a desire for escapism all interacted to create a unique set of films which reflect these times of economic hardship and uncertainty. (HIST)

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar: Striving for Sustainability
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140 and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: Striving for Sustainability. This class explores the role of education in moving toward a more sustainable society.  We will look briefly at arguments for the need to change current practices, the basic tension between industrialism and alternative paradigms such as agrarianism, and educational theory that supports social and cultural change.  The main focus of the class will be researching and developing a sustainability education plan for Luther College. In addition, we will look at ways to collaborate with local schools and educational programs to integrate Luther146s sustainability efforts into the entire community and to reach all ages with sustainability education.

name: BIO-339
title: Special Topic:Molecular Ecology
desc: Molecular Ecology. This course will investigate ecological questions through the use of genetic data sych as DNA- and pro based markers. The focus is on the process of research through group and individual projects including background reading of the primary literature, optimizing lab techniques, analyzing and interpreting data and drafting grant proposals. While a selection of evolutionary and ecological concepts will be introduced and provide background for particular projects, this course will not substitute for more comprehensive introductions to these fields such as Biology 254 or Biology 365. Assessment will be based on projects, presentations, and a grant proposal. Potential projects for 2008 include quantifying genetic diversity, inbreeding, and inbreeding depression of plants in large and small prairie fragments; estimating rate of out-crossing in heirloom vegetables; and examining the effects of gene knock-out on competition and herbivory. Prerequisite: Bio 248.(NWL, NSL)

name: ECON-339
title: Special Topic:American EconomicyHistory
desc: American Economic History.  An introduction to the growth of the American economy from colonial times to the present with emphasis on the nineteenth century.  Topics include technical change, the choice of production technology, incoming distribution, demographic transition, labor supply and resource allocation through factor markets with institutional constraints.  Debates in economic history such as the economic history such as the economic viability of antebellum slavery, the role of railroads in the growth process, and the economic impact of the New Deal are evaluated with evidence from the new economic history.  Econ 339 can be used as an elective for Econ Plan I and II majors.  Prerequisite: Econ 130. (SS, HIST)

name: ART-239
title: Special Topic:Introduction to New Media
desc: Introduction to New Media.  Introduces students to the history of the New Media art in the context of a studio course.  Students are expected to actively engage in the studio process while simultaneously conducting research on the history of New Media in Twentieth Century art. Performance, conceptual, video and installation art will be substantively addressed. (FA, HE)

name: CHEM-185
title: Kaboom! Explosions in Science andySociety
desc: Kaboom!: Explosions in Science and Society. This course will examine the nature of explosives and the impact they have and have had on warfare, engineering, mining, demolition, fireworks, and society. Explosives ranging from gunpowder to thermonuclear weapons will be explored. Students need not have any scientific background.

name: MGT-185
title: Leadership and Ethical Decision-Making
desc: Leadership and Ethical Decision-Making.  In this course, students will examine leadership, ethics, and decision-making in the context of organizational theory and practice.  Topics include introductions to different leadership theories, research leadership practice, moral philosophies, and decision-making processes relevant to organizations including corporations, small businesses, government, churches, and non-profits.  Case studies, discussions, outside speakers, and individual reflection will be used to help students address issues surrounding leadership and ethical decision-making at an organization level, while also connecting what they learn to their personal development and preparation for values-based leadership.

name: ENVS-185
title: First-Year Seminar:From Red to Green?:yEnvironmental Perspectives in the FormerySoviet Union
desc: From Red to Green?:  Environmental Perspectives in the Former Soviet Union.  With the signing of the Kyoto Protocol, Russia seemed to distance itself from its environmentally destructive Soviet past. But has it really?  In this discussion-based interdisiplinary course, we will examine the environmental history of the Former Soviet Union from 1860 to the present, digging below the topsoil to discover how Russians see and relate to the natural world.  To do this, we will base our observations on works in Russian history, literature, film and popular song.  Students will also do research in a specific area and present their findings to the class.  Towards the end of the course we will discuss present-day issues of energy politics, Kyoto, and the controversy surrounding the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics. Finally, we will conclude with the Russian environmental movement, exploring what we, if anything, can do to aid it.  No knowledge of Russian is required.  Cross-listed with Environmental Studies.  Counts toward the Russian Studies Minor.

name: FCUL-185
title: First-Year Seminar:From Red to Green?:yEnvironmental Perspectives in the FormerySoviet Union
desc: From Red to Green?:  Environmental Perspectives in the Former Soviet Union.  With the signing of the Kyoto Protocol, Russia seemed to distance itself from its environmentally destructive Soviet past. But has it really?  In this discussion-based interdisiplinary course, we will examine the environmental history of the Former Soviet Union from 1860 to the present, digging below the topsoil to discover how Russians see and relate to the natural world.  To do this, we will base our observations on works in Russian history, literature, film and popular song.  Students will also do research in a specific area and present their findings to the class.  Towards the end of the course we will discuss present-day issues of energy politics, Kyoto, and the controversy surrounding the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics. Finally, we will conclude with the Russian environmental movement, exploring what we, if anything, can do to aid it.  No knowledge of Russian is required.  Cross-listed with Environmental Studies.  Counts toward the Russian Studies Minor.

name: SCST-239
title: Special Topic: Ole E. Rolvaag: AmericanyWriter
desc: This course will study the work of Ole E. Rolvaag (1876 - 1931), who emigrated from Norway in 1896 and became an American writer. We will read his trilogy, beginning with GIANTS IN THE EARTH (1927), one of his earlier novels, and a few essays. R248lvaag146s texts will be discussed as central contributions to Norwegian-American written culture and also in the context of American immigrant and regional literature and history. Students who take the course for Scandinavian Studies credit will be required to read excerpts of the novels in Norwegian. (HEPT)

name: HLTH-185
title: Exploring Complementary and AlternativeyMedicine
desc: Exploring Complementary and Alternative Medicine. This first-year seminar offers students the opportunity to explore multiple approaches to holistic health care by investigating complementary and alternative health care medicine (CAM) (e.g., acupuncture, chiropractic, aromatherapy, massage therapy, reflexology, etc.). Students will engage in researching the principles, practices, use, and outcomes of CAM leading to individual and group written and oral presentation experiences.

name: PSYC-185
title: Psychology of Forgiveness:yCauses, Correlates, and Consequences
desc: Psychology of Forgiveness: Causes, Correlates, and Consequences. This course will examine the topic of forgiveness from a psychological perspective. We will discuss the meaning of forgiveness and how it differs from concepts such as justice and reconciliation. The course will emphasize the scientific method and the unique perspectives that psychological science can offer on an age-old topic. This is an experiential course where students will assess their own levels of forgiveness, participate in forgiveness experiments, and evaluate current forgiveness research. The connection between forgiveness and the following topics will be included: personality, family, culture, gender and mental and physical health and well-being. Strategies for personal growth will also be considered. (HB)

name: FREN-464
title: Francophone Literatures and Cultures
desc: A survey of the literature and/or the culture and history of a Francophone country, or the study of a literary or cultural theme in several Francophone countries.  Focus will vary, depending on the literary or cultural nature of the topic as well as on the number of Francophone countries studied.  Offered on a rotating basis.

name: WGST-320
title: Women and Gender in theyClassical World
desc: This course explores the constructions and representations of women and gender in ancient Greece and Rome through an examination of textual, art historical, and archaeological evidence. The course also addresses the intersections of women's and gender issues with issues of legal status, class, and ethnicity, and pays close attention to current scholarly methodologies and approaches to the subject.  Offered alternate years. (Same as CLAS 320)

name: AFRS-185
title: First Year Seminar: Stories of FamilyyAnd Struggle in ApartheidySouth Africa
desc: Stories of Family and Struggle in Apartheid South Africa. This seminar will use story, memoir, and film to ask how apartheid affected family life in South Africa from the 1950's to the 1990's. Was it possible during apartheid to carry out one's deepest political commitment without compromising one's family relationships - husband and wife, parent and child, sister and brother? To explore this question we'll look at various families - black, "coloured" (mixed-race), and white, both those who supported apartheid and those who opposed it. Readings will include memoirs of actual families and novels by such writers as Nadine Gordimer, Sindiwe Magona, and others. (HEPT, INTCL)

name: WGST-243
title: Time of Stalin: Literature and MemoirsyLiterature and Memoirs
desc: This course, through the medium of literature and memoirs, focuses on Russia/Soviet Union in the early years after the Bolshevik Revolution (1917) until Gorbachev's glasnot and perestroika. Students will learn about the rise of Stalin, the time of terror and purges at the height of Stalin's regime (mid 1930s), WWII, the "Thaw" after Stalin's death in 1953, and the implications Stalinism has on present-day Russia. We will seek answers to the questions of how Stalin was allowed to rise to power, retain political control, and instigate policies that caused the deaths of approximately 20 million Soviet citizens - many of whom were Bolsheviks and loyal members of the Communist Party.  Literary readings include memoirs, poetry, and novels.  A significant part of the course concerns the role of women in the Bolshevik Revolution and their fate under Stalinism. This course fulfills requirements of international studies, women and gender studies, and Russian studies. This course is taught in English and readings are in English. Offered alternate years.(Same as FCUL 243)

name: WGST-260
title: Feminist Philosophy
pre_req: One course in PHIL or two courses in WGST
desc: Examination of feminist philosophies, including issues in epistemology, ethics, social philosophy, political philosophy, philosophy of religion and historical interpretation. Focus on the challenges which feminist theory presents to traditional philosophical assumptions in the Western tradition. This course counts as theory requirement for the WGST major. Offered alternate years. (Same as PHIL 260)

name: WGST-468
title: Seminar: Gender, Globalization, andyDevelopment
desc: In this course we will examine the phenomena of globalization and development from a sociology of gender perspective. We will focus on the global intersections of contemporary societies and cultures, and the gendered dynamics therein. Questions we will raise include: How does globalization affect women's and men's lives? How is power distributed, and how does this impact development processes? What impact do gender dynamics play in the social institutions of development: econmomic, political, and cultural? (Same as SOC 468)

name: AFRS-185
title: First Year Seminar: "Black" MeetsyWriting: Race, Gender and theyPolitics of Literary Interpretation
desc: When "Black" meets Writing: Race, Gender and the Politics of Literary Interpretation provides students with an overview of black women's writing and an understanding of the practices of literary criticism as it relates to black cultural expression. The course will introduce students to the contexts, approaches, and forms of analysis that scholars use to interpret black women's writing in the US, the Carribbean, and Africa. (HEPT, Intcl)

name: WGST-185
title: First Year Seminar: "Black" MeetsyWriting: Race, Gender and theyPolitics of Literary Interpretation
desc: When "Black" meets Writing: Race, Gender and the Politicis of Literary Interpretation provides students with an overview of black women's writing and an understanding of the practices of literary criticism as it relates to black cultural expression. The course will introduce students to the contexts, approaches, and forms of analysis that scholars use to interpret black women's writing in the US, the Carribbean, and Africa. (HEPT, Intcl)

name: EDUC-185
title: Clinical Experience I in the Schools
desc: Seminars for first-year students offered each January term.

name: HIST-185
title: First-Year Seminar:20th Century FreedomyMovements in America and South Africa
desc: Black Liberation:20th Century Freedom Movements in America and South Africa.  This discussion course examines and compares twentieth century resistance movements and struggles by black people, living in different parts of the world, to liberate themselves from oppressive conditions imposed by dominant political, economic, and social systems. The course is designed as comparative and covers similiar themes at two different global settings. Specifically, we will explore the modern civil rights movement in the United States between 1953 through contemporary times and the liberation struggled waged against Apartheid simultaneously occurring in the Republic of South Africa. (HIST, INTCL)

name: AFRS-185
title: First-Year Seminar: Black Liberation -y20th Century Freedom Movements inyAmerica and South Africa
desc: Black Liberation:20th Century Freedom Movements in America and South Africa.  This discussion course examines and compares twentieth century resistance movements and struggles by black people, living in different parts of the world, to liberate themselves from oppressive conditions imposed by dominant political, economic, and social systems. The course is designed as comparative and covers similiar themes at two different global settings. Specifically, we will explore the modern civil rights movement in the United States between 1953 through contemporary times and the liberation struggled waged against Apartheid simultaneously occurring in the Republic of South Africa. (HIST, INTCL).

name: COMS-185
title: Becoming a Good Alien in Your Own WorldyAnd Communication
desc: The course focuses on how we, living in a "global village," perceive other cultures and our own and interact with each other beyond the conventional boundaries of culture and nationality.  Who are you?  What are you? How do we define ourselves in relation to others?  And how do our differences affect how we communicate and understand each other?  Through readings, discussion, projects and presentations, we will explore together basic concepts in intercultural communication.

name: ENG-185
title: Abraham Lincoln: Legends, Leadership,yLiterature
desc: Abraham Lincoln:Legends, Leadership, Literature. Legends about Lincoln almost crowd out his actual achievements as a leader and his contributions to literature.  We will examine the legends, but situate them in the context of Lincoln speeches, letters and other works, reading them as literature and for what they reveal about the man, his acts and ideas.  We will also explore the conflicting ways Lincoln has been represented, early and late -- as racist compromiser and an accomplished statesman; as ape-like buffoon and as savior and martyr.We will sample films,  TV programs, poetry, photographs, biographies, and historical studies.  A two- to three-day field trip to sites in the Springfield, Illinois, area is planned, and students will need to pay approximately $140.00 to cover these expenses.

name: ENVS-185
title: Freshman Seminar: Ethics andyAnimals
desc: This course explores the ethical questions about the human relationship to and uses of other animals. We will address both theoretical and practical questions about animal ethics including an exploration of the way major moral theories deal with nonhuman animals. A case study approach will be utilized to address specific questions such as primate intelligence, research using animals, livestock, pets, working animals, zoos and aquariums, hunting and trapping. In addition, we will examine what different religious traditions say about animals and the human relationship with animals. This course will use field trips and guests (human and otherwise) to help ground our exploration of the moral status of animals. (HE)

name: PHIL-185
title: Freshman Seminar: Ethics andyAnimals
desc: This course explores the ethical questions about the human relationship to and uses of other animals. We will address both theoretical and practical questions about animal ethics including an exploration of the way major moral theories deal with nonhuman animals. A case study approach will be utilized to address specific questions such as primate intelligence, research using animals, livestock, pets, working animals, zoos and aquariums, hunting and trapping. In addition, we will examine what different religious traditions say about animals and the human relationship with animals. This course will use field trips and guests (human and otherwise) to help ground our exploration of the moral status of animals. (HE)

name: ART-239
title: Special Topic:Facing History-The Art ofyPortraiture
desc: Facing History-The Art of Portraiture.  This course will explore the representation of the individual.  It offers an introduction into the art of portraiture as it was articulated in various media, from early drawings, paintings to sculptures.  The class will survey the history of portraiture from its emergence as a specific genre in the early 1400s.  Primarily we will study how forms and modes of portraiture developed and were shaped throughout what is known as the Renaissance up to the genre maturity in the the 1700s.  In addition, brief excursions into the developments during the succeeding centuries, up to contemporary home video clips, will also be offered.  This class will meet throughout the semester once a week for a 90 minute time period. (FA)

name: BIO-139
title: Special Topic:Ecological Concepts
desc: Ecological Concepts.  A general ecology course for non-science majors, this course will study the interaction between living organisms and their environment.  This course will survey the basic principles of ecology from ecosystems to organisms.  Emphasis will be placed on current ecological issues focusing on the effects of human activity on ecological systems, such as global climate change, urbanization, invasive species, agriculture, habitat fragmentation, and biodiversity loss.  Laboratory includes investigative approaches to learning concepts in ecology, field trips, and discussions.  Students may not earn credit for both this course and Sci/Envs 133 (Conservation). (NWL)

name: MGT-120
title: Personal Finance
desc: A survey of the financial decisions encountered in managing personal and family financial affairs. Topics will include budgeting, housing decisions, auto leasing, personal loans and credit card debt, managing risk through home, health, auto and life insurance, legal protection, taxes, investments and savings for retirement.

name: MGT-339
title: Special Topic:Social Entrepreneurship
desc: Social Entrepreneurship is a rapidly developing field in which leaders in business and nonprofit enterprises work together to develop organizations that benefits the client and the residents of the community.  Students will study how entrepreneurial skills are being utilized to solve major social problems globally and learn how to apply entrepreneurial skills in the social sector. Prerequisite:  Mgt 240.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topic: Apocalypse Then and Now
desc: Apocalypse Then and Now.  The objective of this course is to examine the relationship between apocalyptic discourse and the interests of those who produce such discourses. The class will examine the historical roots of apocalypticism in the Mediterranean region during the Hellenistic and Roman periods, when it first emerged as a genre of protest against a wave of imperialism initiated by Alexander the Great.  We will examine apocalypses from Egypt and Persia, as well as the biblical book Revelation.  We will then examine the ways in which the apocalyptic worldview is currently used for some groups to justify, and by others to oppose American hegemony in the Middle East.  The class will examine and discuss written texts and movies containing apocalyptic content. Prerequisite: Rel-101 Rel-111 or Rel-112.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topic:From Biblical Studies toyBible Study: the Vocation of ReligiousyEducation
desc: Special Topic:From Biblical Studies to Bible Study: The Vocation of Religious Education. In this course, students will study off-campus in a local congregation. Students will learn a variety of methods for interpreting biblical texts, then apply these methods to the development of education programs for use in a congregational setting.  Classes will meet four weekdays each week, Sunday mornings, and two Wednesday evenings. In groups of 4-5 people, students will analyze an assigned biblical text or set of texts and prepare a lesson for a specific age group, which will rotate each week:Sunday school, confirmation, high school, or adult education.  Students will present their lessons/programs to each other during a weekday class period, providing the opportunity for peer review and feedback before the Wednesday night/Sunday morning presentations.  Prerequisite: Rel 101, Rel 111 or Rel 112. (Rel)

name: PHIL-185
title: Big Questions
desc: Philosophy is the study of the most fundamental questions that face human beings: Does god (or gods) exist?  What is human nature? How can I be free if everything has a prior cause? How are the mind and the body connected?  Does life have meaning?  Is science the most reliable method for gaining knowledge?  What is the best form of government?  When is it permissible to use bad means to reach good ends?  Although people have contemplated these issues for thousands of years, perhaps the greatest single attempt to answer the basic questions of philosophy is Plato's famous work The Republic.  With its unforgettable images of "the ship of state", "the divided line", "the allegory of the cave", and "the myth of Er". Plato's Republic is not only fascinating and influential, it is also very fun to read.  The course will introduce students to the major topicsin philsophy through a careful reading of Plato's greatest work.

name: MATH-185
title: Precalculus With Derivatives II
desc: Continuation of topics of Math 130 to rational, logarithmic, and exponential functions and their derivatives; applications.  Graphing calculator use is required.  (Students who earn credit for 131 may not earn credit for 140.)  Prerequisite: 130. (Quant)

name: ART-239
title: Special Topic:Building into the Sky -yThe Art of Skyscrapers
desc: This domestic travel course introduces students to the forces that have defined the design, construction, and image of skyscrapers and their urban environments through the examination of Chicago's most significant works of architecture. Chicago is often regarded as the architectural capital of the world. It is where the story of 20th century architecture unfolded and the icon of the business world first took shape: the skyscraper. The course will focus on the time between 1870, the time of Great Fire, and the 1960s marked by the death of Chicago's most prominent modern architect, Mies van der Rohe. In-depth readings direct observation of the architectonical structures and their spaces, discussions, and smaller research projects will help students expand their understanding of the principles that made Chicago such an important architectural city. Course fee for the Chicago portion of the course: $675 . $825. (HEPT, HIST).

name: CLAS-185
title: First-Year Seminar:Ancient Writing
desc: Ancient Writing.  A historical and linguistic survey of early writing systems from the ancient Mediterranean/Near East and beyond.  Topics will include cuneiform, Egytian hieroglyphs, Linear A, Mycenaean Greek, Etruscan, early Latin, Germanic runes, and Mayan glyphs.  There will be a particular emphasis on the history and problems of decipherment as well as the relationship between writing and culture.  No prerequisite.  (HEPT)

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topic:Latin American Culture ofyArgentina
desc: Special Topic:Latin American Culture of Argentina. This course explores the language and culture of Argentina.  To develop both language and cultural proficiency, students will live with families in Buenos Aires and spend 4 hours daily M-Th studying the regional and ethnic diversity and traditions of Argentina at the University of Belgrano. During afternoons and evenings students will participate in culture excursions such as visits to museums, historical landmarks, and sites of memory related to the recent dictatorship.  In addition to exploring the history and culture of the capital city, students will learn about gaucho culture during a Dia del Campo at a ranch outside the capital, explore the colonial history of the town of Colonia, Uruguay, and spend 3 days in the area of Iguaz Falls visiting the National Park, the Jesuit Ruins and a Guarani Indian Reservation nearby.  Prerequisite:Span 202 and consent of instructor.  (Intcl)

name: PHIL-240
title: Philosophy of Art
pre_req: one course in philosophy or two courses in fine arts
desc: A study of the nature of art and its relationship to the human condition. Issues covered include definitions of art, the relationship between art and the community, the nature of aesthetic experience, and standards of taste. Offered alternate years.

name: WGST-239
title: Special Topic: Modern Arabic Literature
desc: Modern Arabic Literature.  This course is a study in Arabic novels and short stories (in English translation) written by five men and women from countries in the Middle East (authors such as el Sadaawi and Mahfouz).  They depict love and hate, courage and betrayal, doubt and confidence, despair and faith; in short they are stories we tell behind the mask of fiction.  One of the major goals of this course will be to find the connections we have in common with "the other".

name: ECON-339
title: Special Topic:History of EconomicyThought
desc: History of Economic Thought.  The course is designed to provide a survey of the history of economic thought from some of its earliest formations to the present day; from Aristotle to John Maynard Keynes and contemporary schools of thought.  The course will emphasize the intellectual and historical background, which influenced economy.  We will examine how economic theories evolved to explain and understand the way individuals and societies perceive human behavior and the relationships between individuals and society in the process of allocating and using resources.  We will also investigate how the development of economic thought both reflected and influenced developments in "scientific," religious, political, and social thought.  Course applies as a Econ major-Plan I and II elective. Prerequisite: Econ-130, JR or SR Standing.

name: WGST-185
title: Crisis Intervention:interpersonalyViolence
desc: Course is designed to introduce students to current theories, research and practice in the field of crisis intervention with interpersonal violence, with specific focus on the area of family violence.  Crisis intervention strategies with respect to people who have been physically, sexually, and emotionally abused will be covered in this course.  An introduction to assessment and intervention skills for working with individuals and families from diverse backgrounds will be emphasized.  This includes interventions with family members, as well as community level interventions that are culturally appropriate. This course will prepare students to serve as volunteers on the crisis line for the Domestic and Sexual Abuse Resource Center. Students interested in service learning in the area of interpersonal and family violence will have the opportunity to enroll in 104, a one-hour community based field experience which wil be offered during the following spring semester. (Same as women's studies 103.) Prerequisite: Must be first-year students.

name: WGST-139
title: Special Topic: Women in the DevelopingyWorld: Chile and Nicaragua
desc: Special Topic:  Women in the Developing World:Chile and Nicaragua.  Women in Central and South America have historically faced disadvantages in education, health care, income, and political participation.  However, in spite of these obstacles, Nicaragua is home to a thriving women's movement, which includes many efforts to combat poverty, violence, and illiteracy.  In similar ways, women in the poorest areas of Chile have been assisted in organizing a variety of effective community development projects. Students will learn about the challenges and opportunities that face present-day women and men in both countries by visiting both rural and urban locations where people have made and are making a difference.  The course will also introduce students to a number of relevent topics:  fair trade cooperatives, health care training programs, Peace Corps projects, the role of education, and efforts with Lutheran World Relief and the Lutheran Church.  Consent of instructor required.

name: IS-239
title: Special Topic:At the Crossroads ofyCulture and History: Music, Arts andyIdeas in Vienna, Austria
desc: At the Crossroads of Culture and History: Music, Arts and Ideas in Vienna, Austria.  Since its founding in Roman times, Vienna has been a crossroads between East and West, a place where peoples,cultures and ideas have clashed, cross-pollinated and found artistic and political accommodation. A polyglot musical culture, for example, materially supported by the Catholic Church and an artistically ambitious aristocracy, gave rise to a classical tradition that endures to the present day. The course will look at contemporary Vienna through the shifting prism of history, examining such topics as the cultural and political legacies of the Hapsburg Empire, the clash between Islam and Christendom, the period from the Edict of Toleration to the Holocaust, the Austrian Baroque and Viennese Classicism, Fin de Siecle Vienna, and the Viennese melting pot in the age of European Union. The course will include daily readings,lectures,discussions, on-site visits to museums, art galleries, churches, palaces and the United Nations, and attendance at operas and concerts.

name: MUST-120
title: Introduction to Museums
desc: The history of museums, archives, and collections and the nature and variety of museum work in contemporary society. An introduction to museum organization; museological theory and philosophy; concepts of museum exhibition and interpretation. Explores how collections and objects can be used as sources of meaning and information, and how museums and numerous other institutions can be used as educational resources. Workshops with Luther College Collections and Archives staff, as well as case studies at the Vesterheim Norwegian-Amercian Museum and Effigy Mounds National Monument. Offered alternate years.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topics: Survey of Latin AmericanyHistory Since 1825
desc: Survey of Latin American History Since 1825. Course begins with Independence movements against Spain and finishes at approximately 2000. Topics addressed include Independence, the end of slavery, modernization and economic development, democracy and dictatorships and relations with the Americas and the rest of the world. (HBSSM, HIST)

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: Religion and Literature
desc: This course is an exploration of religious and ethical questions and responses as presented in novels, plays and short stories by a selection of major twentieth-century writers. Issues for analysis and reflection include the quest for meaning in life, the presence or absence of God, the role of human community, moral dilemmas, the experience of suffering, the use and abuse of religious authority, and the cross-cultural interaction of religious world views. Authors include Chinua Achebe, Margaret Atwood, Samuel Beckett, Albert Camus, Shusaku Endo, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Graham Greene, Iris Murdoch, Flannery O'Connor, John Updike, Alice Walker, and Elie Wiesel. Prerequisite:Rel-101, Rel-111 or Rel-112. (RP, HEPT)

name: PSYC-270
title: Psychology and Aging
desc: This course is designed to examine psychological aspects of growing older in the 21st century.  Students will be introduced to the current methodologies used to study aging as we explore the physical, cognitive, and psychosocial changes in individuals over the age of 60.  The lecture, readings and assignments will address a range of topics that include expected versus abnormal changes in memory, creativity, the shifting roles of the elderly in family and society, and coping with illness and loss.  In light of the fact that individuals over the age of 85 are the fastest-growing segment of the global population, and that the majority are women (approximately 2:1), we will also study changes associated with gender roles and sexuality during our later years. A major goal for this course is to foster a clearer understanding of the processes associated with normal aging and to dispel a number of the stereotypes that surround this time of life. (Same as WGST 270)

name: ANTH-339
title: Special Topic:Image, Text and Culture
desc: Image, Text and Culture.  This course will examine the relationship between visual images, textual representation, and cultural practice.  We will take as our point of departure that culture is a semiotic phenomenon, that is, it is made up of signs and relationships between signs.  We will explore the ways in which signs encode and represent their meaning, and how, as cultural beings, we read and understand signs.  We will ground philosophical discussion with practical tools in learning to decipher the images and texts that surround us and through the use of case studies of other cultural systems. Prerequisite:Anth 103 or consent of instructor (HBSSM)

name: EDUC-300
title: Approved Teacher Educ Program
desc: Students who are enrolled in, or have completed this course are allowed to enroll in 300 level education courses. Prerequisite: permission of education department.

name: HIST-321
title: Topics in US HistoryyThe Great Depression:
desc: The Great Depression, 1920-1942. This course examines the time period from 1920 to 1942 beginning in rural America where economic crisis in the early 1920's until it became generalized across the nation by 1929-1930. Particular emphasis will include the changing role of the Federal Government and FDR's New Deal, the cultural manifestations of American values (including film, art, literature and conservation projects) and the ways in which the Depression connected with racial, class and gender issues.

name: HIST-485
title: Junior Senior Seminar - Era of AmericanyRevolution
pre_req: Take 16 credits in History or permission of instructor.
desc: The Era of the American Revolution: 1763-1800 By definition a revolution means to overthrow or overturn a previous order. Obviously, the creation of a new nation created a political revolution when Britains's North American colonies became the United States of America.  But did the revolution mean more than simply a change in political leadership?  It involved a long and very bloody war which created or enhanced fissures in American society every bit as great as those of 1861-1865. What caused the Revolution?  What were its consequences for Indian people, for women, for African Americans, for white men?  What did the establishment of new governments at the state and at national level really mean for our political, social and economic future? How does the American Revolution compare to other great revolutions in world history?  The course centers on the era from the end of the Seven Year's War to the election of Thomas Jefferson in 1800.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar: Gender, Sexuality, andyThe Bible
desc: Seminar: "Gender, Sexuality, and the Bible" This course will explore the intersections between biblical interptretation and issues of gender and sexuality. Students will engage with texts from both the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament. They will examine a variety of methods in biblical studies, with a particular focus on postmodern methods of interpretation. They will also engage in interdisciplinary study of contemporary theories and strategies in the fields of gender and sexuality studies, with a particular focus on Queer Theory. Finally, they will explore how their studies of biblical texts may contribute to the sometimes-divisive conversations regarding issues of gender and sexuality in contemporary religious communities.

name: EDUC-139
title: Special Topic:World Language MethodsyAnd Practicum for Elementary Teachers
desc: World Language Methods and Practicum for Elementary Teachers.  This course provides students with experience in World language instructional strategies for the elementary classroom.  The course includes world language instruction practica in area elementary classrooms.  Sophomores and above; permission of department head required.  Prerequisite:Educ 115.

name: EDUC-239
title: Special Topic:Assessment for TeachersyOf English Language Learners
desc: Assessment for Teachers of English Language Learners.  The course focuses on current second language assessment theory and practice.  Includes practical experience with assessment instruments and strategies.  Permission of department head required.  Prerequisite:  Educ 115.

name: HONR-210
title: The Ancient World
desc: This course examines major intellectual movements of antiquity. It investigates key ideas and texts, including literary and artistic expression, in areas such as flowering Greco-Roman philosophy, mathematics and astronomy in ancient Greece, Rome, and Africa, the contemporary blossoming of Buddist, Confucian, and classical Hindu thought, and the cosmologies of ancient civilizations of the Americas. Prerequisite: consent of the instructor. (HEPT)

name: HONR-220
title: From Ancient to Modern: Transitions andyEncounters
desc: This course examines intellectual developments between antiquity and the beginnings of the modern period. It explores such developments as the attempt to reconcile Christianity with ancient Greco-Roman philosophy, the rise of Islamic thought, new intellectual movements in South and East Asia, theological debates of the European Refomation, and encounters among peoples and cultures as a result of global exploration and migration.  Prerequisite: Acceptance into the Honors Core program. (HE, Hist)

name: HONR-320
title: Modernity: Natural Sciences
desc: This course examines major developments in the natural sciences from the scientific revolution onward. It investigates key issues on subjects such as cosmology, the growth of biological sciences and evolutionary theory, relativity and quantum mechanics, and computational science, with attention to social and cultural context and the social and ethical implications of these developments. Prerequisite: HONR 210 or 220. (NWNL)

name: PHIL-310
title: Metaphysics and Epistemology
desc: A comparative and critical study of major theories about being and knowing.  Metaphysical issues focus on the nature of reality, including the relationship between mind and matter, substance and attribute, time, space, causation, change, modality, and identity.  Epistemological topics concern the possibility, origins, nature, and extent of human knowledge.  The course includes classical as well as contemporary readings, covering a wide range of philosophical theories and their interaction. Offered alternate years.

name: CHEM-139
title: Special Topics: Kaboom!: Explosions inyScience and Society

name: MUS-139
title: Special Topic:Music and Culture ofyBrazil
desc: A survey of the social and music history of Brazil. Introduction to the native people, the colonization by the Portuguese, slavery, independence, immigration and how these elements evolved into Brazilian culture.  Performance and dance of choro, maxixe, samba, baiao, maracatu, frevo, bossa-nova, and MPB.

name: FCUL-339
title: Special Topic:Russia and Scandinavia:yHistorical and Cultural Ties
desc: This course will involve travel in both Norway (Oslo and Lillehammer) and Russia (St. Petersburg and Moscow).  In this course we will examine cultural and historical ties between Russia and Scandinavia, beginning with the Varangians (Vikings) in medieval times as the first ruling dynasty in medieval Rus' was established.  We will follow these ties to the present day, with special consideration given to contemporary environmental issues and current political events.  The study of art, architecture, music and literature of Norway and Russia is an important component of the course.  MLL and the Russian Studies Committee have approved this course as counting towards one of three electives for the Russian Studies Major and Minor.

name: HIST-239
title: ST:The Vietnam War
desc: By some measures, the Viet Nam War was the longest in United States history. It brought Lyndon Johnson's presidency to an end, divided American society, and resulted in a reexamination of the limits of American power which continues today. Using historical texts, a novel, articles, music, and film, the course will examine the Viet Nam War from multiple perspectives: first, as military and political history, including Amercian political history; second, as an event framed by and comprehensible in terms of the Cold War; and, third, as an event which had both contemporary and lasting cultural and social impact.

name: CHEM-301
title: Biochemistry
desc: An introduction to the chemistry of the four major classes of biological molecules:proteins, sugars, lipids, and nucleic acids.
