The relationship between the functional roles of these molecules and their structure and reactivity will be examined using the chemical principles mastered in the prerequisite courses of general chemistry and two semesters of organic chemistry.  This course will fulfill the one-semester biochemistry prerequisite of typical health professional programs.

name: ECON-256
title: Economic History
desc: This course focuses on applying basic methods of economic way of thinking (cost/benefit analysis, supply and demand analysis, simulation) through empirical examination of episodes in American, European and world history.

name: BIO-195
title: Biology of RaceyAnd Sex
desc: This course will introduce students to basic concepts of inheritance and expression of genotypes into phenotypes, using the inheritance of sex and race-associated traits as case studies. These complex traits are useful examples of the influence of individual genes, genomes, and the physical environment on phenotypes. Not intended for biology majors. (Same as WGST 195)

name: FREN-490
title: Senior Project
desc: The senior project requirement gives students an opportunity to participate in independent study, to read relevant literature in their chosen area, to develop methods of research and analysis appropriate to their selected topic, and to construct a sustained argument in the language of their major. To enrich their work, students will be encouraged to reflect on and use their study-abroad and firsthand cultural experiences as a means of contextualizing their projects. The research paper is written in French and is presented orally as well. If students have another major in addition to French, they are not required to complete a senior project in both majors.

name: HIST-321
title: Top U.S. Hist-Fren Ind Wars
pre_req: Take Hist-135 Hist-201 Hist-202, Hist-203 or consent of instructor. Take Paideia 112D or the equivalent.
desc: Topics in U.S. History - The French and Indian Wars 1689-1763.  Focuses on the military, diplomatic and social consequences of the century of struggle between England, France and various Native groups in North America.  Prerequisite: Hist 135, Hist 201, Hist 202, Hist 203 or consent of instructor. (HBSSM, Hist)

name: HIST-485
title: Junior/Senior Seminar:Hitler and NaziyGermany
pre_req: Take 16 credits in History or permission of instructor.

name: MUS-131
title: Theory I - Honors
desc: Honors section of theory for first-year students.  A placement test is required before registering for any section of music theory.

name: MUS-131L
title: Ear Training I - Honors
desc: Honors section of ear training for first-year students.

name: SPAN-304
title: Advanced Grammar and Translation
pre_req: SPAN 201 or placement into the course.
desc: This course is for students who have completed SPAN 201 or the equivalent and who require more practice with advanced grammar structures. This course is especially recommended for those who plan to teach Spanish. Focus on advanced grammar functions and correcting common mistakes. Translation exercises reinforce grammar fundamentals. It is recommended to take this course after SPAN 302 and SPAN 303.

name: ENG-239
title: Masterworks of 19TH-CENTURY RussianyLiterarture
desc: A survey of 19th-century Russian literature  (in translation) from Romanticism to Realism. Reading and discussion of selected works of major Russian authors, including Pushkin, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Checkhov, Gogol and Lermontov. The course will be conducted in English and readings are in English.  No prerequisite.

name: COMS-239
title: ST: Crime and Media
desc: This course examines relationships between elements of the criminal justice system and elements of the mass media, and how each influences the other. Included will be discussion of crime depiction in news  media (TV, newspapers, internet), crime depiction in entertainment media (music, TV, video games, film) and use of media/media technology by law enforcement and criminal defendants.

name: SOC-273
title: Crime and Media
desc: This course examines relationships between elements of the criminal justice system and elements of the mass media, and how each influences the other. Included will be discussion of crime depiction in news media (TV, newspapers, internet), crime depiction in entertainment media (music, TV, video games, film) and use of media/media technology by law enforcement and criminal defendants.

name: ECON-239
title: Special Topics: To Boldly Go: By RoadyAnd River Through the Bolivian,yBrazilian and Peruvian Amazon
desc: The southwestern Amazon, where the rainforest meets the Andes Mountains, includes some of the most ecologically diverse areas on earth - and sustains human populations whose livelihoods use strategies consistent with the region's environment. Yet deveolpment of another kind - the extension of paved roads and of pipelines, the building of dams - threatens these populations and this diversity. Our course involves travel by road and river through the area where three countries meet (Bolivia, Brazil and Peru), as we explore what development means in this corner of the Amazon. We spend several days camping in the forest, as guests of and indigenous commmunity; we visit agroforestry projects and farmer cooperatives that harvest natural rubber and Brazil nuts and such fruit as acai and cupuacu. Above all, we ask the people in all three countries what they think of the coming changes, and what hope there is of preserving the viable alternative they themselves have created. Although most of our time will be spent in the Amazon lowland, our course begins and ends in the Bolivian capital of La Paz, and includes a visit to the colonial city of Cusco and the "lost city of the Incas" at Machu Picchu.

name: ECON-339
title: Special Topics: To Boldly Go: By RoadyAnd River Through the Bolivian,yBrazilian and Peruvian Amazon
desc: The southwestern Amazon, where the rainforest meets the Andes Mountains, includes some of the most ecologically diverse areas on earth - and sustains human populations whose livelihoods use strategies consistent with the region's environment. Yet deveolpment of another kind - the extension of paved roads and of pipelines, the building of dams - threatens these populations and this diversity. Our course involves travel by road and river through the area where three countries meet (Bolivia, Brazil and Peru), as we explore what development means in this corner of the Amazon. We spend several days camping in the forest, as guests of and indigenous commmunity; we visit agroforestry projects and farmer cooperatives that harvest natural rubber and Brazil nuts and such fruit as acai and cupuacu. Above all, we ask the people in all three countries what they think of the coming changes, and what hope there is of preserving the viable alternative they themselves have created. Although most of our time will be spent in the Amazon lowland, our course begins and ends in the Bolivian capital of La Paz, and includes a visit to the colonial city of Cusco and the "lost city of the Incas" at Machu Picchu.

name: ENVS-239
title: Special Topics: To Boldly Go: By RoadyAnd River Through the Bolivian,yBrazilian and Peruvian Amazon
desc: The southwestern Amazon, where the rainforest meets the Andes Mountains, includes some of the most ecologically diverse areas on earth - and sustains human populations whose livelihoods use strategies consistent with the region's environment. Yet deveolpment of another kind - the extension of paved roads and of pipelines, the building of dams - threatens these populations and this diversity. Our course involves travel by road and river through the area where three countries meet (Bolivia, Brazil and Peru), as we explore what development means in this corner of the Amazon. We spend several days camping in the forest, as guests of and indigenous commmunity; we visit agroforestry projects and farmer cooperatives that harvest natural rubber and Brazil nuts and such fruit as acai and cupuacu. Above all, we ask the people in all three countries what they think of the coming changes, and what hope there is of preserving the viable alternative they themselves have created. Although most of our time will be spent in the Amazon lowland, our course begins and ends in the Bolivian capital of La Paz, and includes a visit to the colonial city of Cusco and the "lost city of the Incas" at Machu Picchu.

name: POLS-239
title: Special Topics: Conflict andyReconciliation in Northern Ireland.
desc: The goal of this course is a deeper understanding both of the conflict between the Nationalist/Republican/Catholic and Unionist/Loyalist/Protestant communities and the decade-long peace process. Representatives of the warring factions now sit across from each other in Northern Ireland's Parliament. Because Northern Ireland is a place where the British and Irish nations overlap, we will meet with government officals and scholars in London and Dublin as well as in Belfast. There will be visits to the British, Irish and Northern Ireland Parliaments, in addition to the conventional tourist sites in each city. The last week will be spent in Northern Ireland, with the intinerary including: Belfast, the Corrymeela Peace and Reconciliation Centre in Ballycastle (on the coast), Derry (Londonderry), and Omagh where a 1998 terrorist bombing proved a tipping point in the peace process. Meetings with police, representatives of the nationalist and unionist communities, and former paramilitary members will be arranged.

name: PAID2-450
title: Constructing Islam
desc: Understanding Islam is essential in today's geopolitical climate.  This course will explore the nature of Islam, examine how Islam and Muslims are represented in global media, especially in light of the events of September 11, 2001, and consider the relevance of movements like Islamic Democracy, Islamic Economics and Islamic Feminism or an understanding of Islam in the contemporary world.  The representation of Islam and Muslims in a variety of rhetorical forms in the U.S. will be evaluated and compared with media messages in Islamic countries, and the ethical implications of these constructions will be analyzed.

name: EDUC-378
title: Content Area Reading, Elementary/MiddleySchool
pre_req: Admission to Teacher Educ Program and EDUC 226
desc: Introduction to the teaching of reading in content areas for elementary and middle school; assessment in content area reading; improving content area literacy by developing strategies in reading, writing, speaking, and listening.  Required for elementary reading endorsement, middle school specialist, and ESL endorsement.  Requires acceptance into the Teacher Education Program.

name: EDUC-323
title: Teaching Methods for EnglishyLanguage Learners
desc: Basic introduction to historical and contemporary theories and methods of English as a second language instruction with an emphasis on methodologies for teaching reading, writing, listening and pronunciation skills within the context of content areas grounded in academic and social/cultural language goals.

name: FREN-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar. Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed project is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department. All projects must be presented publicly. Only projects awared an "A- or A" qualify for "department honors" designation. The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: EDUC-324
title: Assessment for English Language Learners
desc: This K-12 course is an introduction to assessment for English language learners including formal and informal tools, interpretation of assessment data, use of data to inform instruction, and the fundamental technical aspects of assessment.

name: CHIN-101
title: Beginning Chinese
desc: This course offers an introduction to speaking, reading, listening to, and writing Chinese. Through the study of the language, the student will also gain an appreciation of Chinese culture and contemporary life.

name: POLS-339
title: Special Topics:Latin American Politics
desc: This course examines the development of Latin American countries' current political situations. Historical emphasis will be placed on US-Latin American relations.  Country-specific analysis of current political situations will form the basis for comparative analysis.

name: HONR-210
title: Ancient World:Intellectual DevelopmentsyIn the Ancient World
desc: This course will examine the major intellectual developments of antiquity in ancient Mesopotamia, Egypt, Greece, Rome, India and China.  Together we will explore the eternal problems of justice, ethics, love, death and more, meeting along the way great thinkers from Homer and Socrates to Confucius and the Buddha.  See Honors webpage for the application to the core.

name: HONR-210
title: The Ancient World: Gender and Sexualityyin the Ancient and Classical World
desc: Where do our contemporary attitudes toward gender and sexuality come from, and how do we challenge the customs and practices of the past?  A focus on the roles of women and men, sexuality and marriage, in defining periods of western and eastern culture, from "trickster women," priestesses, and Bacchanalian rites, to manly love and the male code of the war hero and political leader.  Readings include stories from the Hebrew Bible, Greek plays and poetry, Roman mythology, Arabic and Chinese folk tales, marriage laws and rituals, as well as interpretations by historians, artists, and philosophers of gender roles and lives lived in antiquity.  See Honors webpage for the application to the core.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topic: Apostle Paul: Discourseyand Practice
desc: This course examines the discourses and practices that Paul, an itinerant missionary within the early Christian movement, developed in interaction with a variegated social world.  Through a close examination of Paul's authentic letters, the class will identify the practical and discursive strategies that he deployed in an effort to garner the prestige, authority, and economic resources necessary to sustain his enterprise. Prereq: Rel 101, 111 or 112. (Rel)

name: EDUC-486
title: Teaching Practicum
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.
desc: Observation and teaching in an area schools. Student teaching experiences are offered in each of the following areas: elementary education, secondary education, and K-12 student teaching in art, music, and physical education. Those who do 18 weeks of EDUC 486 to meet the Wisconsin certification and additional licensure endorsements will register for 2 additional credits during January term.

name: HIST-339
title: Special Topic:Topics in Latin AmericanyHistory:The United States and LatinyAmerica
desc: The complicated relationship of the nations of Central and South America with the United States is the focus of this course.  It begins with the era of American Manifest Destiny in the early 19th Century and ends with contemporary debates over the War on Drugs and NAFTA.  Particular attention will be given to the Mexican-American War, Spanish-American War, various US interventions in Central America and the Caribbean, and the inconstancy of US views of its Latin American neighbors: from unruly children needing control and discipline, to Good Neighbors, to Allies for Progress.  Students will examine this relationship through texts, literature, film, music, and preparation of a research paper. ((HBSSM, Hist, Intcl)

name: CS-239
title: Special Topic: Introduction to GraphyTheory
desc: This course will cover an introduction to graph theory and provide a foundation for most areas of study within the field.  Graph theory techniques have been applied to a large collection of real world problems.  The course will pose many problems in terms of these real world examples. It will introduce students to theorems and proofs within the field of graph theory.  This course will also introduce algorithms as they apply to the solution of problems covered in the course and students willhave the opportunity to solve some of the problems by implementing these algorithms. Prereq: CS 150, CS/Math 220, and CS 151 or consent of instructor.

name: MATH-239
title: Special Topic:Introduction to GraphyTheory
desc: This course will cover an introduction to graph theory and provide a foundation for most areas of study within the field.  Graph theory techniques have been applied to a large collection of real world problems.  The course will pose many problems in terms of these real world examples. It will introduce students to theorems and proofs within the field of graph theory.  This course will also introduce algorithms as they apply to the solution of problems covered in the course and students willhave the opportunity to solve some of the problems by implementing these algorithms. Prereq: CS 150, CS/Math 220, and CS 151 or consent of instructor.

name: FCUL-339
title: Special Topics:Topics in ChineseyCulture
desc: This course will study in depth a particular topic in Chinese culture as seen through primary tests or film.  It will be conducted in English.  More information will be forthcoming soon.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures: Comic and CosmicyQuests
desc: Literary Ventures: Comic and Cosmic Quests. How can the plucky hero grow up, get a job, get a life, slay the dragon, and find true love? After all the excitement is over, how will the hero tell the story? All sorts of storytellers - contemporary poets, Hollywood filmmakers,authors of popular children's books, ancient bards, postmoderinst novelists - have been drawn to the archetypal story of the quest. We will exploe that quest narrative in drama, poetry, fiction, and film. Expect weekly writing assignments and readings both contemporary and ancient, familiar and unfamiliar, in this course about quests, dreams, love, truth, art, and (mostly) happy endings.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar: Jacobean Theatre
desc: Seminar: Jacobean Theatre. The second half of Shakespeare's career coincided with a remarkable period of English stage history. Dramatists developed tragedies that anatomized such volatile issues as gender (The Changeling), incest ('Tis Pity She's a Whore), and lycanthropia (The Duchess of Malfi); created new genres like the hyper-realistic city comedies (Bartholomew Fair); risked their careers by penning plays with topical political commentary (A Game of Chess); and wrote biting satires that skewered a court and society that many considered decadent (The Reventer's Tragedy, A New Way to Pay Old Debts). This seminar will explore the way in which a thriving theatre tradition can simultaneously explore the most local and the most universal questions.

name: REL-239
title: Of China and JapanyST: New Religions of ChinayAnd Japan
desc: This course introduces history, teachings, and practices of religious movements that have appeared in China and Japan in the last 150 years. Emphasis will be on the ways these forms of religious experience have affected and been affected by cultural, political, and social contexts. We will study the history, teachings, and practices of these new religious movements, placing them within the contexts of traditional religious and philosophical systems, ritual practices, representations in popular media, and changes in family structure and dynamics.

name: MATH-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Involvement in a research project under the supervision of department faculty. Recommended for students who expect to attend graduate school. Prerequisites and requirements vary by department.

name: POLS-139
title: Special Topic:Controversy and the U.S.ySupreme Court (Washington Consortium)

name: EDUC-490
title: Senior Project
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Educ Program

name: GS-98
title: HS Lang (None) - Semester 1
desc: No language completed in high school

name: GS-99
title: HS Lang (None) - Semester 2
desc: No language completed in high school

name: GER-101
title: Elementary German I
desc: The basic structures of German. Students will learn to understand, speak, read, and write German at a beginner's level and gain awareness of the culture of German-speaking countries.

name: HIST-185
title: The Rise and Development of BlackyNationalism in the United States
desc: A study of the philosophy and movements of black unification in the United States, beginning with the Ethiopian move and ending with Black Power and the cultural revolution of the late 1960s and 1970s.

name: AFRS-185
title: The Rise and Development of BlackyNationalism in the United States
desc: A study of the philosophy and movements of black unification in the United States, beginning with the Ethiopian move and ending with Black Power and the cultural revolution of the late 1960s and 1970s.

name: CHEM-141
title: Essentials of Chemistry
desc: A one-semester general chemistry class for students who require or wish to take just one semester of college chemistry with a laboratory component.  Topics will be chosen from the Chemical Principles sequence (Chemistry 151-152) and laboratories will introduce students to basic chemistry lab skills and techniques.  This course is not intended for students going on in chemistry or biology.  Algebra skills are assumed. (Students who earn credit for 141 may not earn credit for CHEM 114, 116, 151 or 152).

name: CLAS-255
title: Ancient Roman Culture
desc: This course explores various cultural institutions and practices of the ancient Romans through an examination of textual, historical, and archaeological evidence.  Emphasis will be on the period from the late Republic to early Empire. Topics include Roman banquets, the toga, houses and villas, the bath complexes, the gladitorial games and chariot races, the theater, religion, and slavery. Offered alternate years.

name: CLAS-299
title: Study Abroad-Classics
desc: In-depth study of selected topics in the Greco-Roman world taught during January term as part of Luther's study abroad offerings.  Topics will vary according to faculty member and location.  Possible topics may include the Ancient Empires of the Mediterranean, Age of Pericles, the World of Alexander, Caesar's Rome, and Roman Britain. Consent of instructor required.

name: GER-102
title: Elementary German II
desc: The basic structures of German. Students will learn to understand, speak, read, and write German at a beginner's level and gain awareness of the culture of German-speaking countries.

name: ENVS-310
title: Earth: Evolution of a Habitable Planet
desc: Among the planets of our solar system, the Earth alone has remained hospitable to life throughout its long history.  What processes and feedbacks have consistently maintained conditions on the Earth's surface within the bounds required for survival of life?  From the earliest Earth to the modern day, we will explore the intertwined histories of life, atmospheric chemistry, geologic processes, and the climate system.  Additional emphasis on the scientific techniques used to reconstruct Earth history.  Laboratory includes fieldtrips exploring regional geology.

name: MUS-239
title: Special Topic: Bach and ContemporaryyMusical Life in Germany
desc: This course, open to majors and non-majors, will give students the opportunity to study a broad historical outline of J.S. Bach's life and work, with visits to key places in Bach's chronology, such as Eisenach, Weimar, and Leipzig.  In addition to these site visits, the course will also examine current musical life in Germany through attendance of musical performances in major cultural centers, including Berlin.  While in Berlin, students will also spend several days visiting sites related to the Berlin Wall and participate in lectures and guided tours that will consider the challenges the city faced during the Cold War.  Discussions will also compare the differences in East German and West German cultural life during this era.

name: MUS-239
title: Special Topic:Listening Live in LondonyAnd Paris
desc: This is a course about broadening the contexts that inform our listening experiences.  It is intended for students from all majors--the wider variety, the better.  Taking full advantage of the range of musical performances available and the rich musical history and cultures of London, we will attend concerts in the evenings and spend the afternoons visiting sites that help provide the context for the music we hear.  Morning class time will be devoted to discussions not only of music, but of art, literature, and historical and current events as they relate to the cultural climate of the musical works.  Day trips around England, and a visit to Paris will expand the boundaries even further.  As a group, we'll explore the ways in which our knowledge and differing perspectives affect the experience of listening to musical performances.

name: ANTH-139
title: Special Topic:Global Christianities
desc: From its beginnings, early believers and leaders of Christianity were evangelists intent on spreading their beliefs to others in the Levant and beyond.  Throughout the history of Christianity, the missionizing, evangelizing efforts of believers have placed Christian belief and practice in contact with other cultures and spiritual traditions.  Such contact has resulted in local understanding of Christianity as a living tradition.  This course will examine the consequences of these interactions and the ways in which local understandings and uses of Christian belief and practice vary across cultural contexts. Topics covered will include folk Catholic beliefs among indigenous populations in the Americas, Christian syncretism, culture change as a result of missionization, and the global spread of Evangelical Christianity.

name: BIO-185
title: Natural History of Food
desc: An exploration of agriculture and ecology; the geography, history, and evolution of foods; and the art of cooking.  Course format will be mainly discussion and student presentation, , in addition to the preparation and eating of nine meals (mainly vegetarian).  Course fee required, gastronomic curiosity strongly recommended.

name: EDUC-239
title: Special Topic: Developmental/AdaptedyPhysical Education:introduction
desc: Developmental/Adapted PE:Introduction. A study of higher-incidence disabilities commonly found among students in the public school setting and the impact upon physical growth, development and motor learning.  Discussion of the historical, philosophical basis for adapted physical activity, and the impact of state and federal legislation. Analysis of the roles and responsibilities of the developmental/adapted physical education (DAPE) specialist and the inclusive educational environment.  The course is applicable to all disciplines dealing with the disabled.

name: EDUC-239
title: Special Topic:Developmental/AdaptedyPhysical Education:Application
desc: Developmental/Adapted PE:Application. A study of prescriptive programming in the public school setting for individuals with disabilities including mental, emotional, learning, and other health impairments.  Emphasis will be placed upon: instructional and developmental teaching methods, designing IEP's, unit plans, assessment, referral, planning and placement procedures, and organizational abilities related to teaching physical and motor fitness skills.  These strategies will be explored relative to the diverse setting in physical education classes or the separate adapted physical education class setting.

name: ENG-185
title: What Tolkien Read
desc: In "The Lord of the Rings", JRR Tolkien attempted to recreate a native mythology for England. To do so, Tolkien drew on the medieval poems and stories he studied as an Oxford professor. In this course, we will read some of the works that fed his imagination, including "The Wanderer", "Beowulf", and "Gawain and the Green Knight", and stories from the Icelandic sagas. Through class discussion, small group projects, and seminar presentations, we will think about how those works provided Tolkien with his materials and how they were transformed in his own work.  It would be good if students could read (or re-read) "The Lord of the Rings" before the term starts.

name: MGT-185
title: Women in the Workplace
desc: Examines the role of women in the workplace, with emphasis on business.  Course activities include use of the Myers-Briggs and Strengthsfinder instruments, research of topics related to the advancement of women, sexual harassment, work/life balance, leadership, and mentoring, and opportunities to learn from resource people.

name: GER-201
title: Intermediate German
desc: Completion of basic grammatical structures. Beginning composition and conversation through greater emphasis on the creative aspects of language use, i.e., speaking and writing.

name: PAID2-450
title: Making Peace and Breaking Bread
desc: Although ordinary and even humble, food is an important link to the ideas of community and peacemaking.  The choices we make regarding food and those with whom we break bread carry deep ethical, political and spiritual implications.  In exploring the international communities of Assisi and Taize, and the stories of Saints Francis and Clara of Assisi and Brother Roger of Taize, students will be challenged to recognize the potential violence and polarization that underlie unexamined patterns of consumption, individualism and nationalism.  The course will include a week with the Taize community, and international community known as the "city of peace", and a week with the Taize community, an international community committed to prayer, reconciliation and ecumenism.  Travels will be framed by the rich and complex cities of Paris and Rome.

name: PAID2-450
title: Hip-Hop and Cultural Identity
desc: This class examines the history, culture and politics surrounding the creation and commercialization of the African American movement known as "Hip-Hop".  Growing out of the five boroughs of New York, hip-hop has revealed itself as a global cultural arts movement.  This course will examine how hip-hop functions as an important site of cultural production and identity formation within a racialized society.  Students will explore how the intersection of race, gender, sexual orientation and class is inherently a part of hip-hop's dialogue of identity formation while considering whether hip-hop challenges or reinforces racial, gender, and sexual orientation stereotypes.  The course will also grapple with topics relating to the commerical success and market-driven commodification of hip-hop, questioning if such mass consumption inevitably undermines hip-hop's original intent of social resistance and empowerment.

name: COMS-339
title: Special Topic:Dubai and the United ArabyEmirates: a Model Islamic Development?
desc: An Islamic Bedouin society officially established as a nation-state in 1971, the United Arab Emirates has developed into a remarkably progressive post-industrial, cosmopolitan, commercial society in the span of 37 years.  This course will explore the history of and modern developments in the United Arab Emirates, particularly in Dubai.  Topics include: Bedouin culture, world class development projects, women's roles in the UAE, the Western education model, diversity in population and class issues, and gender roles.

name: WGST-339
title: Special Topic: Dubai and the UnitedyArab Emirates: a Model IslamicyDevelopment?
desc: An Islamic Bedouin society officially established as a nation-state in 1971, the United Arab Emirates has developed into a remarkably progressive post-industrial, cosmopolitan, commercial society in the span of 37 years.  This course will explore the history of and modern developments in the United Arab Emirates, particularly in Dubai.  Topics include: Bedouin culture, world class development projects, women's roles in the UAE, the Western education model, diversity in population and class issues, and gender roles.

name: CHEM-185
title: Molecules That Changed the World
desc: A study of the impact of seventeen groups of molecules upon civilization.  These molecules determined what we now eat, drink, and wear; they inspired voyages of discovery, grand fears of engineering, and monumental advances in medicine and law.  The course will emphasize the structure of molecules; it will demonstrate repeatedly how a change as small as the position of an atom can alter the properties of a substance and, in turn, shift history and culture.  No previous background in science or mathematics is required.

name: CS-185
title: Introduction to Programming Using 3DyAnimation
desc: This seminar will introduce students to computer programming through the use of Alice, an innovative 3D programming environment.  Students will learn about the object oriented programming paradigm as they construct virtual worlds and animation. Students who have completed CS 150 are not allowed to enroll in this course.

name: FCUL-185
title: Introducation to Chinese Cinema
desc: This course will introduce Chinese films made in mainland China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong with the aim of exposing students to non-Hollywood filmmaking traditions.  Films that are representative of new Chinese Cinema will help students to better understand China's history, culture, politics, and aesthetic conventions over the past century.  It will also examine new changes brought in by the advent of globalization.  Issues including gender relations, nationhood, tradition versus modernity, film's pedagogical function versus entertainment, cross-cultural spectatorship, and authorship will be addressed in this course.  All films have English subtitles.  All readings are in English. No language background required.

name: LIST-185
title: Web 2.0: Creating Information in aySocial Environment
desc: Web 2.0 environments, such as Facebook, YouTube, and Wikipedia, are commonly viewed as venues for entertainment and recreation, but many also allow information and media to be created and shared communally.  Students in this course will research the origins of many Web 2.0 applications, will gain experience creating and sharing information in these environments, and will create and imagine new environments sparked by emerging information needs.

name: PHYS-185
title: The Development of Atomic Weapons andyAtomic Power
desc: The building of nuclear reactors and atomic bombs required an enormous amount of resources.  Cities that were home to thousands of workers and manufacturing plants covering hundreds of acres were built just to make atomic bombs, yet, much of the initial work was done by small groups of scientists working with very few resources.  This course traces this development from the work of a few individuals in a close knit scientific community to the large administrative enterprise it became.  There will be a focus on the basic science necessary to understand how atomic bombs and nuclear reactors work as well as how these devices changed the culture in the United States.

name: SOC-185
title: Social and Economic Worlds of Wal-Mart
desc: This course will study Wal-Mart in order to examine cultural, social, and economic dynamics of contemporary American life.  Economic topics include:  prices, labor markets, working conditions, growth of discount retailers, globalized supply chains, and unions. Socio-cultural topics include:  consumer behavior, social class and lifestyle, identity, consumer culture, anti-sweatshop activism, and community conflict over new Wal-Mart stores.

name: MGT-239
title: Special Topic: The Influence of NGOsyAnd Technology on Education in Tanzania
desc: This course will study a variety of NGOs in Tanzania, most of which are focused on providing educational resources.  Students will study the organizational structure and leadership of the NGOs and the influence those organizations have on the local community.  Attention will be paid to the benefits and challenges of the NGOs as well as sustainability of the NGOs themselves and the sustainability of the benefits provided by the NGOs.  Students will also visit secondary schools in the Arusha and Monduli areas that have been influenced by the work of different NGOs, with particular interest in how NGOs have influenced the use of computers in the schools.  Finally, students will work on service projects will the schools, such as teaching basic computer skills to students and faculty.

name: MGT-239
title: Special Topic:Power, Influence andyDiversity
desc: Social dynamics and "culture" in the workplace, from the microcosm of the immediate work group, to the macrocosm of the whole company and industry, will be studied in this class.  Students will learn about how these often "unseen" factors come into play in cross cultural business interactions, mergers, and organizational change, as well as in day-to-day happenings in any business.  Students will be equipped to manage challenging situations more effectively, both for themselves and in helping others.

name: MGT-339
title: Special Topic:Supply Chain Management
desc: Supply Chain Management (SCM) views the entire "value chain", including a company, its suppliers, and its customers, as a whole "system" made up of interdependent components, and provides the logic, principles, and methods for managing in that context.  The instructor will focus on methods used in SCM to smooth the flow of products, services and information up and down the supply chain that create "harmony" in the system, reduce waste and improve product quality and customer satisfaction.

name: PSYC-185
title: You're As Young As You Feel: theyPsychology of Aging
desc: This seminar will introduce students to the study of adult development and aging.  We will discuss the physical, cognitive, and social changes that effect individuals aged 60 to 95, and examine some current findings in aging research.  In addition, we will consider how external influences contribute to ageism and shape our expectations of growing older in the 21st Century.

name: ART-185
title: Character and Environmental Design
desc: An immersion into the design world of film, animation, theatre, and video games. A studio seminar class for first year students that introduces them to the tools and concepts involved in designing sets, costumes, characters, and environments. Drawing will be used primarily in the course for generation of ideas, and advanced software and hardware will be used for the final execution of student projects. The student will explore conceptual, cultural, and practical concepts encompassing character and environment design.  A variety of media will be used including pencil, collage, photography, 3D model building, and 3D rendering. Group problem solving skills are emphasized in this course.

name: POLS-239
title: Special Topic:Black Political Thought
desc: Politics has played a key role in the African American experience in the United States.  This course offers an intensive introduction to black political thought.  This course focuses on the various ideologies and strategies which have informed the African American quest for human fulfillment, self actualization, and equity in the United States of America.  The readings will focus on thinkers and activists from the rebellion against slavery to the contemporary charges of institutional racism and reparations.  The course will focus on such activists, thinkers, and writers, as Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth, Booker T. Washington, Maria Stewart, W.E.B. DuBois, Ida B. Wells, Marcus Garvey, Martin Luther King, Jr, Angela Davis, Kwame Toure, Malcolm X, bell hooks, Patricia Hill Collins, Barack Obama, the contemporary African American conservatives, public intellectuals, and lesser known figures.

name: AFRS-239
title: Special Topic:Black Political Thought
desc: Politics has played a key role in the African American experience in the United States.  This course offers an intensive introduction to black political thought.  This course focuses on the various ideologies and strategies which have informed the African American quest for human fulfillment, self actualization, and equity in the United States of America.  The readings will focus on thinkers and activists from the rebellion against slavery to the contemporary charges of institutional racism and reparations.  The course will focus on such activists, thinkers, and writers, as Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth, Booker T. Washington, Maria Stewart, W.E.B. DuBois, Ida B. Wells, Marcus Garvey, Martin Luther King, Jr, Angela Davis, Kwame Toure, Malcolm X, bell hooks, Patricia Hill Collins, Barack Obama, the contemporary African American conservatives, public intellectuals, and lesser known figures.

name: ART-239
title: St: Travel Path Early BooksyST: Traveling the Path of Early Books:yLondon, Oxford and Ireland
desc: Participants in this art class will spend time visiting libraries, museums and historic sites that are not related to the development of the book. Our journey will begin with site visits in London and them we will travel to Dublin and other Irish locations. We will continue on our way to Ireland's West where we will take some time to practice studio book making skills. Students will be constructing a variety of personal volumes, based on the sites, models and experiences encountered while traveling. No pre-requisites, though interest in visual art or writing would be helpful.

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History:FrenchyRevolution and Napolean
desc: This class will examine the course of the French Revolution, from its beginnings as an "aristocratic resurgence" against the king, through the outbreak of violent revolution, the Reign of Terror, the rise of Napolean and the Grand Empire, and the restoration of the Bourbon monarchy.  It will also trace the development of movements such as nationalism, liberalism, conservatism, and individuals, which emerged from the revolutionary era to become dominant forces in the 19th century. (HB, Hist)

name: BIO-139
title: ST: Pandemic Viruses
desc: An introduction to viruses that have the potential to cause pandemics, including Avian Influenza A, Ebola, Hanta, Small Pox, HIV, and SARS. Techniques used by virologists to analyse and manipulate viral genomes and possible dangers associated with such techniques will be discussed. The development and limitations of antiviral drugs an viral vaccines will be addressed. Each student will investigate a specific human virus of his or her own choice and present their research to the class. Emphasis will be placed on familiarzing student with authoritative scientific sources of information. Using these sources, students will evaluate popular representations of highly pathogenic viruses and approaches to pandemic preparedness.

name: HIST-299
title: Topics in History:Reading Local HistoryyIn India
desc: This course examines Indian history from the ground up, using local narratives to think about historical figures and processes operating on a larger scale.  Travel to ordinary and well-known historical sites in northern and western India shows how people use the past to engage in current dialogues and how material life affects the construction of history.  Guest lectures and student interviews with a variety of locals will encourage students to consider the many different ways individuals' memory of historical events interact with more formal constructions of historical narratives.

name: ENG-185
title: Walking Books
desc: Walking offers us a world we cannot experience in an automobile or airplane or on a screen. In this course we will learn about walking's history and discuss its role in, for possible examples, memoirs, novels, short stories, play, poems, or essays (e.g., "Walden," "Persuasion," "Dubliners," "Virgin Time," "The Wasteland," or "Wanderlust: A History of Walking"). We will also walk--on trails, sidewalks, and open spaces: in towns, cities, and country; in weather fair and fairer. The course will include student writing and presentations, both academic and personal. (Possible additional cost for travel:$25-50.)

name: LIST-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: Readings on specific topics in Library and Information Studies under the direction of a member of the department.

name: LIST-380
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on- or off-campus work in public or private organizations. Students may complete their internship in Preus Library at Luther College or at another library (J-term or Summer only). A plan must be submitted for approval before the internship begins. Minimum 2.5 GPA and sophomore standing. Prerequisites: consent of faculty internship coordinator.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar: Possession
desc: Narrators gain possession of the storie they tell, shaping their reader's persperctives as they seek to make us thieir allies and position themselves in relation to other characters and situations. In these three novels and two novellas of spirit possession and extra-sensory phenomena (Bronte's Jane Eyre, Rhy's Wide Sargasso Sea, Jame's The Aspern Papers and The Turn of the Screw, Atwood's Alias Grace)first-person narration raises questions about self-representation, self-deception, and the nature of subjectivity itself, as narrators make and break their contracts to tell us, strictly speaking, the truth.

name: REL-185
title: Bible Movies
desc: The Bible provided content for some of the earliest movies made in the late 19th century, and it has continued to do so to this day. This course will survey Bible movies of the 20th and 21st centuries. Students will learn to analyze these movies as interpretations of biblical narratives situated in their own historical and cultural contexts, and they will reflect on their own experience of watching these movies today. Students will have multiple opportunities to present their work in class.

name: GER-344
title: German Play
desc: Students will write and perform a play in German. Emphasis is on oral expression, pronunciation, review of advanced grammatical structures, and writing. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: REL-185
title: Religion, Ethics, and Animal Welfare
desc: This course will familiarize students with contemporary animal-rights issues through an examination of the philosophical arguments for and against animal rights and an exploration of various religious perspectives on nonhuman animals and the ethical dimensions of their relationships with human beings. Particular emphasis will be given to Buddhist, Christian, and Hindu religious views on animal welfare concerns. Students will develop research projects focusing on an array of issues related to non-human animals which may include, but are not limited to, the vivisection debate, animal fighting, associations between animal abuse and person to person violence, factory farming, and puppy mills. The course will include field trips to the humane society, zoos and local farms.

name: PHIL-185
title: Technology and the Human Condition
desc: This class will inquire into the profound and subtle ways technology has changed human life by looking at both the natural and human environments.  We will enhance our critical thinking skills by learning to decipher the not so obvious effects of technological change.  Our goal is to wrestle with the complex and too-little-asked question of what we mean be technological progress.  Our guiding principle will be that any humane policy on technology must be grounded in a well-thought out position on what constitutes progress for humanity.  What is it to live a good life?

name: REL-239
title: ST:Come Let Us Build a City (Gen.y11:4): Illustrating Architectural ImagesyIn the Bible
desc: The Bible takes for granted that its readers will understand and recognize its references and allusions to architecture. Given our distance from the events described in the Bible; we often are mystified by descriptions of buildings that do not seem to make sense. Through hand on work, we will clear up these hazy pictures.

name: REL-239
title: ST: Church and State in the West
desc: A survey of the ideas and policies embraced by religious and political leaders concerning the proper relationship between the church and the state from the early church to the present, with particular attention given to issues of religious establishment, disestablishment, toleration, and libety in modern Europe and the United States.

name: REL-257
title: Contemporary Islamic Movements
desc: This course explores the development and influence of a variety of Islamic movements that are growing in the contemporary world. After an overview of the basic structure of Islamic thought and of the Islamic Revivialist and Modernist movements of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, attention will be given to contemporary expressions of these larger trends such as Islamic Democracy, Islamic Economics, Islamic Feminism, and Progressive Islam. Special attention will be given to the role of Islamic thought in the post-9/11 world.

name: PSYC-381
title: Internship
desc: Supervised learning experience in a psychological work setting. Interested students should discuss internship well in advance of placement with the psychology internship advisor. Prerequisites: PSYC 130, overall GPA of 2.5 or higher, and consent of the instructor. Students may not receive credit for more than four hours while at Luther. Course graded A-F.

name: GER-345
title: Advanced German Grammar
desc: This course allows students to master advanced grammar structures as they encounter them in Germany during the Munster Semester. Focus on advanced grammar functions and correcting common mistakes in oral and written expression.

name: ART-239
title: ST: Living Objects: The Art andySpectacle of Puppetry
desc: This course will explore how to design objects that can be given life for use in theatre, street performance, parades and theatrical spectacles. Course work will center on the ideation and creation of objects and how to animate them. Students will explore how design elements of environment and scale are used to initiate dynamic action.

name: MGT-239
title: Special Topic:global Business on theyPacific Rim: Hong Kong and Taishan,yChina; Nagasaki, Japan; and Perth,yAustralia
desc: This course will expose students to four distinct cultural, political, and economic contexts of international business: three Asian and one Western.  Japan and China are two Asian countries with significant impact on the global economy. Their cultures offer significant differences critical for the businessperson to understand, yet about which most Westerners know very little. Hong Kong, with its western influence, is quite different from the rest of China.  Taishan will provide a more rural setting in the mainland of China to contrast with the urban tempo of Hong Kong.  Perth, Australia will present a different perspective, a western window on Asia.  In addition to daily lectures, students will get real-world exposure to the challenges of global business by visiting small and large, private and publicly held companies as well as government, nongovernmental (NGOs) and educational institutions that impact business

name: MGT-339
title: Special Topic:Global Business on theyPacific Rim: Hong Kong and Taishan,yChina; Nagasaki, Japan; and Perth,yAustralia
desc: This course will expose students to four distinct cultural, political, and economic contexts of international business: three Asian and one Western.  Japan and China are two Asian countries with significant impact on the global economy. Their cultures offer significant differences critical for the businessperson to understand, yet about which most Westerners know very little. Hong Kong, with its western influence, is quite different from the rest of China.  Taishan will provide a more rural setting in the mainland of China to contrast with the urban tempo of Hong Kong.  Perth, Australia will present a different perspective, a western window on Asia.  In addition to daily lectures, students will get real-world exposure to the challenges of global business by visiting small and large, private and publicly held companies as well as government, nongovernmental (NGOs) and educational institutions that impact business

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures: Literary Detectives
desc: From the coolly scientific Sherlock Holmes to the hard-drinking Philip Marlowe, detectives and their stories have fascinated readers since the 1800s. In this course we will explore classics in detective fiction as well as contemporary texts, including works by Edgar Allen Poe, Agatha Christie, Raymond Chandler, and P.D. James.  We will explore how detectives have been portrayed on the radio and in television and film.  As part of the course students will produce short radio mysteries.

name: ENG-261
title: Shakespeare Performed
desc: The study of approximately five representative Shakespeare plays, with special emphasis on the close analysis and public performance of one play.  All students will do analytical writing and will be involved in some aspect of the performance.  ENG 260 and 261 have common goals and both fufill the departmental "Shakespeare" requirement, but because of the two courses' differing emphases, students may earn credit for both courses.  Although students with previous experience in Shakespeare or acting are welcomed, the course is open to all students sophomore and above.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar:John Donne:RelationshipyTroubes
pre_req: Take 2 courses; From courses Eng-352 Eng-353 Eng-354 Eng-361 Eng-362 Eng-363 Eng-364 Eng-365 Eng-366 Eng-367 Eng-367 Eng-251
desc: One of the greatest poets in English literature, in his early years Donne wrote love poetry.  He created a dizzying variety of speakers expressing diverse visions of love, from cynical to idealistic.  His lyrics ask how we know that love will last, that we're really in love, that it's not just physical.  Later, having committed to a career in the church, he transferred these questions to his relationship with God: how do we know that God's love applies to us, that we're reading the signs of God's attitude correctly, that our sins do not ultimately define us?  This course will explore these questions and the literary means (voice, irony, metaphysical figures, etc.) by which Donne represented the search for satisfactory answers.  We will read the "Songs and Sonets" and the "Devotions upon Emergent Occasions."

name: AFRS-239
title: Special Topic: Lynching in the US Past
desc: Historians conservatively estimate that five thousand men, women and children perished at the hands of lynch mobs during the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries.  "Lynching in the US Past" will explore the historical development of lynching, survey lynching and its impact on American society, investigate the ways in which race, class, gender, and sexuality shaped particular lynching episodes and justifications for the practice, and examine lynching's historical legacy.  These topics will be interrogated through secondary literature on lynching, photographs, music, film, and newspaper accounts.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic:Lynching in the US Past
desc: Historians conservatively estimate that five thousand men, women and children perished at the hands of lynch mobs during the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries.  "Lynching in the US Past" will explore the historical development of lynching, survey lynching and its impact on American society, investigate the ways in which race, class, gender, and sexuality shaped particular lynching episodes and justifications for the practice, and examine lynching's historical legacy.  These topics will be interrogated through secondary literature on lynching, photographs, music, film, and newspaper accounts.

name: MUS-132
title: Theory II - Honors
desc: A continuation of Theory I. Includes modulation, small forms, and variation technique. Keyboard exercises and computer-assisted instructional materials are integrated into the course.

name: MUS-132L
title: Ear Training II - Honors
desc: Continuation of MUS 131L. Honors section for first-year students.

name: PHIL-139
title: ST:Ethical Issues in Business
desc: An examination of theoretical issues and questions in ethics, applied to the complex circumstances of actual companies, markets, and places of work. The course begins with an introduction to ethical theroy, and then looks at various normative issues in business, such as employee rights, product liability and safety, marketing ethics, affirmative action and diversity in the workplace, business and the natural environment, obligations of multinational corporations, and the corporation as a social institution.

name: HIST-362
title: Topics in South Asian History: ModernyAfghanistan and Pakistan
desc: Students in this course will examine the shared legacy of culture, history, and geography between Pakistan and Afghanistan, their role in shaping the contours of global politics in that region over the past three hundred years.  The course will focus on the political and economic development of the region, but students will also consider social, ethnic, religious, and sectarian movements and discourses of the past ten years, including the Taliban, the invasion of Afghanistan, Musharraf's coup, Benazir Bhutto's assassination, and the lawyers' movement. (HBSSM, Hist)

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History:Hitler andyNazi Germany
desc: "Hitler and Nazi Germany" will examine political, economic, and social developments in Germany between 1918 and 1945.  Through lectures, readings, discussions, and individual research papers, we will examine such topics as:nineteenth century "Volkisch ideology" and the roots of National Socialism; World War I and the development of Hitler's political philosophy; the Weimar Republic; the growth of the Nazi Party and Hitler's rise to power; German society in the "Third Reich;" Hitler's foreign policy; and Nazi racial policies and the Holocaust.  In addition to reading and participating in class discussions, students will be required to write a 10-12 page research paper.

name: HIST-321
title: Topics in US History:The American West
desc: The course will focus on the Euro-American conquest of the American west, an ever-shifting boundary that eventually moved from the Atlantic seaboard to the Pacific Ocean and beyond to Alaska and Hawaii.  This focus will include analysis of shifting patterns of treatment of original peoples, concepts of Manifest Destiny, the thesis that conquest of the frontier was the essential component of forming an American nation, and contrasting the cowboys and Indian myths which evolved in the late 19th/early 20th centuries with factual patterns of settlement of the west.  These analyses will draw on multiple disciplines including cultural history, border studies, economics, and geography.  ((HBSSM, Hist)

name: WGST-212
title: Sex in Religious Texts
desc: This course will explore constructions of gender and sexuality in the texts of two or more religious traditions.  Students will be introduced to contemporary theories of gender and sexuality that they will use to analyze primary texts in relation to their sociopolitical and religious contexts.  Specific topics may include competing representations of men and women, different constructions of marriage, the use of marriage as a metaphor, the role of sexuality in mystical traditions and spiritual manuals, and representations of homoeroticism and bisexuality in religious texts. (Same as REL 212)

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History:DivineyEcstasy:Religious Mystics and theyMedieval Romance With God
desc: This course explores the medieval European phenomenon of religious mysticism.  While most religions possess some form of mystical expression, medieval Christianity developed a very specific form of mystical worship.  Its adherents were overwhelmingly female, a situation surprising in a culture in which female religious leaders were few.  As spokeswomen of God, these mystics were authorized by the Church yet also outside the Church's control.  Women mystics often lived in religious seclusion, yet developed groups of devoted followers who they taught and for whom they wrote.  We will spend the semester examining the unique historical circumstance in which these religious women lived, and read a selection of their writings, many of which constitute romantic, even sexual descriptions of "union with the Divine."

name: REL-212
title: Sex in Religious Texts
desc: This course will explore constructions of gender and sexuality in the texts of two or more religious traditions.  Students will be introduced to contemporary theories of gender and sexuality that they will use to analyze primary texts in relation to their sociopolitical and religious contexts.  Specific topics may include competing representations of men and women, different constructions of marriage, the use of marriage as a metaphor, the role of sexuality in mystical traditions and spiritual manuals, and representations of homoeroticism and bisexuality in religious texts. (Same as WGST 212)

name: HIST-485
title: Junior/Senior Seminar:Slavery in Africa
pre_req: Take 16 credits in History or permission of instructor.
desc: This class will address questions pertaining to slavery in Africa.  Through readings, discussions and individual research papers, students will explore such issues as: why Europeans of the early modern period sought slave labor rather than wage labor; the extent and character of slavery in Africa before the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade and the participation of African peoples in the Slave Trade, the short and long-term effects of the trade on African social, economic and political development.  In addition to readings and class discussions, students are required to produce a 3-5 page bibliographic essay and an 18-20 page research paper.

name: REL-239
title: ST: Buddhism, Animals, andyAnimal Welfare
desc: In this course students will become familiar with traditional Buddhist treatments of non-human animals through an examination of Buddhist sutras, moral tales and ritual practices in the cultural contexts of India, China, and Japan. They will also study fundamental Buddhist doctrines such as "great compassion," emptiness, the bodhisattva ideal, and rebirth that have been used in various Buddhist cultural contexts to both justify and reject violence and killing. Finally, students will investigate efforts among contemporary Buddhist thinkers to develop a Buddhist "theology" of animal welfare.

name: REL-339
title: ST: Religious Fundamentalisms andyModernity
desc: One of the most intriguing phenomena in moderrn religion is the emergence and resurgence of conservative movements that have become known as "fundamentalisms." And, in the wake of 9/11, questions about the relation of religion and politics, and religion and terrorism, have taken on new dimensions and new urgency. In this course we explore the factors and forces that give rise to fundamentalist impulses and explore the challenges they pose for religious traditions, and society, today.

name: REL-485
title: Sem: Secularization in the West
desc: An examination of the interdisciplinary debate and the various theories concerning the causes of religious decline in the West. We will explore the origins of secularization theories in nineteenth-century social thinkers such as Marx and Durkheim. We will discuss those elements of modernity and modernization that are often viewed as culprits in secularization, including science, technology, industrialization, urbanization, economic prosperity, and religious pluralism. We will survey theories that suggest that the West is not as secular as is often assumed. And we will grapple with the larger questions of what kind of distinction can be made within West between a "secular Europe" and a "religious America,"  and how the West differs from the Global South in terms of the influence of religion.

name: CHIN-102
title: Beginning Chinese
desc: This course offers an introduction to speaking, reading, listening to, and writing Chinese. Through the study of the language, the student will also gain an appreciation of Chinese culture and contemporary life.

name: FCUL-239
title: Special Topic:Survey of Chinese Culture
desc: This course will provide a basic understanding of Chinese culture, including philosophy, literature, art, popular culture, and contemporary life in China.  Through reading selected works of Chinese literature and looking at various visual materials, we will examine some of the major features of Chinese society: religious and philosophical beliefs; the imperial system and dynastic change, gender relations, notions of class and ethnicity, family, romance and sexuality.  All works are read in English translation; no Chinese or Mandarin language background is necessary.

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar:Luther's Environmental History
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.

name: AFRS-239
title: Special Topic:New Hope Summer Camp -ySouth Africa: Service Learning andyVocation
desc: In this course Luther students will experience the joys, challenges, and realities of service in the world through the opportunity to lead a two-week summer camp for disadvantaged youth ages 8-16 in Cape Town, South Africa.  Organized by New Hope Ministries (Cape Town), the camp will offer music, sports, art, drama, personal health, and other activities according to Luther student interests, as well as life skills and vocational decision-making.  In the final week we will travel to rural Kwazulu-Natal for sightseeing and an additional service learning opportunity. Throughout the month we will visit historical sites and speak with various South Africans about the challenges of transforming a post-apartheid, democratic society.  At heart this course will invite each of us to ask: how do I live out my vocation of service in a wondrous but complicated world?

name: COMS-464
title: Advanced Research Methods
desc: Students build on research methods learned  in COMS 357.  Research focus is dependent upon instructor and ranges from rhetorical to qualitative, quantitative, and media research. Students will produce a research project suitable for professional presentation.

name: NURS-185
title: Rx for Survival
desc: Using the ten great public health achievements in the twentieth century as a basis for discussion, this course will explore health issues that impact the survivability of people around the globe.  The course will explore challenges facing individuals and communities including new and emerging infectious diseases, "superbugs" that are reemerging in our society, the impact of modern medical advances, and public health approaches needed to avert a global health crisis.  Students will explore how these issues impact their own health, and identify personal choices and lifestyle factors to improve their chances for a healthy and sustainable life.

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topic: Language and Culture inyThe Dominican Republic
desc: This course will introduce Luther students to the most meaningful aspects of Dominican culture while combining intense study of the Spanish Language with artistic expressions, guided visits to cultural centers, NGOs, FLACSO-RD and live with Spanish speaking host families in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic.  Prereq: Span 302.

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topic:Mexican Culture
desc: This course will examine Mexican culture as a fusion of the indigenous and Spanish cultures that have come together since colonial times.  Language immersion, living with local families, lectures, and visits to archeological sites and museums will highlight aspects that show the forces that formed and continue to form modern Mexican life and culture.  The course duration is twenty four days. In Taxco students will participate in daily classes at Centro de Ensenanza para Extranjeros of the Universidad Nacioanl Autonoma de Mexico. Students will also visit Mexico City, Acapulco, and the archeological sites of Teotihuacan, Xochicalco, and Malinalco.  Prereq:Span 302.

name: ACCTG-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. ACCTG 295 is only offered during the fall or spring semesters.

name: MGT-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opporunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during January term.

name: ENG-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during January term.

name: MATH-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. MATH 285 only offered during January term.

name: WGST-381
title: Internship
desc: Required for the WGST major. Each WGST major will complete a 2-credit-hour internship. Students must have had at least two WGST courses before completing an internship. Internship opportunities will be approved for credit by the WGST Board. Internships will be administered through the Career Center, with each intern having a faculty advisor chosen from the WGST Board or WGST faculty. Summer/Fall internship deadline is April 1. January/Spring internship deadline is November 1. Interships will be graded A-F. Contact WGST program chair for information.

name: SOC-185
title: Social Problems and Social Planning
desc: This course provides a sociological analysis of the research concerning such major social problems as alcoholism, mental illness, delinquency, and crime.  In addition, the work of private and public agencies concerned with the reduction of such problems is also considered.

name: SCI-185
title: Energy Problems and Issues
desc: Energy is developed as a physical concept with an emphasis on its use in understanding natural phenomena.  Students explore how energy has been used by human societies.  Environmental, economic, social and practical utility issues surrounding various energy sources will be examined.  Solar, nuclear, wind, tidal, geothermal, ethanol, fossil fuels, hydroelectric and other sources may be examined as student interest dictates.

name: NURS-185
title: Health for Women (and the People WhoyCare About Them)
desc: This course takes a look at women's health concerns that are of interest to college students, both female and male.  We will discuss physical, psychological, historical, and political impacts on the health and well-being of women today. While the course will emphasize health issues that are timely to undergraduate students we will also look at women's health through the lifetime continuum.  Stress reduction, nutrition, contraception, violence against women, and sexually transmitted infections are among the topics we will explore.  Enrollment in this course is open to both women and men.

name: BIO-239
title: Invertebrate Zoology
desc: A study of the morphology, physiology, taxonomy, and ecology of the major phyla of invertebrate animals from marine, freshwater, and terrestrial environments. Offered fall of even-numbered years. Prerequisites: 151, 152.

name: ANTH-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiental learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. ANTH 285 offered only during January term.

name: PE-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity of pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during the fall, spring, or summer terms.

name: MUS-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during January term.

name: CLAS-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Involvement in research project under supervision of department faculty. Recommended for students who expect to attend graduate school. Prerequisites and requirements vary by department.

name: ART-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. ART 285 can be taken only during January term.

name: GS-139
title: Special Topic:American Diversityy(washington Consortium)
desc: Only available to students participating in Washington Consortium

name: SPAN-339
title: ST: Spanish Rhetorical Skills
desc: Course developed for a student with a special academic need through SASC.

name: ART-381
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on-the-job learning experience with a professional artist or organization.  A plan must be submitted for departmental approval before the internship begins.  Normally available for seniors only. Does not count toward hours in the major. Course graded A-F.

name: ANTH-239
title: Special Topics:Reading Cities
desc: This course engages the idea of urban space as a conjunction of planning policies, architecture, and lived cultural experience.  Emphasis is on the intersection between urban design features and everyday life.  Through the use of several case studies of major world cities, we will investigate how cultural life and political interests intersect in the urban environment.  Topics may include suburbanization and peri-urban development, cultural use space, architecture and lived experience, gated-communities, and city planning and political movements.

name: ANTH-339
title: Special Topic:ReconstructingyPrehistoric Technology
desc: The anthropological study of material culture and technical processes provides a wealth of information about their cultural contexts.  This course will focus on employing ethnographic analogy and experimental archaeology as means for reconstructing a specific example of past technology.  We will search for and analyze relevant ethnographic data, design and implement replicative experiments based on this data, and evaluate the effectiveness of the results for interpreting the archaeological record.  In the process of recreating past technology we will explore how material culture and technology can be employed to investigate aspects of human cognition, social boundaries, gender, and symbolism.  Prerequisite: Anth-104.

name: ART-239
title: Special Topic:Life Drawing
desc: This course teaches drawing from life with a variety of conceptual and technical points of view.  Learning to see and to respond graphically to one's gathered visual information and human anatomy are stressed.  Observed interior environments including the human figure (clothed and unclothed) are emphasized.  Efforts are made to improve student understanding of form and through rigorous studio practice.  A final portfolio of a selection of the semester's best work is made by students and submitted, in lieu of a final exam, as partial fulfillment of work for the final grade.  There are weekly assignments given throughout the course.  These are done both in a sketchbook and as larger, separate, finished drawings.  Assignments parallel in-class concerns, and are reviewed and returned to students with oral or written comments by the instructor. Prerequisite: Art-120.

name: POLS-339
title: Special Topics: Politics of India,yChina and Russia
desc: This course will be divided into three major blocks focusing on India, China, and Russia.  Each block will begin with an introduction to the political ideology and political history of each nation.  The course will then look at pre-twentieth century government, democracy, revolution, development, and political change. The course will also spend considerable time examining the current political, economic, and environmental challenges which confront these globalizing nations.

name: POLS-485
title: Seminar:Decision-Making in PoliticalyCrisis
desc: This course will explore how political leaders make decisions in high-threat, high-stakes situations.  The course will begin by exploring several cases of decision-making with positive and negative outcomes.  Case studies will include the Cuban Missile Crisis of 1962, the invasion of Iraq in 2003 and another international crisis. Students will then explore a case of their own choosing, write a research paper and present the findings to the class.  Topics are not limited to international crisis.  Open only to 3rd and 4th year Political Science majors.

name: MATH-110
title: Mathematics in Our World
desc: Quantitative literacy plays an important role in an increasing number of professional fields, as well as in the daily decision-making of informed citizens in our changing society.  This course is designed to improve students' quantitative reasoning and problem-solving skills by acquainting them with various real-world applications of mathematical reasoning, such as fair division, voting and apportionment, graph theory, probability, statistics, the mathematics of finance, check digits and coding, and geometry. This course is recommended for students who wish to take a non-calculus-based mathematics class as they prepare for their lives as informed members of a larger world. Prerequisite: high school algebra.

name: REL-339
title: Hellenistic Religions
desc: This course surveys aspects of ancient Mediterranean religion during the Hellenistic-Roman period (300 BCE- 300 CE). Topics include mystery religions, ancient miracle workers (e.g., Apollonius of Tyana), the Roman imperial cult, domestic religion, the practice of magic, and "gnostic" religions.

name: CLAS-339
title: Hellenistic Religions
desc: This course surveys aspects of ancient Mediterranean religion during the Hellenistic-Roman period (300 BCE- 300 CE). Topics include mystery religions, ancient miracle workers (e.g., Apollonius of Tyana), the Roman imperial cult, domestic religion, the practice of magic, and "gnostic" religions.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topics:Christianity and itsyModern Critics
desc: A survey of some of the more prominent Western critics of "orthodox" Christianity from the Renaissance to the present, with a particular focus on the last two centuries. The thinkers that will be examined include philosophers, politicians, scientists, novelists, and even some theologians. Critiques articulated by Voltaire, David Hume, Karl Marx, Sigumd Freud, Fredrich Nietzsche, Mary Daly, Carol Christ, James Cone, and Richard Dawkins, among others, will be analyzed and discussed along with the ways in which theologians and church leaders have responded to these critiques. Criticisms of Christian beliefs such as the nature and existence of God, the afterlife and immortality of the soul, and the possibility of miracles will be addressed, as will accusations of Christianity's detrimental influence on political institutions and a variety of social movements.

name: REL-485
title: Sem: The Power of Naming: "Religion"yAs a Political Discourse
