desc: The generic concept religion is traditionally understood to refer to a universal aspect of human experience possessing its own essence that is clearly distinguishable from non-religious things like political and economic systems or science. But more recently scholars have challenged this view, seeing "religion" not as a thing but as a discourse with profound political and ethical implications. In this seminar we will examine the traditional view as developed by thinkers like Emile Durkheim, Mircea Eliade, and Clifford Geertz along with the contemporary critique represented by scholars like Talal Asad, David Chidester, Timothy Fitzgerald, and Tomoko Masuzawa. What are the implications of viewing "religion" as discourse for issues like church-state separation, global justice issues, and interreligious understanding?

name: REL-439
title: ST: Lost Scriptures
desc: Thos course will examine writings which were considered sacred by some Jewish and Christian groups but which were not included in the orthodox canons of the Hebrew Bible or the New Testament. Students will analyze selected texts from the so-called Old Testament Pseudepigrapha, New Testament Apocrypha, and Nag Hammadi Gnostic Library in their social, historical, political, economic, ideological, religious contexts. Students will also use these texts to identify to analyze alternative forms of Judaism and Christianity.

name: CHIN-201
title: Intermediate Chinese
desc: A continuation of the study of Mandarin Chinese: grammar, writing, speaking, reading and listening comprehension.  Speaking proficiency will be developed through active class participation.  The use of authentic materials (video, music, texts) will enhance language skills and cultural knowledge.

name: HIST-485
title: Junior/Senior Seminar - The Black Death
desc: In this course we will examine the plague epidemic that swept across Europe beginning in 1348, killing an estimated one third of the population in a two-year period, then recurring repeatedly until its last European outbreak in 1720. We will begin by considering the nature of the disease itself, whether it was actually bubonic plague, theories of transmission, and reasons for the frequency with which it returned. Students will then write seminar papers on the plague's immediate and long-term impact on Europe, papers which may focus on issues that include, but not limited to: popular responses, medical responses, civic responses, changes in urban and rural demographics, impact on the economy, on intellectual and artistic endeavors, and on popular and elite religion. As students report on their on their individual progress in these areas, the course will also serve as an introduction to various types of social and cultural history of medieval and early modern Europe.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar - Traveling Literature
desc: We will study some travel writing classics (Swift's Gulliver's Travels and possibly Twain's Innocents Abroad) as well as works by some more recent authors (possibilities include Paul Theroux, Bill Bryson, Joan Didion, Peter Mathiessen, or Patricia Hampl). We will also explore the genre's boundaries by looking at guide books, brochures, and travel essays. In addition to writing a full-scale research paper, students will be asked to write a fictional or factual piece based on their own real or imagined travels.

name: FREN-460
title: Topics in French Literature and Culture:yFrom Enlightenment to the Magic Kingdom
desc: From Enlightenment to the Magic Kingdom: French Literary Fairy Tales, telling and retelling. The course will concentrate on the evolution of the fairy tale literary genre with the analysis of 17th and 18th century French contes (Beauty and the Beast, Cinderella, Little Red Riding Hood, Sleeping Beauty...) with an emphasis on the persistence of their relevance at times of unease and cultural transition.  We will identify the "Merveilleux" in other genres: French Baroque Opera, early 20th century French movies, Broadway Musicals, and of course Disney. We will pay particular attention to the representation of the feminine with a textual comparison of male (Perrault) and female (Mme Leprince de Beauamont) writers of fairytales.

name: PHIL-485
title: Seminar: The PhilosophicalyInterpretation of Modernity
desc: Philosophical Interpretations of Modernity: Circumstances of human life since the Reformation and Scientific Revolution -- capitalism, colonialism, totalitarianism, technology, globalization -- have caused many philosophers to develop new theories and categories to make sense of the unique experience of modernity. This course will consist of an in-depth reading of some of the most influential interpreters of the modern condition, including Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Freud, Weber, Heidegger, Adorno, and Arendt.

name: SPAN-239
title: ST: Spanish Rhetroical Skills
desc: Course developed for student with special  circumstances.

name: HIST-290
title: Gender and Women's History:U.S. Women'syHistory
desc: This course surveys United States Women's history from the colonial era to the present day.  The class will emphasize not only legal status and efforts over time to effect equal rights for women but will also seek to enlarge the familiar narrative of American history to include women as actors.  In this regard, students will both examine the lives of particular women through a research paper shared with the class and will explore how women's lives--and their concerns and strategies the employed to assert agency--were differently impacted by their situation, time, social class, race, and other factors.

name: WGST-290
title: Gender and Women's History:U.S. Women'syHistory
desc: This course surveys United States Women's history from the colonial era to the present day.  The class will emphasize not only legal status and efforts over time to effect equal rights for women but will also seek to enlarge the familiar narrative of American history to include women as actors.  In this regard, students will both examine the lives of particular women through a research paper shared with the class and will explore how women's lives--and their concerns and strategies the employed to assert agency--were differently impacted by their situation, time, social class, race, and other factors.

name: CHIN-202
title: Intermediate Chinese
desc: A continuation of the study of Mandarin Chinese: grammar, writing, speaking, reading and listening comprehension.  Speaking proficiency will be developed through active class participation.  The use of authentic materials (video, music, texts) will enhance language skills and cultural knowledge.

name: CS-385
title: Understanding Entrepreneurship inySilicon Valley
desc: Internet technology has fundamentally changed marketing, communications and the operations of every business in our society.  Silicon Valley is home to the people, places and power sources that drive this machine.  Students in this J-Term trip will gain both theoretical and tactical understanding of business strategies utilized in the Valley and also have the opportunity to speak with industry leaders and the companies they represent.  We will visit companies and key people including entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, engineers and marketing professionals. (Same as MGT 385)

name: MGT-385
title: Understanding Entrepreneurship inySilicon Valley
desc: Internet technology has fundamentally changed marketing, communications and the operations of every business in our society.  Silicon Valley is home to the people, places and power sources that drive this machine.  Students in this J-Term trip will gain both theoretical and tactical understanding of business strategies utilized in the Valley and also have the opportunity to speak with industry leaders and the companies they represent.  We will visit companies and key people including entrpreneurs, venture capitalists, engineers and marketing professionals.(Same as CS 385)

name: GS-200
title: Lives that Matter: Vocation, Self andyService (Arizona)
desc: This course is designed to help students connect their own gifts, talents, and vocation with the needs of the world.  The course begins with on-campus days of introduction to the major concepts of community, service, compassion, social justice, social change, leadership and vocation.  These classes will also enable students to identify their own strengths.  The second part of the course, based at the ELCA "Spirit in the Desert" retreat center in Carefree, Arizona (close to Phoenix), offers an intensive service experience through area churches in order to allow students to address a specific need such as homelessness.  The course concludes with a special 2-day Blessed to be a Blessing retreat at Spirit in the Desert, offering students further readings, discussion, and rich inter-generational reflection in order to incorporate their service experience into an understanding of their own vocation in relation to the needs they have witnessed and addressed. Additional fees will apply ($850 for flight and accommodations in Arizona) Requires sophomore status or above.

name: BIO-140
title: Introduction to Ecology of the Southwest
desc: Field study of the ecology of the arid Southwest, with a focus on adaptations of organisms to arid conditions and understanding the challenges of setting environmental policy.  Course activities include hiking in the deserts, mountains, and riparian areas of Arizona; daily readings and discussions; a paper exploring the ethical dimensions of environmental policy; and a research project which may be qualitative.  Students who earn credit for Bio 140 may not earn credit for Bio 240.  Fulfills Paideia 450 when students with junior or senior standing enroll in Political Science 258 in the following term. Offered alternate years during January term.

name: BIO-240
title: Ecology of the Southwest
desc: Field study of the ecology of the arid Southwest, with a focus on adaptations of organisms to arid conditions and understanding the challenges of setting environmental policy.  Course activities include hiking in the deserts, mountains, and riparian areas of Arizona; daily readings and discussions; a paper exploring the ethical dimensions of environmental policy; and a research project including statistical analysis of data.  Students who earn credit for BIO 240 may not earn credit for BIO 140.  Fufills Paideia 450 when students with junior or senior standing enroll in POLS 258 in the following term. Offered alternate years during January term.

name: ENG-239
title: Special Topic:Dramatic Greece
desc: This course will explore the history of theater's birthplace and its fifth-century role by studying Classical Greek plays, theater sites, and other cultural and natural settings.  We will read such plays as Agamemnon, Oedipus Rex, Antigone, The Trojan Women, and Lysistrata and will perform scenes in the very spots where they were performed--the Theater of Dionysius in Athens and theaters in Delphi and Epidaurus--or where their mythical stories are set--such as Mycenae with its beehive tombs and Tiryns with its Cyclopean rocks. We will not only study the great sites of Greek antiquity-the Acropolis, the Parthenon, Olympia-- and walk in their landscapes, but will also visit cultural sites like Corinth (where St. Paul preached to the Corinthians) and the beautiful Renaissance city of Nauplion.  The course will explore how we make new the cultural traditions we inherit.  (Substitutes for Classics 299.)

name: CHEM-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: An opportunity to pursue a specialized area of the discipline for which course offerings are limited by following a prescribed reading list under the direction of a faculty member. Prerequisites and requirements vary by department.

name: PAID2-450
title: Cyberethics
desc: This course explores the legal and ethical issues connected with computers, the Internet, and the digital reality they create.  It is the nature of technological innovations to be a challenge to every legal and ethical system.  As our lives are changed by these inventions, existing laws will have to be expanded or new laws will have to be created.  Our understanding of "right" and "wrong" must be applied to new circumstances, and even as society adapts these new insights, technology itself changes again.  Topics covered include Internet governing, cyber-rights and cyber-liberties, privacy, intellectual property, professional codes of ethics, freedom of speech, and issues related to ethical use of technology.

name: PAID2-450
title: Bioethics in a Multicultural World
desc: This course will critically examine contemporary bioethical issues from a multicultural perspective. Attention will be given to the biological and ethical concepts related to various issues such as justice in health care, genetic counseling and screening, environmental influence on public health, and other contemporary health care and health research issues.  The course is being developed for seminary students from LSTC and other members of the ACTS, a consortium of Chicago seminaries; Luther students will be enrolled as space permits.  The first week will be an intensive introduction to the principles of ethics and biology that inform bioethical issues, and to the history of health care disparities and eugenics in the U.S.  Both case study and community organizing methods for research and project development will also be introduced. During the second week, student teams will develop a Field Project by conducting visits to five different individuals, congregations, or organizations involved in some aspect of health care, then draft a report to present to the class for discussion during the third week.  A final paper will be submitted by the end of the class. Students will have some additional charge to cover housing (at LSTC) and costs for participation in Chicago exploration activities (i.e. CTA transportation passes, city passes for museums, at least one theater and one sporting event, etc.) Actual costs not yet determined.

name: SPAN-340
title: Language and Culture in the Spanish-ySpeaking World
desc: This January-term study abroad course will introduce students to the culture of a Spanish-speaking country first-hand.  Course locations may include Peru, Dominican Republic, Spain, Ecuador, Mexico, Argentina and other countries where Spanish is an official language. In addition to language and culture instruction at a local institution, students will live with host families and participate in guided visits to sites that illustrate the diverse cultural history of the country.  This course satisfies the immersion requirement for the Spanish minor. All interested students must complete an interview with the instructor prior to enrollment.  May be repeated for credit up to three times in three different locations.

name: SPAN-341
title: Spanish for Medical Professionals
desc: This course is designed for students studying to become medical professionals and who require training in Spanish to serve Spanish-speaking clients in hospital or clinical settings.  In addition to exploring medical terminology related to the human body, illnesses and treatments, we will also study communication between Spanish-speaking clients and English-speaking providers in U.S. clinical settings.  The course takes place abroad in Spain or Latin America and thus fulfills the immersion requirement for the Spanish minor.  In addition to academic work, students will live with host families; visit local clinics, hospitals or medical offices; and participate in guided tours to sites that illustrate the diverse cultural history of the country. All interested students must complete an interview with the instructor prior to enrollment.

name: HIST-299
title: Topic in History:European Historyythrough the Irish Lens: The IrishyRepulic and Northern Ireland
desc: Since the prehistoric migrations of peoples in Western Europe, there has been frequent interaction between Ireland and the rest of Europe.  In many cases, Ireland has been the object of other nations' policies, and subject to the ambitions of outsiders.  At other times, Ireland has been actively involved in the political, economic, and cultural life of Europe and the world.  This course will survey the interaction of Ireland with Europe from prehistoric times to the present.  In addition to examining Ireland's long and difficult relationship with England, it will look at such topics as the role of the Vikings in developing Irish urban culture and trade, Ireland and the Napoleonic Wars, relations with England from the Normans to Independence, the Spanish Armada and the "Flight of the Wild Geese" following the Battle of Kinsale, "the Troubles" and Northern Ireland, and the "Celtic Tiger" and the European Union.  Visits to historical sites and museums will be supplemented by guest lecturers from local academic institutions.  There will also be regular viewings of contemporary Irish films which will explore historical and cultural topics from a national perspective.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topic:Egypt:Where Faiths Meet
desc: This course will explore the role of religion in Egyptian culture and society, addressing both ancient and contemporary realities.  It will allow students to visit historical and cultural sites (such as the pyramids and the Valley of the Kings), analyzing how religious practices shape culture.  It will also offer the unique opportunity of meeting with communities from different religious backgrounds (Islam and Christianity), studying how particular religious groups mark their presence in modern Egypt and how thy might engage in inter-faith relationships. The course will also expose students to a variety of traditions within each religion, for instance, learning more about the Coptic Church (its art and architecture) as an early presence of Christianity in Northern Africa.

name: MUS-145
title: Orchestral RepertoireyFor Harp
desc: This is a one-credit course covering the performance and rehearsal aspects of harp in orchestral playing and other ensembles employing the harp.  Course includes marking and pedaling harp parts, pre-rehearsal preparation including listening to recordings and studying scores, and ensemble practice and performance including conducting skills.  Students may register regardless of orchestral experience.

name: SW-110
title: Mental Health First Aid
desc: This course helps students recognize risk factors and warning signs of mental health problems, acquire skills to assess immediate problems, intervene to connect people with professional care, understand the prevalence of disorders and the need to reduce stigma, and understand common treatments.  Students who complete the course will receive Mental Health First Aid certification. Grading will be Credit/No credit.

name: FCUL-185
title: Latino Immigrant Experience in the U.S.yThrough Texts and Film
desc: The course will focus on the immigrant experience through careful reading of a series of texts that will include novels, short stories, poetry, and films that present different views of Latin American immigrants.  We will study the lives of immigrants in their home countries and why they choose to come to the "North"; we will explore the journey and border-crossing, then life and work in the United States.  Students will study immigrants from a series of countries, including Mexico, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, and Cuba, the interactions among different Latino communities in the U.S., interactions between Latinos and the dominant Anglo culture and with other groups such as Jewish-Americans and African-Americans.  The experience of local immigrants from Postville will be included in the course through written testimonials, documentary films, a drama and other texts produced in Postville's multiethnic community.

name: PHIL-185
title: The New Atheism and the New ReligiousyDefenders
desc: Blind faith cuts both ways:  one can blindly believe that God does not exist.  A philosophical approach utilizes logical arguments and evidence to address such questions.  Recent writers, (Dawkins, Harris, and Hitchens) have argued that there is no God and that religion is anti-scientific and irrational.  However, new philosophical and scientific defenders of theism (Moreland, Willard, Geivett, and Polkinghorn) argue the opposite.  We will examine the best contemporary and traditional arguments for and against the existence of God, at the introductory level.

name: SCST-185
title: Everyday Life in Hitler's Norway
desc: Norwegians remain vividly aware of their country's World War II invasion and occuption by Hitler's forces. A recent film on the homefront resistance has been breaking viewership records ever since its release. Using this and other fictional films and documentaries to quickly create the context, this course will explore the way the humanities (underground poetry, clandestine humor, and illegal newspapers, as well as secret symbols and diaries) helped Norwegians cope with this unprecedented period of their history. Students will gain experience and guidance in verbally expressing their views, first by chosing to join a group dedicated to one of the 5 main feature films and after discussing the film among themselves, learning to lead the class in discussing that film. Each student will also choose a special topic to explore in a small group of others pursuing related issues, and ultimately make a class presentation on his/her concurrent research on an aspect of the general topic chosen. Students will also keep a daily journal detailing their own reactions to each main film as well as the progress of their topical discussion group and of their own research.

name: SW-185
title: Growing Old in America
desc: This course will help students better understand their grandparents'and great-grandparents' generations. Disucssion will include: what older people are like, what they have to teach us, positions they occupy in society, care they need and who provides it, how changes in families afftect how we care for our elders, and what it's really like in a nursing home. Learning will take place through readings, instructor-led and student-led discussions, student presentations, independent projects, guest speakers, and related films.

name: SOC-185
title: Life on the Inside: Sociology ofyPrisons
desc: What are prisons and jails really like? This course examines different types of correctional institutions from several perspectives--the inmates, workers, administrators, family members, lawmakers, and researchers. We will discuss the myths and realities of prison life and current issues facing the correctional system. Students will also have the opportunity to visit the correctional institutions in the area. There will be a $25.00 course fee for each student to cover travel costs.

name: ANTH-239
title: Special Topic:Archaeological Analysis
desc: Archaeological research is dependent on the material remains left behind by ancient people. This course will investigate both the technical aspects and theoretical underpinnings of using artifacts to unlock details about past cultures. We will explore these central issues both through readings and by conducting an analysis of materials from prehistoric sites in northeast Iowa.

name: CLAS-239
title: Special Topic:Enduring Questions: FromyGilgamesh to Frankenstein
desc: This course is an exploration of crucial questions through the careful reading of key works from some of the greatest minds in human history.  This seminar course will ask what is the nature of love and friendship, what is justice, and what do we mean by human dignity?  Students will read The Epic of Gilgamesh, the Antigone of Socrates, several Platonic dialogues, the Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Dante's Inferno, Machiavelli's The Prince, Shakespeare's King Lear, Swift's Gulliver's Travels, Mary Wollstonecraft's A Vindication of the Rights of Women, and Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.  The readings will be supplemented by attendance to local artistic and dramatic events and by the study of material artifacts in museums.

name: COMS-339
title: Special Topic:Journalism and Media inyChina
desc: This course is designed to immerse students in the history and culture of one of the world's emerging superpowers, the People's Republic of China. Specifically, students will engage in a comparative study of the role of journalism in China vis a vis that in the U.S.  Student will visit Bejing, Shanghai, and other cities where they will have opportunity to meet both with Chinese journalists and media professionals as well as with American journalists working in China.

name: ENG-262
title: Tolkien and Lewis in Context
desc: J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, two of the most popular English writers of the 20th century, lived strangely parallel lives, and worked together to create mythologies of places where the sacred is threatened by the spread of evil.  Our travels will follow the lives of these two writers from childhoods in Northern Ireland and Warwickshire, to England's national center of London, to the battlefields of France, and to the universities they loved (Oxford and Cambridge) to see how the ideas of countryside, mechanization, disenchantment and religion, heroism, and humanity that figure in their work have their roots in the life experiences of each author.

name: PAID2-450
title: Body of Knowledge
desc: This course will explore the role of subjectivity as the foundation for ethical decisions.  At its heart, this course asks to what degree can our embodied and sensual experience be a root of critical action in our relationships with ourselves, others and the world at large. Specifically, the course will look at particular sets of ethical questions from the perspective of embodiment. Examples include medical decision making, imprisonment and punishment, cultural standards of beauty, and social suffering. When we shift our understanding of reality from an assumption of shared objective knowledge to one which recognizes individual and subjective sensory experience we may be able to strip bare layers of cultural bias and understand ourselves as individuals who participate in various social structures. Through the use of personal reflection, critical reading, and sensory and movement practices, we will raise awareness of the body as a site of perception and action, and analyze how we might choose to participate in informed and ethical ways.

name: PHIL-239
title: Special Topic:Wittgenstein
desc: Study of the major works of Ludwig Wittgenstein, especially Philosophical Investigations and Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.  Topics (mainly in philosophy of language and mind) include the nature of meaning, rules, mental privacy, and the relationship between logic and ordinary language. The course will focus on questions raised by Wittgenstein's work about what philosophy is and how it works.  Prerequisite:one course in philosophy.

name: WGST-339
title: ST: Love and Gender in China
desc: Love is one of the most important motifs shared by different national literatures. This course focuses on the inescapable conflicts between individual love and other boarder social issues represented in Chinese literature, including family, class, ethnicity, national identity, religions, and political changes. It invites students to examine a literary tradition that is quite different from the West, yet similar, from a gender perspective. Through textual and other sources, students will achieve a comprehensive understanding of how gender identity is constructed and/or challenged in love relationship. Major readings will cover important works of classical Chinese literature, but also include literary representation of the changing role of women and homosexual love in modern China. All readings will be in English. No knowledge of Chinese language or culture is required. Sophomore standing or instructor approval required.

name: GER-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: Students who develop an interest in a specialized area of the discipline for which course offerings are limited may follow a prescribed reading list under the direction of a faculty member with expertise in that area.

name: FCUL-339
title: ST: Love and Gender in China
desc: Love is one of the most important motifs shared by different national literatures. This course focuses on the inescapable conflicts between individual love and other boarder social issues represented in Chinese literature, including family, class, ethnicity, national identity, religions, and political changes. It invites students to examine a literary tradition that is quite different from the West, yet similar, from a gender perspective. Through textual and other sources, students will achieve a comprehensive understanding of how gender identity is constructed and/or challenged in love relationship. Major readings will cover important works of classical Chinese literature, but also include literary representation of the changing role of women and homosexual love in modern China. All readings will be in English. No knowledge of Chinese language or culture is required. Sophomore standing or instructor approval required.

name: GS-239
title: ST:Service Learning: Teaching EnglishyTo African Refugees in Malta, EuropeanyUnion
desc: A J-term service learning study abroad course teaching English to African migrants seeking asylum in Malta, EU. Luther students will learn basic teaching English as a foreign language (TEFL) strategies, then work with refugee students at one of the residential centers for migrants in Malta. Lectures on immigration policies and the socio-economic-political dynamics of the refugee issues in Malta and the EU will be integrated into the course.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topic:Reformation Theology
desc: A survey of the beliefs and doctrines of prominent Protestant and Catholic reformers and theologians in sixteenth-century Europe.  We will focus particularly on the writings of Martin Luther, Ulrich Zwingli, John Calvin, Thomas Cranmer, the Anabaptists, the Council of Trent, and Teresa of Avila.  The primary topics that we will cover include the authority of Scripture, sin, justification, good works, predestination, the Eucharist, church-state relations, and gender and sexuality.  Prerequisite: Rel 101, 111 or 112.

name: MGT-339
title: ST: Social Media Marketing toyGeneration Y
desc: Social Media Marketing to Generation Y. There will be 100 million consumers that were born between 1985 through 2010. Generation Y consumers includes a large second-generation Latino contingent and are very "green" in lifestyle and product selection. This market segment is consuming at a rate far above the Baby Boomer generation. Students will spend a week in Chicago, IL visiting advertising agencies, publication firms, E-commerce service providers, and corporate bloggers. Fees:$850. The course will examine Web 2 technology and communication strategies for Generation Y comsumers. This will include looking at various strategies being planned by manufacturers, retailers, higher education institutions and professional marketing service providers.

name: REL-439
title: Special Topic:Biblical Voices in theyPersian Period
desc: In the past twenty years, the Persian Period has come into focus in biblical scholarship as a crucial period for understanding the edition and writing of much of the Hebrew Bible.  In this course, students will read and assess recent scholarship in Persian Period studies in order to understand the socio-political dynamics of Achaemenid Yehud, and do close readings of biblical texts understood to reflect the interests of the various Yahwistic groups in this context. Class activities will be designed so that students proficient in biblical Hebrew will be able to use their language skills while others will work in translation.

name: SOC-290
title: Visual Sociology
desc: In this course students will explore the theory and method of visual sociology and have the opportunity to pursue their own projects.  As a group and individually, we will explore the social milieu from a visual perspective to answer such questions as:  What does the visual world tell us about our society?  What meaning and importance do we attach to the visual?  What can we learn about human behavior by examining visual culture? Students will collect their own data, analyze it, and report their findings. Camera needed (of any type).

name: PAID2-450
title: Humans Living With Nature: a New ZealandyCase Study
desc: This course will use such outdoor activities as hiking, kayaking, and white water rafting to examine the relation between humans and nature. The investigation will take place at two levels: (a) students will question in general how humans ought to coexist with the natural world and (b) students will explore how humans have interacted with the natural world in the Island nation of New Zealand.  Students will prepare oral presentations on such topics as invasive species, indigenous peoples, alternative energy, ecotourism, and so forth, and will keep a daily journal in which they respond to the physical activities, class discussions, and on-site meetings.

name: MUS-339
title: Special Topic:Music Research andyBibliography
desc: This course will be an opportunity to explore and develop discipline-specific research and writing skills in music through an intensive use of information resources.  It will allow students to reflect on what it means to be a scholar/performer while providing an environment in which to practice and develop independent learning and critical thinking.  With the co-requisite of Mus 375: Directed Readings (2 credits), students will work individually with the instructor to choose appropriate readings that will be used for course assignments.  Outside of class, students should expect to devote significant time to identifying, reading and using music sources for their research.  Students interested in music librarianship should register for LIST 339. Sophomore standing and above; students must complete the required form to register for 2 credits of Music 375.  Prerequisite: Music 122.

name: MUS-239
title: ST: Jazz Theory and Arranging
desc: An intensive study of jazz theory as it applies to the vocabulary of improvisation. This course focuses on written exercises, original writing, and the analysis of written examples ranging in style from swing to bebop to avant garde. The course also includes a study of the fundamentals and practices of arranging and composing for jazz ensembles from quintet to big band.

name: LIST-339
title: Special Topic: Music Research andyBibliography
desc: This course will be an opportunity to explore and develop discipline-specific research and writing skills in music through an intensive use of information resources.  It will allow students to reflect on what it means to be a scholar/performer while providing an environment in which to practice and develop independent learning and critical thinking.  With the co-requisite of Mus 375: Directed Readings (2 credits), students will work individually with the instructor to choose appropriate readings that will be used for course assignments.  Outside of class, students should expect to devote significant time to identifying, reading and using music sources for their research.  Students interested in music librarianship should register for LIST 339. Sophomore standing and above; students must complete the required form to register for 2 credits of Music 375.  Prerequisite: Music 122.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures: Love, War, andyGender: Stories Ancient and Modern
desc: Literary Ventures: Love, War, and Gender: Stories Ancient and Modern -  Men and women in love, war, and peace, wielding their influence in public and private.  Read stories from the Hebrew Bible and Arabian Nights, Greek and African epics, mythology and plays, as well as modern retellings, including Toni Morrison's "Song of Solomon," new versions of "Antigone," and selected short stories.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar:Imaging God: ContemporaryyLiterature and Belief
desc: The course will focus on how British and American writers of the last sixty years have portrayed Christian faith and doubt.  We will look at some short texts from previous centuries, but through focused readings in contemporary novels and poems we will explore the theological and literary questions raised by how these writers portray religious devotion and doubt, and image God--as transcendent Other; as indifferent Fate; as invasive judge or moral yardstick; as pervasive spiritual Presence or Love in the world; even as the human spirit itself.  Some possible writers include novelists Alice Walker, Barbara Kingsolver, Marilynne Robinson, and Mary Gordon; and poets Gerard Manly Hopkins, T.S. Eliot, Jane Kenyon, and Mary Karr.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar: Prophetic Voices andySocial Transformation
desc: While it has often been asserted that prophetic voices serve as catalysts for social transformation, what exactly is the relationship between prophetic voices and societal transformation? The biblical model used for understanding prophetic voices has traditionally identified the prophet as an isolated, marginalized , and possibly delusional figure engaging in direct, confrontational encounters with established powers in an attempt to "speak truth to power." This notion of the prophet as an isolated voice against the establishment, however, has been challenged and criticized by many scholars. This seminar will consider whether prophetic voices are isolated voices or representative voices that stand in solidarity with and give social expression to larger engaged social constituencies. We will begin by attempting to define the "prophetic." We will then consider four aspects of prophetic activity: 1) the context that gives rise to the prophetic, 2)the content of the prophetic, 3) responses to the prophetic, and 4) the social contribution made by the prophetic. The seminar will consider both historical and contemporary prophetic activity.

name: POLS-185
title: Liberation on Stage:Politics throughyTheater
desc: Gay Rights, Female Liberation, Racial Equality, Communism, and Capitalism through the lens of theater will be the focus of this course. We will read plays and engage accompanying texts to explore the political implications of theater. No acting ability or theatrical experience is necessary. Potential plays include Waiting for Lefty, Mulatto, Trifles, and Execution of Justice.

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History: ConqueringyMind, Body and Soul: A History of EarlyyModern Spain
desc: Conquering Mind, Body, and Soul: A History of Early Modern Spain   This course explores the history of the Iberian peninsula through the study of three themes. We will begin with a consideration of the coexistence of Muslims, Jews, and Christians in early modern Iberia, known as convivencia. How did these seperate, religiously exclusive communities manage to live peacefully together for so long, and what forces caused their peaceful coexistence to end? We will then study the history of the Spanish Inquisition, quite a different experience of religious pluralism in the territory. Our final theme will be the early modern voyages of exploration, through which the Spanish crown extended its influence from Europe to the New World. By the end of the course, we will have compiled a brief survey of Iberian history from the Muslin invasions of 711 to the voyages of the sixteenth century.

name: HIST-321
title: Topics in United States History: IndianyCountry: Race, Gender, and PoliticsyOn American Frontiers
desc: Three seperate "Old Worlds" collided in the several centuries following 1492 as the peoples of Africa, the Americas and Europe came together to create a world that was genuinely new. These encounters touched every conceivable belief and type of behavior. This course concentrates on several changes of particular importance -- in economic and material life, in religious practices, in diplomacy and warfare, and finally in the re-invention of identities at both the individual and societal level. Each of these types of encounter is viewed through the three major "lenses" used to organize the course: race, gender and politics. We will concentrate on the consequences that these encounters had for the lives of Indian people, a perspective of considerable scholarly interest and greatly increased sophistication in recent years. Re-discovering Early America as Indian Country enables us to see the experience of Native Peoples as one of the core ingredients of American history; without the presence, the nation and all of us would be unimaginably different. Counts for Native American certification in the State of Wisconsin certification for Education Majors.

name: MATH-140
title: Calculus I with Review, Part A
desc: MATH 140 and 141 cover all the material in MATH 151; Calculus I, while concurrently reviewing precalculus material. Algebraic and graphical representations of functions including: polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic; techniques of solving equations and inequalities; modeling with various functions. An introduction to calculus concepts such as instantaneous rates of change: limits; derivatives; continuity; applications of derivatives. Graphing calculator use may be required. Prerequisite: a suggested placement.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar: Postmodernism andyFariy Tales
desc: "The fairy tale, which to this day is the first tutor of children because it was once the tutor of mankind, secretly lives on in the story." --Walter Benjamin The Danish author Louise Jensen, the Argentinian author Jorge Luis Borges, and the Italian author Italo Calvino are innovative, experimental post-modernists, who all have deep roots in the old tradition of fairy and folk tales. They were especially drawn to the stories of H.C. Andersen and the "1001 Abrabian Nights." In this seminar, we will explore how the fairy tale lves on in the stories of these contemporary writers.

name: FCUL-185
title: From the Enlightenment to theyMagic Kingdom: French Literary FairyyTales, Telling and Retelling
desc: This seminar will concentrate on the evolution of the fairy tale literary genre with attention to 17th and 18th century French contes that have become favorites in the English speaking world (Beauty and the Beast, Cinderella, Little Red Riding Hood, Sleeping Beauty, Puss in Boots...). Drawing on studies by theorists such as Bettelheim, Tatar, and Zipes, we will identify the use of fantastic elements in other genres such as French Baroque Opera, early 20th century movies, Broadway Musicals, and of course Disney. Questions to examine include the persistence and relevance of fairy tales in times of unease and cultural transition, the representation of the feminine and cultural differences between French and American adaptation of these stories. Students wil take responsiblity for course presentation and interaction with peers. (All reading will be in English). HE/PT/

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar: Energy and Community
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: This course explores community level responses to the challenges of climate change and rising energy costs.  Using Decorah and Winneshiek County as a case study, students will study options for communities as they transition toward a post fossil fuel economy.  Emphasis will be on positive visions for community change regarding electricity, heating, transportation, business, and food systems. t

name: ANTH-239
title: Special Topic:Anthropology of Sports
desc: The aim of the course is to offer anthropological perspectives on sports in a variety of cultures and societies, and to draw on sports to gain a foothold in anthropological theory, method, and case studies.  The study of sports offers a perspective for the discipline to better envision and engage the new social and economic networks of interdependence and communication of the contemporary world.  The course will consist of readings, videos, and lectures, as we consider sports of the past and present across the world and ask what they tell us about what it means to be a human.

name: ENVS-185
title: Global Climate Change:Science andySociety
desc: What is the mounting evidence that has scientists concerned about the changing climate, and how can society best confront the challenges posed by a warmer future?  This course will include an introduction to the Earth's climate system, an investigation of the scientific understanding of modern climate change and its future consequences, and an exploration of the scientific, technological, and political issues associated with addressing the climate crisis.

name: SCI-139
title: Special Topic:The Science of LightyAnd Color
desc: This course will emphasize color - the properties of light and materials that give rise to color, how we describe and analyze color, how we see color, and how color is produced in nature.  It will also include basic topics in optics.  The course is designed with non-science majors in mind.

name: SCST-348
title: Vikings in History
desc: This course covers the "Viking Era," approximately 780 - 1070 CE. It will examine Viking society, religion and mythology, social structure, maritime technology and shipbuilding, political developments, literature and arts, and Viking expansion. Students will submit papers written in Norwegian, Danish or Swedish. Students without a background in Scandinavian studies should enroll in HIST 348.

name: GER-490
title: Senior Project
desc: The senior project requirement gives students an opportunity to participate in independent study, to read relevant sources in their chosen area, to develop methods of research and analysis appropriate to their selected topic, and to construct a sustained argument in the language of their major. To enrich their work, students will be encouraged to reflect on and use their study-abroad and firsthand cultural experiences as a means of contextualizing their projects. Assessment includes the paper, the process, and the required formal presentation of the project at end of term. If students have another major in addition to German, they are not required to complete a senior project in both majors.

name: FCUL-185
title: Trials and Tribulations of BeingyGerman: (Almost) 65 years of Germany'syMost Recent History
desc: This course will focus on Germany between 1945 and today.  Beginning with the disastrous defeat in WWII, we will address the occupation of Germany by the victorious Allies, the Cold War period leading to the creation of two German states and the building of the Berlin Wall, and the opening of the Wall and Germany's unification; and we will conclude with discussion of the subsequent two decades of the unified (or not so unified) country.  Through individual research, class discussions, and exposure to East and West literature (in translation) and films, students will explore to what degree Germany was successful in its endeavors and where the German shortcomings lay.

name: PHIL-320
title: Topics in Value Theory: Kant's Ethics
desc: Study of particular theories, movements, issues, major philosophers in value theory.  Examples include major works in virtue ethics, utilitarian theory, deontological ethics.  Prerequisite: two courses in philosophy.  Offered alternate years.

name: CHEM-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Only offered during January term.

name: CS-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: An opportunity to pursue a specialized area of the discipline for which course offerings are limited by following a prescribed reading list under the direction of a faculty member.

name: SPAN-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue inidividualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major.  Can be taken only during January term.

name: MATH-141
title: Calculus I with Review, Part B
desc: Continuation of topics of MATH 140: trigonometric functions, derivatives, chain rule, the mean value theorem, Riemann sum approximation for integrals, definite integrals, antiderivatives, and applications. Graphing calculator use may be required. (Students who earn credit for MATH 141 may not earn credit for MATH 151.)

name: ATHTR-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experienctial learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. ATHTR 285 only offered during January term.

name: HIST-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a facutly member, at the sophomore level or above, either without or outside the major. HIST 285 only offered during January term.

name: HLTH-381
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on-or off-campus work situations in public or private organizations. Graded A-F.

name: PE-381
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on-or off-campus work situations in public or private organizations. Graded A-F.

name: AFRS-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. AFRS 285 only offered during January term.

name: EDUC-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during January term.

name: RUS-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Rus 285 can be taken only during January term.

name: ART-239
title: ST: Arts and the City Seminar
desc: Seminar offered through the Chicago Semester program.

name: GS-239
title: ST: Metropolitan Seminar
desc: Seminar completed through the Chicago Semester program.

name: CLAS-395
title: Independent Study
desc: Used by the student who wishes to design a course of independent study not otherwise available in the curriculum. Requires a detailed proposal written in consultation with the instructor.

name: HONR-420
title: The Senior Symposium
desc: The Senior Symposium is an opportunity for select seniors to discuss intellectual ideas with the President and Dean of the college. Students with a Cum GPA of 3.7 or higher will typically be invited to participate in the spring of the senior year. Applications will be evaluated by the Director of College Honors in consulation with the instructor(s). The students selected will meet once a moth with the Presiden/Dean to discuss an article, or book, or some issue of scholarly interest. (No academic credit awarded.)

name: FCUL-242
title: Chinese Cinema andyChinese Modernity
desc: From the fall of the Clestial Empire to the rise of China's economy today, Chinese cinema has witnessed many social changes in the modern era. This course will focus on the interaction between Chinese cinema and the process of modernization. By examining how Chinese films dialogue with Hollywood, it will explore Chinese people's experiences of semi-colonial modernity, socialist modernity and postsocialist/global modernity. Students will watch select films made in mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.  Along with reading and writing assignments, students will be required to do oral presentations.  All films have English subtitles.  All readings are in English. Students with Chinese language background may elect to enroll in CHIN 242 for additional assignments n Chinese.

name: POLS-339
title: Special Topics:Latin American Politics:yBrazil, Venezuela, and Mexico
desc: This course will be divided into three parts focusing on Brazil, Venezuela, and Mexico. Historical emphasis will be placed on US-Latin American relations before delving into the current political situations of each nation.  The class will focus on analyzing Brazil's multi-party democratic system, Venezuela's socialist revolution, and Mexico's leadership structure. Some classwork will also be devoted to understanding the political situations of neighboring countries and the cultures that influence them.  Country-specific understandings will form the basis for comparative analysis.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics:Jerusalem:The Center ofythe World
desc: We all have sacred space:  a place we hold dear, we keep in our hearts, to which we retreat, and for which we will fight.  This course explores what happens when the same space is sacred to several groups.  Jerusalem is claimed as sacred space by Jews, Christians, Muslims, and many others.  We will examine issues surrounding the ongoing conflicts over Jerusalem - political, religious, social, and economic - focusing on the central role religion has played.  We will search for the beginnings of these conflicts, hoping to make a step toward resolving them.  Prerequisite: Rel 101, Rel 111 or Rel 112.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar: Film Adaptations of Literature
pre_req: Complete 2 courses from Eng 251, Eng 352-354 or Eng 361-368.
desc: The seminar will explore what it means to call a film an adaptationof a novel, story, or play. Questions include whether an adapted film is comparable to translation, its value dependent on its fidelity to the source, or whether a film is more like a performance, a commentary, or a critique. Or do the possibilities of adaptations, remakes, and parodies challenge the very notion of inviolable work of art and conventional concepts of authorship? Such issues will arise as we examine adaptations of established classics such as Macbeth and Huckleberry Finn, and contemporary and popular films/texts such as The Orchid Thief/Adaptation, Where the Wild Things Are, and Brokeback Mountain. Students will frame individual approaches to issues in adaptation and write papers that interpret texts and films of their choice.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar:Christianity and the Fate ofyEarth
desc: A host of environmental problems have emerged over the past fifty years that pose grave challenges to virtually all forms of life on Earth and the ecological systems that support them.  This seminar will examine ways Christian traditions have contributed to these problems but it will also explore ways Christian traditions can be recovered or transformed to respond to them.  The seminar will give particular attention to the eco-feminist claim that the degradation of nature and the oppression of human beings are linked by a logic of domination.  We will read a wide range of books by contemporary biblical scholars, theologians and ethicists, including works by Thomas Berry, Steven Bouma-Prediger, Ellen Davis, Sallie McFague, Larry Rasmussen, and Rosemary Radford Ruether.

name: MATH-151
title: Calculus I
desc: Topics related to instantaneous rates of change: functions, limits, continuity, derivatives, mean value theorem and applications; antiderivatives and definite integrals. Graphing calculator use may be required. (Students who earn credit for MATH 151 may not earn credit for MATH 140 or 141). Prerequisite: three years of high school mathematics including algebra, trigonometry, and geometry, and a suggested placement.

name: REL-364
title: Topics in Asian Religion:BuddhistyEthics
desc: The course introduces a variety of approaches to general ethical questions developed and offered by thinkers and texts from the Buddhist traditions. It explores questions such as "What moral guidelines does the Buddhist tradition provide?" "How do Buddhist texts conceive of good and evil?" "How do Buddhist groups and movements use Buddhist texts and ideas to support their struggle for social justice?"  "How do Buddhist thinkers and leaders respond to contemporary ethical challenges?"  The course combines textual study, theoretical reflection, and an examination of specific cases in order to explore the contributions of classical and contemporary Buddhist thought to the solution of current ethical questions.

name: POLS-485
title: Seminar:America and the World
desc: Is America an exceptional nation?  What kind of America does the world need?  How should America respond to the security, humanitarian, economic and environmental challenges of the twenty-first century?  In this course we will explore the work of scholars and political figures, American and non-American, who suggest different answers to these and other questions about America's role in a global world.  In addition to regular participation and occasional leadership in class discussions, each student will develop a research project on a course-related topic and present his/her findings to the class.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures: Love,ySex, and the Police
desc: "The course of true love never did run smooth," Shakespeare tells us. In stories and films, something always seems to come along to threaten lovers, and apparently desire is more than a little risky. So what is it that wants to police love,and why? Can love triumph over the forces of opposition: should it always? We will think about these questions and more, as we discuss one of Chaucer's tales, a Shakespeare play: novels by Henry James, Maxine Houg Kingston, Mohsin Hamid; and films by Michael Curtiz (Casablanca)and Mike Leigh, among other selected texts.

name: HIST-485
title: Junior-Senior Seminar: Colonialism inyAsia
desc: This semester's seminar will explore the field of colonialism in Asian history. The first part of the course students will read some of the most important scholarship that has defined the terms and questions of the field, e.g. direct or indirect rule, gender, Orientalism, and mission civilatrice. While developing a research project in a case of their choice, students will read examples of the historiographical schools in which colonial Asian history has been written, e.g. dependency theory, the Annales school, and Subaltern Studies. Students will produce a journal-length article and make an oral presentation of their research.

name: WGST-195
title: Biology of RaceyAnd Sex
desc: This course will introduce students to basic concepts of inheritance and expression of genotypes into phenotypes, using the inheritance of sex and race-associated traits as case studies. These complex traits are useful examples of the influence of individual genes, genomes, and the physical environment on phenotypes. Not intended for biology majors. (Same as BIO 195)

name: ART-110
title: Handbuilding with Clay
desc: This course is designed to introduce students to the basic techniques of handbuilding with clay.  There will be a minor introduction to the pottery-wheel as a tool for generating sculptural forms. Aspects of ceramic history and contemporary practices will also be explored.  Assignments will focus on sculptural design and explore a wide range of shaping, surface treatment and firing methods.

name: PAID2-450
title: Biology/Religion Paideia II Cluster
desc: Biology 195 introduces students to fundamental concepts of inheritance and development, with particular attention to the role of environmental influences on phenotypic expression of complex traits. Traits associated with racial and sexual/gender identity are explored in more detail, including historical distortion and current misconceptions about the role of genes in defining one's race and/or gender. The course includes some activities, problem-solving, and discussion of ethical issues. Religion 339 will examine race, gender and sexuality as social constructions. Students will study a range of religious discourses, from the Bible to contemporary religious websites, and will learn how to analyze them in their social, historical, political, economic, ideological, and religious contexts. Students will also consider the ethical implications of different ways of constructing race, gender, and sexuality. For students with Junior or Senior standing, taking these two courses(Bio/Wgst 195 and Rel 339) as a cluster will satisfy the Paideia II requirement.

name: GRK-101
title: Elementary Greek I
desc: The first course of a two-semester sequence emphasizing basic grammar, vocabulary, and syntax of ancient Greek. Translation passages are drawn from different Greek works, including the New Testament.

name: REL-339
title: Race and Sex in Religious Discourse
desc: This course will examine race, gender, and sexuality as social constructions in the discourses of multiple religious traditions. Students will study a range of texts, from the Bible to contemporary religious websites, and will learn to analyze them in their social, historical, political, economic, ideological, and religious contexts. Students will also consider the ethical implications of different ways of constructing race, gender, and sexuality.

name: ART-491
title: Senior Project
desc: A self-directed project that fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.  Students will focus on creating a new body of work for exhibition.  This project also includes:  a research statement, an artist statement, CV, and a Visual Portfolio of works.  Students will orally defend their project exhibition.

name: PHIL-485
title: Seminar:Existentialism
desc: Existentialism is not a unified intellectual movement, or a coherent set of doctrines.  It is rather a constellation of attitudes finding philosophical expression in response to the challenge of living authentically in a world experienced as dehumanizing and absurd.  Major figures to be explored in this seminar include: Kierkegaard, Dostoevsky, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Camus, Sartre, de Beauvior and Tillich.

name: HIST-239
title: ST: The Modern Black Freedom Movement
desc: The debate over the timing, scope and the trajectory of the civil rights movement has long been contested among historians. Scholars are now challenging the traditional non-violent southern movement narrative by pointing to a broad range of regionally diverse black political struggles across the "long" twentieth century. Furthermore, researchers are calling into question the notion that civil rights and black power were two distinct movements. By engaging in these conversations and covering such themes as gender, sexuality, class, region, community formation, and grassroots activism, we will cover the mass protests of the thirties and forties, the direct action campaigns of the fifies and sixties, and black liberation struggles that stretched into the seventies. This course will examine key texts in new civil rights and black power studies, speeches, music, film, television, oral histories, and photography to investigate the movement's objectives and results, raise questions about American democracy and racial politics in the late twentieth century, and explore what is new about the "post-civil rights era".

name: AFRS-239
title: ST: The Modern Black Freedom Movement
desc: The debate over the timing, scope and the trajectory of the civil rights movement has long been contested among historians. Scholars are now challenging the traditional non-violent southern movement narrative by pointing to a broad range of regionally diverse black political struggles across the "long" twentieth century. Furthermore, researchers are calling into question the notion that civil rights and black power were two distinct movements. By engaging in these conversations and covering such themes as gender, sexuality, class, region, community formation, and grassroots activism, we will cover the mass protests of the thirties and forties, the direct action campaigns of the fifies and sixties, and black liberation struggles that stretched into the seventies. This course will examine key texts in new civil rights and black power studies, speeches, music, film, television, oral histories, and photography to investigate the movement's objectives and results, raise questions about American democracy and racial politics in the late twentieth century, and explore what is new about the "post-civil rights era".

name: MATH-152
title: Calculus II
desc: Applications of the definite integral, techniques of integration, differential equations, power series, Taylor series, and an introduction to computer algebra systems.

name: PE-226
title: Ropes/ChallengeyCourse Programming: Theory and Practice
desc: In this course students will study the integration of ropes/challenge course programming in physical education. This course prepares students to use and implement ropes/challenge course curriculum in elementary and secondary physical education. Students who successfully complete the course will test for Level 1 Challenge Course Certification endorsed by the ACCT (Association of Challenge Course Technology). Students will become aware of and understand the use of adventure activities and ropes/challenge course programming for various purposes and various populations. Prerequisite: PE 110 Ropes Course suggested.

name: HONR-210
title: Ancient World:Antiquity and the Past
desc: Just as we explore ancient cultures and literatures to give us insight into our own, we can look into how those ancients thought of their own antiquity.  We use our past in realms of politics, art, power, and social norms.  By examining how we use the past, we may understand our own values.  In this course we will examine key ideas, texts, and artifacts of multiple ancient cultures with a focus on the ancients' views of their past, in order better to understand their values - especially as we invoke those values ourselves.

name: HONR-210
title: Ancient World:Thought of the AncientyWorld
desc: The stories, myths, poems and literature of ancient civilizations are not merely artifacts of cultures long gone -- they are the animated expressions of perennial human questions and the thought that aims to address them.  In this course, we will work to uncover these universal questions and the unique responses of the Mesopotamian, Judeo-Christian, Greek, and Chinese traditions.

name: WGST-239
title: Special Topic:The Modern Black FreedomyMovement
desc: The debate over the timing, scope, and trajectory of the civil rights movement has long been contested among historians.  Scholars are now challenging the traditional non-violent southern movement narrative by pointing to a broad range of regionally diverse black political struggles across the "long" twentieth century.  Furthermore, researchers are calling into question the notion that civil rights and black power were two distinct movements.  By engaging in these conversations and covering such themes as gender, sexuality, class, region, community formation, and grassroots activism, we will cover the mass protests of the thirties and forties, the direct action campaigns of the fifties and sixties, and black liberation struggles that stretched into the seventies.  This course will examine key texts in new civil rights and black power studies, speeches, music, film, television, oral histories, and photography to investigate the movement's objectives and results, raise questions about American democracy and racial politics in the late twentieth century, and explore what is new about the "post-civil rights era".

name: GER-202
title: Conversation and Comprehension
desc: This course is for students who have completed GER 201 and who want to develop their speaking as well as their oral and reading comprehension skills, increasing proficiency in extended narration and dialogue and developing knowledge of German-speaking cultures.

name: GRK-102
title: Elementary Greek II
desc: The second course of a two-semester sequence which continues the study of ancient Greek grammar, vocabulary, and syntax. Passages are drawn from a variety of Greek works, including the New Testament.

name: CS-381
title: Internship
desc: On-the-job learning experience. The plan must be presented for departmental approval before the experience begins. Graded A-F.

name: ART-101
title: Art Matters
desc: As an introduction to the visual arts, this course takes a global and thematic approach to focus on the way that artists across time and across cultures have engaged issues central to the human condition. Offered alternate years.

name: MATH-240
title: Linear Algebra
desc: Theory, computation, abstraction, and application are blended in this course, giving students a sense of what being a mathematics major is all about. Assignments will include computations to practice new techniques and proofs to deepen conceptual understanding. This course starts by solving systems of linear equations, views matrices as linear transformations between Euclidean spaces of various dimensions, makes connections between algebra and geometry, and then extends the theory to more general vector spaces. Topics include matrix algebra, vector spaces and subspaces, linear independence, determinants, bases, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, orthognality, and inner product spaces.

name: ART-205
title: Art and Technology
desc: This studio course examines the intersection of art and technology with particular attention to the ways that software, video, and interaction are used to produce emerging art forms and genres. Instruction will focus on object-oriented programming, application and algorithm design.

name: ART-208
title: Life Drawing
desc: This studio course provides students with a thorough understanding of the structural anatomy of the human figure with emphasis on proportion, weight distribution, form and mass.

name: ART-316
title: Printmaking II
desc: This course focuses on expanding and enriching practices related to the creation of original prints, including the exploration of alternative printmaking processes and the development of multi-colored images.

name: GRK-201
title: Intermediate Greek
desc: A review of ancient Greek grammar, vocabulary, and syntax, followed by readings in both the New Testament and classical authors.

name: GS-139
title: Academic Discourse and English LanguageySkills
desc: This course focuses on improving spoken English in an academic setting. Independently, students will develop critical listening skills with emphasis on how to participate in class discussions and ask and answer questions. In addition, students will improve pronunciation, increase academic vocabulary, learn note taking techniques, and study skills strategies. Students may take this course multiple times as needed, but the course may be taken for credit only once.

name: MGT-339
title: Special Topic:Event Management: Historyyand Management of the Modern OlympicyGames
desc: A seminar course studying event management in the context of the Olympic games.  Participants will study the various entities involved in managing the games, the bid process, operation of the games, and post-games use of venues.  Financing, staffing, information technology, broadcasting, sponsorship/marketing, venue construction, and transportation/logistics are among the topics to be considered.  The history of the Modern Olympic movement will be studied.  Planned site visits include NBC Sports in New York City; International Olympic Committee (IOC) headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland; Torino, Italy, site of the 2006 Winter Games; Munich, Germany, site of the 1972 Summer Games; and London, England, host city of the 2012 Summer Games.

name: EDUC-366
title: Advanced Methods Clinical Placement
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Educ Program and EDUC 352, EDUC 353, PE 343, or HLTH 343
desc: As a part of the secondary education methods course sequence, the student observes and teaches small and large groups of students in a public/private school classroom in the discipline. During the three-week practicum, the student develops and teaches a unit to document planning, teaching, assessment and reflection protocols. Note:  taken during the January Term, this course would meet the January II general graduation requirement, and if placed in a middle school classroom would meet the clinical requirement for the middle school endorsement.

name: EDUC-367
title: Advanced Teaching Methods II
pre_req: Admission to Teacher Educ Program and EDUC 366
desc: Continued study of advanced teaching methods for students seeking licensure in English, K-12 world languages, mathematics, science, social science, and health/physical education with special emphasis on analysis of best practice, methodological research and curriculum design within the respective content area.  This course builds on the content of EDUC 352 and the clinical appointment in EDUC 366 and must be taken prior to EDUC 486.

name: ART-290
title: Art in Cultural Perspectives:yRenaissance Drawing in HistoricalyContext
desc: A studio course focused on drawing from direct observation of Italian masterworks in museums and special collections across central and northern Italy.  Students will study form and application of media as used in the early to late Italian Renaissance.  Critiques and study of drawings created during the course will help students understand how the Italian Masters laid the foundation for our understanding of Western art and how Renaissance methods can be applied to students' creative works.  Prerequisite:Art 108 or permission of instructor.

name: AFRS-185
title: The Age of Jim Crow
desc: This course will explore arguments and controversies over "the strange meaning of being black" from the post-Reconstruction period to the mid-to-late twentieth century.  We will read and analyze a variety of primary documents related to the social, political, and economic aspects of the Jim Crow era, a period of de facto and de jure segregation.  Through critical analysis of speeches, music, films, articles, poetry, short stories, and legal documents, "The Age of Jim Crow" will emphasize how African Americans challenged structures of power and in the process forged a rich culture of resistance. Additionally, we will read articles by leading historians of the field as we learn how African Americans made sense of, created, and negotiated meanings of the racialized staff. (Same as Hist 185)

name: HIST-185
title: The Age of Jim Crow
desc: This course will explore arguments and controversies over "the strange meaning of being black" from the post-Reconstruction period to the mid-to-late twentieth century.  We will read and analyze a variety of primary documents related to the social, political, and economic aspects of the Jim Crow era, a period of de facto and de jure segregation.  Through critical analysis of speeches, music, films, articles, poetry, short stories, and legal documents, "The Age of Jim Crow" will emphasize how African Americans challenged structures of power and in the process forged a rich culture of resistance. Additionally, we will read articles by leading historians of the field as we learn how African Americans made sense of, created, and negotiated meanings of the racialized staff.  (Same as Afrs 185)

name: BIO-185
title: Plants Rule the World
desc: The air we breathe, food we eat, and medicine we take, are examples of how plants sustain life on earth.  This course will explore the biology, origin, and use of plants and their products and how they influence our everyday life and well-being.  We will study broad concepts relating to food, energy, medicinal products, ecosystem services, and wildlife habitat.  Students will investigate the compounds produced by various plant species.  Previous study of plants is not required.  The course will include local day-trips.

name: CHEM-185
title: Satan's Resin
desc: An examination of the impact of plastics upon modern civilization and the environment. Can we live without them?  Are they "green" or "brown"? Should they be embraced or banned?  Topics will include the production and applications of synthetic plastics; their health and environmental impacts; their disposal, recycling, and down-cycling; and alternative sources and materials.  No previous background in mathematics or science required.

name: GRK-202
title: Readings in Greek
desc: Fourth-semester readings from one or more ancient Greek authors or works, such as Homer, Plato, Sophocles, and the New Testament.

name: WGST-185
title: Blaxploitation:It's Birth and Evolution
desc: This course will explore the development of the film genre commonly referred to as blaxploitation. Beginning in the late 60s and lasting through the 70s, this body of movies starred African-American actors who would become icons in black American culture. Our study will focus on the social and political forces that gave birth to this wave of art, noting how the films challenged, resisted, transformed, or confirmed public perception about African-Americans, both within the black and white communities. Thus the films' political content, as it relates to racial discourse, class realities, and gender norms, will serve as the focus of the class conversation. We will view films such as Cotton Comes to Harlem, Superfly, Foxy Brown, and Shaft. (Same as Afrs 185 and Eng 185).

name: WGST-331
title: Gender, Health and Medicine
desc: This class will invite students to examine gender and health issues around the globe.  We will take an interdisciplinary perspective, which will involve readings in women and gender studies, anthropology, sociology, public health, and related disciplines.  The course will focus on 3 major themes: equity and androcentrism in health care and health research, medicalization of bodily experiences, and reproductive health.  We will address these issues both in domestic and global contexts.  Our goal is to understand how bodies and health are connected to the politics of gender, race, and class, as well as to see how people have made sense of their bodies, desires, identities, suffering, and resistance to the various dimensions of oppression.  This course counts as theory requirement for the WGST major. Offered alternate years.

name: ART-239
title: ST: American Art
desc: This course will survey the history of painting, sculpture, photography, and to a lesser extent, architecture in the United States from the colonial period through the twenty-first century. The class will address the meaning of and controversy surrounding the idea of a strictly "American" art. We will discuss the ways in which our relatively new country sought to define itself through visual media.

name: ART-239
title: ST:Magic and Misdirection: AyTheater of Influence
desc: This course examines the history, principles and methods of performance magic. From close-up magic to grand stage illusions, magic has transformed the human relation with the impossible. Merging psychology misdirection, showmanship and scholarship this course addresses the influence of performance magic in entertainment, theater, film, advertising , politics, crime, intelligence trade craft, and warfare.

name: BIO-250
title: Restoration and ConservationyBiology
desc: This course is an introduction to restoration ecology and conservation biology, with a primary focus on ecological principles used in restoring human-altered landscapes and conserving natural habitats. Secondarily, it considers basic policy and non-governmental avenues for the protection of biodiversity. Class is a combination of lecture, discussion, and lab. Discussion includes scientific literature and case-studies. In lab, students put theory into practice to develop restoration and conservation plans for local sites in a semester-long project. Requires sophomore standing or above.

name: ENG-185
title: "Frankenstein" and Its Contexts
