desc: Mary Shelley's novel "Frankenstein" or, "The Modern Prometheus" (1818) has spawned a host of imitators and catch-phrases, from Frankenfoods to It's alive! But few people know that this classic tale of science gone wrong was written by a nineteen-year-old girl in love with a sexy married man, insecure about her place among her brilliant friends, and struggling with the legacies of her dead mother, her distant father, and the loss of her first baby. We'll read and reread Frankenstein and pair it with historical background and selections of work by Mary Shelley's family and friends - Mary Wollstonecraft, William Godwin, P.B. Shelley, and Lord Byron - to explore a single question: How was this young artist haunted, and how did she draw on her obsessions to create this novel that still haunts us?

name: COMS-339
title: ST: Rhetoric of War and Peace
desc: This course explores the rhetoric of war and peace from a 21st century perspective. Students will analyze assumptions and social values expressed by advocates of war and peace through a critical examination of such rhetorical acts as books, speeches, blogs, film, song, and print media. The course investigates the relationships between war and public discourse, such as public debate about the conduct of war, the representation of war in contemporary media, and the role of gender in the theory and practice of war and peace. Students will also explore media images opposing nations employ to characterize the other; strategic choices in public rhetoric that gained acceptance of contemporary wars; and metaphors and ideological frames that characterize war rhetoric.

name: WGST-339
title: ST: Rhetoric of War and Peace
desc: This course explores the rhetoric of war and peace from a 21st century perspective. Students will analyze assumptions and social values expressed by advocates of war and peace through a critical examination of such rhetorical acts as books, speeches, blogs, film, song, and print media. The course investigates the relationships between war and public discourse, such as public debate about the conduct of war, the representation of war in contemporary media, and the role of gender in the theory and practice of war and peace. Students will also explore media images opposing nations employ to characterize the other; strategic choices in public rhetoric that gained acceptance of contemporary wars; and metaphors and ideological frames that characterize war rhetoric.

name: ENG-185
title: Becoming a Writer:Vocation and theyWriting Life
desc: No one is born a writer. We often think that some writers are naturally gifted, but writing is something one does, not something one is. Nonetheless, our literary history is filled with myths about writing and writers - we sometimes think of them as lonely, edgy, maybe even a little crazy, alcoholic, or both. But what does it mean to have a writing life and what does it take to sustain one? This course explores these questions through both writing and reading, with autobiographies and commentaries by writers as diverse as Ralph Waldo Emerson and Stephen King. We'll practice different writing exercises and genres to explore how our identities, values, and sense of self emerge on the page, for readers we know or can only imagine.

name: MATH-220
title: Mathematical Reasoning and Writing
desc: This course introduces students to logic, set theory, and methods of proof.  The emphasis will be on learning to write rigorous mathematical proofs.  Topics will include induction, functions, equivalence relations, cardinality, combinatorics, and recurrence relations.

name: ECON-239
title: ST: The Amazon Rainforest andyClimate Change
desc: The ecological richness of the Amazon rainforest is well known; what is less well recognized is the complex interaction between the rainforest and its numerous human inhabitants. One approach to preservation of the ecosystem's diversity is for those in other countries who value the forest (as a brake on climate change, or for other reasons) to support the economies of the Amazon, so that people living there don't have to look to deforestation as an income-generating strategy. That the question of value links the disciplines of economics and environmental studies is particularly evident in the Amazon. This transfer of resources (from the rest of the world to the communities of the Amazon) is known as REDD: Reduction of Emissions through Deforestation and Degradation. We plan to visit several locations, in Brazil and Guyana, in which the REDD programme is either in place or being established. The REDD idea is not easily implemented, but by visiting these sites we explore the circumstances under which it could provide a model for the region and, indeed, contribute to the mitigation of climate change. We shall also visit Manaus, the capital city of Amazonas state, as well as other areas in the western Amazon which are experiencing the socioeconomic and ecological impact of dams, roads and the expanding soy frontier.

name: ENVS-239
title: ST: The Amazon Rainforest andyClimate Change
desc: The ecological richness of the Amazon rainforest is well known; what is less well recognised is the complex interaction between the rainforest and its numerous human inhabitants. One approach to preservation of the ecosystem's diversity is for those in other countries who value the forest (as a brake on climate change, or for other reasons) to support the economies of the Amazon, so that people living there don't have to look to deforestation as an income-generating strategy. That the question of value links the disciplines of economics and environmental studies is particularly evident in the Amazon. This transfer of resources (from the rest of the world to the communities of the Amazon) is known as REDD: Reduction of Emissions through Deforestation and Degradation. We plan to visit several locations, in Brazil and Guyana, in which the REDD programme is either in place or being established. The REDD idea is not easily implemented, but by visiting these sites we explore the circumstances under which it could provide a model for the region and, indeed, contribute to the mitigation of climate change. We shall also visit Manaus, the capital city of Amazonas state, as well as other areas in the western Amazon which are experiencing the socioeconomic and ecological impact of dams, roads and the expanding soy frontier. This course is to offered in January 2011.

name: ENG-239
title: ST: American Environmental Literature
pre_req: Take Paid-111d Paid-112d or transfer equivalent.
desc: Through a broad examination of the environmental literature of America, starting from Native American oral traditions and ending with twenty-first century urban nature texts, this course will explore the premise that nature is a distinctive theme of American culture. Possible readings include authors such as Henry David Thoreau, Mary Austin, and Bill McKibben. In addition to critical writing focused on course texts, students will develop a piece of their own nature writing placed within the "Decorah Wilderness." Prerequisite - Paideia 111, 112 or transfer equivalent.

name: NURS-185
title: Introduction to Servant Leadership
desc: This course serves as an introduction to the concept of servant leadership, a philosophy and practice of leadership developed by Robert Greenleaf and now in use in business and health care settings. Servant leaders are committed to making sure that other people's most important needs are being served, and they seek to remain humble and committed to stewardship. Participants will build an understanding of the theological and philosophical foundations of servant leadership, and will begin to identify the leadership style and skills they plan to further develop and incorporate into personal and professional relationships.

name: ENVS-239
title: ST: American Environmental Literature
pre_req: Take Paid-111d Paid-112d or transfer equivalent.
desc: Through a broad examination of the environmental literature of America, starting from Native American oral traditions and ending with twenty-first century urban nature texts, this course will explore the premise that nature is a distinctive theme of American culture. Possible readings include authors such as Henry David Thoreau, Mary Austin, and Bill McKibben. In addition to critical writing focused on course texts, students will develop a piece of their own nature writing placed within the "Decorah Wilderness." Prerequisite - Paid 111, 112, or transfer equivalent.

name: PHIL-185
title: Philosophy Through Film
desc: Plato said "those who tell stories rule society." Today the primary storytellers are not philosophers but filmmakers. Yet, embedded in many films are powerful statements concerning the fundamental philosophical questions that every thoughtful person must face: What is the nature of reality? What is the extent of human knowledge? Are there objective moral facts? In this seminar, students will analyze films selected for the class, think critically about the views being presented, and discuss them in a rigorous way. Study of the films themselves will be supplemented by texts introducing philosophical issues in films and philosophical analysis of film as medium.

name: REL-185
title: From Ancient Texts to ModernyTranslations:The Strange Odyssey of theyBible
desc: A fascinating and complex history stands between the ancient manuscripts that form the foundation of the biblical text and the modern translations we read today. In this course we will explore this history, looking to develop an understanding of how social, political, and economic factors have influenced the way communities of faith have shaped the text of the Bible we read today. Special emphasis will be given to ancient texts of the Hebrew Bible, including the Dead Sea Scrolls, the development of the Greek New Testament, and the development in recent American history of various English translations of the Bible.

name: GRK-375
title: Directed Readings
desc: Consent of instructor.

name: ENG-239
title: ST: Shakespeare and Politics
pre_req: Take Paid 111D Paid 112D or transfer equivalent.
desc: This course is a general introduction to Shakespeare's plays of each major type (comedy, tragedy, and history), both as literature for reading and scripts for performance. We will emphasize such political topics as legitimacy, leadership, expediency, the relationship of the personal and the public, and the ethics of decision-making, as they are exhibited in international, national, and family settings. Students will have the opportunity to explore their interpretations in writing and by staging a scene. Substitutes for English 260/261. Prerequisite: Paideia 111, 112, or transfer equivalents.

name: REL-250
title: Living Religions
desc: This course explores the ways religion constitutes a vital force in the 21st century. It explores questions such as: what is religion, how can we study religion, why does religion appeal to people in an age of science, and how does religion facilitate personal and social transformation? The course integrates field trips, critical analysis, literature and films, the study of religious art, and theoretical reflection in order to examine the role religion plays in today's world. Particular emphasis will be given to religious worldviews, practices, art, and ethics. While the course focuses on the phenomenon of religion in general rather than individual religious traditions, the course addresses religious diversity worldwide as well as in the Midwest.

name: REL-314
title: Teaching the Bible
desc: In this course, students will apply interpretive methods to biblical texts in order to develop an understanding of the context and significance of these texts, then develop educational programs for use in a congregational setting that reflect this analysis. The entirety of the course will consist of collaborative work in groups. Class time will consist of four weekdays and Sunday mornings; a significant amount of the course will consist of group work outside of class. In groups of 4-5 people, students will choose a text appropriate for a specific age group, apply interpretive methods to that text, and develop a Sunday School lesson for that age group. Groups will rotate to different Sunday School classes each week. In addition, students will develop an outline for an adult education series, and assess existing curricular materials after the experience of developing their own programming.

name: REL-270
title: Religious Identity and InterfaithyEngagement
desc: This course explores issues of religious identity and interfaith engagement in a pluralistic world. Through a variety of methods, including textual study, theoretical reflection and a case study approach, we will discuss questions such as: what is religious identity, is it possible to identify with more than one religious tradition, can one remain committed to a single religious tradition in a pluralistic world, and how can people of different faiths build relationships with each other and work together for the common good? In addition, this course will examine interreligious encounters in a variety of contexts (in the United States and globally), and analyze responses to religious pluralism from a number of different religious perspectives.

name: POLS-239
title: ST: Shakespeare and Politics
pre_req: Take Paid 111D Paid 112D or transfer equivalent.
desc: This course is a general introduction to Shakespeare's plays of each major type (comedy, tragedy, and history), both as literature for reading and scripts for performance. We will emphasize such political topics as legitimacy, leadership, expediency, the relationship of the personal and the public, and the ethics of decision-making, as they are exhibited in international, national, and family settings. Students will have the opportunity to explore their interpretations in writing and by staging a scene. Substitutes for English 260/261. Prereq: Paideia 111, 112, or transfer equivalents.

name: PAID2-450
title: Got Health?...we Can Tell You How to GetyIt - Marketing Health in Today's World
desc: This course explores ethical issues connected withthe marketing of health and health care services.Health (as defined in a variety of ways) and delivery of services is a lucrative business. Big business has developed retail strategies to communicate to consumers a clear definition of what health is - often achievable with the purchase of certain products or services. Innovative websites, traditional media advertising and social media are all being utilized to sell profitable health care services and health care products to certain demographics in such fields as maternity, cosmetic surgery, ER/trauma and cardiac care. Pharmaceutical companies are marketing medications directly to consumers as well as to physicians raising ethical concerns related to conflicts of interest. The relationships between the disciplines of marketing and the disciplines in health care are problematic. Medicine often needs marketing to provide a "competitive advantage" along with a frequent need to communicate information valuable to the consumer. However, financial inducements can impede the trust and confidence that the consumer has for their medical provider. These potential interdisciplinary conflicts will be explored and analyzed using specific case studies as the mechanism for ethical reflection. Students will be challenged to consider how marketing is used to construct notions of value and import and how these notion might challenge ethical principles.

name: BIO-231
title: Microscopy
desc: An introduction to the theoretical and technical aspects of light and electron microscopy and digital imaging as tools for scientific study. Demonstrations supplement lectures with no formal laboratory. This first-seven-week course offered each fall is designed to provide a broad overview of microscopy theory and technique while giving students an introduction to the available on-campus instrumentation. A full semester companion laboratory, BIO 232, is open to students enrolled in Bio 231.

name: MATH-253
title: Vector Calculus
desc: The tools of calculus are developed for real-valued functions of several variables: partial derivatives, tangent planes to surfaces, directional derivatives, gradient, maxima and minima, double and triple integrals, and change of variables. Vector-valued functions are also studied: tangent and normal vectors to curves in space, arc length, vector fields, divergence and curl. The fundamental theorem of calculus is extended to line and surface integrals, resulting in the theorems of Green, Stokes, and Gauss, which have applications to heat conduction, gravity, electricity and magnetism.

name: PAID2-450
title: Ethics in Theatre
desc: Theatre dramatizes humans negotiating ethical dilemmas, and therefore confronts its public with current moral, social, and political questions. At the same time, theatre almost inevitably reflects on the ethics of theatre-making itself. In this course, students will read plays and secondary sources, view recorded and live performances, have frequent discussions, write regularly, and occasionally do small-scale theatre of their own. There will be a course fee of approximately $200 to cover out-of-town performances.

name: REL-239
title: ST: Stories of Conflict, Horror,yAnd Dissent in the Bible
desc: The biblical corpus is filled with stories that would shock and challenge the modern reader - stories of genocide, child sacrifice, rape, incest, and capricious and malevolent deities. This course will focus on the meaning, significance, and function of these tales for the ancient as well as the modern reader. Why did ancient people tell these stories? How did these stories end up in the Bible? How do we responsibly interpret such narratives? Should the Bible still be considered holy even though it contains such morally problematic accounts? By examining these stories, we will explore how they impact our understanding and vision of the Bible as sacred literature. Prerequisite - Rel 101, 111, or 112.

name: REL-339
title: ST: Kings and Kingship in they Hebrew Bible
desc: Ideas, concepts, and stories about kings and kingship in the Bible have had a lasting influence on Western thought. In this course, we will study the origin, function, and theological and political ideas associated with kingship in the Hebrew Bible. We will look at the relationship between kings and prophets, the theological idea of God as king, and the concept of anointment and messianism. In so doing, we will explore how biblical notions of kingship continue to shape current ideas of religion and politics. Prerequisite - Rel 101, 111, or 112.

name: BIO-232
title: Microscopy Laboratory
desc: Students will develop a short-term project using at least one type of light or electron microscopy studied in Biology 231, including transmission and scanning electron microscopy as well as scanning laser confocal microscopy, fluorescent microscopy and various forms of enhanced contrast techniques. This course will also focus on specimen preparation as well as microscope operation and project design. Projects will likely support current research by biology faculty and will require a poster or oral presentation. Laboratory only with supplemental specimen preparation lectures.

name: SOC-185
title: Gender, Bodies and Desire:Sociology ofySexualities
desc: This course examines the lived experience of human sexualities through a social lens. Using sociological methods, students will engage the question: What is sexual? The course encourages students to critically examine the subject by focusing on such topics as: identity, socialization, norms, politics and media representation. (Same as Wgst 185)

name: WGST-185
title: Gender, Bodies and Desire:Sociology ofySexualities
desc: This course examines the lived experience of human sexualities through a social lens. Using sociological methods, students will engage the question: What is sexual? The course encourages students to critically examine the subject by focusing on such topics as: identity, socialization, norms, politics and media representation.  (Same as Soc 185)

name: WGST-147
title: Literature of African Peoples
desc: Modern African writers are some of the most dynamic and innovative writers as they draw from and respond to different literary traditions, such as their own oral and written traditions, as well as European models. This course serves as an introduction to the various themes and styles of written literature of the 20th century. Central to discussion will be an analysis of gender within various African cultural contexts. Understanding constructions of masculinity and femininity, dominant female and male roles in society, and the ways in which the works challenge traditional norms of gender will be priorities within applied theoretical approaches.  (Same as AFRS 147 and ENG 147)

name: AFRS-239
title: ST: The Black Arts Movement: Theory,yTheatre, & Performance
desc: This course will approach the Black Arts Movement (1965-1976) as a sequence of debates, rather than a consistent or monolithic practice. We will investigate Black Arts Movement theory, theatre and performance utilizing primary documents such as manifestos and play texts in order to understand how individual theorists and playwrights approached and critiqued the "black aesthetic." The dramatic literature which we will read will also serve as a springboard to explore complex issues such as race, representation, gender and sexuality. The course will attempt to answer the following questions: What was the Black Arts Movement? In other words, what were its origins and purpose? What factors caused its demise and what is its legacy? What relationship did the Black Arts Movement have with other nationalist and women's liberation movements of the 1960s-1970s?

name: WGST-239
title: ST: The Black Arts Movement: Theory,yTheatre, & Performance
desc: This course will approach the Black Arts Movement (1965-1976) as a sequence of debates, rather than a consistent or monolithic practice. We will investigate Black Arts Movement theory, theatre and performance utilizing primary documents such as manifestos and play texts in order to understand how individual theorists and playwrights approached and critiqued the "black aesthetic." The dramatic literature which we will read will also serve as a springboard to explore complex issues such as race, representation, gender and sexuality. The course will attempt to answer the following questions: What was the Black Arts Movement? In other words, what were its origins and purpose? What factors caused its demise and what is its legacy? What relationship did the Black Arts Movement have with other nationalist and women's liberation movements of the 1960s-1970s?

name: ENVS-185
title: Plants Rule the World
desc: The air we breathe, food we eat, and medicine we take, are examples of how plants sustain life on earth.  This course will explore the biology, origin, and use of plants and their products and how they influence our everyday life and well-being.  We will study broad concepts relating to food, energy, medicinal products, ecosystem services, and wildlife habitat.  Students will investigate the compounds produced by various plant species.  Previous study of plants is not required.  The course will include local day-trips.

name: MATH-351
title: Ordinary Differential Equations
desc: Differential equations is an area of theoretical and applied mathematics in which there are a large number of important problems associated with the physical, biological, and social sciences. Analytic (separation, integration factors, and Laplace transforms), qualitative (phase and bifurcation diagrams), and numerical (Runge-Kutta) methods are developed for linear and nonlinear first- and higher-order single equations as well as linear and non-linear systems of first-order equations. Emphasis is given to applications and extensive use of a computer algebra system.

name: COMS-185
title: Exploring Your Social Network
desc: Interpersonal communication used to be conducted only in face-to-face encounters. These are still important, but today we use the telephone, text, email, Facebook, and other technologies to keep in touch with our family, friends, and acquaintances. How does technology shape or alter our interpersonal relationships? In what ways does the medium we choose change the messages we exchange with important people in our lives? Has Facebook changed our definition of friendship? How are our online selves different from our real life selves? This course will explore ways researchers have sought answers to these and other related questions, and to design research that will help us discover our own answers.

name: COMS-270
title: Rethinking Freedoms of Religion, Speech,yAnd Press
desc: The First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution guarantees freedom of speech and the press, along with freedoms of religion and assembly. Often news media tests the boundaries of these freedoms with controversial stories and blased reporting that raises questions of journalistic ethics.  This course reviews the history of the First Amendment with a particular focus on media law and Supreme Court decisions, and examines the ethics of news reporting on controversial matters.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar - Walt Whitman
pre_req: Complete 2 courses from Eng 251, Eng 352-354, Eng 361-368.
desc: An in-depth study of Whitman in the context of his time and in light of contemporary scholarship. The course will examine Whitman's poetic innovations and his views on democracy, the self, nature, spirituality, race and slavery, gender and sexuality, the Civil War, and everything else the poet absorbs. Individual research projects and a public class reading of Whitman's poetry.

name: ART-290
title: Art in Cultural Perspective:Potter'syBrigade to Nicaragua
desc: Students in this course will tour various pottery centers and visit potters in their studio.  They will learn about clay mining and preparation, shaping, decoration, firing, and marketing of local ceramic crafts.  A photo journal will be expected as a major portion of the course study. The course will also include the study of history, social, and political aspects of Nicaragua. Students will experience first hand life in a developing country.  In addition, students will have hands on experience with the production of a ceramic water filter developed by Potters for Peace and a workshop involving all aspects of the water filter will be planned.  Discussions will include topics about the need for clean water and the potential for starting new micro businesses which could produce the water filters.

name: POLS-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. POLS 285 only offered during January term.

name: POLS-485
title: Junior/Senior Seminar:American Courts,yInternational Tribunals, TruthyCommissions and Sharia Courts
desc: How do nations find justice?  This course will answer that question by examining various court options.  First, we will look at the development of the American Supreme Court followed by an analysis of international courts such as the International Criminal Court and international war criminal tribunals.  Next, we will investigate the search for justice in the form of international truth commissions in countries including South Africa, Argentina and East Timor.  We will complete the course by comparing courts and the rule of Islamic law in nations such as Afghanistan, Nigeria and Indonesia.

name: HIST-351
title: Top Eur Hist:Eur Inquis
desc: Contrary to popular belief, Spain was not the only early modern country to have an inquisition.  In this course, we will look at the development of inquisitions throughout Europe in the medieval and early modern periods.  We will focus in particular on the inquisitions as they functioned in four countries:France, Spain, the Netherlands, and Italy, and the ways in which the inquisitors teated heretics, Jewish and Muslim "conversos," witches, sorcerers, and homosexuals.  Reading materials will consist of recent scholarly articles discussing these issues, as well as translated primary source documents, including anti-heresy edicts, excerpts from chronicles, legal testimony from those tried by the inquisitions, and eye-witness accounts of executions.  The goal of the course is to examine the inquisitions as they were conceived by those who created them, experienced by those who fell victim to them, and understood by historians ever since.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar:Pre-monarchic mayhem to PersianyPeriod Protest: The Book of Judges inyRecent Research
desc: "There was no king in Israel; everyone did what was right in his own eyes" (Judges 17:6, 18:1, 19:1, 21:25).  Is this phrase descriptive of the period between the settlement and the establishment of a monarchy?  Is it a retrospective reflection on Israel and Judah's history with an overlay of retributive theology? Is it a rhetorical feature meant to signal another context in which "there was no king in Israel" - the Persian Period?  In this course we will do a close reading of the entire book of Judges as a cohesive narrative (with particular attention to rhetorical features of the text) while examining and assessing recent research trends.

name: HIST-290
title: Gender and Women's History:History ofyBlack Sexual Politics
desc: This course is a survey of how gender and sexuality functioned within African American communities and in racial ideology and racism in the United States from the trans-Atlantic slave trade to the post-civil rights era.  We will seek to understand how African Americans employed understandings of masculinity, femininity, sexuality, respectability, and sexual agency to construct families, arrange households, build communities, form organizations, seek employment, plan leisure, and organize struggles for equality. In addition, we will interrogate how complex racial formations such as colonialism, slavery, and segregation depended upon gender ideologies and sexual discourses for meaning.  Reading the works of leading scholars, we will cover such topics as the origins of racial slavery, slave families, interracial relationships, lynching, criminality, urban geography, homosexuality, the relationship between civil rights/black power and sexuality, Hip Hop, and black queer studies.

name: WGST-290
title: Gen/Wom His:Black Sexual Pol
desc: This course is a survey of how gender and sexuality functioned within African American communities and in racial ideology and racism in the United States from the trans-Atlantic slave trade to the post-civil rights era.  We will seek to understand how African Americans employed understandings of masculinity, femininity, sexuality, respectability, and sexual agency to construct families, arrange households, build communities, form organizations, seek employment, plan leisure, and organize struggles for equality. In addition, we will interrogate how complex racial formations such as colonialism, slavery, and segregation depended upon gender ideologies and sexual discourses for meaning.  Reading the works of leading scholars, we will cover such topics as the origins of racial slavery, slave families, interracial relationships, lynching, criminality, urban geography, homosexuality, the relationship between civil rights/black power and sexuality, Hip Hop, and black queer studies.

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar:Environmental Decision Making
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: Although the causes and consequences of many environmental problems are increasingly understood on a scientific level, this understanding often fails to translate to widespread and meaningful changes in human behavior. This seminar explores the topic of environmental decision making - what is known about the factors that impel individuals and groups to act in environmentally friendly ways? We will draw on examples from history, modern social science research, and personal experience to understand practical approaches to successfully tackling the environmental problems the world currently confronts.

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar:Environmental Leadership
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: This course will explore theories and practices of leadership as they relate specifically to sustainability, environmental decision-making, and systems change.  Examples of effective leadership -- both local and global -- will be examined as well as leaderless organizations and leading by example.  Emphasis will be placed on students identifying and utilizing their own strengths as leaders/followers.  The perspective of systems thinking will be used throughout the course.

name: GER-342
title: German Culture
desc: This course introduces students to the study of German history, culture, and society. It investigates selected trends and developments in contemporary German culture and examines their historical backgrounds. A special emphasis will be put on German media and film. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: MATH-321
title: Probability and Statistics I
desc: Axioms and laws of probability, conditional probability, combinatorics, counting techniques, independence, discrete and continuous random variables, mathematical expectation, discrete probability distributions, continuous probability distributions, functions of random variables, joint probability distributions and random samples, statistics and their distributions, central limit theorem, distribution of a linear combination of random variables.

name: MUS-249
title: Listening Live in London and Vienna
desc: This is a course devoted to listening carefully and thoughtfully to live music, and to broadening the contexts that inform our listening experiences. It is intended for students from all majors, with discussions centering on music and benefiting from the varied academic and experiential backgrounds of the students. Taking full advantage of the range of musical performances available and the rich musical history and cultures of London, we spend approximately the first two weeks of the course attending concerts in the evenings and spend the afternoons visiting sites that help provide the context for the music we hear. Morning class time is devoted to discussions not only of music, but of art, literature, and historical and current events as they relate to the cultural climate of the musical works. For the remainder of the course, we travel to another city or series of smaller towns for a different set of listening experiences to explore different functions, audiences, and styles of music making. As a group, we explore the ways in which our knowledge and differing perspectives affect the experience of listening to musical performances. Offered alternate years, during January term.

name: HIST-185
title: "From Mobile to Margaritaville: HumanyGeography in the Music and Fiction ofyJimmy Buffett"
desc: This course will use the fiction and extensive musical repertoire of Jimmy Buffett as a focal point for studying world geography and the human interactions associated with it through the course of history.  Geographic references in Buffett's songs and fiction will serve as a springboard for student presentations, discussion, and writing.

name: PAID2-450
title: From Sea to Mountain: EthicalyDilemmas of Land Use in Hawaii
desc: Students will explore the geographic and cultural mosaic of contemporary Hawaii.  The Hawaiian Islands encompass a unique environment that is threatened by overuse, invasive species, and economic pressures.  Citizens of the state bring competing ideas about land use from Hawaiian, Asian, and Western perspectives to bear on efforts to preserve Hawaii's distinctive character.  Local politicians and activist fight to protect the natural environment while still providing for the economic well being of the citizens of the island state.  Students in this class will be asked to weigh these competing efforts.

name: HLTH-233
title: Mental/ Emotional Health: StressyManagement
desc: This course approaches stress management from a holistic perspective. Causes of stress, signs and symptoms produced by stress, and modalities for dealing with stress are emphasized. Students will gain stress management knowledge, techniques, and responsible applications in daily lives.

name: ANTH-381
title: Internship
desc: Course graded A-F

name: GER-239
title: Special Topic:Intro to German Culture
desc: This course introduces students to the study of German history, culture, and society.  It investigates selected trends and developments in contemporary German culture and examines their historical backgrounds.  A special emphasis will be put on German media and film.  Offered on a rotating basis.  This course contains similar content to German 342 and therefore credit can only be earned for German 239 OR German 342 but not both.  It is designed for students who have completed German 201 or the equivalent, but no higher level of German.  Consent of instructor required.

name: EDUC-339
title: ST:Music Education
desc: This course will utilize a professional development school model in a collaborative arrangement with Westside Early Childhood Center and a music classroom at John Cline Elementary. Students will work with content, materials, methods of instruction and assessment in the teaching of music to early childhood learners. Select applications of ORFF or KODALY, supplemental materials/equipment, technology and classroom management as it applies to learners age 4 to 8 will be presented.  This course will combine the study of content with weekly teaching sessions.

name: MATH-322
title: Probability and Statistics II
desc: Sampling distribution of mean, standard deviation and proportion, theory of estimation, methods of point estimation, hypothesis testing, large and small sample confidence intervals, inferences for means, proportions and variances. Distribution free procedures.

name: PHIL-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during January term.

name: BIO-262
title: Environmental Animal Physiology
desc: This course will examine the homeostatic control mechanisms of organ systems across species lines. Additionally, the course will focus on the molecular, cellular and systems adaptations that allow animals to live in particular environments. Lectures and laboratory. Students may not earn credit for BIO 262 and BIO 255. Offered alternate years.

name: CHEM-349
title: Biochemistry Laboratory
pre_req: CHEM 241 and one of the following: CHEM 301, BIO 243, 248, 363 or 364. CHEM 202 and 365 recommended.
desc: A laboratory introduction to the isolation and analysis of biological molecules. Techniques employed will include cell culture, protein purification, use of fluorescent tags, and immunochemical methods of analysis.

name: REL-214
title: Lost Scriptures
desc: This course will examine writings which were considered sacred by some Jewish and Christian groups but which were not included in the orthodox canons of the Hebrew Bible or the New Testament. Students will analyze selected texts in their social, historical, ideological, and religious contexts, and they will use these texts to identify and to analyze diverse ancient forms of Judaism and Christianity. The sources of texts include the Old Testament Pseudepigrapha, the Dead Sea Scrolls, the New Testament Apocrypha, and the Nag Hammadi Library.

name: REL-223
title: Christianity and Its Modern Critics
desc: A survey of the more prominent critics and criticisms of Western Christianity from the Enlightenment to the present. Students will engage critics from a variety of spheres, including philosophy, theology, politics, science, literature, journalism, and popular culture. Criticisms of traditional Christian beliefs in the existence of God, the afterlife, and the possibility of miracles, among others, will be addressed, as will accusations of Christianity's detrimental influence on constructions of race, gender, and sexuality.

name: ART-239
title: Special Topics: Art of the 20th Century
desc: This course delves into the complex and messy pluralism of modern and contemporary art. Since the turn of the 20th century, artists have stepped up their challenge to previous art movementsconfronting, transforming, and reorienting the direction of art over the course of the 20th century. We will study major artists and art movements, including Cubism, Fauvism, Dada, Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Minimalism, Conceptual art, and art of the postmodern era. In this endeavor we will be primarily focused on the works of art themselves and on the writings of artists and critics.

name: HLTH-249
title: Personal and Community Health
desc: Course objectives include dissemination of current health and health care information, experiential learning opportunities, and investigation of cultural differences in wellness programs.

name: CHEM-139
title: Special Topics: The Environment: AyChemical Perspective (non-lab)
desc: A study of the environment with an emphasis on the relationship between technology and our surroundings. The course is designed for non-science students with little or no science background. No prerequisite. Students who earn credit for this course may not earn credit for 114, 115 or 116.

name: COMS-339
title: Special Topics: Perspectives onyGlobal Media
desc: This course will explore social, political, and economic aspects of the mass media with which students are familiar, but not always consciously aware. They will be challenged to directly compare these aspects of media in the United States with parallel aspects of other global media systems. By observing print, broadcast, and electronic media in the U.K. and other parts of Europe during their time abroad, by exposure to media from Asia and Africa in the classroom, and by reading theoretical texts on the functions media fulfill in culture, students will reflect on the role of media in our society and in their own lives. This is part of the Nottingham program for 2011-12. Acceptance to Nottingham program.

name: CS-239
title: Special Topics: Technology and CultureyIn the Year of the Dragon
desc: This travel course to China will explore the influence that the technology sector is having on one of the world's oldest cultures as it becomes one of the world's fastest growing economies. Students will participate in site visits and meet with representatives of tech companies with local as well as global economic influence in order to study the role that computer science and associated technologies are playing in this transformation. In order to gain an understanding of the interplay between new and old, students will also visit important sites such as Tian'anmen Square, Forbidden City, Yuyuan Garden (Old City), the Bund, and the Great Wall. A weekend home stay is planned to celebrate the Chinese New Year. Students will experience the traditions of Chinese culture while seeing first-hand the impact of technology, modernization, and rapid economic growth of that culture.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topics: Medieval History inyFilm
desc: Unfortunate though it may be, film is the most common means by which modern people encounter the historical past. This course takes the medium of film, and examines the various ways in which the medieval world has been represented in it. The course is divided into a series of six units, each concerned with a different aspect of medieval life (e.g. warfare, religiosity, philosophy and learning, romance, etc.) For each unit, students analyze a selection of scholarly background material, as well as a number of primary sources, written and visual. We will use the knowledge amassed through these sources to assess the choices made by screenwriters and directors as they represent scenes from the medieval world. Our task is therefore two-fold: to better understand the realities of the medieval world, and to assess the choices made by modern screenwriters as they construct their own portrayals of that historical reality for modern audiences.

name: PAID2-450
title: Ethics and Technology
desc: Technologies pervade modern life. They buzz in ourpockets, heat our food, transport us across vast distances, but also change the atmosphere of the planet. Are they merely means that contribute to our fulfillment of the good life? Or do some technologies and the mindset that accompanies them diminish what it means to be human? How should we assess technologies ethically? To what extent do technologies illumine, exacerbate, create, or resolve moral problems? This course explores questions like these as they arise in the areas of globalization, economics, and human rights; computers, robotics, and information technology; biotechnology and genetic engineering; and population, energy, and the environment.

name: PAID2-450
title: Mosque and State: Turkey
desc: This study abroad course will explore the role of religion and state in Turkish culture and society. It will offer the unique opportunity of meeting with communities from different religious backgrounds (Islam and Christianity), as well as political leaders within the country to see how faith, law, and ethics interact in the religious-political sphere. We will learn about Islam and minority populations, and we will explore change through an ethical lens. We will also visit historical and cultural sites (such as Istanbul and Ephesus).

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: Family Feud: KinshipyAnd Conflict in the Bible
desc: Not only is the Bible filled with stories about families, but the Bible as a whole can be viewed as a grand story about the family of God. This course will look at the family, big and small, in the Bible, with a special focus on stories about intrafamilial conflict. In particular, we will read and analyze narratives about sibling rivalry, incest, child sacrifice, fratricide and parental favoritism. In so doing, we will ask and attempt to answer questions such as: What defines family in the Bible? Why are these biblical families seemingly so dysfunctional? And why were the ancient biblical authors so willing to or even interested in airing their dirty laundry? By examining these narratives, we will explore how biblical conceptions of the family intersect with larger issues of kinship, election and identity.

name: REL-485
title: Sem. Comparative Theology
desc: This course examines the philosophical systems of leading thinkers from the Christian, Hindu, and Buddhist religious traditions, focusing primarily on their metaphysics, ethics, and their conception of religion. Special attention will be given to their conception of the absolute as god. In addition, the course will explore contemporary criticisms, feminist, postcolonial, and deconstructive, of traditional approaches to religious philosophy. Finally, the course will enable students to sytematically think about religious topics and to develop their own religious philosophy.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar: Rhetoric in (Environmental)yLterature: Sweetness and Light
pre_req: Take 2 courses from Eng 251, Eng 352-354, Eng 361-368.
desc: Rhetoric in (Environmental) Literature: Sweetness and Light   The earliest meditations on the purpose of literature often employ the metaphor of the beehive and its honeycombs: a communal life given order (light) and tasty nourishment (sweetness) through artistic labor.  This seminar will use the concepts and vocabulary of rhetoric to consider how literature delights, instructs, and persuades us.  Our case readings will be from the tradition of writing about nature: Virgil's poem The Georgics, Thoreau's meditative Walden, George Eliot's Silas Marner, Terry Tempest Williams' polemical family memoir Refuge, Wendell Berry's Selected Poems, and Barbara Kingsolver's novel Prodigal Summer.

name: MATH-365
title: Geometry
desc: This course follows the historical development of geometry, indcluding the important question of which parallel postulate to include. This is a proof-oriented course focusing on theorems in plane Euclidean and hyperbolic geometry, with some mention of elliptic geometry. We examine the development of a lean set of axioms, (incidence, betweenness, congruence, continuity) and investigate which theorems about points and lines can be derived using them.

name: PHIL-485
title: Seminar:Making Sense of Human Rights
desc: Talk of human rights dominates moral and political discourse but rarely do we stop to examine "rights talk" closely.  This seminar will focus on a philosophical examination of the concept of human rights both historically and as applied to a range of contemporary issues.  Starting from a study of the philosophical foundations of rights we will proceed to examine a series of challenges to rights and questions about the scope and substance of rights claim.  Issues to be examined include rights, torture, and terrorism, welfare rights, the rights of future generations, the rights of nonhumans, and the role of technology and artificial intelligence in extending rights. Students will be responsible for facilitating discussion during the seminar and will conduct a major research project on a topic of their choosing.

name: ANTH-239
title: Special Topic: Ecological Anthropology
desc: This course provides a wide-ranging introduction to the field of ecological anthropology. Focus is placed on issues of cooperation and the management of common property in the framework of an intercultural understanding of competing approaches to the relationship of ecology to the social world of humans. Specifically, we begin with an introduction to the relationship of ecology and social behavior among the primates. We continue our exploration of human behavior and sociality with an analysis of the world's best studied hunter-gatherers, the ju/025hoansi of southern Africa, also known as the Kung! Next, we see how systems ecology has been combined with social anthropology to explain the cycles of ritualized warfare among a modern Stone Age society in Papua New Guinea. Finally, we move on to the Indonesian Island of Bali where today its thousand-year old water-temple system of common property management is threatened with collapse. Same as ENVS 239.

name: ENVS-239
title: Special Topic:Ecological Anthropology
desc: This course provides a wide-ranging introduction to the field of ecological anthropology. Focus is placed on issues of cooperation and the management of common property in the framework of an intercultural understanding of competing approaches to the relationship of ecology to the social world of humans. Specifically, we begin with an introduction to the relationship of ecology and social behavior among the primates. We continue our exploration of human behavior and sociality with an analysis of the world's best studied hunter-gatherers, the ju/025hoansi of southern Africa, also known as the Kung! Next, we see how systems ecology has been combined with social anthropology to explain the cycles of ritualized warfare among a modern Stone Age society in Papua New Guinea. Finally, we move on to the Indonesian Island of Bali where today its thousand-year old water-temple system of common property management is threatened with collapse. Same as ANTH 239.

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History:Middle Agesyin Film
desc: Unfortunate though it may be, film is the most common means by which modern people encounter the historical past.  This course takes the medium of film, and examines the various ways in which the medieval and early modern world has been represented in it.  The course is divided into a series of units, each concerned with a different aspect of medieval and early modern life (e.g. warfare, religiosity, philosophy and learning, romance, etc.)  For each unit, students analyze a selection of scholarly background material, as well as a number of primary sources, written and visual.  Students will use the knowledge amassed through these sources to assess the choices made by screenwriters and directors as they portray scences from the past.  Our task is therefore two-fold:  to better understand the historical reality of the Middle Ages, and to assess the choices made by modern screenwriters as they construct their own portrayals of that historical reality for modern audiences.

name: HLTH-352
title: Consumer Health and Safety Education
desc: Instruction in factors involved in the selection and evaluation of health services and products. Consumer laws and organizations will also be examined.  An overview of approaches to safety education and injury reduction will be addressed.

name: HIST-485
title: Junior/Senior Seminar:The Long Civil
desc: During the past decade, the debate over timing, scope, and trajectory of the civil rights movement gained steam as historians persuasively challenged the traditional non-violent southern movement narrative.  Studies that are currently reshaping the field point to a range of black political struggles across much of the twentieth century, reveal the underlying connections between civil rights and black power, and identify how activists defined citizenship and liberation in varied and contradictory ways.  We will join these conversations by writing our own histories of the movement based on primary source research.  Topics and themes will include labor, student, and legal activism, struggles in the North and the West, welfare rights battles, segregation, militancy, gender, sexuality, conflict, and urban reform. This course concludes by examining the movement's outcomes and drawing preliminary conclusions about racial policies in the late twentieth century.

name: ANTH-339
title: Special Topics: Matters of Life andyDeath: Anthropology and Bioethics
desc: This course focuses on anthropological approaches to bioethics and is grounded in the field of medical anthropology and related disciplines. The course will challenge students to understand tenacious assumptions that underline our medical decision-making and recognize multiple determinants of this process. We will address a wide range of topics in medical ethics, including individual and corporate responsibility, genetic screening, death and birth, organ exchange, medical tourism, health issues and transnational migration, roots of ill health, pharmaceutical business, clinical research trials, bioethics and public policy, and other controversial issues in medical decision making.

name: PAID-001
title: Paid 111 Transfer Equivalent
desc: A dummy course created to indicate on TSUM who has completed the equivalent of paideia 111 with a transfer course.  This course can now be used as a prerequisite for a course that requires the equivalent of paideia 111.

name: PAID-002
title: Paid 112 Transfer Equivalent
desc: A dummy course created to indicate on TSUM who has completed the equivalent of paideia 112 with a transfer course.  This course can now be used as a prerequisite for a course that requires the equivalent of paideia 112.

name: INSYS-140
title: Technical Aspects of Information Systems
desc: An introduction to the technology upon which information systems are built.  Topics include fundamental computer and network architecture, system and network software, communications protocols, decision support system structure and configuration, and methods for developing IS software and for constructing IS infrastructure.

name: MATH-327
title: Applied Statistics I
pre_req: MATH 321, BIO 256, PSYC 350, SOC 350, ECON 242, or MGT 150
desc: Regression Analysis: Least square estimates, simple linear regression, multiple linear regression, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for linear regression models, prediction intervals, and ANOVA. Model diagnostics including tests of constant variance assumptions, serial correlation, and multicollinearity. Time series: Linear time series, moving average, autoregressive, and ARIMA models. Estimation and forecasting. Forecast errors and confidence intervals.

name: MGT-250
title: Data Analysis for BusinessyDecision-Making
desc: This course is an introduction to business intelligence and analytics, focusing on the extensive use of data analysis to drive business decisions and actions. Areas of emphasis are efficient manipulation of data sets, defining and organizing needed data using data modeling techniques, retrieving and mining data using database tools, using data to create models for analysis, and presenting data effectively for decision-making. The course will utilize current software tools, such as spreadsheets and databases, and will focus on techniques for improving business reporting and data visualization.

name: MGT-371
title: Project Management
desc: This course provides an introduction to the core concepts, techniques, and principles of project management required to successfully meet an organization's goals and objectives, with particular emphasis on Information technology (IT) projects.  The course explores the Industry standard Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) guide and also incorporates learning objectives related to communication, influence, and negotiation, and their relationship to project success.

name: PAID2-450
title: Hilter and Bonhoeffer:yGenocide and Ethics in a TotalitarianyState (history/Religion, Paideia IIySequence
desc: Juniors or seniors who wish to earn Paideia II credit for this pairing of courses must enroll in,and successfully complete, History 351, Topics In European History: Hitler and Nazi Germany in Fall 2011 and Religion 334, Dietrich Bonhoeffer, in Spring 2012. Students taking Religion 334 for Paideia II credit will be required to write a 10-12 page research paper on an approved topic.

name: HIST-111
title: Survey of US History to 1877
desc: This course surveys American history from the early colonial period to the end of Reconstruction in 1877. Topics are wide-ranging and include society, politics and culture but the overall theme emphasizes the evolution of the New England colonies, the Middle Colonies, the Chesapeake,and the Lower South into coherent regions with different economies, social structures and cultural attributes. The course then explores how these various regions successfully cooperated with one another long enough to engage in an independence movement that separated them from Great Britain and created the United States. These regional differences lived on into the nineteenth century, however, and became the basis for the sectional conflict which erupted into Civil War in 1861. The course closes with the successes and failures of Reconstruction policy as a bridge to later American history.

name: HIST-112
title: Survey of US History Since 1877
desc: This course surveys American history since Reconstruction, exploring transformations in American politics, society, and culture. Though it is wide-ranging, it has as a unifying theme the question of how and why people have defined the American nation in different ways, and how those ideas have related to race and gender. Topics covered include the end of the westward expansion after the Civil War and Indian resistance, industrialization, immigration, World War I, African American migration and cultural innovation, the cultural turmoil of the 1920s, the Depression and New Deal, the Second World War at home and abroad, the Cold War, the Civil Rights Movement, feminism, other social movements, the Vietnam war and the anti-war movement, cultural politics in the 1970s, the new conservatism and 1980s culture wars, the 1990s, 9/11, the Gulf War, and the Iraq and Afghanistan Wars.

name: PAID2-450
title: Ritual and PerformanceyIn Japan
desc: This course will examine religious rituals as well as performance arts that emphasize religious themes in Japan. The course focuses on Buddhist and Shinto rituals, which it compares to the basic liturgy of the Roman Catholic Church. The course will examine how rituals use choreography to convey religious meaning and how performance arts, especially Noh and Kabuki, fulfill a religious function. Particularly, the course will explore how religions use movement as ritual device and inscribe religious meaning on the body. Finally, the course investigates the ethics of body politics and ritual representation.

name: HLTH-358
title: Substance Abuse Education
desc: An introduction to social, psychological, pharmacological, and cultural aspects of substance use and abuse. An overview of resources, materials, and instructional strategies available to the substance abuse educators will be presented. Methods of identifying substance abuse problems and substance abuse prevention theories will also be discussed.

name: ANTH-339
title: Matters of Life and Death:yAnthropology and Bioethics
desc: This course focuses on anthropological approaches to bioethics and is grounded in the field of medical anthropology and related disciplines. The course will challenge students to understand tenacious assumptions that underlie our medical decision-making and recognize multiple determinants of this process. We will address a wide range of topics in medical ethics, including individual and corporate responsibility, genetic screening, death and birth, organ exchange, medical tourism, health issues and transnational migration, roots of ill health, pharmaceutical business, clinical research trials, bioethics and public policy, and other controversial issues in medical decision-making.

name: MUS-239
title: ST:Music in the Shape of a Pear:yContemporary Music Immersion
desc: This course will offer students the opportunity to explore the music of our time through rehearsal, performance, research and creative work, with approximately half of the course devoted to the preparation of contemporary repertoire for performance, and half the course devoted to guided independent research and/or creative work. Repertoire will be chosen based on student enrollment, with an eye towards representative works that introduce students to common contemporary instrumental and vocal techniques not typically encountered in applied lessons or ensembles. Following several initial classes which will orient students to the language of contemporary concert music, students will undertake guided explorations into specific works, composers, or genres and begin their own independent projects, resulting in research papers, presentations, and possibly additional performance opportunities. Students with a particular interest in composition will also have the option of completing a creative project that stems from their research. Final projects and performances will be featured in a new music festival to be held in early February, a joint venture with the Iowa Composers Forum.

name: ANTH-239
title: Leipzig, Dresden, Berlin:yMusical Life in Germany, PastyAnd Present
desc: This course, open to majors and non-majors, will give students the opportunity to study a broad historical outline of German musical heritage as it stems from the cities of Leipzig, Dresden, and Berlin. Not only will the course consider the important composers associated with these centers (such as Bach, Handel, Mendelssohn, Wagner, and Richard Strauss), but it will also examine musical institutions and people that have profoundly shaped German musical life (including the Berlin Philharmonic, the Gewandhaus Orchestra, the Dresden Staatskapelle, the Semperoper, and the Deutsche Oper). A prominent component of this course will be listening to live musical performances, including symphonic concerts, operas, and services that feature cantatas of J.S. Bach at the Thomaskirche in Leipzig. In addition to attending performances, the course will also examine current musical and cultural life in Germany by interacting with guest lecturers and visiting historical sites and museums. While in Leipzig and Berlin, students will spend several days visiting sites related to the Cold War and the Berlin Wall, with particular emphasis on differences between East German and West German musical and cultural life during this era.

name: MUS-239
title: ST: Leipzig, Dresden, Brelin:yLife in Germany, Past and Present
desc: This course, open to majors and non-majors, will give students the opportunity to study a broad historical outline of German musical heritage as it stems from the cities of Leipzig, Dresden, and Berlin. Not only will the course consider the important composers associated with these centers (such as Bach, Handel, Mendelssohn, Wagner, and Richard Strauss), but it will also examine musical institutions and people that have profoundly shaped German musical life (including the Berlin Philharmonic, the Gewandhaus Orchestra, the Dresden Staatskapelle, the Semperoper, and the Deutsche Oper). A prominent component of this course will be listening to live musical performances, including symphonic concerts, operas, and services that feature cantatas of J.S. Bach at the Thomaskirche in Leipzig. In addition to attending performances, the course will also examine current musical and cultural life in Germany by interacting with guest lecturers and visiting historical sites and museums. While in Leipzig and Berlin, students will spend several days visiting sites related to the Cold War and the Berlin Wall, with particular emphasis on differences between East German and West German musical and cultural life during this era.

name: EDUC-321
title: Clinical Experience II:Literacy inyElementary/Middle School
pre_req: Admittance to Teacher Educ Program and EDUC 326
desc: As a part of the elementary/middle school education sequence the student observes and teaches small and large groups of students in a classroom in the area of literacy. During the clinical experience the student develops and teaches a unit that documents the planning, teaching, assessment and reflection of literacy protocols. This course is co-requisite with EDUC 322 and is based in a public or private school for three weeks.

name: EDUC-322
title: Clinical Experience II: Mathematics inyElementary/Middle School
pre_req: Admittance to Teacher Educ Program and EDUC 325
desc: As a part of the elementary education methods sequence the student observes and teaches small and large groups of students in an elementary/middle school classroom. During the clinical experience, the student develops and teaches a unit that documents planning, teaching, assessment and reflection protocols in the area of mathematics. This course is co-requisite with EDUC 321 and is based in a public or private for three weeks.

name: LING-133
title: Introduction to Syntax
desc: The syntax of natural languages is a beautifully complex system of subconscious rules. What are they like? This course enables students to engage in building a theory of syntax. After an introduction to the basic tools of syntactic analysis, students tackle increasingly complex sets of data from English (and, occasionally, other languages), proposing and testing competing hypotheses against each other and refining them in light of new data. By the end of the course, students are able to identify syntactic puzzles in English or another language of their choice, propose analyses in the theory they have developed, and present their research in written and oral form.

name: INSYS-320
title: Management of Information Technology
desc: This course explores the issues and approaches in managing the information systems function in organizations and how the IS function integrates, supports, and enables various types of organizational capabilities.  It explores the acquistion, development and implementation of plans and policies to achieve efficient and effective information systems.  The course addresses issues relating to defining the high-level IS infrastructure and the systems that support the operational, administrative and strategic needs of the organization.  Other topics include funding IT, IT investment analysis, emerging technologies, and managing risk and security.  Prerequisite: INSYS-250 or INSYS-260, junior standing or above (E)

name: ART-339
title: Special Topics:Dutch Baroque MethodsyAnd Motifs
desc: This course investigates Dutch Baroque painting from both an art historical and studio perspective. Seventeenth-century Dutch painting provides a particularly illuminating moment of historical analysis as painters, for the first time, supplanted patrons as primary generators of artistic imagery. Students will examine the cultural and technical connections between Dutch Baroque painters and the contemporary painting canon, specifically researching the core themes and functions of Dutch art, while simultaneously exploring traditional handmade materials and painting techniques. Prerequisite:  Art 108 or Art 200 or Art 252 recommended.

name: ENG-239
title: Special Topics: Tales of the Sea
pre_req: Complete Paideia 111 and 112 or transfer equivalent. Consent of instructor required.
desc: This J-Term course in the Virgin Islands involves reading the literature of the sea while sailing on a two-masted schooner.  Students will stay aboard the windjammer, Roseway, home of the World Ocean School, where they will read the stories of lives and characters transformed by the challenges of the sea.  Texts will include classic works such as The Odyssey and Conrad's The Shadow Line, as well as contemporary texts like H.M.S. Surprise. During the course students will learn some basic elements of seamanship and navigation, and also learn to sail a small craft.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topics:The European Reformation
desc: A travel course that analyzes the various elements of the Protestant and Catholic Reformations in their historical contexts and locations.  The focus is on the traditions, beliefs, values, and theologies of the various Christian confessions that formed during the sixteenth century.  The course will also include aspects of social, economic, and political history that serve to inform and contextualize the reformers' ideas, as well as demonstrate their impact across society. With regard to geography, particular emphasis is placed on Prague and proto-Reformer, Jan Hus; Wittenberg and Martin Luther; Muenster and the Anabaptists; Antwerp and the Counter and Catholic Reformations; and Amsterdam and Calvinism.  Note: History 239 and History 355 may not both be taken for credit.

name: MUS-227
title: Music/Performing Arts in theyElementary Classroom
desc: This course presents methods of teaching music/performing arts for use in the classroom by the elementary teacher.  Topics included are: basic music/performing arts concepts, presenting music/performing arts to elementary children and an overview of such programs in the elementary school including content, methods and materials for instruction.

name: MATH-454
title: Principles of Real Analysis
desc: The course studies functions of a real variable and examines the foundations of calculus, with an emphasis on writing rigorous analytical proofs, and follows the historical development of analysis from Newton to Leibniz through Lagrange, Cauchy, Bolzano, Weierstrass, Cantor, Riemann, and Lebesgue. Topics include the topology of the reals, sequences, series, limits, continuity, pointwise and uniform convergence, differentitaion, Taylor series, and integration.

name: PHIL-320
title: Topics in Value Theory:Rousseau andyNietzsche: Critics of Modernity
desc: Beginning in the 15th century, European civilization experienced rapid changes in society, politics, and culture.  These developments (such as the emergence of the nation-state, industrialization, democracy, urbanization, mass literacy, public opinion, individual rights, and capitalism) are often grouped under the terms "modernity" and "modernization," and they have had profound affects around the world.  Many people equate modernization with "progress," but it has critics as well, none more profound and provocative than the philosophers Jean-Jacques Rousseau and Friedrich Nietzsche.  These two thinkers argue that the institutions of the modern epoch systematically undermine the values that they claim to promote, and in developing their arguments Rousseau and Nietzsche produced radical, provocative, and highly influential new perspectives on society and politics.  Prerequisite:  Two courses in philosophy.

name: IS-490
title: Senior Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar. Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed project is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department. All projects must be presented publicly. Only projects awarded an "A- or A" qualify for "department honors" designation. The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: AFRS-239
title: Special Topic: Victim or Villian: TheyCauses of Contemporary Crises in Africa
desc: This course examines several crises affecting post-colonial African states. Special attention will be paid to economic problems, civil war, and AIDS. Through close study of autobiography and film, the course will explore how different colonial and post-colonial policies contributed to the emergence of problems in post-colonial African states. Although the course focuses on Zimbabwe, Rwanda and South Africa, it will give students an opportunity to understand both the achievements and failures of post-colonial rule in Africa.

name: HLTH-465
title: Current Issues in Health
desc: This course affords students the opportunity to examine local, national, and international health issues. Students will actively participate in selecting course topics, work collaboratively with others in developing and implementing course objectives, and will research, write, and present information on selected course topics.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic: Victim or Villian: TheyCauses of Contemporary Crises in Africa
desc: This course examines several crises affecting post-colonial African states. Special attention will be paid to economic problems, civil war, and AIDS. Through close study of autobiography and film, the course will explore how different colonial and post-colonial policies contributed to the emergence of problems in post-colonial African states. Although the course focuses on Zimbabwe, Rwanda and South Africa, it will give students an opportunity to understand both the achievements and failures of post-colonial rule in Africa.

name: ANTH-185
title: The Culture of Capitalism
desc: There has emerged over the past five hundred years a distinctive culture of capitalism dominated by a belief in trade and commodity consumption as the main source of well-being. The spread of the capitalist-world system has been accompanied by the creation of peculiar ways of constructing social relations, ways of viewing the world, methods of food production, the creation of needs through advertisement, and relationships to the environment. The spread of this culture has not gone unchallenged. How and why capitalist culture developed and the reasons why some groups resisted and continue to resist its development are among the questions to be explored in this course.

name: CLAS-239
title: Underwater Archaeology
desc: This course examines the history and archaeology of the maritime world from prehistory to the nineteenth century with a special emphasis on Greek and Roman material culture. It traces the development of the discipline, surveys the techniques and results of underwater archaeology, and investigates how it contributes to a greater understanding of regional and global history. In addition to covering a large pool of evidence that includes shipwrecks and maritime literature, it also examines the shifting ethical and legal frameworks of archaeology under the sea.

name: ANTH-239
title: Underwater Archaeology
desc: This course examines the history and archaeology of the maritime world from prehistory to the nineteenth century with a special emphasis on Greek and Roman material culture. It traces the development of the discipline, surveys the techniques and results of underwater archaeology, and investigates how it contributes to a greater understanding of regional and global history. In addition to covering a large pool of evidence that includes shipwrecks and maritime literature, it also examines the shifting ethical and legal frameworks of archaeology under the sea.

name: ART-185
title: Magic and Misdirection: A Theatre ofyInfluence
desc: This course examines the history, principles and methods of performance magic. From close-up magic to grand stage illusions, magic has transformed the human relationship with the impossible. Merging psychology misdirection, showmanship and scholarship this course addresses the influence of performance magic in entertainment, theater, film, advertising, politics, crime, intelligence trade craft, and warfare.

name: BIO-139
title: Biology of the Coral Reef
desc: This course takes place at the Gerace Research Centre on the island of San Salvador, the Bahamas. It includes both classroom lectures and lab / field experiences. Students will learn to identify and study the life cycle, anatomical adaptations and behavior of the various marine reef organisms (including fishes, invertebrates, plants). Coral reefs are plentiful in the shallow ocean around San Salvador. The biodiversity of the marine reef will be compared to other marine communities found on the island (lagoon, tidal creek, rocky shore). Students cannot earn credit for Coral Reef Biology 239 and Coral Reef Biology 139 or Subtropical Marine Biology Bio 247.

name: BIO-239
title: Biology of Coral Reef
desc: This course takes place at the Gerace Research Centre on the island of San Salvador, the Bahamas. It includes both classroom lectures and lab / field experiences. Students will learn to identify and study the life cycle, anatomical adaptations and behavior of the various marine reef organisms (including fishes, invertebrates, plants). Coral reefs are plentiful in the shallow ocean around San Salvador. The biodiversity of the marine reef will be compared to other marine communities found on the island (lagoon, tidal creek, rocky shore). Students cannot earn credit for Coral Reef Biology 239 and Coral Reef Biology 139 or Subtropical Marine Biology Bio 247.

name: ECON-185
title: The Economics of Imaginary Societies
desc: What if the wellbeing of a rich society - all its ease and prosperity - depended on the imprisonment, deep underground, of a single child? If you'd accept the bargain, there are those in Ursula LeGuin's short story (to be read in this course) who would not. Or, what can we learn from a society where wealth itself is scorned, and the greatest prestige is earned by those who live in deprivation and squalor? James de Mille's novel explores just such a setting. Through studying works like these - taken from film as well as literature - we may well come to see our own society in a different light.
