Ethical considerations will be discussed, such as: who should initiate, implement, evaluate, and financially support public health programs. Students will be encouraged to think about these issues in terms of social justice and equitable distribution of resources and responsibilities around the globe. Sample topics will include communicable diseases, sexually transmitted diseases, addictive behaviors, and reproductive health issues, highlighting health promotion and illness prevention.

name: PAID-450
title: Ethics of Animal Management in India
desc: This course explores some of the many ethical issues pertaining to animal care and management in Indian contexts. Topics may include: the formation, funding, and work of goshalas (homes for unclaimed urban cattle); the intentional and unintentional feeding of langurs and rhesus macaques at temples and urban sites; public and private management of urban populations of feral animals (particularly dogs); the purpose and function of public zoos; the management of human and nonhuman animal populations in and around wildlife preserves; the provision of veterinary care; and others. Daily class discussions and informal writing will be organized around site visits and presentations by Indian staff of public and private institutions.

name: PAID-450
title: People and Parks:Pastoralism andyConservation in East Africa
desc: This course will examine the tensions between the national parks movement and pastoralist societies through the lens of the Maasai people of northern Tanzania and southern Kenya. Of particular interest is how wildlife conservation efforts and ecotourism have impacted the relationship of the Maasai to their environment, in turn causing rapid cultural change such as shifts from herding to agropastoralism and wage labor; modification of coming-of-age rituals; and increasing adoption of formal modes of education and Christianity in place of or alongside traditional modes and beliefs. From bases near the city of Arusha and the small town of Monduli, we will study 'traditional' Maasai culture and examine the ways in which the Maasai of northern Tanzania are adapting to changing social, political, economic, and environmental conditions. Students will interact with Maasai people in urban and rural marketplaces; in schools, medical facilities, and places of worship; and at Maasai bomas (multi-family compounds) in the bush. We will also visit the African Wildlife Foundation, the Ngorongoro Crater Conservation Area, the Manyara Ranch Conservancy, Gibbs Farm (a luxury resort for western tourists that highlights Maasai culture), and the pilgrimage route at the Oldoinyo Lengai volcano in order to explore points of intersection between wildlife conservation programs, ecotourism, and pastoralist societies.

name: PAID-450
title: War, Peace and Reconc Cambodia
desc: In this J-term study abroad course, you will have an opportunity to engage with people who are making a difference in their post-war environment (after years of recent civil war at the hands of the Khmer Rouge) in southeast Asia. This course will be taught through the eyes of the women and children of Cambodia, a country with a very young population having lost many men and elders to the civil wars of the recent past. It is also the poorest country in SE Asia. We will meet local citizens, engage in service learning, study the political and religious background of the area from native experts, all while observing and learning about life in this land vastly different from our own. Specifically we aim to focus our explorations to the topics of human rights, the environment, children and women's issues and the role the US has played in this nation's history and current climate. While visiting local sites we will learn about the challenges and opportunities that face people in modern day Cambodia, based on the past. We will visit both rural and urban locations and examine how peace after war has affected the citizens in multiple regions of Cambodia. Ethical questions will be a focus of our discussions as we look at the past and current state of the country.

name: PAID-450
title: Crowds, Culture, and Cuisine: theyAncient and Modern City (italy/ France)
desc: The rebuilding of Paris in the 1860's created perhaps the first modern city-a rationalized environment for organizing vast populations. This project has since become the norm for modern societies-in apartment complexes, subdivisions, amusement parks, shopping malls, sports stadiums, and entire planned cities. Yet urban life is not a purely modern experience. Rome is thought to have reached a population of one million in the first century BCE, a size not achieved again on the European continent until the 19th century. This course will visit four European cities that reached the height of their influence in successive periods of European history from ancient to modern times: Rome, Florence, Lyon, and Paris. By reading some of the classic literature from these cities produced during these periods (such as Boccaccio in Florence and Baudelaire in Paris), and by experiencing the cities themselves, we will ask: How does the built environment of the city affect our relationships to each other, to ourselves, and to the natural world? This course will ask students to reflect on questions of value: what is created and what is lost with density of population, comprehensive built environments, mixing of ethnicities, control of nature, the separation yet mixing of classes, the availability of spectacle, the growth of the arts, the overarching regimentation of life (movement, work, and leisure, etc.)? What ways of thinking, and what ways of life, are enabled or precluded by urban experience? And how can we understand the paradoxical phenomena of the self in the city: isolation and the crowd; freedom and regimentation; stimulation and boredom; social mobility and class structure?

name: POLS-485
title: Seminar:Gender and Politics in Americayand Beyond
desc: Using the United States as a starting point and comparing its experience to other countries, students will learn about the role gender plays in the political process.  Focusing on the different types of representation (descriptive, substantive, and symbolic), students will especially read and discuss the role of women's movements (local, national, and international) and female politicians on changing policy.  Debates about what is gender, what is gender-related policy, women's rights, and women's rights, and women as an interest group will drive most readings and discussions.

name: HIST-321
title: Topics in U.S. History:Colonial andyRevolutionary America
desc: Colonial and Revolutionary America will explore early American history from roughly 1500 to about 1800.  There are several major themes in this course.  These include the interactions among Native, European and African peoples and the lives of ordinary men and women from the sixteenth through the eighteenth centuries.  The course also examines how and why British America evolved into different regions, the ways in which their inhabitants created differing economic structures, societies and cultures and gradually took different paths toward the future with all the attendant consequences for American history.  Toward the latter part of the course we will give considerable attention to the ways in which the British mainland colonies overcame their considerable regional and social differences during the American Revolution, how and why they joined together to rebel against Britain and how they became an independent nation.  We will examine the question of what was revolutionary about the American Revolution, what changes it brought about and what did not change.  Finally, we will see that some citizens formulated a vision of a New American Empire that sustained them during a long and bloody war for independence and provided a vision that proved central to the process of nation building and expansion during the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.

name: HIST-362
title: Topics in South Asian History: India'syEnvironmental History
desc: This course introduces students to the relatively new yet rapidly growing practices of re-reading South Asian history to create narratives of environmental change and using the environment as an analytical tool to rewrite narratives of India's past.  Readings will be drawn from all historical periods but will reflect the field's attention to history since about 1500.  Themes will include agriculture, animal husbandry, irrigation, deforestation, hunting, mining and mineral processing, urbanization, sanitation, industrialization, colonization and decolonization, and economic liberalization as causes of environmental change, and we will examine how religious, caste, class, national, and gender identities affect these causes.

name: DAN-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during the fall, spring or summer terms.

name: PAID-450
title: Ethics and Technology
desc: Technologies pervade modern life. They buzz in ourpockets, heat our food, transport us across vast distances, but also change the atmosphere of the planet. Are they merely means that contribute to our fulfillment of the good life? Or do some technologies and the mindset that accompanies them diminish what it means to be human? How should we assess technologies ethically? To what extent do technologies illumine, exacerbate, create, or resolve moral problems? This course explores questions like these as they arise in the areas of globalization, economics, and human rights; computers, robotics, and information technology; biotechnology and genetic engineering; and population, energy, and the environment.

name: PAID-450
title: Society, Business, & Ethics
desc: This course examines how commercial life and ethical life intersect. We will be reading texts from many economic, social and ethical theorists, which will provide us with a variety of structures and concepts for understanding how human beings interact and how they can live well together. These theories will also be brought to bear in analyzing specific cases of ethical issues in economic relationships. In addition, based on research groups, students will give a class presentation on the ethical issues highlighted by a specific case, facilitating discussion and reflection upon the ethical decision-making involved in the case.

name: REL-239
title: Healing and Indigenous Religions
desc: This course will explore the relationship between healing, medicine, culture and society with a focus on Indigenous Religions. To study Indigenous healing is to study Indigenous spirituality. Therefore we will survey the spiritual paradigms of several Indigenous cultures before we begin studying Indigenous Healing Traditions. We will discuss cross-cultural notions of the body, ritual performance in healing, embodiment of healing powers by religious specialists, the importance of sound and music in healing, and the relations of healing practices to cosmology and sacred narratives. We will discuss the notion of 'efficacy', the cosmological rationale behind diagnoses, methods and resources to restore individual and community health, and the transformations of self and meaning that emerge during or from a cure. Finally, we will explore attempts to integrate Indigenous and Western medicines.(Students may use this course to fulfill either the second Religion requirement or the Human Behavior requirement, but not both.)

name: THE-239
title: Special Topic:Digital Rendering foryTheatre Design
desc: This course introduces students to computer-generated rendering techniques for the theatre.  Students will analyze plays and use the elements and principles of design to develop original design ideas.  Photoshop and Illustrator will then be used to generate digital drawings of the design.  Equal time will be spent on the development of the design concepts and on the digital rendering techniques.

name: MGT-150
title: Statistics
desc: A first course in statistics which introduces descriptive and inferential statistical tools as they apply to management, accounting and the social sciences. Students who earn credit for MATH 115 cannot earn credit for MGT 150.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures:Fiction, Fantasy andythe Fantastic
desc: Can thought-provoking, "serious" literature also be fun to read? Yes! Now is an exciting time for readers and writers alike, as lines between genres like "literary fiction" and "fantasy" are breaking down in all directions, and writers with serious credentials are busting out novels and stories that draw on fairy tales, action films, corporate-America satires, and even zombies.  We'll be reading novels and short stories from authors like Angela Carter, Louis Jensen, Benjamin Percy, William Faulkner, and George Saunders, as well as trying our hand at writing a fantastical short story of our own.

name: ENG-485
title: Possession:Narrative Voice and theyCreative "Daimon"
desc: Possession:Narrative Voice and the Creative "Daimon".  A study of narrative voice in a selection of poems and novels.  Narrators gain possession of the stories they tell, shaping perspectives as they seek to make us their allies and position themselves in relation to other situations and characters.  Can we trust them?  When do their accounts prove ambiguous or unreliable, and how can we tell?  What is each narrator's relationship to the author penning the tale?  Readings may include selected poems by Emily Dickinson, Henry James's "The Aspern Papers" and "The Turn of the Screw", Charlotte Bronte's "Jane Eyre", Emily Bronte's "Wuthering Heights", Mary Shelley's "Frankenstein", Ford Madox Ford's "The Good Solider".

name: PHIL-320
title: Topics in Value Theory:Morality,yBiology, and the Limits of HumanyIngenuity
desc: This seminar style course will examine several issues in contemporary ethics at the intersection of biology, genetics, technology, and morality.  We will look at questions raised by studying the history of human evolution as well as possible futures for the human species.  The course will primarily address the following questions:  Can everything about humans - including morality and religion - be fully explained by biology and neuroscience?  What should be the limits, if any, on technological enhancements of humans and other species?  How do we resolve the ethical issues raised by biotechnology, especially genetic engineering and gene-based medicine?

name: PHIL-485
title: Seminar:Friedrich Nietzsche:A Thinkeryin His Time
desc: No philosopher has a more complicated and controversial legacy than Friedrich Nietzsche. His ideas have been championed by thinkers as diverse as Ayn Rand and Michel Foucault, and his writings have been seen as both the highest pinnacle and the deepest abyss of European philosophy. Amid these controversies, however, it is easy to lose track of the man and his books. This seminar will read all of Nietzsche major works, from "Human, All Too Human" to "Twilight of the Idols," including his enigmatic masterpiece "Thus Spoke Zarathustra." We will pay special attention to the intellectual and cultural context in which these works were written, especially his study of the philosopher Arthur Shopenhauer and his relationship with the composer Richard Wagner. We will interpret his key concepts, such as "the Superman," "the revaluation of values, and "the Anti-Christ," in light of the specific philosophical and cultural questions that emerged from his encounter with 19th century European civilization.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar: Comparative Scriptures
pre_req: Take 3 courses from Rel or consent of instructor.
desc: What can we learn by studying the phenomenon of scripture across religious traditions? This course will explore various methods for comparing sacred texts and will identify different kinds of knowledge that can be produced by employing such methods. The comparative material the professor utilizes in class will focus on the scriptures of the Abrahamic religious traditions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam, and Mormonism. The comparative material utilized in the book a student will review may include the sacred texts of other religious traditions, including Asian religions. As a capstone course, the research paper will provide students an opportunity to build on their prior work in the major/minor, and the topic of comparison may therefore include the scriptures of other religious traditions the student has studied, including Asian religions.

name: PAID-111D
title: Paideia I:Enduring Questions
desc: A two-semester common course for all first-year students that addresses questions central to the human condition.  It develops students' ability to read, write, analyze, discuss, and research by engaging with works from across the disciplines, drawn from different time periods and parts of the globe.  As a signature course and a foundation for liberal learning, "Enduring Questions" is taught by faculty from all divisions of the college. Students may not withdraw from PAID 111 or 112. If they fail the course, they must retake it in the next semester that it is offered.

name: FCUL-339
title: Special Topic:Peace and ReconciliationyDialog in Norway and the Balkans
desc: Norway is well known as a world leader in peace studies. This course will focus on the work of Norway's Nansen Center for Peace and Dialog (NCPD). The NCPD works in peace education for refugees in Norway and in dialog/reconciliation projects in deeply segregated societies in the world. This course involves residency in Lillehammer at the NCPD to learn about peace and reconciliation dialog, issues in contemporary Norway, and the history of ethnic, religious, and political conflict in the Balkan Peninsula. After residency in Lillehammer and time in Oslo, we will travel to the Western Balkans to Nansen Dialog Centers in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition to smaller cities, students will experience two capitals (Sarajevo in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Belgrade in Serbia). This course is offered by Laurie Iudin-Nelson (Luther) together with Steinar Bryn of the NCPD, who has a long relationship with Luther College and has twice been nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize for the Nansen Center's work in peace dialog. This course has been approved by the Russian Studies Board to fulfill one elective in the Russian Studies minor/major. Pending approval of the proposed changes to the Scandinavian Studies program, it could fulfill one course in the major/minor.

name: SCST-339
title: Special Topic:Peace and ReconciliationyDialog in Norway and the Balkans
desc: Norway is well known as a world leader in peace studies. This course will focus on the work of Norway's Nansen Center for Peace and Dialog (NCPD). The NCPD works in peace education for refugees in Norway and in dialog/reconciliation projects in deeply segregated societies in the world. This course involves residency in Lillehammer at the NCPD to learn about peace and reconciliation dialog, issues in contemporary Norway, and the history of ethnic, religious, and political conflict in the Balkan Peninsula. After residency in Lillehammer and time in Oslo, we will travel to the Western Balkans to Nansen Dialog Centers in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition to smaller cities, students will experience two capitals (Sarajevo in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Belgrade in Serbia). This course is offered by Laurie Iudin-Nelson (Luther) together with Steinar Bryn of the NCPD, who has a long relationship with Luther College and has twice been nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize for the Nansen Center's work in peace dialog. This course has been approved by the Russian Studies Board to fulfill one elective in the Russian Studies minor/major. Pending approval of the proposed changes to the Scandinavian Studies program, it could fulfill one course in the major/minor.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar:Literary Transmissions and TomyMcCarthy
desc: The course focuses on work by the rising contemporary writer, Tom McCarthy and on the matters of literary transmissions that feature in his novels. The British novelist Zadie Smith has suggested that McCarthy is THE writer shaping the novel today.  We will read McCarthy's novels--Remainder, Men in Space, and C, as well as his book-length work of literary criticism, Tintin and the Secret of Literature.  In addition to McCarthy's own writing, we'll read and screen texts that he invokes intertextually--these range from Sigmund Freud's "Wolfman" case to Jean Cocteau's film, Orpheus.  McCarthy's novels are deeply engaged with thinking about technologies and transmission--about literature and the histories and narratives of communication technologies. Within this broad engagement, the novels offer students research project prospects relating to various matters of techno-culture, aesthetics, economics and literature, death and literature, notions of authenticity, and love.

name: CHEM-185
title: Food for Thought: The Nature of ayHealthy Diet
desc: This course will take a critical look at diets (low-fat vs low-carb); the research of Ancel Keys, which led to the establishment of the USDA food pyramid; and the role of food science in the development of "irrestible" foods.  Students will examine health and nutrition claims with the goal of understanding the fundamentals of the argument and to discern whether or not a claim is validated scientifically.  The role of drugs to treat nutrition-related illnesses (like diabetes and high cholesterol) will be included.

name: COMS-247
title: Electronic News Gathering
desc: In the modern technological environment, journalists construct the news for a variety of media in a style that is fast-paced, visual, and highly standardized.  This project-based course explores the process of establishing a story focus, gathering appropriate audio and video, scripting, presentation, and final editing to produce spot news packages.  At the same time, students will be challenged to critique both the process, as well as the structure of the news industry, and to consider social, legal, ethical, and aesthetic issues that affect audience perceptions of newsworthy events. Offered alternate years.

name: MATH-239
title: Special Topic:Mathematical Methods inyBiology
desc: This course will examine a variety of ways that mathematical methods can be brought to bear on biological phenomena.  Topics chosen will depend on student interest, and may include food webs, disease etiology, gene regulatory networks, disease transmission dynamics, phylogeny, metabolism, natural selection in haploid and diploid populations, and others.  Mathematical methods used may be drawn from graph theory, linear algebra, differential equations, or others, but no previous familiarity in these areas will be assumed.

name: THE-339
title: Auditions
desc: This class focuses entirely on moments of solo performance: monologues, solo songs, and auditions. In this class students will build on the foundational work actors put into freeing their expressivity, strengthening the creative interplay of body, voice, intellect, and emotion. Furthermore, students will learn to build complete characters through thorough analysis of a play's text. Students will develop the specific techniques for auditioning for plays (musical and nonmusical), including monologue selection, song preparation, resume writing, and crafting a full scene in a compressed time. Emphasis will be placed on putting together an audition that demonstrates the actor's craft. Students will find and develop audition material throughout the course, their work culminating in a polished audition package. The class will also investigate techniques for handling a variety of audition and callback scenarios. In these scenarios students will learn to collaborate quickly with other actors and in response to suggestions from a director. Finally, this class will deepen the actor's script analysis skills as they explore contemporary and verse texts.

name: FCUL-251
title: Topics in Nordic Film
desc: The course will offer viewing and discussion of films of various genres, directors and time periods of Norway and other Nordic countries.  Topics will change annually and rotate.  Students may enroll in the course multiple times for credit (and count towards the major/minor in Nordic Studies), provided that the topic is new.  The course is taught in English, readings are in English, and films are subtitled in English.  Students who have completed SCST 202 may elect to enroll in SCST 251 for extra assignments in Norwegian.

name: SCST-251
title: Topics in Nordic Film
desc: The course will offer viewing and discussion of films of various genres, directors and time periods of Norway and other Nordic countries.  Topics will change annually and rotate. Students may enroll in the course multiple times for credit (and count towards the major/minor in Nordic Studies), provided that the topic is new.  The course is taught in English, readings are in English, and films are subtitled in English.  Students who have completed SCST 202 may elect to enroll in this course for extra assignments in Norwegian.

name: FCUL-350
title: Topics in Russian/Soviet Literature
desc: This course will offer reading and discussion of literature of various genres, authors and time periods of Russia and the USSR. Topics will change annually and rotate.  Students may enroll in the course multiple times for credit (and count towards the major/minor in Russian Studies), provided that the topic is new.  The course is taught in English and readings and writing assignments are in English.  Advanced Russian language students who have completed RUS 202 may elect to enroll in RUS 350 for supplementary assignments in Russian. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: RUS-350
title: Topics in Russian/Soviet Literature
desc: This course will offer reading and discussion of literature of various genres, authors and time periods of Russia and the USSR.  Topics will change annually and rotate.  Students may enroll in the course multiple times for credit (and count towards the major/minor in Russian Studies), provided that the topic is new.  The course is taught in English and readings and writing assignments are in English.  Students without background in Russian language should enroll in FCUL 350. Russian language students who have completed the prerequisite of RUS 202 may elect to enroll in this course, rather than FCUL 350, for supplementary assignments in Russian. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: POLS-239
title: Special Topic:Brazil, the World Cup,yand Development:Connecting Soccer,yPolitics, and Economics
desc: Brazilians like to joke that "Brazil is the country of tomorrow, and will always be." However, this last decade has shown that "tomorrow" may have finally arrived in Brazil. Now a stable democracy and a rising economic power, Brazil is hosting two of the biggest sporting events in the world: the 2014 FIFA World Cup and the 2016 Olympics. This course uses the preparations for the 2014 World Cup as the backdrop for a discussion of important themes regarding Brazil's political and economic development. Participants will visit four of the host cities, the stadiums to be used during the World Cup, and learn about the improvements made throughout these cities in preparations for the event. As we visit these cities participants will also learn about themes/topics that are essential to understanding Brazil's rise as a regional superpower, including: the recent oil discoveries, the agricultural boom, environmental consequences of development, corruption (especially in relation to World Cup projects), inequality, among other important topics.

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topic:Explorations in HispanicyCulture
desc: This course will study the Spanish-speaking world through its cultural manifestations: language, literature, film, arts, television, music and the news media.  Several topics will be offered on a rotating basis: cinema, social revolution, and the arts, Hispanics in the U.S., current events, popular music and poetry, Spanish and Latin American civilizations.  May be repeated up to two times for credit under different topics.

name: SCST-250
title: Topics in Nordic Literature
desc: This course will offer reading and discussion of literature of various genres, authors and time periods of Norway and other Nordic countries.  Topics will change annually and rotate. Students may enroll in the course multiple times for credit (and count towards the major/minor in Nordic Studies), provided that the topic is new.  The course is taught in English and readings are in English.  Students who have completed SCST 202 may elect to enroll in this course for extra assignments in Norwegian.

name: FCUL-250
title: Topics in Nordic Literature
desc: This course will offer reading and discussion of literature of various genres, authors and time periods of Norway and other Nordic countries.  Topics will change annually and rotate. Students may enroll in the course multiple times for credit (and count towards the major/minor in Nordic Studies), provided that the topic is new.  The course is taught in English and readings are in English.  Students who have completed SCST 202 may elect to enroll in SCST 250 for extra assignments in Norwegian.

name: FCUL-363
title: Norway's Nobel Prize-Winning Authors
desc: Through the lives and literature of Nobel Prize-winning authors, Bjornstjerne Bjornson, Knut Hamsun, and Sigrid Undset, the history of Norway unfolds with its struggles and triumphs from the Middle Ages through Norway's World War II occupation by Hitler's forces. Reading selected works and viewing films based on them, as well as researching the authors' lives and times, students will gain an understanding of the highlights of Norway's history and literary production. All readings and discussion are in English.  Advanced Norwegian language students may enroll in SCST 363 for additional coursework in Norwegian. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: FCUL-361
title: Henrik Ibsen
desc: Norway's preeminent playwright, Henrik Ibsen, lived most of his life outside of his homeland, which he nevertheless observed with unmatched acuity. The course follows Ibsen's development as a dramatist while also exploring the cultural context of his time. The course includes recent film productions of selected plays and an opportunity to experience an Ibsen play as performed by the Commonweal Theater in Lanesboro, MN.  All readings and discussions are in English. Students who have completed SCST 202 may elect to enroll in SCST 361 for additional coursework in Norwegian. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: CS-296
title: Writing in the Major Lab
desc: A companion to any of CS 320, 330, 352, 353, 360, 370, 420, 430, 440, or 450. Students wishing to delve deeper into a subject in one of the companion courses may register for this lab with consent of instructor.  A student taking this lab will be required to write a technical paper in the style typical of a computer science journal or conference proceedings, on a topic agreed to by the companion course instructor.  Feedback will be provided on writing style and content with the paper going through multiple revisions.  Students receiving a C or better on their paper will fulfill the writing in the major requirement. Students may register for this as a seven week lab anytime prior to the middle of the semester in which the companion course is taught. Requires consent of instructor.

name: SW-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Involvement in a research project under the supervision of department faculty. Recommended for students who expect to attend graduate school. Prerequisites and requirements vary by department.

name: SCST-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Can only be taken during fall, spring, or summer terms.

name: AS-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Capstone course for the Asian Studies minor.

name: CLAS-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar. Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed projects is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department. All projects must be presented publicly. Only projects awarded an "A- or A" qualify for "department honors" designation. The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: NURS-234
title: Pathways to Practice I
pre_req: Admission to nursing major. BIO 115, 116, 152, HLTH 125
desc: First of two courses focusing on assessment, health promotion and communication skills; development and application of cognitive and psychomotor skills to perform systematic, holistic, and culturally sensitive assessments with an emphasis on the application of clinical reasoning.  This course facilitates the acquistion of knowledge for the liberal arts, sciences and nursing as the foundation of professional nursing practice.

name: NURS-374
title: Behaviorial Health Care
desc: Basic theories and concepts related to psychiatric-mental health care of children, adolescents, adults and older adults are examined.  Emphasis is placed on the biopsychosocial/physiologic basis for mental health care and provides knowledge necessary for a beginning practitioner.  Primary emphasis is given to mental health promotion and to the treatment of commonly occurring mental health concerns and illnesses.

name: NURS-376
title: Behavioral Health Care Clinical
desc: Application of theories and concepts related to the care of psychiatric clients.  Emphasis on knowledge of nursing and pharmacological management as well as advanced communication skills provide the basis of the clinical experiences in psychiatric nursing necessary for preparation as a beginning practitioner.

name: NURS-235
title: Pathways to Practice I Clinical
desc: First of two clinical courses focusing on the development of communication and assessment skills and selective application of cognitive and psychomotor skills for the safe care of adult patients in long term care settings.

name: SCI-240
title: Pathophysiology
desc: This course offers a foundation in understanding the molecular, cellular/tissue, and organ system changes that are present in numerous disease states and injuries.  Mechanisms and etiologies of selected pathophysiological processes will be utilized to understand the evidence of disease and its clinical manifestations.  These principles will enable the student to frame clinical problems through the critical thinking process.

name: SCI-250
title: Clinical Pharmacology
desc: This course provides a basic understanding of pharmacology as a foundation for clinical education in the appropriate and safe use of medications.  Fundamental concepts including pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics and pharmacogenetics will be covered along with an in-depth analysis of important medication classifications.  The laboratory component of the course will provide opportunities to apply pharmacological knowledge in a context that realistically models patient care.

name: NURS-236
title: Pathways to Practice II
desc: Second course in a series focusing on further development of assessment, health promotion and communication skills and the application of cognitive and psychomotor skills to patients experiencing common abnormalities with an emphasis on the application of clinical reasoning.

name: NURS-237
title: Pathways to Practice II Clinical
desc: Second clinical course in a series focusing on the application of cognitive and psychomotor skills on the care of adult patients with common abnormalities in a rural acute care and long term care settings.  Upon completion of this course, students will be expected to perform appropriate nursing interventions safely and effectively under direct clinical supervision.

name: NURS-370
title: Health and Healing I
desc: In this course students will develop the knowledge and skills to support adult patients experiencing alterations in health while examining values, meanings, and experience.  Focus will be on how nurses intervene in a complex care environment, with an emphasis on integrating patient education and health promotion strategies to promote healing and achieve optimal health.  Concepts will relate to acute care needs with beginning discussion related to complex chronic health care needs.

name: NURS-371
title: Health and Healing I Clinical
desc: This clinical course is meant to apply the knowledge and skills learned previously, with emphasis on developing clinical decision making abilities.  Students will practice in an adult, acute-care setting and with regular opportunity to relfect on values and experiences in order to make meaning of health and healing.

name: NURS-372
title: Health and Healing II
desc: Continuation of NURS 370, with added complexity reflected in a focus on chronic disease management in the setting of acute alterations to health.  Students will continue to build on concepts of health promotion and patient education to address discharge needs, especially as related to acute-on-chronic healthcare needs.

name: NURS-373
title: Health and Healing II Clinical
desc: This clinical course is meant to apply the knowledge and skills learned in NURS 370 with continued emphasis on developing clinical decision making abilities. Students will explore the continuum of care in both inpatient and outpatient settings with a special focus on engaging in patient education and health promotion strategies in discharge planning.

name: NURS-377
title: Family/Child Nursing
desc: This course focuses on childbearing and childrearing families, with emphasis on culturally competent and developmentally appropriate nursing care to promote healthy infant/adolescent and family function.  Concepts of family theory, family-centered care, family culture and health promotion are emphasized.

name: PHIL-100
title: Introduction to Philosophy
desc: An introduction to basic questions in philosophy concerning God, the nature of reality, knowledge and truth, human nature, morality, and the individual in society, together with the range of arguments and answers that philosophers have developed in response to them.

name: NURS-378
title: Family/Child Nursing Clinical
desc: This clinical course is meant to apply knowledge and skills learned in NURS 377 with childbearing and childrearing families.  Students will utilize clinical decision making skills, assessment and therapeutic communication.

name: NURS-382
title: Gerontological Nursing
desc: This course is designed to build upon learning in previous nursing courses with an emphasis on the aging phase of the life process.  The focus of the course is on the knowledge, attitudes, and skills needed to understand and care for the growing geriatric population.  Students will acquire understanding of the uniqueness of the health related needs of the aging population and learn to recognize the physiological, cognitive, psychological, social changes, and atypical presentations of disease associated with aging.

name: NURS-384
title: Evidence Based Practice
desc: This course emphasizes the use of research as a key component in clinical decision making for nursing practice.  Theoretical and practical components of research perspectives and the research process are discussed.  The course incorporates ethical aspects of the research process and research history.  Integration of multiple sources of evidence to guide nursing practice is analyzed.

name: NURS-386
title: Professional Nursing Practice: AyConceptual Immersion Experience
desc: This clinical course immerses students in a concept-based, systems-level analysis of the continuum of care.  This immersion allows students to work closely and collaborate with other healthcare providers to develop a conceptual understanding of how the patient experiences and the nurse contributes to the continuum of care.  Emphasis is on analysis of concepts and theories while also reflecting on leadership skills that promote quality care within a complex health care system.

name: NURS-388
title: Health Informatics
desc: This course includes the study of health informatics and information technology from consumer, clinical, and public health perspectives.  Students will analyze the use of information technology to communicate, manage knowledge, mitigate error, and support clinical decision-making.

name: NURS-390
title: Nursing Leadership in HealthyCare
desc: This course will view integrated concepts of leadership and management and advocacy, recognizing nursing as a collective profession within the larger health care delivery system.  This course will emphasize nurses' roles in promoting social justice in health care, in the context of economic, social, political, and ethical influence.  Students will understand how the health care system impacts the delivery of care, in health care organizations and direct patient care, focusing on cost, quality, safety, and access.  Historical perspectives of health care will be used to contextualize trends in nursing leadership and their role in the delivery of care.

name: NURS-420
title: Population-Based Care
desc: This course focuses on health promotion with disease and injury prevention in population groups.  Social justice principles are woven throughout course content to emphasize collective action toward improving national and international health.  With an introduction to the science of epidemiology, students will analyze health patterns of populations in connection with contextual contributing factors, such as lifestyle, social, economic, cultural, and historical perspectives.  Public health interventions are explored at individual, aggregate, and population levels.  Key focus areas of public health will be addressed including but not limited to environmental health, disaster and emergency preparedness, and political involvement.

name: NURS-421
title: Population-Based Care Clinical
desc: This clinical nursing course allows nursing students to practice public health nursing, incorporating theoretical and analytic components from NURS 420. Determinants of health are examined as students practice in collaboration with agencies and organizations, preparing students to specialize in rural public health priorities and interventions.  Emphasis is placed on the principles of public health combined with the nursing process to focus on health promotion, life-style factors, and disease prevention that facilitate the development of healthy populations, communities, families, and individuals.

name: NURS-425
title: Synthesis of Clinical Practice AcrossyThe Lifespan
desc: This course emphasizes clinical and critical reasoning skills synthesized from knowledge obtained in prior nursing courses to address fundamental to complex situations across the lifespan.  Students will engage in critical inquiry in both the classroom and simulation lab settings that is evidence based and that applies and integrates concepts associated with safe, high quality, professional nursing practice.

name: NURS-480
title: Senior Leadership Capstone
desc: This capstone course will include experiences similar to those students are likely to confront as newly employed baccalaureate prepared registered nurses.  Students will work in 1:1 experiences with baccalaureate nurse preceptors in selected clinical settings.  An emphasis is placed on the development of personal and professional strategies needed to make the transition from student to graduate nurse by highlighting role development skills of bedside nurse leaders.

name: COMS-347
title: Critical Television Studies
desc: This course examines television within the context of cultural, aesthetic, technological, textual, regulatory, social, and political practices. There are a number of intersecting aims: to trace the development of television (mainly in the United States, but with attention to global systems); to map the contours of critical TV studies; to understand theories and methods of television scholarship; to theorize television's relationship to consumer culture, history, capitalism, diversity, citizenship, everyday life, and selfhood (among other key concepts); and to entertain new directions in critical TV studies.  Because television is a medium in transition, the extent to which television remains (or has never been) a truly distinct medium, and its current relationship to media convergence, will also be considered.

name: ENG-185
title: Playing With Shakespeare
desc: In this course, we will ask what it means to "play with" Shakespeare--whether that involves staging his plays in new settings, filming his sonnets, making a comic book out of King Lear, or creating "easier" versions of his language.  As we investigate differents ways to play with the text, we'll ask deeper questions:  What does it really mean to be a cultural icon?  How does Shakespeare himself play with ideas of culture, and how does a culture play with ideas of Shakespeare?  Does something have to be original to be creative (or interesting?)  And why do we keep making new versions of Shakespeare--what's in it for us?

name: ENG-185
title: Reading Other People's Mail
desc: Why do we love opening the mailbox to find a letter addressed to us in the hand of a friend? Why do we keep letters, sometimes for years? Do letters offer something that digital texts do not, or can an email, text, or tweet be a letter? This course explores the art and the allure of the letter. Students will see how letter writers begin, maintain, and end relationships, struggle with big ideas and questions, and come to know themselves by writing to others. Readings include letters, both historical and literary, by famous and not-so-famous writers, as well as an epistolary novel, letter poems, and war letters collected in the Luther College Archives. These offer everything from gossip to politics, passion to philosophy. Students will analyze letters in papers and presentations. They also will discover what letters can teach about writing, exploring their own voices by writing to family, friends, strangers, and themselves.

name: ENG-185
title: Superpowers and Disabilities
desc: In this course, we will examine the way bodies both ordinary and extraordinary are represented in literature. We will ask: how do abilities and impairments--especially physical abilities and impairments--shape our ideas about heroes, villains, and ourselves? By reading texts that range from medieval poems to X-Men comics, we'll explore the role that literature and culture play in defining our ideas about normalcy, disability, and superiority. New understandings of physical difference will give us a useful lens for complicating our ideas about our own lives and bodies.

name: HIST-185
title: Look It Up! Using Text From HieroglyphsyTo Google
desc: From the beginnings of writing, those who have created documents have not only recorded text but also developed and employed a variety of techniques and tools to help readers use that text. Students in this course will explore how changes in the technologies of and ideas about document production have altered how people record, use, and understand information. They will investigate the history and "archaeology" of the book from antiquity through the present, and they will gain hands-on experience in assessing and using sources of information by exploring and reporting on print and electronic databases and other sources covering historical topics of interest to them. Students also will have direct experiences with both a copy of the Bible that was printed in 1498 and a facsimile of the famous Gutenberg bible of 1455, and they will explore many digitized examples of handwritten illuminated manuscripts and printed texts drawn from libraries and archives around the world, including such works as the Lindisfarne Gospels and the Book of Kells.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic:From Muscle to Machine:yIndustrialization and Its Effects
desc: During the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, an economic revolution occurred in Western Europe that changed the way people worked and made things. Commonly referred to as the "Industrial Revolution," this transformation also drastically altered the political, social, and environmental landscape of Europe. In this course, we will survey the process of industrialization from its origins in England to its adoption on the European continent. We will also explore industrialization's effects on major European historical developments, including the founding of political ideologies such as Marxism, the creation of welfare policies, formation of the working class, and alterations of family life. We will examine primary sources--including political manifestos, art, parliamentary hearings, laws, oral histories and diaries--and secondary sources in order to investigate the broad impact industrialization had on European history.

name: MATH-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. MATH 295 only offered during the fall, spring, or summer terms.

name: HIST-262
title: Everybody Loves Gandhi
desc: M. K. Gandhi remains the Indian most indelibly associated with India, one of the most frequently-quoted thinkers of all time, and one of the most important figures in developing the theory and practice of non-violent resistance. However, Gandhi's ideas and philosophy have managed to become detached from the historical context in which they were created, and indeed from the human being who created them. This course examines Gandhi's life, political positions, and political legacies in India and globally, in an effort to re-evaluate his achievements and failures, to place his life within the broader historical context of India in the early twentieth century, and to consider the reasons why some people, since his death, have variously beatified and demonized the man and his ideas.

name: MUS-185
title: Hollywood's Soundtrack: Great SymphonicyFilm Music
desc: This course explores the role of symphonic film music in the history of American cinema. We will study approximately 10 representative films from the 1930's through the present day that are remarkable for the ways in which the composed soundtrack enhances the viewer's experience. We will encounter classic scores by Korngold, Waxman, Herrmann, Goldsmith, and Williams, among others. The course will include opportunities for both scholarly and creative responses to the ideas we encounter. Previous musical study is helpful but not essential.

name: REL-185
title: Religion and Media
desc: This course examines depictions of religion (particularly Judaism, Christianity, and Islam) within television, film, music, and print media. Students learn how to check the accuracy of media depictions of religious beliefs and practices. Students also question whose interests are being advanced by these depictions. The course challenges students to become critical consumers of media and to understand how religion and media construct and critique each other.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topic:Interpreting BiblicalyTexts through Movement
desc: This course seeks to interpret texts of the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament through the use of movement and dance. Students will read and analyze selected biblical texts in their historical, social, and political contexts and use movement to construct interpretations of these particular texts. The use of movement and dance will help students create interpretations from different perspectives leading to a deeper reflection and will begin to address the ethical and moral issues relevant to our contemporary context.

name: REL-239
title: ST:Paul and His Interpreters
desc: This course studies the legacy of the Apostle Paul. Students extensively engage the New Testament letters purportedly written by Paul along with canonical and apocryphal texts written about him. Important considerations include Paul's relation to Jesus' teachings and his disciples; Paul's relation to Judaism, its Scriptures, and its Temple; and Paul's relation to Greco-Roman philosophy and religion as well as Roman imperial authority. Additional topics may include theological interpretations of Paul (for example, by Martin Luther in the Reformation) and reinterpretations of Paul in contemporary philosophy.

name: REL-239
title: St:reading the New Testemen Eyes MarginyThrough the Eyes of the Marginalized
desc: This course will introduce students to the different ways in which New Testament texts are read and interpreted among marginalized communities. Students will get a glimpse of the various contextual theologies that marginalized communities use to construct interpretations that are meaningful and address the social, political, and ethical issues present in their immediate context. By engaging voices from the margins, students will have the opportunity to construct interpretations that are multicultural and could speak to a wider audience.

name: INTS-185
title: Islam and the West: A Clash ofyCivilizations?
desc: Are Islam and the West engaged in a "clash of civilizations," an inevitable conflict driven by irreconcilable cultural and religious differences? In recent decades, and particularly since 9/11, politicians, religious leaders, and scholars have vigorously debated this question. This seminar explores this contemporary debate through an analysis of Muslim and Western texts and attention to the following questions: What explains the violent conflicts between Muslim and Western peoples and societies from the Crusades to the War on Terror? Is Islam compatible with democracy, or is democracy the preserve of the West? What drives the common perceptions in the Muslim and Western worlds that the "Other" exploits and oppresses women? Why has the integration of Muslim minority communities in parts of the West been so difficult? How have Christian-Muslim interactions both hindered and facilitated the relationship between Islam and the West?

name: INTS-301
title: Science and Policy
desc: The course examines the ways scientific knowledge and practice inform policy decisions, primarily in the United States.  At the core of the course is an investigation of how scientific understanding is generated, how that understanding is passed to policy makers use that understanding in pursuit of the common good.  The course also examines how public support for science influences the scientific knowledge available to contribute to policy decisions.  Examples of current, proposed and past policies will be used throughout the course.

name: ANTH-339
title: Special Topic:Anthropology ofyGlobalization and Social Change
desc: This class explores globalization though anthropological lens, paying special attention to the gendered nature of the rapid flow of capital, people, goods, images, and ideologies across national boundaries.  We will contextualize the large-scale political, economic, and cultural processes in the everyday realities of particular societies and everyday experiences of regular people.  In other words, this course will study globalization from below.  We will address questions such as how do men and women around the world mediate the processes of globalization?  How do they understand them?  How is globalization implicated in their wellbeing, occupations, family lives, intimacies, futures?  In addition, students will be challenged to think about the interactions between the issues of social justice, human rights, and the anthropological dedication to cultural rights of the populations they study.

name: WGST-339
title: Special Topic:Anthropology ofyGlobalization and Social Change
desc: This class explores globalization though anthropological lens, paying special attention to the gendered nature of the rapid flow of capital, people, goods, images, and ideologies across national boundaries.  We will contextualize the large-scale political, economic, and cultural processes in the everyday realities of particular societies and everyday experiences of regular people.  In other words, this course will study globalization from below.  We will address questions such as how do men and women around the world mediate the processes of globalization?  How do they understand them?  How is globalization implicated in their wellbeing, occupations, family lives, intimacies, futures?  In addition, students will be challenged to think about the interactions between the issues of social justice, human rights, and the anthropological dedication to cultural rights of the populations they study.

name: BIO-358
title: Toxicology
pre_req: BIO 151, 152, and BIO 255 or BIO 252 or CHEM 241.
desc: This course covers the principles of toxicology, the study of poisons.  Topics include molecular and cellular sites of toxicant action, physiological effects of toxicants in mammalian systems and ecological systems, and the application of toxicology to public health and policy.  Central toxicology concepts such as dose-response, mixtures, gene-environment interaction, and endocrine/reproductive toxicity will be explored in the laboratory culminating in student-designed research projects and scientific papers. It is recommended that students have completed CHEM 152 or 201 before enrollin in this course. Lectures and laboratory.

name: MGT-239
title: Special Topic:Business Writing andyCommunication
desc: This course introduces the fundamentals of writing for business through practical application of the principles of effective communication.  Students will draft, revise and present a range of useful business documents.  Topics examined include organization, drafting, editing, peer review, audience attention, and development of oral/written presentation skills.  Throughout the course, students will begin to build individual professional portfolios, completing job search/inquiry letters, emails/memos, presentations and a research proposal.  Students who have earned credit for Communication Studies 252 "Business Communication" cannot register for this course.

name: SOC-239
title: Special Topic:Sociology of Health andyMedicine
desc: This course introduces students to the social, political, and economic context of health and illness in society.  The course is divided into four parts.  First we focus on social factors and illness, with a particular focus on the role of inequality in shaping health risks.  We will discuss how we measure and quantify mortality and morbidity and the effect of social context.  In the second part of the semester we focus on the meaning and experience of illness, with a particular focus on how different kinds of social deviance are categorized as medical, criminal, or personal issues in different societies and at different times.  Next the course will focus on health systems and technologies, especially the political and economic configurations of health care provision in different countries.  Finally, the course will consider the role of health professionals and issues of bioethics, with a focus on the medical profession in the United States as a case study.

name: SOC-283
title: Sociology of Education
desc: This course provides a broad overview of the field of sociology of education and its goal is to understand the relationship between education and society.  This course reviews a variety of theoretical perspectives and empirical research to examine the role and structure of schooling in contemporary life.  Topics include social mobility and stratification; social reproduction and meritocracy; social and cultural capital; the dynamics of race, class and gender in American higher education; the social processes and factors affecting students' academic achievement; horizontal and vertical stratification of higher education.  Students will better understand their own experience within educational system, as well as the relationship between educational system and inequality in American society.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topic:Global Christianities
desc: This course considers the theological diversity and geographical spread of contemporary Christian traditions (Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholic, and Protestantism including Pentecostals/Charismatics).  Topics may include how Christians understand the economy (e.g., liberation theology and the prosperity gospel), the media, (e.g., televangelism), politics (e.g., nationalism, immigration, persecution), public health (e.g., HIV/AIDS), and religious identity.

name: INTS-185
title: Faith and Reason
desc: What is faith, and what does it have to do with reason? Are they opposed? Is one a substitute for the other? Are they directed at different kinds of claims? Can they support each other or work together? Is one better than the other? Is this what distinguishes science from religion? To explore the ongoing debate about the meaning and relation of faith and reason, this seminar will introduce philosophical theories about knowledge, examine historical and contemporary approaches to these questions in multiple religious traditions, and consider how our understanding of the nature of science might relate to these issues.

name: ENVS-185
title: Sustainable Cities?
desc: From the glistening desert skyscrapers of Dubai to the rainy streets of Seattle, more than half of all people on the planet live in an urban area. By 2050, this ratio will increase to 7 out of 10 people. Given this demographic trend, it becomes difficult, if not impossible to think about environmental sustainability without paying close attention to our cities. Can we think of cities as complex, living organisms that survive in deserts, tropical rainforests and icy tundra? Are cities good or evil? How can cities be more sustainable? This course offers an introduction to environmental sustainability through the lens of the city with a focus on case studies of specific cities and their challenges and sustainability initiatives. Through readings, discussions, debates, presentations and day trips we will seek to understand the increasingly important role of the city in human society and for the planet and what possibilities the future may hold for us.

name: ENVS-185
title: Dinosaurs!
desc: How smart were dinosaurs? How fast could they run? How did they evolve? How can we even know these things about dinosaurs in the first place? In this course we will explore the evolution, life, and extinction of the dinosaurs. We will also discuss misconceptions about paleontology, pop culture representations of dinosaurs, and the reporting of paleontological discoveries in the news media. We will also analyze scientific publications and talk with dinosaur paleontologists to better understand how paleontologists can make inferences about dinosaurs and their environment.

name: AFRS-371
title: Topics in African History:"A RevolutionyBetrayed?" Nationalism in South Africayand Zimbabwe
desc: This class is an in depth examination of nationalism in Southern Africa.  The aim is to probe the deep complexities of Southern Africa's nationalist history including European conquest, early attempts at anti-colonial liberation, emergence of mass movements such as Nelson Mandela's ANC and Robert Mugabe's ZANU (PF), their ideological underpinnings including their relation to the United States and the Soviet Union, and the implications of national independence.  Several of our readings (which include autobiographies from Nelson Mandela and Robert Mugabe) will help students understand the legacy of white rule and the unfulfilled dreams of ordinary men and women who participated in the anti-apartheid struggle.  This course will be taught through a combination of discussion, lecture, selected historical documents, and films.  This course satisfies requirements for Africana Studies and History. (Same as HIST 371)

name: HIST-371
title: Topics in African History:"A RevolutionyBetrayed?" Nationalism in South Africayand Zimbabwe
desc: This class is an in depth examination of nationalism in Southern Africa.  The aim is to probe the deep complexities of Southern Africa's nationalist history including European conquest, early attempts at anti-colonial liberation, emergence of mass movements such as Nelson Mandela's ANC and Robert Mugabe's ZANU (PF), their ideological underpinnings including their relation to the United States and the Soviet Union, and the implications of national independence.  Several of our readings (which include autobiographies from Nelson Mandela and Robert Mugabe) will help students understand the legacy of white rule and the unfulfilled dreams of ordinary men and women who participated in the anti-apartheid struggle.  This course will be taught through a combination of discussion, lecture, selected historical documents, and films.  This course satisfies requirements for Africana Studies and History. (Same as AFRS 371)

name: HIST-290
title: Gender and Women's History:Speaking foryOurselves: The History of African-yAmerican Women
desc: Is Beyonce in control of her own image, or is her image dictated by the media surrounding her and the audience consuming her music and videos?  The answers to this question can only be understood within the full context of U.S. history.  For the past three hundred years, African-American women have struggled to define themselves in the face of persistent stereotyping by the national media, slave-owners, black men, and white women.  This class will examine primary sources from black women about their lives, as well as historical monographs about the time periods in which black women lived.  We will discuss the periods from the slave era to the modern hip-hop era.  Students will be expected to present and lead discussion, read the weekly materials, and participate in a class-wide research project.

name: WGST-290
title: Gender and Women's History:Speaking foryOurselves:The History of African-yAmerican Women
desc: Is Beyonce in control of her own image, or is her image dictated by the media surrounding her and the audience consuming her music and videos?  The answers to this question can only be understood within the full context of U.S. history.  For the past three hundred years, African-American women have struggled to define themselves in the face of persistent stereotyping by the national media, slave-owners, black men, and white women.  This class will examine primary sources from black women about their lives, as well as historical monographs about the time periods in which black women lived.  We will discuss the periods from the slave era to the modern hip-hop era.  Students will be expected to present and lead discussion, read the weekly materials, and participate in a class-wide research project.

name: MUS-439
title: 18th Century Counterpoint
desc: A study of the 18th century tonal counterpoint style of J.S. Bach. Written exercises lead to the composition and performance of intrumental canons, inventions and fugues.

name: HIST-321
title: Topics in US History:The US and theyCold War
desc: No other event of the twentieth century - not the Great Depression, the Second World War, the Civil Rights Movement -- shaped American history, politics and culture more than the Cold War.  The Cold War created a world divided and dominated by two ideologically opposed and antagonistic world powers, each possessing enough weaponry to destroy human civilization several times over.  The US and western European democracies exchanged economic, diplomatic, military and psychological threats with the Soviet Union and its satellites from 1945 to 1991 when the latter collapsed.  Periods of detente alternated with periods of high political drama.  Open war between the US and the Soviets nearly broke out on several occasions, including the Berlin Blockade of 1948-49, the Berlin Crisis of 1961, and the Cuban Missile Crisis of 1962.  In addition, wars in Korea, Vietnam and Afghanistan, plus a variety of smaller conflicts, saw the two superpowers resorting to indirect war by proxy states to achieve their desired ends.  The course focuses on the US role in these events as well as the impact of the Cold War on American culture

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History:PopularyReligion and the State in ReformationyAge
desc: This course explores the changes and conflicts that arose in Europe around issues of traditional or "popular" religious practices and states' oversight of those practices as the result of the religious reformations of the sixteenth century. Students will read and discuss a variety of primary and secondary sources related to popular religion (including folk religion and witchcraft) and to the church and secular authorities who tried to control and change others' religious behavior. Research into specific topics and questions of their own choosing will allow students to investigate the webs of power and authority that connected church, state, and people in early modern Europe.

name: HIST-485
title: Jr/Sr Seminar:History of theyFamily in Modern Europe
desc: This seminar will explore the history of the family in modern Europe.  During the first part of the course students will read some of the most important scholarship that has defined this area of historical investigation, including examples of childhood history, social history,gender history.  Students will discover the variety of approaches to the topic of the history of the family, while developing a research project in a case of their choice.  This study will result in a journal-length article and an oral presentation of their research.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures:Literature andyMedicine
desc: How do race, culture and gender influence experiences of the medical establishment--and how do literary genres portray illness in different ways?  In this course, we'll examine the treatment of medical issues in a range of genres, from journalistic reporting to memoir, poetry, short stories, and a play.  As we do so, we'll ask how literary texts expose new facets of the experience of illness, and how these facets are influenced by cultural factors.  We'll also explore the relationship between the body and the soul in these texts--asking how illness (and health) contribute to a picture of our overall humanity.

name: PHIL-200
title: Ancient Philosophy
desc: An examination of the development of philosophy among the Greek speaking peoples and the civilizations they influenced. Primary focus will be on the thought of Plato and Aristotle as the major founders of western philosophical thought, with a brief review of subsequent developments in Hellenistic and Roman philosophy.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar:John Donne and George Herbert:ySelf-representation and its discontent
desc: Renaissance poets, with their consciousness of world as stage, relished the creation of extravagant poetic personae.  But what cost does this theatricality have for pinning down and expressing a true inward state?  Especially when a poet seeks to present himself honestly to God, theatricality undermines the effort.  This seminar will investigate the ways in which two poets approached the challenge of self-knowledge and self-representation.  John Donne was a courtier, scholar, ladies' man, pastor, a poet of metaphysical wit and keen religious insight.  George Herbert similarly sought political advancement and then turned to the ministry; he left what some consider the finest body of religious lyrics in English.

name: ENVS-485
title: Urbanism & Sustainable Development
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: What sets communities apart economically, culturally, and ecologically? What constitutes sustainable development?  In this capstone course, we will seek answers to these questions using international case studies, stakeholder interviews and field trips to regional communities.  Students will engage in hands on research through individual and group research projects in order to gain a deeper understanding of the best practices and successful models of development that shape sustainable communities.

name: ART-118
title: Beginning Digital Photography
desc: This course combines lectures with hands-on experience in digital photography.  Instruction includes technical aspects of digital photography, including camera function, exposure control, and creative control, as well as discussion on the contemporary and historical impact of the medium.  The format of the class includes lectures, visual presentations, lab time, individual research/presentations and a portfolio.  A personal DSLR camera is highly recommended.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar: Mudbloods, Centaurs,yAnd Demigods: How Interfaith FamiliesyAre Changing Our Religious Identities
pre_req: Take 3 courses from Religion or consent of instructor.
desc: "Mudbloods, Centaurs, and Demigods: How Interfaith Families are Changing our Religious Identities" As we move further into the 21st century, more and more of us are crossing religious boundaries as we enter into relationships and have children. While sociologists have been tracking this development for some time, and psychologists and therapists have more recently begun to consider the implications for their clients, scholars in religion have been slow enter the conversation.  In this course, we will examine the phenomenon from an interdisciplinary perspective, exploring the impact of interfaith relationships  on the ways we are being religious as well as religions themselves.

name: THE-185
title: Sem: Filmmaking Labortory
desc: An introduction to the principles of visual storytelling with special focus on narrative script elements, shot size/shot selection and the pre-visualization process. Students will move one visual exercise and one short film through all stages of production: preproduction, production and postproduction.

name: THE-222
title: Acting: Shakespeare
desc: Acting Shakespeare begins with the premise that a deeper understanding of Shakespeare's works is reached in performing them.  This course will place an emphasis on freeing the voice for use as a primary vehicle for conveying meaning.  Students will develop tools for analyzing, speaking and embodying Shakespeare's text.  Students will analyze and perform scenes while investigating the plays from which they are selected.  Learning the structure of the text will enable students to use it as a springboard for action, emotion, and character.

name: PAID-450
title: Reconciliation in South Africa
desc: This course will examine how South Africans are attempting to overcome their tortured past by examining it and facing squarely the implications of human rights abuses that occurred during apartheid and the violent struggle to topple it. In the course of three weeks in Johannesburg, Kwazulu Natal, East London, and Cape Town areas, students will meet with survivors of apartheid violence, politicians, journalists and reporters who covered the work of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, judicial officials and religious leaders who ran it, and individuals who bared their pasts to the Commission either in search of the truth or in an attempt to receive amnesty from it. Prereq: consent of instructor.

name: BIO-139
title: Genetics and Society
desc: Genetics plays an ever increasing role in our society, and a basic understanding of this field is vital for all students, not just biologists. In this course, students will explore how the current and future use of genetics can impact their health, safety, and environment. We will begin with basic coverage of the science of genetics, including the structure, expression, and transmission of heritable information. We will also learn about common techniques such as gene cloning and DNA fingerprinting to gain greater insight into how scientists actually use genetic technology. The bulk of the course will be dedicated to examining the uses of genetics in four main areas: 1) health and medicine; 2) forensics; 3) agriculture; and 4) ecology/evolution. Along the way, we will discuss the ethical, legal, and social questions surrounding issues as diverse as reviving extinct species, creating genetically modified organisms, and screening human embryos for genetic traits. Field trips will enable students to visit with scientists involved in each of the four main areas listed above.

name: INTS-130
title: Scholars Colloquium
desc: This is a 1-credit course that provides small-group discussions of readings, of local or national current events, or of the amazing cultural and intellectual events available on campus. Some sections of the colloquium focus on a particular theme for the semester; others range more broadly to include attendance at such events as lectures (by Luther faculty members and visiting scholars and dignitaries), concerts (ranging from classical to jazz to contemporary), theatre and dance performances, poetry readings, and art shows. The various sections of Scholars Colloquium are taught by faculty members from across the curriculum.

name: PHIL-220
title: Early Modern Philosophy
desc: An examination of the development of modern European philosophy. Primary focus will be on the formation of scientific philosophies in the 17th and 18th centuries and upon the synthesis of these views in Kant's philosophy.

name: ANTH-239
title: Special Topic: Women and IndigenousyReligions
desc: This course will focus on indigenous religions, which are traditions based on oral traditions rather than on written law and sacred texts. Indigenous religions far from becoming extinct, are quite complex, vary from culture to culture and have been affected considerably by change. In several of these traditions, indigenous women are central figures and are the main religious specialists entrusted with transmitting rituals and practices to future generations. Throughout the course we will explore issues of power, healing, and spirituality, the multifaceted tensions between indigenous traditions and gender and the genealogy of positions of authority in religion and spirituality. In addition we will look at examples of indigenous women as agents for social justice and the creation of an "indigenous spirituality." Through mainly ethnographic studies that weave together multiple women's voices we will appreciate that indigenous religions, with their women specialists, are still a source of inspiration for millions of women and men. (Students may use this course to fulfill either the second Religion requirement or the Human Behavior requirement, but not both.)

name: INTS-350
title: Civic Engagement
desc: This one-credit colloquuim is a project-driven course designed to inspire participation in the communities in which we live and to encourage students to use their knowledge and passion to live out Luther College's mission to "serve with distinction for the common good."  The objective of this course will be to identify and understand a local or global challenge and tackle a piece of it.
