Students will collaborate to research a problem, design an action plan, carry out a project, and report on their project and its outcomes.

name: WGST-239
title: Special Topic:Women and IndigenousyReligions
desc: This course will focus on indigenous religions, which are traditions based on oral traditions rather than on written law and sacred texts. Indigenous religions far from becoming extinct, are quite complex, vary from culture to culture and have been affected considerably by change. In several of these traditions, indigenous women are central figures and are the main religious specialists entrusted with transmitting rituals and practices to future generations. Throughout the course we will explore issues of power, healing, and spirituality, the multifaceted tensions between indigenous traditions and gender and the genealogy of positions of authority in religion and spirituality. In addition we will look at examples of indigenous women as agents for social justice and the creation of an "indigenous spirituality." Through mainly ethnographic studies that weave together multiple women's voices we will appreciate that indigenous religions, with their women specialists, are still a source of inspiration for millions of women and men. (Students may use this course to fulfill either the second Religion requirement or the Human Behavior requirement, but not both.)

name: INTS-201
title: Scientific Perspectives
desc: This course examines the major developments in physical science (specifically astronomy and physics) over recorded history. Students will engage with the key concepts from the scientific fields of astronomy, classical physics, relativity, quantum mechanics, and cosmology, and will consider the nature of scientific inquiry. Throughout the semester, students will also use philosophical and historical approaches to address the question "What is science?".

name: PAID-450
title: Environmental Politics and Policy
desc: This paideia 450 course is open only to students who completed the J-term Biology 140,240. Their experiences in that course will provide them with case studies to tie to the theoretical framework developed in Political Science 258,'Environmental Politics and Policy' (content covered in this course). Students will identify and evaluate both current and proposed policies for addressing environmental issues. Particular attention will be paid to the range of actors involved in the making of environmental policy and will emphasize the relationship among politics, economics, ethics, and science in the making of environmental policies in the U.S. and internationally. Students will reflect on how regulations are made despite scientific uncertainty, the role of scientists when setting policy, and the concept of scientific neutrality' in the political arena.

name: ECON-339
title: Special Topic: Economics, Information,yand the Future of Higher Education
desc: Application of microeconomic, macroeconomic, and game theortic concepts to today's "crises" in higher education.  Anchored by semester-long consideration of the "cost" and "value" of higher education today, students examine historical and contemporary arguments regarding the functions, objectives, curricula, pedagogies, and output of higher education.  Economic concepts applied will include opportunity cost, supply and demand, national income accounting, scale-free and directed networks, cooperative and non-cooperative games.  Each student will complete an individual research project and collaborate on an integrated presentation of several of those projects.

name: PHYS-339
title: Special Topic:Gravitation
desc: Mathematical and conceptual introduction to Einstein's theory of general relativity.  Mastery of the necessary tensor analysis will be carefully developed as the course progresses.  Topics include the curvature of space-time, black holes, the orbits of planets, gravitational waves, and cosmology.

name: GER-470
title: Topics in German Literature andyCulture
pre_req: GER 202 and one German course at the 300 level.
desc: Study in depth of a particular topic as seen through primary texts. The focus will vary each time, and may include topics such as women writers, social criticism, the environment, East and West, the Holocaust, German media. Significant practice in writing, including a research project. May be repeated for credit up to three times under three different topics. Offered on a rotating basis.

name: INTS-202
title: Modernity and Society
desc: Beginning in the seventeenth-century, European thinkers began to sense that a fundamentally new constellation of human institutions, ideologies, cultural practices, and personal relations was coming into being in the wake of the Renaissance and Reformation. It was characterized by phenomena such as globalization, capitalism, bureaucracy, democracy, urbanism, imperialism, the nation-state, technology, mass literacy, public opinion, and a naturalistic rather than providential view of history. The term "modernity" was developed to name the society and structures of human subjectivity resulting from these changes. While such vast transformations seem to defy description and interpretation, several of the most important social theorists in recent centuries have found patterns and meanings within these developments. This course will consist of a careful reading of some the most significant interpretations of modernity including those of Rousseau, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Freud, Adorno, Arendt, Foucault, Habermas, and Berman.

name: PHIL-120
title: Ethics
desc: A topical introduction to moral philosophy, considering both historical and contemporary developments. Topics include human nature, standards of morality, obligation and rights, justice, responsibility and freedom, character and action.

name: EDUC-367
title: Advanced Teaching Methods II-English
pre_req: Educ 366, Admission to Teacher Educ Program

name: EDUC-367
title: Advanced Teaching Methods II:Math
pre_req: EDUC-366, Admission to Teacher Educ Program

name: EDUC-367
title: Advanced Teaching Methods II;Science
pre_req: EDUC-366, Admission to Teacher Educ Program

name: EDUC-367
title: Advanced Teaching Methods II:WorldyLanguages
pre_req: EDUC-366, Admission to Teacher Educ Program

name: PE-130
title: Experiential Leadership
desc: This course will examine current and historical leadership theories and practices that have effectively instilled change in education and society. Students will explore personal leadership styles through experiential application and example. A personal leadership profile will be completed. This course is specifically designed to follow the National Outdoor Leadership School (NOLS) curriculum.

name: FREN-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Only offered during the fall, spring or summer terms.

name: WGST-485
title: Seminar:topics in Women and Gender:yStudies: Queer Theory
desc: An interdisciplinary seminar on women's social action and social change as it is understood and guided by feminist theories. The conflicts and contradictions among feminisms will be discussed and critically examined in terms of implications for the future of gender relations. Students will develop projects related to course materials.  Offered alternate spring semesters.  Prerequisites: 130 and junior standing.

name: EDUC-367
title: Advanced Teaching Methods II:SocialyStudies
pre_req: Educ 366, Admission to Teacher Educ Program

name: SW-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Can only be taken during January term.

name: WGST-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Can be taken only during Janury term.

name: PHIL-110
title: Logic
desc: A study of reasoning and argumentation, introducing formal symbol systems, including propositional and predicate logic, with attention to informal logic and fallacies.

name: GER-346
title: Introduction to German Literature:yFrom Runes to Rap
desc: Modern German literature and film often draw from significant works of their artistic predecessors. This course offers a general introduction to the principle literary forms of prose, poetry, and drama, as illustrated by some of the best known authors of the German-speaking world. Attention will be paid to increasing students' fluency in writing.

name: INTS-375
title: Directed Study
desc: Directed Study through the Intersections (Honors)  Program

name: INTS-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Directed Research through Intersections Program

name: SCST-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Can only be taken during January term.

name: SOC-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Can be taken only during January term.

name: DAN-381
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on- or off-campus work experience related to professional demands and expectations of persons and organizations involved in theatre and/or dance. Graded A-F.

name: ECON-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during the fall, spring or summer terms.

name: IS-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during January term.

name: DAN-389
title: Directed Research
desc: Involvement in research project under supervision of department faculty. Recommended for students who expect to attend graduate school.

name: CHEM-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Only offered during the fall, spring or summer terms.

name: ATHTR-381
title: Intership
desc: Supervised on- or off-campus work situations in public or private organizations. Graded A-F.

name: MUS-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during the fall, spring, or summer terms.

name: PHIL-150
title: Social and Political Philosophy
desc: An introducation to major social and political theories with focus on such concepts as obligation, law, authority, freedom, rights, justice, individual, community, ideology, and oppression.

name: CS-130
title: Fundamentals of Web Programming
desc: This course focuses on learning the basic building blocks of web programming. The student will be introduced to three languages used for web page design and implementation: HTML, CSS, and Javascript. To develop a deeper understanding of how web sites work together, the HTTP protocol will be introduced along with basic AJAX programming. The 4 credit option is available when offered during the summer. Recommended for students with an interest in computer science but no prior experience.

name: SPAN-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue inidividualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major.  Can be taken only during the fall, spring, or summer terms.

name: PAID-450
title: The Impacts of Mining and Tourism onyIndigenous Peoples and the EnvironmentyIn Northern Chile
desc: The course will take place in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile, where for millennia people have made a living in a remote and extremely arid environment.  We will examine how mining and ecotourism have affected the physical and biotic environment of the region, and how these environmental changes impact the livelihoods of indigenous peoples.  Through readings, site visits, and data analysis, students will be asked to observe and document the ways in which these industries affect the social, political, and economic conditions of the Atacameno people.

name: ECON-262
title: Development Economics
desc: This course focuses on the issues facing developing nations. We will use both theoretical and empirical methods to address questions such as: What does it mean to "develop?" Why does so much of the world's population live in extreme poverty? What are their lives like? What can be done to speed development?

name: SOC-461
title: Seminar: Contemporary Issues ofyImmigration
desc: This upper-division undergraduate seminar will provide an overview of issues related to international immigration to the United States. This class involves the sociological analysis of immigration, particularly with respect to intercultural dynamics between the sending and the receiving countries, race and ethnicity, social structure, social inequality, and social policy. Students will learn about sociological theories of immigrant incorporation as well as specific issues related to the second-generation children of immigrants including their educational, labor-market and transnational experiences. They will also learn about the history of immigration and immigration policy along with other various aspects of immigration such as transnationalism, enculturation, marginalization, globalization, gendered migration, immigrant labor market, second generation and segmented assimilation.

name: ENG-114
title: Introduction to U.S. Academic Writing
desc: This course helps students become fluent, confident, and effective writers and readers in U.S. academic culture. It strengthens skills in writing college-level essays (including thesis-driven, analytic essays), in responsible use of outside sources, and in making surface corrections and refinements. Some instruction takes place in individual conferences. Students will usually take this course concurrently with PAID 111. Student may not earn credit for both ENG 110 and ENG 114.

name: PSYC-358
title: Psychology of the Workplace
desc: This course focuses on the major research areas involved in the field of Industrial-Organizational Psychology, the scientific study of people at work. Some major topic areas include job analysis, employee selection, work stress, job attitudes, motivation, and work-life balance. Lectures, discussions, and weekly laboratories will be held. Students will be involved in original research.

name: ART-206
title: Graphic Design I
desc: This course introduces students to the use of raster and vector graphics applications as advanced art-making tools. Students will produce static 2-dimensional works of art that simultaneously explore 2-D design concepts and the cognitive processes of software learning. (Same as THE 206)

name: THE-206
title: Graphic Design I
desc: This course introduces students to the use of raster and vector graphics applications as advanced art-making tools. Students will produce static 2-dimensional works of art that simultaneously explore 2-D design concepts and the cognitive processes of software learning. (Same as ART 206)

name: ART-310
title: Ceramics II
desc: This course expands the vocabulary of ceramic materials and techniques.  Processes and techniques will be directed in individual and group projects questioning design, function and the expanding potential of sculptural outcomes.  Greater emphasis will be placed on developing individual ideas by directing the ceramic process to address concepts in contemporary art and ceramics.  This course will also delve deeper into topics of ceramic history and contemporary ceramic practices questioning the role of ceramic objects and our relationships with and to them.

name: ART-207
title: 3D Modeling and Animation
desc: Course will cover computer based 3-D animation with emphasis on creative content, experimentation and critical thinking. Advanced software and hardware will be used to explore modeling, texturing, physics simulations, and animation. Offered alternate years.

name: ART-121
title: World Pottery
desc: Geared primarily toward non-majors, this course will balance the basic mechanics of wheel thrown pottery with an exploration of global traditions and practices in functional ceramics. Offered alternate years.

name: MUS-110
title: Musicianship Workshop
desc: This course is designed to help students acquire basic musicianship skills (primarily singing, rhythm, keyboard, and notation) that will aid them in their theory and ear-training courses at Luther. It is offered as a optional one-hour supplement to Theory I (Music 121). Co-requisite: MUS 121, MUS 121L.

name: FCUL-239
title: Special Topic: Putin's Russia
desc: This course will examine the many challenges Russia currently faces in its domestic and international spheres at the current time, given the rapid economic, social and political changes since the fall of the USSR in 1991. We will focus on the historical background of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the roles of former President Boris Yeltsin and current President Vladimir Putin. Specific attention will be given to timely current events such as the unstable situation in Ukraine; the Chechen Wars, terrorism and ethnic strife in the Caucasus area; control of media; political dissent; anti-gay legislation; and the role of the Orthodox Church. The course is taught in English. Students who have completed RUS 202 may register for the course as RUS 239, and additional coursework will be completed in Russian. Either FCUL or RUS 239 will count as one elective towards the Russian Studies major or minor. No prerequisite. (Hist, Intcl)

name: PHIL-130
title: Philosophy of Religion
desc: A study of attempts to bring rational justification and clarification to religious beliefs and practice, focusing primarily on the concepts of Christian theology. Topics may include: the existence and attributes of God, faith and reason, death and immortality, miracles and revelation, the problem of evil, and religious pluralism. (Same as REL 230)

name: RUS-239
title: Special Topic: Putin's Russia
desc: This course will examine the many challenges Russia currently faces in its domestic and international spheres at the current time, given the rapid economic, social and political changes since the fall of the USSR in 1991. We will focus on the historical background of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the roles of former President Boris Yeltsin and current President Vladimir Putin. Specific attention will be given to timely current events such as the unstable situation in Ukraine; the Chechen Wars, terrorism and ethnic strife in the Caucasus area; control of media; political dissent; anti-gay legislation; and the role of the Orthodox Church. The course is taught in English. Students without a background in Russian language should register under FCUL 239. Students who have completed RUS 202 may register for the course as RUS 239, and additional coursework will be completed in Russian. Either FCUL or RUS 239 will count as one elective towards the Russian Studies major or minor. (Hist, Intcl)

name: EDUC-470
title: Music Education Senior Capstone:yAdministration of School Music Programs
pre_req: Admission to Teacher Education Program and EDUC 361
desc: A study of the organization, direction and management of the school music program. This course includes business management aspects of a school music job from budgeting to creating handbooks, recruiting, publicity, and competitions to communicating with parents, colleagues and principals.

name: EDUC-386
title: Vocal Pedagogy and Methods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program
desc: Students learn physiology and pedagogy of the developing voice. Included in the curricula are planning, assessment, literature, music literacy, and grading. Students teach private and in-class voice lessons to secondary students.

name: EDUC-387
title: High School Choral Methods
pre_req: Admission to Teacher Education program and EDUC 361
desc: Students learn choral literature, pedagogy, rehearsal techniques, rehearsal planning, music literacy strategies, assessment and grading, rehearsal management, and administration of a high school choral program.

name: MUS-130
title: Private Instruction: Jazz Improv
desc: For all applied music students in their first year of study.  Non-majors and music majors in their secondary areas may repeat this course for credit in subsequent years.  Studio seminars may be required.  Additional fees will be assessed for this course.

name: MUS-230
title: Private Instruction: Jazz Improv.
desc: For music majors and minors in their second year of study.  Non-majors and music majors in their secondary areas may register for this course with consent of instructor.  Studio seminars may be required.  Prerequisite: music major or music minor with 2 semesters of 130 (Private Instruction).  Additional fees will be assessed for this course.

name: MUS-330
title: Private Instruction: Jazz Improv
desc: For music majors in their third year of study. Non-majors and music majors in their secondary areas may register for this course with consent of instructor.  Studio seminars may be required. Prerequisite:  music major or music minor with 2 semesters of 230 (Private Instruction). Additional fees will be assessed for this course.

name: PHIL-230
title: Philosophy of Science
pre_req: one course in philosophy, or two courses in natural science.
desc: A study of the nature of scientific methodology, which has entitled the sciences (especially the natural sciences) to their authoritative status as reliable sources of knowledge and rational belief. This involves issues such as the relation between theory and evidence, the nature of confirmation, explanation, probability, and rational considerations in delivering and consuming scientific information. Offered alternate years.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar:Native Sons in American andySouth African Novels
desc: The life and fate of young black males is a familiar theme in South African and American Literature.  In this seminar we will study four classic novels in which the black male protagonist, constrained by socio-economic forces beyond his control, finds himself accused of a crime he did not mean to commit.  Why do black and white authors from South Africa and the U.S. choose this narrative arc to interrogate the racial dynamic of these two societies?  In what ways do these novels question white liberalism as it seeks to bring about racial equality and justice?  How does the writer's choice of literary form - for example, naturalism - relate to subject matter?  These and other questions will inform our readings of Cry, the Beloved Country (Alan Paton), Walk in the Night (Alex La Guma), Native Son (Richard Wright), and Light in August (William Faulker).

name: POLS-485
title: Seminar: Liberty, Community and theyPolitics of Place
desc: In this seminar we will read some American political theory (de Tocqueville, Wendell Barry, Robert Putnam, etc.), take a look a utopian communities throughout American history, and examine some of the recent social science research on community in America.  There also will be a strong element of applied politics, including visits from community leaders and case studies based on conflicts and successes in Decorah and the surrounding area.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar:Is Morality Any Good?
desc: This seminar explores moral theories framed in the context of multiple religious traditions.  In particular, it examines how selected primary and secondary texts develop religious moral theories in response to the fact of evil within a monotheistic, humanistic, or non-dualist framework.  The seminar focuses on following questions:  What is Evil?  How do religious texts explain the existence of evil?  What is the goal of moral theory?  How does moral theory respond to evil?  What makes a moral theory effective?  Is moral theory necessary for the attainment of religious goals?  Is religion necessary for a moral life?  The students will engage a variety of religious and philosophical positions.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures:Detective Fiction
desc: Everybody loves a good detective story-but what can they tell us about ethics, narrative, and social expectations? As we read a range of short stories and novels, from "A Scandal in Bohemia" (Sherlock Holmes) to Agatha Christie's wartime fiction and Henning Mankell's more recent Scandinavian suspense, we'll ask how detective stories can both reflect and prompt contemporary debates about relationships, treason, decorum, and virtue. Along the way, by watching adaptations and appropriations of detective stories (like the recent BBC version of Sherlock), we'll ask how narrative structure and form can influence the meaning, ethics, and social implications of a story.

name: PAID-450
title: Archaelogies of the Future
desc: We cannot change the past. We can try to live in the present. But it is only into the future that we can project our hopes for and fears of change. The future is a time and place that remains open. To be sure, the shape of things to come is influenced by the shapes of things that already exist, and yet, the future is not entirely predictable. This course explores a range of fictional and non-fictional imagined futures from various places and times with a particular focus on three main areas: Social Structures, Technology, and Environment. We will excavate past and contemporary visions of the future in order to learn how predictions, and the ethical positions from which they are built, are subject to the ideas of their times and places and to examine which factors influence the success or failure of these visions. The future, after all, is the site and the stakes of our ethical imagination and action in the present.

name: AFRS-239
title: Stories in South Africa
desc: We tell stories to help us make meaning in our lives and give us a sense of who we are in the communities in which we live. Stories in South Africa are especially powerful, given its history of apartheid, resistance, and the transition to a non-racial democracy less than 20 years ago, and stories remain important in this country that is always becoming something new. In this course we will seek to understand South Africa by seeing, hearing, and collecting stories from a rich diversity of story-tellers and sources including writers, and musicians; museums and sites of history, science, and art; and ordinary individuals young and old from various ethnic and racial backgrounds. Students will tell their own stories in a course journal and final paper. Course sites will be Johannesburg, the Eastern Cape, and Cape Town.

name: ENG-239
title: Stories in South Africa
desc: We tell stories to help us make meaning in our lives and give us a sense of who we are in the communities in which we live. Stories in South Africa are especially powerful, given its history of apartheid, resistance, and the transition to a non-racial democracy less than 20 years ago, and stories remain important in this country that is always becoming something new. In this course we will seek to understand South Africa by seeing, hearing, and collecting stories from a rich diversity of story-tellers and sources including writers, and musicians; museums and sites of history, science, and art; and ordinary individuals young and old from various ethnic and racial backgrounds. Students will tell their own stories in a course journal and final paper. Course sites will be Johannesburg, the Eastern Cape, and Cape Town.

name: PHIL-140
title: Environmental Philosophy
desc: A study of the philosophical response to the environmental crisis.  The course begins with a survey of environmental problems and a brief history of the environmental movement. It then examines various philosophical attempts to reevaluate human attitudes and responsibilities toward the nonhuman environment.

name: EDUC-371
title: Elementary General Music MethodsyAnd Lab
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.
desc: Survey of the K-5 general music program. Study of the music student, content, materials, and methods of instruction. Includes Orff and Kodaly approaches, technology, and classroom management. This course provides practical experience in elementary general music methods through a teaching partnership with area schools. Required of all music education minors.

name: EDUC-383
title: Middle School Choral Methods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program
desc: Study of the middle school learner in the choral classroom. Students learn choral literature, pedagogy with special emphasis on the changing voice, rehearsal planning, music literacy strategies, assessment, and rehearsal management techniques.

name: EDUC-384
title: Middle and High School MarchingyBand Methods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.
desc: This course examines the high school and middle school marching band program. Included are studies in marching philosophies, program organization, administration and student recruitment and retention. Students experience marching band instrumentation, unique marching equipment, field topography, terminology, marching drill charting tools and basic drill drawing. This class included a practicum with a local high school marching band.

name: EDUC-385
title: Middle and High School JazzyMethods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.
desc: This course explores the purposes of jazz education, a history of jazz and jazz education, types of jazz ensembles, instrumentations, recruitment and audition methods for the jazz program. Students will lean fundamentals of improvisation and to play the instruments of the rhythm section.

name: EDUC-388
title: Beginning and Middle SchoolyOrchestra Methods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program
desc: A study of the organization, direction, and management of the beginning and middle school orchestra program. The course includes the curricula, pedagogy and assessment of the beginning and middle level school string program, instrument repair/maintenance, arranging for school orchestra, teaching string instruments, program organization, direction, and business management of the orchestra program. Laboratory hours include participation with area school orchestras.

name: EDUC-390
title: Middle School and High SchoolyConcert Band Methods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program
desc: This course explores formal wind ensembles including types, styles and instrumentation. Instrument transposition, maintenance and repair are studied as well as traditional set up, seating arrangements and ensemble voicings. Middle and high school band literature are studied, rehearsed and conducted with Luther ensembles.

name: BIO-303
title: Bioethics
pre_req: 8 hours in biology at the 200-level or above and junior standing
desc: This course will explore various ethical issues embedded in biomedical and environmental topics.  Students will be introduced to fundamental ethical principles from which ethical positions are derived.  Graded credit/no credit. Requires junior or senior standing.

name: SCI-340
title: Science Communication Seminar
desc: This course examines the role of communication in math and science as well as the theory and practice of different types of science communication.  The course will include observation, evaluation, and practice of oral and poster science presentations for different audiences, both general and scientific.  Communication strategies for science educators will also be explored.  Intended for students participating in the Howard Hughes Medical Institute (HHMI) Trio program, though other students with extensive research experience may also inquire.    Requires consent of instructor.  Graded credit/no credit.

name: FCUL-185
title: Nordic Myths and Fairy Tales:yPrincesses and Trolls
desc: This class focuses on the myths and folk and fairy tale traditions of Norway and Denmark. Students will learn the necessary tools to analyze myths, folk tales and fairy tales, gain an understanding of the role oral and written tales serve in culture, and examine the adaptation of tales in contemporary culture. The first half of the class will examine myths and the folk tales of Norway's Asbjornsen and Moe. Students will learn to perform structural analyses of the tales, reading for symbols, metaphors and cultural norms. Similar analyses will be conducted on the fairytales of Danish author Hans Christian Andersen in the second half of the class. Additionally, students will examine how Andersen's tales have been adapted for film and musical performances. At the end of the course, students will be able to: conduct a critical analysis of a myth, folk tale or fairytale, differentiate between a folktale and a fairytale, analyze and read tales for how they reflect cultural norms and examine how and why adaptations occur. For a final project, students will present their own adaptations of a myth, folk or fairy tale studied in the course.

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar:Sustainable Development,yPolicy and Analysis
pre_req: ENVS major or minor; junior or senior standing; completion of Bio 151, Envs 134, Phil 140, and Pols 258; or consent of instructor.
desc: What sets communities apart economically, culturally, and ecologically?  What constitutes sustainable development?  In this capstone course, we will seek answers to these questions using international case studies, stakeholder interviews and field trips to regional communities.  Students will engage in hands on research through individual and group research projects in order to gain a deeper understanding of the best practices and successful models of development that shape sustainable communities.

name: INTS-203
title: Shaking the Foundations: fromyA Medieval Toward a Modern World
desc: The transition from the middle ages to modernity was neither quick nor easy because it required the complete alteration of an entire worldview that was based upon deeply held assumptions about sources of truth; methods of acquiring knowledge; the human condition and human abilities; the role of God in the world; and standards of proper morality. The subject of this course is the first manifestations of this transformation, which appeared in response to the challenges posed by the Renaissance, the Reformation, and the discovery of the New World. The course is divided into two halves. The first half establishes key components of the medieval worldview; the second half examines how and why they began to break down, and what took their place. Covering the period from 800 to 1550, with a geographical scope that stretches from Bagdad to the Americas, students will examine a variety of kinds of primary sources, from art and architecture to literature and academic discourse, in order to ascertain and plot the nature of these changes over time.

name: ENG-239
title: Special Topic: Teaching Writing:yTheory and Practice
desc: This course introduces students to the composition theory that underpins effective writing instruction. Its objective is to help students understand how theories of composition, rhetoric and pedagogy inform contemporary practices in writing instruction on such topics as argument, structure, style, and grammar. The course also examines ways to work with writers who differ in ability, maturity, preparation, and language acquisition. In addition to reading composition theory and pedagogy, students will write a reflective journal.

name: EDUC-391
title: High School Orchestra Methods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program
desc: A study of the organization, direction, and management of the orchestra program in public schools.  The course includes the curricula, pedagogy and assessment of the high school string program, instrument repair/maintenance, arranging for school orchestra, teaching string instruments, program organization, direction, and business management of the orchestra program.  Laboratory hours include participation with area school orchestras.

name: ENVS-239
title: Special Topic: Sustainable Food Systems
desc: This course will examine all aspects of the food system from production to consumption with a systems approach as a way to understand and participate in efforts to create a more sustainable food system. Primary emphasis will be on sustainable food production. Students will explore and evaluate alternative farming models and participate in Luther's efforts to significantly increase food production on campus. Working with the Center for Sustainable Communities and the Northeast Iowa Food and Fitness Initiative students will also investigate different models for systems change with specific emphasis on addressing issues of health and access to healthy food.  Prerequisite:  Sophomore standing or above.

name: ENVS-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered during fall, spring or summer terms.

name: THE-199
title: Theatre Synthesis
desc: During the sophomore year a major will develop a written reflection outlining their previous work in the performing arts and develop possible pathways for future directions leading toward their senior project.

name: DAN-199
title: Dance Synthesis
desc: During the sophomore year majors will develop a written reflection outlining their previous work in the performing arts and develop possible pathways for future directions leading toward their senior project.

name: NURS-235L
title: Pathways to Practice I Lab
pre_req: Bio115, BIO 116, BIO152, HLTH125 BIO 243, PSYC 130, SCI 240, NURS 234

name: HIST-139
title: Special Topic;World History since 1500:yThe Age of Globalization

name: PHIL-260
title: Feminist Philosophy
pre_req: One course in PHIL or two courses in WGST
desc: Examination of feminist philosophies, including issues in epistemology, ethics, social philosophy, political philosophy, philosophy of religion and historical interpretation. Focus on the challenges which feminist theory presents to traditional philosophical assumptions in the Western tradition. Offered alternate years. (Same as WGST 260)

name: SCI-140
title: Special Topic:Belize: EnvironmentalyImplications of Eco-Adventure Growth inyCentral America
desc: This course will be based on Ambergris Caye, a small island off the coast of Belize. Students will spend a significant amount of time studying the ecology and taxonomy of the many ecosystems this unique area provides. We will take daily field excursions to the barrier reef and mainland, rainforest destinations. Students will explore relationships between adventure recreation and ecotourism, in the responsible use of natural resources. Additionally, we will learn of the opportunities and challenges presented to Belizeans by the rapid growth of adventure related tourism. Activities will include kayaking, snorkeling, cave tubing,canopy tours,field observations and assigned readings.

name: EDUC-540
title: Mathematical Modeling with Maple andySage
desc: The course will introduce and reinforce methods for mathematical modeling in concert with software applications Maple and Sage.  Mathematical modeling techniques (functions, linear systems, and statistical analysis) will be, primarily, at the pre-calculus level so that the participants (in-service 7-12 mathematics instructors)may incorporate them in modeling projects in courses taught at their high school.  Some calculus-level work will be included (average rate of change, instantaneous rate of change, and total change).  Use of common computer algebra systems Maple and Sage will be introduced.  The primary text for the course is Environmental Mathematics in the Classroom (Classroom Resource Materials) authored by B.A. Fusaro and P.C. Kenschaft.  Participants will work through projects offered in the text as well as develop new projects for use in their high school course offerings.

name: CS-140
title: Data Modeling and Querying
desc: The course focuses on constructing relational models of data, the relational algebra, querying relational databases using SQL. Students will become familiar with a popular open source data management system such as MySQL or Postgresql.

name: CS-260
title: Computational Models
desc: In this course we examine mathematical structures that are relevant to understanding both theoretical as well as practical ideas in computer science.  Topics include:  logic, sets, graph theory, regular languages, deterministic and nondeterministic finite automata, regular grammars, regular expressions, induction and recursion, pushdown automata, turing machines, and computability.

name: CS-165
title: Software Development Tools
desc: Students are introduced to tools for automation including shell programming, use of the Linux operating system including redirection of input and output, piping, file management, and system security.

name: CS-252
title: Object-Oriented Programming With Java
desc: Introduction to Java and development in an object-oriented programming language.  Topics include project setup and organization, packages, classes, object creation, inheritance, interfaces,  polymorphism and the use of built-in types and the Java class library.  Considerable time is dedicated to learning incremental programming, debugging strategies, testing strategies, interface documentation, preconditions, postconditions, boundary case testing, unit testing of individual functions, test stubs and test harnesses.

name: CS-253
title: Object-Oriented Programming With C++
desc: Introduction to C and C++ and development in an object-oriented programming language.  Topics include C++ organization of classes and function prototypes, header files, class declaration and implementation.  Other topics include inheritance, polymorphism, the use of copy constructors, destructors, streams, and operator overloading.  Considerable time is dedicated to learning incremental programming, debugging strategies, testing strategies, interface documentation, preconditions, postconditions, boundary case testing, unit testing of individual functions, test stubs and test harnesses.

name: CS-430
title: Computer Networks
desc: Concepts, principles, protocols, and applications of computer networks with a focus on the Internet, including application layer protocols such as http, smtp; socket programming and peer-to-peer networks; transport-layer protocols such as TCP, UDP and congestion control; network layer algorithms for routing and broadcast, and multicast; link-level protocols for local area networks such as Ethernet and WIFI; and issues in network privacy and security.

name: WGST-270
title: Psychology and Aging
desc: This course is designed to examine psychological aspects of growing older in the 21st century.  Students will be introduced to the current methodologies used to study aging as we explore the physical, cognitive, and psychosocial changes in individuals over the age of 60.  The lecture, readings and assignments will address a range of topics that include expected versus abnormal changes in memory, creativity, the shifting roles of the elderly in family and society, and coping with illness and loss.  In light of the fact that individuals over the age of 85 are the fastest-growing segment of the global population, and that the majority are women (approximately 2:1), we will also study changes associated with gender roles and sexuality during our later years. A major goal for this course is to foster a clearer understanding of the processes associated with normal aging and to dispel a number of the stereotypes that surround this time of life. (Same as PSYC 270)

name: AFRS-239
title: Queer Bronzeville:IntersectionalyIdentities in Black Chicago
desc: There are two assumptions alive and well in our current world: That African Americans tend to be more homophobic than other cultures and that the U.S. Civil Rights Movement and the Gay Rights Movement were two separate entities. This class, by examining the history of Queer Bronzeville, will challenge both of those assumptions by looking at original documents produced by the members of that community. We will have an opportunity, as a class, to travel to Chicago, meet with elders of the community and hear their experiences throughout the momentous 20th century, listen to blues music, research queer stories in the archives, and attend the DuSable Museum of African American History. As a class, we will analyze the urbanization of African Americans in the twentieth century, with a focus on Chicago. In addition, we will consider the intersectional identities that black people forged for themselves, in negotiation with identities imposed upon them by the external society. We will read a novel, essays by sexologists, texts by historians, and articles in the Chicago Defender, Ebony, and Jet. Students will be responsible for two papers and an oral presentation.

name: HIST-239
title: Queer Bronzeville:IntersectionalyIdentities in Black Chicago
desc: There are two assumptions alive and well in our current world: That African Americans tend to be more homophobic than other cultures and that the U.S. Civil Rights Movement and the Gay Rights Movement were two separate entities. This class, by examining the history of Queer Bronzeville, will challenge both of those assumptions by looking at original documents produced by the members of that community. We will have an opportunity, as a class, to travel to Chicago, meet with elders of the community and hear their experiences throughout the momentous 20th century, listen to blues music, research queer stories in the archives, and attend the DuSable Museum of African American History. As a class, we will analyze the urbanization of African Americans in the twentieth century, with a focus on Chicago. In addition, we will consider the intersectional identities that black people forged for themselves, in negotiation with identities imposed upon them by the external society. We will read a novel, essays by sexologists, texts by historians, and articles in the Chicago Defender, Ebony, and Jet. Students will be responsible for two papers and an oral presentation.

name: PHIL-330
title: Minds, Brains, and Persons
pre_req: take two courses in philosophy, or at least one course in psychology or neuroscience numbered 300 and above.
desc: This course explores topics in the philosophy of mind, including historical and contemporary attempts to address a wide range of questions about the mind and mental phenomena, such as: Is the mind independent of the body/brain? Can consciousness be explained? Can machines think? How can we account for personal identity? Is free will an illusion? How do evolutionary theory and neuroscience relate to our understanding of the mind?

name: WGST-239
title: Queer Bronzeville:IntersectionalyIdentities in Black Chicago
desc: There are two assumptions alive and well in our current world: That African Americans tend to be more homophobic than other cultures and that the U.S. Civil Rights Movement and the Gay Rights Movement were two separate entities. This class, by examining the history of Queer Bronzeville, will challenge both of those assumptions by looking at original documents produced by the members of that community. We will have an opportunity, as a class, to travel to Chicago, meet with elders of the community and hear their experiences throughout the momentous 20th century, listen to blues music, research queer stories in the archives, and attend the DuSable Museum of African American History. As a class, we will analyze the urbanization of African Americans in the twentieth century, with a focus on Chicago. In addition, we will consider the intersectional identities that black people forged for themselves, in negotiation with identities imposed upon them by the external society. We will read a novel, essays by sexologists, texts by historians, and articles in the Chicago Defender, Ebony, and Jet. Students will be responsible for two papers and an oral presentation.

name: CS-320
title: Data Analysis and Visualization
desc: A tool based approach to data manipulation, modeling, machine learning, and visualization using one or more packages such as matplotilb, pandas, d3.js, scikit-learn.  Topics include data extraction, discovery, cleaning, machine learning algorithms, training procedures, prediction, and visualization.  Specific application to real data sets in native formats from actual data sources.

name: CS-352
title: Embedded Android Programming
desc: Study Android development with attention to HCI. Taught alternating years.

name: CS-353
title: Embedded iOS Programming
desc: Study iOS development with attention to HCI. Taught alternating years.

name: POLS-350
title: Economic Policy
desc: This course will examine the role of the state in the economy in democratic societies.  Topics covered will include international trade policy, the government's capacity to manage the economy, the balance between state and market force and political pressures that influence economic policies. Offered alternate years.

name: CS-370
title: Programming Languages
desc: A comparison of the structure, design, and applications of various programming languages.  Topics include history, language definition, formal models of syntax and semantics, data types and structures, data abstraction, control structures, data flow, and runtime considerations.  Languages will be discussed in a logical organization based upon the major paradigms including imperative, logic, functional, and object oriented.  Examples from classic and contemporary languages.

name: CS-440
title: Database Managment Systems
desc: This course takes a bottom-up approach to understanding a complex software system.  The course examines the implementation of a database management system.  Topics include disk and file management, transaction processing, meta-data management, query planning and implementation, parsing queries, indexing, query optimization, and B-trees.

name: JOUR-100
title: News Practicum
desc: This practicum consists of one full semester of work at either CHIPS or KWLC, as regular staff members. Students will participate fully in the gathering, production, or editing of news stories. Students may use two semesters at CHIPS, or two semesters at KWLC, or a combination of the two, to fulfill the requirement for the Journalism minor.

name: JOUR-380
title: Internship
desc: Supervised work experience at an off-campus news organization.

name: ENVS-185
title: Society & the Sixth Mass Extinction
desc: We are currently in the midst of a sixth mass extinction of species on Earth. This extinction, however, is different from others in geologic history in that it is the only one caused by another living species: humans. In this course, we will explore questions of extinction, biodiversity, and conservation through political, cultural, and ethical lenses. Why might we value biodiversity? What are the social and environmental implications of the loss of living species? What is our responsibility to try to stop or slow this mass extinction and how might we do so?

name: GS-100
title: Foundations for Learning and Development
desc: The purpose of this course is to enable students to understand the foundations of learning and development by examining their skills, attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors, and the contribution of a liberal arts education to their holistic development (emotional, ethical, intellectual, physical, social, spiritual, and vocational). Students will develop academic and other skills related to higher-order thinking, social and emotional intelligence, cultural competence, digital age learning, and financial decision-making. They will learn to enhance their own motivation, responsibility and leadership. Students will also explore their personality, strengths, interests, and purpose in order to fully engage in the education process and set goals that represent their values and priorities. Open to first-year students accepted into the SSS TRIO Program.

name: PHIL-320
title: Topics in Value Theory
desc: Study of particular theories, movements, issues, major philosophers in value theory.  Examples include major works in virtue ethics, utilitarian theory, deontological ethics. Offered alternate years.

name: HIST-185
title: On Skis and Rafts: Norwegian ExplorersyAnd the Building of a National Identity
desc: This course examines the historical relationship between Norwegian nation building and exploration through the study of three of Norway's most famous explorers: Fridtjof Nansen, Roald Amundsen, and Thor Heyerdahl. Students will analyze primary source documents, including Nansen's, Amundsen's and Heyerdahl's diaries, log books, photographs and video recordings, to understand explorers' varied motivations for venturing across oceans. These sources will inform their study of Norwegian interest in and experiences of exploration alongside larger historical developments, including the creation of nation states and global conflicts over resources. This course will also look at issues of change over time, including the similarities and differences between the fierce competition to reach the North and South Poles in the nineteenth century and the sailing of a balsam raft from Peru to Polynesia in the wake of World War Two.

name: HIST-185
title: The Journey to China: TravelingyImaginations of Westerners From the 13thyCentury to the Present
desc: This course will explore representations and interpretations of China in Western travel accounts from the 13th century to the present. It will examine the way in which the image of "China," and by extension any country, is not a fixed and unchanging entity, but rather a set of representations that are constantly shifting and adapting to reflect historical conditions and concerns. Each week we will focus on one piece of travel writing. The readings will include works by the 13th century merchant explorer Marco Polo, the 19th century missionary Evariste-R‚gis Huc, and the contemporary Dutch-American travel writer J. Maarten Troost. Following in the footsteps of these tourists we will travel through time and space, through China and beyond. We will explore historical changes and geographical variation through their eyes (i.e., through the eyes of foreign cultures and religions). They will gain a foundation in early modern to contemporary Chinese history and China's changing status vis-a-vis the West. (both Europe and America).

name: PSYC-185
title: Why You Picked This Course: TheyPsychology of Judgment and DecisionyMaking
desc: This course examines the psychology of human judgment and decision making. How do we make judgments? What influences our choices? Can we become better decision makers? Throughout the course, students will be exposed to basic models and strategies of decision making, with attention to its history and development within cognitive and social psychology and its impact on our everyday lives. Specifically, students will come away with an understanding of the empirical work and implications surrounding the question of how to make the most rational decisions in contrast to how people actually make decisions and how people should make decisions. In other words, together we will address the questions of how do we make decisions, how should we make decisions, and how best to make decisions.

name: INTS-185
title: Revolution 1791: The Price of Liberty
desc: Is violence a legitimate means of changing society or of purging it of dangerous enemies? Do traditional institutions and values constitute restraints on freedom and individual dignity or are their essential supports? Are all men and women equally entitled to the "rights of man"? Should religious leaders obey the "general will" of their nation or the dictates of their religious authorities? To explore the ongoing debate about the meaning and relation of freedom and nationhood, this seminar will plunge students into the intellectual, political, and ideological currents that surged through revolutionary Paris in the summer of 1791. Students will be leaders of major factions within the National Assembly (and in the streets outside) as it struggles to create a constitution amidst internal chaos and threats of foreign invasion, and explores the larger questions of the price of liberty, equality, and "fraternity."

name: INTS-185
title: Is Modernism Dead?
desc: Is "Modernism" dead? How, or why, does it matter? At the end of the 19th Century, dramatic and broad-based changes in Western societies gave rise to the philosophical movement that has come to be known as Modernism. In the music, art, and literature of the West, prominent artists became proponents of this movement, as they believed the artistic expressions of the past were no longer relevant in an industrial, urban society. These artists challenged the notions of progress and rationality that had undergirded the Enlightenment. They created works of art that radically broke from centuries-long forms and traditions, and they challenged audiences to re-envision the place of art in society. Have today's artists carried the torch their forebears raised? What do the debates surrounding Modernism's legitimacy tell us about ourselves and our society? This seminar will examine selected prominent works of art, music, and literature and the questions they raise.

name: INTS-302
title: Hot Or Not? the Challenge of GlobalyClimate Change
desc: The reality of human-caused global warming is no longer seriously debated, but even with widespread acceptance of this fact, we are still left with an enormously challenging question: What are we supposed to do about it? In this course we will examine what lies behind the scientific, economic, political, technological, and ethical issues that make a simple solution to climate change very difficult to attain. Through our discussion of climate change, we will also address broader societal questions such as: How do we make decisions in the face of unavoidable uncertainties, both scientific and economic? How do we reconcile the seemingly competing goals of human, environmental, and economic well-being? To what extent can (and should) humans manage the natural environment?

name: INTS-303
title: The Universe
desc: The look upwards to the sky has always confronted humans with questions about themselves and the world around them. What are stars? Why do they move? Are the heavens beyond the sky? Are we alone in the universe? Where does the universe come from? This course investigates the human quest for understanding space, the galaxies, and the universe. But rather than looking only at the scientific history of space explorations, the course will mostly focus on the human struggle with the concept of space and infinity, and on space discovery as a creative and artistic process. What influence does our understanding of the universe have on our life on earth? How do humans react if their concept of the universe is called into question? What are the similarities between various creation myths and how do they account for the experienced universe of those who believe in them? How do we explain the origin of space and the universe and what does this tell about us? How has the idea of space and an infinite universe been adopted by artists and what do their renditions tell us about the time of their creation? Students will read and engage various creation myths, texts and ideas from astronomers such as Copernicus, Kepler, and Galileo, from physicists like Einstein, Hawking, and LemaŒtreas, well as early and modern Science Fiction.

name: REL-215
title: Sacred Texts & Religious Diversity
desc: This course will explore contemporary religious diversity through the critical, comparative study of sacred texts from two or more religious traditions. Students will examine the relationship between diversity within and among sacred texts and diversity within and among historical and contemporary expressions of each religious tradition. They will also consider the role of sacred texts in interfaith engagement.

name: SCI-225
title: Women in Science
desc: This course studies various topics in the sciences by looking at great discoveries of female scientists. The class will start by examining scientific methodology, research, and process as well as an introduction to the various field of science. The history of women in science is followed by through daily reading assignments. In addition to the history and science taught by the instructor, students will be responsible for an in-depth project on an individual female scientist, studying both the science and other aspects of her life.  The class will include some student-led class discussions and oral presentations, along with class lecture, activities assignments and tests. (Same as WGST 225)

name: REL-239
title: ST: Politicis, Murder, and Cover-Up:yA Postcolonial Reading of the Books ofySamuel
desc: Throughout history, social, political, and economic power have been used to marginalize and suppress people, often with tragic consequences. In the recent past there have been increasing calls by postcolonial scholars in general as well as by those within the field of religion/biblical studies to utilize postcolonial theoretical frameworks to contest imperial power and to create a society that is attentive to social justice, and welfare of all people regardless of color, race, nationality, or social status. In this course students will engage in learning about postcolonialism as a methodology of reading texts and to utilize the method to identify stories of marginalization embedded in the narratives of the books of Samuel, as well as in specific contemporary societies.

name: REL-239
title: ST: Revelation: Then & Now
desc: This course will critically analyze the Book of Revelation and its reception in the form of literature, art, and the movies. Students will critically analyze the historical context that led to the inception of this fascinating text in dialogue with contemporary discourses such as feminist studies, masculinity studies and queer theory, liberation hermeneutics, postcolonial studies, and ecotheology and ecocriticism.

name: REL-239
title: ST: The Book of Ruth & Ethic/yRacial Conflict Analysis and Resolution
desc: A major problem in the 21st century is the enduring persistence of ethnic/racial expressions that often flare up into binary differences that lead to violence, as well as the role that religious texts/expressions play in accenting the problem. In the last ten or so years, scholarship both in the Social Sciences and Biblical/Religious Studies has increasingly been turning to address this problem. In this course students will engage in a historical, literary, and exegetical reading of the Book of Ruth in order to understand the historical, sociopolitical, ideological, and economic forces that shaped ethnic/racial identifications in the context of the ancient Israelite community that produced this text, as well as how this community sought to resolve potentially violent interethnic relationships.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic:Chinese EnvironmentalyHistory
desc: This course explores the significant role of the environment in Chinese history from the 5th B.C. to the present. It focuses on the interaction between nature and cultural norms, religious concepts, political management and economic growth. The course will begin by discussing Chinese traditional concepts of nature, include the ones brought up in Confucian and Daoist classics, in comparison with other world cultures. We will then focus on the imperial period, examining how people's daily lives were shaped by various environmental elements, such as plant, animal, weather, irrigation, agriculture, and disease. The last part will cover the complex evolution and management of the environment as responding to varying historical developments in the 20th century, including colonialism, Maoist revolution, consumption, and pollution. Through this course, students will gain a better understanding of the geographical diversity of China and its interactions with the outside world.

name: ENVS-239
title: Special Topic:Chinese EnvironmentalyHistory
desc: This course explores the significant role of the environment in Chinese history from the 5th B.C. to the present. It focuses on the interaction between nature and cultural norms, religious concepts, political management and economic growth. The course will begin by discussing Chinese traditional concepts of nature, include the ones brought up in Confucian and Daoist classics, in comparison with other world cultures. We will then focus on the imperial period, examining how people's daily lives were shaped by various environmental elements, such as plant, animal, weather, irrigation, agriculture, and disease. The last part will cover the complex evolution and management of the environment as responding to varying historical developments in the 20th century, including colonialism, Maoist revolution, consumption, and pollution. Through this course, students will gain a better understanding of the geographical diversity of China and its interactions with the outside world.

name: REL-371
title: Jesus and Jihad: A New Approach toyComparative Religion
desc: A contemporary Muslim scholar, Amin Ahsan Islahi, has stated that Jesus urged his disciples on to wage jihad. Given the negative images often associated with a concept like jihad, this might seem like a heretical statement. Several new lines of research, however, suggest that connecting Jesus with jihad might provide an interesting way to rethink the fields of comparative religion studies and interfaith relations. This course will combine newer insights emerging in the study of the New Testament, early Islamic history, and theoretical approaches to the study of religion to consider whether the Jesus/jihad connection makes sense, though perhaps in a way different than Islahi intends. Could connecting Jesus with jihad provide a new way to conceive of the relationship between Christians and Muslims?

name: PAID-450
title: Stability and Change: The Balkans
desc: Students will travel to the Balkan Peninsula - a borderland where many of the world's great civilizations have intermingled, merged and often clashed. Although the nations of the Western Balkans were all once a part of Yugoslavia, they have remarkably diverse economic conditions, political situations, culture, religion, architecture and terrain. Not only will we study the past and present of these four Balkan countries because of their intrinsic interest, we will use this as a case study for exploring the roles of culture, history, and geography in the evolution of nation-states, the development of economies, and the formation of intra and international conflict.

name: POLS-354
title: Women, Representation, and Politics
desc: This course explores the role of gender in politics through the conceptual framework of representation. Focusing specifically on women's representation, this course provides a comparative analysis of women's movements in various countries, explores the role of transnational advocacy networks (TANs) in the implementation of gender-related policies, and discusses the rise in the number of women elected to political offices across the globe and its impact on political systems. (Same as WGST 354)

name: WGST-354
title: Women, Representation, and Politics
desc: This course explores the role of gender in politics through the conceptual framework of representation. Focusing specifically on women's representation, this course provides a comparative analysis of women's movements in various countries, explores the role of transnational advocacy networks (TANs) in the implementation of gender-related policies, and discusses the rise in the number of women elected to political offices across the globe and its impact on political systems. (Same as POLS 354)

name: AFRS-345
title: Constructs of Race and Racialization
desc: This course examines the social construction of race as a concept and the racialization of US society. An assessment of how racialization has changed over time and has created various interactions between groups from Whites and enslaved Africans, Mexicans and Native Americans to present day race relations. We also examine how racialization both determines and impacts social structures and the attainment of societal honors, rewards and power in modern society. (Same as SOC 345)

name: ANTH-301
title: Experimental Archaeology
desc: The anthropological study of material culture and technology provides a wealth of information about human behavior. This course will use ethnographic analogy and experimental archaeology as tools for reconstructing a specific example of prehistoric technology. We will search for and analyze relevant ethnographic data, design and implement replicative experiments based on this data, and evaluate the effectiveness of the results for interpreting the archaeological record. In the process of recreating past technology we will explore how the analysis of material culture and technology can be used to understand topics such as cognition, social boundaries, gender, and symbolism.

name: ENG-485
title: Seminar:Essential AmericanyNonfiction
desc: This seminar examines significant works of American nonfiction to understand the impact of narrative documentary and nonfiction prose on culture and national consciousness.  We begin with two seminal works of autobiography that have transformed individual life stories into American icons of "self-made men" (Ben Franklin and Malcolm X).  We will look at the treatment of the American landscape as shaped by Thoreau's Walden and Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, and conclude the course with the genre-changing reportage of the New Journalists, with particular attention to the complicated relationship between writer and subject, the importance of style and structure in nonfiction texts, and the interplay between writing and culture.

name: PAID-450
title: Food and Environment
desc: Environmental problems resulting from our current system of food production and distribution threaten the sustainability of the planet.  In this course we will explore these problems as well as the ethical and political dimensions of individual eating choices.  Through readings, lectures, visits to local farms, and individual projects, we will examine both conventional food systems and sustainable alternatives with particular focus on the Upper Midwest.

name: PHIL-485
title: Seminar
desc: In-depth study of specific topics or philosophers in seminar format, designed for students with significant experience in philosophy.

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History:yThe Renaissance
desc: This course examines the cultural movement known as the Renaissance, which was based upon the attempt to recreate the world of antiquity by imitating its style and values, and which occurred in Europe between the mid-fourteenth and early seventeenth centuries.  We will seek to define the parameters and objectives of the movement's protagonists, the Renaissance humanists (both male and female), who were active first in Italy in the mid-fourteenth century.  Thereafter we will consider the effect of these ideas as they were applied to other disciplines, analyzing their influence on religion and the church, art and culture, society and economics, and political theory.  Geographically, we will move out of Italy to Northern Europe, focusing especially on humanism's influence in The Holy Roman Empire (Germany) and England.  Finally, we will examine the negative forces unleashed by the movement, its definition and treatment of outsiders and "undesirables", as well as the areas in which it demonstrated close continuity with medieval viewpoints.

name: HIST-239
title: "G-d's Curse and Hell Fire fall uponyThem That First Discovered the Plot":yComparing Slave Rebillions in EarlyyAmerica
desc: In American history, by far the two greatest and most successful slave rebellions were the American Revolution (where slaves normally fled to the British armies)and the Civil War (where from early on, Union forces harbored escaped contraband, but where, later, tens of thousands of ex-slaves traveled in the wake of the Northern armies). These examples are hugely important but they are exceptional. More normally, slave rebellions were brief spasms of intense drama, often filled with bloodshed and incredible violence -- and a notable lack of success for the slaves. But in every case, they inspired intense fear and wild rumors throughout the white community. The course examines why such rebellions only periodically erupted, why they broke out where and when they did, and the reasons for their failure. The course focuses on three well-documented examples -- the New York Slave Conspiracy of 1741, Gabriel Prosser's Rebellion in Richmond (Virginia), South Carolina in 1800, and Nat Turner's Rebellion in Southampton County (Virginia) in 1831.

name: REL-185
title: Bible Blogging
desc: The Internet is a medium that is unparalleled in its reach. Never before have average people been able to reach a global audience with such ease. Blogging has profoundly influenced not only the nature of the internet today, but also the nature of modern communication. While many may rightly point to the democratic nature of blogging whereby anyone anywhere with internet access can provide perspectives that challenge dominant and possibly oppressive views, blogging has also spawned much misinformation that is presented as "truth" and "facts" especially misinformation associated with religion in general and the Bible in particular. In this first-year seminar students will work in groups to (1) discover and analyze a wide variety of religious blogs and make presentations to the class regarding the content and apparent objectives of these blogs and (2) design and create their own religious blogs--focusing on content and design strategies.

name: POLS-185
title: Revolution and Genocide: When Rules andyInstitutions Fail
desc: How are laws and rules created? When do political actors choose to follow or deviate from such laws and rules? Thinking of laws and rules as political institutions, this class will explore what makes these institutions stick and what makes them fail. We will use Reacting to the Past (RTTP)-a series of elaborate games, set in the past in which students are assigned roles informed by classic texts in the history of ideas-to delve into the complex discussion of institutional creation and breakdown. Using the French Revolution and the Rwandan Genocide as the two case studies, students will get in character and make decisions based on the ideologies of the day.

name: ART-290
title: Art in Cultural Perspective:PicturingyChange in Hong Kong (Hong KongySAR, China)
desc: This three and a half week journey through Hong Kong and Shanghai provides an opportunity to investigate the cultural history and art scene of major international cities through photography.  Students will engage in street culture on a daily basis through photo assignments in the field for the purpose of seeing how these cities and their residents respond to globalization and change.  Each student will contribute work to a final photography exhibition when they return to campus.

name: FCUL-185
title: Caught Between Love, Family, andyDesire: Why Anna Karenina Matters in OuryOwn Time.
desc: Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina is considered one of the greatest works of Russian literature. It is a novel written about 19th c. Russia and its glittering world of wealth, privilege and power. Yet Anna Karenina lives still-the most recent edition of the novel is an Oprah's Book Club selection and the latest filmed version stars Keira Knightley and Jude Law. It is a novel about what finding love can cost you, about family loyalty, and about the sacrifices women make to be true to themselves. In this course, we will read the novel Anna Karenina and explore the connections between Anna Karenina's world and our own: are women facing the same kinds of conflicts now when it comes to love and family? The course will include both analytical and creative responses to the novel, as well as student presentations. All course readings are in English.

name: PAID-450
title: Ethics and Sports
desc: This course is designed to increase students' knowledge of a wide range of ethical issues related to interscholastic, intercollegiate, professional, and recreational sports, and to provide models for and opportunities to practice ethical decision making.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar:Beyond Conversion andyPersuasion:Reinterpreting DominantyBiblical (and Christian) Portrayals ofyConversion
desc: For many Christians, "conversion" is a perennially important topic.  With a special emphasis on the Bible and its teachings, evangelical Christianity has championed the need for "conversion" in modern life.  But what does the Bible really say about conversion?  Is the New Testament view of conversion uniform?  Is it a one-time occurrence or an ongoing process?  Since conversion is often thought of as a personal change or transformation resulting from being effectively persuaded of the need to change, is the model of "conversion" through persuasion the best way to think about personal change and transformation?  This seminar will examine these and other questions.  The seminar will also examine whether persuasion is the only (or most effective) form of rhetoric to bring about change.

name: PHIL-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar. Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed project is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department. All projects must be presented publicly. Only projects awarded an "A" or "A-" qualify for "department honors" designation. The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: HIST-321
title: Topics in U.S. History
desc: In-depth study of a selected topic in U.S. history. Introduction in this course will require students to read and assess monographs written by prominent historians related to the topic. Students will write an eight-to-ten-page research paper on a subject linked to the selected topic. Topics may include but are not limited to: Revolutionary America, disease in the American past, history of the American family, U.S. immigration history, the Vietnam War.

name: INTS-450
title: Global Positioning for Service (GPS)
desc: What now? How have all of your college learning experiences prepared you for life after Luther?
