This 1-credit colloquium will ask students to reflect on their goals, their research opportunities, and their learning in relation to opportunities for graduate school, career, citizenship, and leadership in the larger world. It will emphasize investigation of and reflection on contemporary global issues and needs, as well as analyzing potential solutions and how we individually and collectively might use our learning, gifts, and skills to address them. Requires junior or senior standing.

name: HIST-351
title: Topics in European History: TheyHolocaust
desc: This course will examine the interrelated individuals, institutions, historical events, and ideologies that contributed to the Holocaust.  In order to understand this genocide, we will begin our study with an analysis of some of the important historical factors that occurred before the Nazi rise to power.  We will then examine the anti-Jewish policies the Nazis cobbled together during 1933-1938 and the varied Jewish responses to these policies.  This historical background will inform our investigation of the Final Solution itself.  In this part of the course, we will study the prepetrators, bystanders, and victims of the Holocaust.  Finally, we will consider the Holocaust's aftermath and legacy among Jews and non-Jews in Germany, Israel, and the United States.  The readings will challenge us to think about the Holocaust from new perspectives, and we will work together to understand the role individuals played in this state-sponsored genocide.  Discussions will be an integral part of this course as we will use them to work through many of the difficult topics under study.

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar: Environment and Community
pre_req: Complete 16 credits in courses that apply toward ENVS major.
desc: Communities have gained a greater role in influencing their environmental fates. As such, active grassroots environmental movements and community-based conservation projects are on the rise. These community-based approaches speak to calls to "think globally and act locally".  In this seminar, we will examine the ways communities become a critical unit of social action for promoting positive environmental change.  We will draw from case studies to investigate key questions such as: Why might communities be particularly well suited to push for environmental change? What makes certain communities more successful than others? How can we work to build community capacities for sustainability? In addition to engaging with ideas and literature related to community organizing, students will develop proposals for their own community-based environmental projects through a semester-long process of research, writing and presentation. (W)

name: ENVS-485
title: Seminar: Environment and Community
pre_req: Pols-258 or Phil-140 AND Bio-151 or Envs-134
desc: Communities have gained a greater role in influencing their environmental fates. As such, active grassroots environmental movements and community-based conservation projects are on the rise. These community-based approaches speak to calls to "think globally and act locally".  In this seminar, we will examine the ways communities become a critical unit of social action for promoting positive environmental change.  We will draw from case studies to investigate key questions such as: Why might communities be particularly well suited to push for environmental change? What makes certain communities more successful than others? How can we work to build community capacities for sustainability? In addition to engaging with ideas and literature related to community organizing, students will develop proposals for their own community-based environmental projects through a semester-long process of research, writing and presentation. (W)

name: PHIL-239
title: Special Topic:Existentialism,Literatureyand Film
desc: What does it mean to be a vibrant human being?  Who is responsible for the way I am?  How should I live my life?  Do our lives have any meaning? How does the inevitability of death affect life?  Such questions are the focus of one of the most influential philosopical trends in history:  existentialism.  Thinkers such as Kierkegaard, Dostoevsky, Kafka, Heidegger, De Beauvoir, Sartre, and Camus departed from much contemporary philosophy by insisting that it have a cultural presence and that it be utterly relevant to our lives.  This course will explore the writings of these philosophers and artists along with the art, literature, and films which passionately expressed their challenging thoughts.

name: THE-305
title: Acting:Special Topics: MeisneryTechnique
pre_req: Take The-205 or consent of instructor

name: PHIL-395
title: Independent Study
desc: Used by the student who wishes to design a course of independent study not otherwise available in the curriculum. Requires a detailed proposal of study written in consultation with the instructor.

name: GS-185
title: The Power of Water
desc: This course will explore water from many perspectives: geological, biological, economic, sociopolitical, recreational, symbolic. We will examine the role of water in literature, arts, and film as well as its use in the physical and living world. Various assignments will introduce students to specific forms of writing and types of oral presentations.

name: AFRS-371
title: Topics in African History:Problems ofyNation-Building in Post-IndependentyAfrica
desc: This course investigates the challenges and problems faced by post-independent African states.  Starting with an examination of colonial rule, African nationalism and independence movements, it uses the 1960s as the focal point to explore some of the continent's problems, with all their implications for nation building.  Students will investigate themes such as ethnic conflicts, secessionist pressures, civil wars and military dictatorships, religious fundamentalism, economic decline, natural disasters, health and disease, HIV/AIDS, and Ebola.  Drawing on media reports, documentaries, and primary sources, students will be encouraged to research and make informed judgments about the problems investigated. (Same as HIST 371)

name: HIST-371
title: Topics in African History:Problems ofyNation-Building in Post-IndependentyAfrica
desc: This course investigates the challenges and problems faced by post-independent African states.  Starting with an examination of colonial rule, African nationalism and independence movements, it uses the 1960s as the focal point to explore some of the continent's problems, with all their implications for nation building.  Students will investigate themes such as ethnic conflicts, secessionist pressures, civil wars and military dictatorships, religious fundamentalism, economic decline, natural disasters, health and disease, HIV/AIDS, and Ebola.  Drawing on media reports, documentaries, and primary sources, students will be encouraged to research and make informed judgments about the problems investigated. (Same as AFRS 371)

name: SPAN-339
title: Special Topics: Explorations inyHispanic Culture
desc: This course will study the Spanish-speaking world through its cultural manifestations: language, literature, film, arts, television, music and the news media.  Several topics will be offered on a rotating basis: cinema, social revolution, and the arts, Hispanics in the U.S., current events, popular music and poetry, Spanish and Latin American civilizations.  May be repeated up to two times for credit under different topics.

name: FCUL-185
title: Stalin:The Great Terror
desc: This course will focus on the rise of Soviet dictator Josef Stalin (1879-1953) and the Great Terror that resulted in the deaths of approximately 20 million Soviet citizens.  Attention will be given to the "Cult of Personality" and the conditions that allowed a dictatorship and state terror for many years.  Could such a scenario be possible again?  The course will be supplemented by film (Russian and American), literature, and memoirs.

name: AFRS-139
title: Special Topics:Music and the Struggleyfor Freedom in South Africa:Mandela,yMasekela and Mahlesela
desc: This one-credit course examines the role of music in South Africa in the struggle for freedom during apartheid.  The course is offered in the context of two important events:  the 25th anniversary of Nelson Mandela's release from prison on February 11, and the March 5 concert at Luther College of two South African musical legends: trumpeter Hugh Masekela and singer-songwriter Vusi Mahlesela.  Readings include excerpts from autobiographies by Mandela and Masekela.  Credit-no credit only.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic:Black Influence onyPopular Culture:African Americans inyMusic, TV, Sports, and Film
desc: This course will investigate African American artistic creations and athletic achievement throughout the twentieth century. While that century began as an era in which black Americans were present in American popular culture primarily through black face minstrelsy (white performers put on boot polish in order to mimic stereotypical black features), black people currently influence every major arena of American popular culture. How did this come to be? How have African American responses to widespread stereotyping of themselves and their culture changed over time? How have media depictions of black people narrowed black and white perceptions of what it means to be a certain race, class, and gender? By reading a variety of works by historians, we will see how scholars have understood the development of black influence on American popular culture. We will also analyze a wide range of memoirs, songs, movie clips, TV shows, and sporting events in order to understand continuity and change within this topic.

name: PHYS-112
title: Energy and the Physical World
desc: The unifying theme of energy molds the study of the physical concepts of motion, gravitation, electromagnetism, heat, radiation, and nuclear physics. Solar, wind, nuclear, tidal, hydroelectric, and thermal electric energy conversion processes are also included. This course is intended for the general student with no special background in mathematics or science. (Same as ENVS 112 and SCI 112.)

name: AFRS-239
title: Special Topic:Black Influence onyPopular Culture:African Americans inyMusic, TV, Sports, and Film
desc: This course will investigate African American artistic creations and athletic achievement throughout the twentieth century. While that century began as an era in which black Americans were present in American popular culture primarily through black face minstrelsy (white performers put on boot polish in order to mimic stereotypical black features), black people currently influence every major arena of American popular culture. How did this come to be? How have African American responses to widespread stereotyping of themselves and their culture changed over time? How have media depictions of black people narrowed black and white perceptions of what it means to be a certain race, class, and gender? By reading a variety of works by historians, we will see how scholars have understood the development of black influence on American popular culture. We will also analyze a wide range of memoirs, songs, movie clips, TV shows, and sporting events in order to understand continuity and change within this topic.

name: DAN-380
title: Internship
desc: Supervised on- or off-campus work experience related to professional demands and expectations of persons and organizations involved in theatre and/or dance. Graded credit/no credit.

name: FCUL-139
title: Special Topic:History and Culture:yDenmark and Norway
desc: This course is a survey of the history and culture of Denmark and Norway. The first half of the course will focus on the history of the region including topics such as the Vikings, Dano-Norwegian union and modern Norway. The second half of the course will explore the contemporary culture, language and geography of the region. The course will be taught on campus during the second half of spring semester. In groups, students will be asked to conduct independent research and present their findings in class. Students will also be expected to complete readings related to course topics. These readings will provide the basis for active and engaging in-class discussions. The course will be graded Cr/NC.

name: PAID-450
title: Practicing Embodiment
desc: This course is an interdisciplinary exercise between spirituality, sustainability, and the body.  While there is no single definition of "embodiment" this course will consider an understanding of "embodiment" as the practice of recognizing all human attributes (e.g. senses, emotions, physicality, sexuality, etc.) as both material and spiritual realities.  The course will explore what it means to approach the human body and the earth as living partners of a sacred reality, co-creating and sustaining all physical and spiritual life.  While working on an organic farm, students will employ techniques and practices of spirituality, somatic studies, and sustainable organic eco-farming--including harvesting and meal preparation--to critically deconstruct the dualisms between body and mind, secular and sacred, and the material and spiritual dimensions.  The ethical consequences of such dualisms will be evaluated and concrete practices will be explored for developing embodied ways of living that foster and promote integrated, sustainable, and morally responsible lives.

name: PHYS-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. PHYS 285 only offered during January term.

name: ENVS-285
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Offered only during January term.

name: LAT-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. LAT 295 can only be taken during the fall, spring, or summer terms.

name: ENVS-239
title: Special Topic:Rivers and Society
desc: Rivers are important environmental, cultural, and economic features in the landscape, yet we struggle to manage them sustainably.  Using rivers as an integrating element, the course draws from multidisciplinary perspectives to understand social dependence on river systems, as well as human modification and management of river environments.  In particular, we will examine cultural meanings of rivers in the arts; the politics of dams; rivers and pollution policy; water rights and water conflicts; fishing culture and fisheries policy; and river recreation and restoration.  We will ground our examination in case studies of rivers, ranging from the local Upper Iowa River, to the Mississippi, to major river systems of the world, such as the Ganges, the Yangtze, and the Amazon.

name: MUS-139
title: Special Topic:Sacred Choral Music ofyItaly
desc: The primary focus of this course will be upon Italian sacred choral music.  The course will explore the influences of the Roman Catholic Church on the choral music of the Renaissance and subsequent musical eras.  Students will gain an understanding of the development of sacred music and its role in the larger corpus of western art music.  The compositional styles of composers such as Palestrina of the Roman School and Monteverdi and Gabrieli of the Venetian School will be central to the study.

name: PAID-450
title: Borders, Migration, and Identity:yDominican Republic and Haiti
desc: This course will offer a first-hand opportunity to study the social, economic, cultural, and religious effects that displacement (whether voluntary or involuntary) has particularly on disenfranchised communities. It will focus on the construction and renegotiation of people's identities as they face migration, immigration, and displacement. Particular attention will be given to human rights as social groups face the weakening or loss of support networks (provided, for instance, by family, neighbors, religion, work place, citizenship rights, education, etc.) and what mechanisms are put in place to enable survival. Themes to be considered include working conditions, gender constructions, violence, religious discourse, race, politics, and access to education. The course will take place in the Dominican Republic (2 weeks) and Haiti (1 week).

name: PHYS-114
title: Physics of Sound and Musical Acoustics
desc: The course explores the physical basis for sound, its production and detection, with applications to speech, hearing, music, and acoustics of musical instruments and buildings.  Intended for the student who has special interest in the acoustical phenomena associated with music and human speech.  No special background in mathematics is assumed, but basic mathematics will be an important tool used throughout the semester.  A basic knowledge of music theory is recommended but not required.

name: PAID-450
title: Participating in the Divine: Godythrough Art
desc: This course looks at ways in which the Russian artistic tradition is deeply embedded in transcendent experience. Although these experiences arise out of a particular cultural context and are bound by time and space, they can inform and enrich our own faith experience and remain relevant. One way to more fully appreciate this relevance is to analyze their symbolic content. According to theologian Paul Tillich, symbols are representations of the infinite in a finite form, pointing beyond themselves and opening up levels of reality otherwise veiled. The course will interpret symbolic religious language through religious images (icons), novels, music, and films. It will enable students to reflect on their own moral decision-making by studying how human beings interact, the meaning of humanity in its relation to the divine, the human condition and its representation(s), and how courage, acceptance, and forgiveness are manifested in the midst of ignorance and oppression.

name: PAID-450
title: Stability and Change in Vietnam
desc: We will begin our exploration of Vietnam in Ho Chi Minh City, where we will experience the changing Vietnam in the form of a modern commercial city. We then will travel to the Mekong Delta, a world of waterways, farming, and rural charm, resting on the South China Sea. We will travel on land to the center of Vietnam where we will visit historical sites, eat traditional food, and learn more about the Vietnamese culture. We will end our exploration with visits to Hanoi, more like an old colonial city than Ho Chi Minh City, and the stunningly beautiful Halong Bay. Two particular characteristics of the course are noteworthy. First, will supplement the city visits with a number of off-the-beaten path forays and opportunities to meet (and stay) with native Vietnamese. Second, we will explore the following themes related to stability and change: Vietnam's transformation into a modern, robust economy; the problems that always accompany traditional countries going through the process of modernization, including environmental degradation; the balancing act required of citizens in a country still governed by the communist party; and the American involvement in Vietnam's past by way of what the Vietnamese refer to as the "American war."

name: PAID-450
title: The Value (s) of College?
desc: Recognizing that institutions of higher learning in the United States are being transformed by new and changing demographics (of both faculty and students), practices, programs, policies, and agendas, this course focuses on the important issues that these changes raise including among others the affordability and value of higher education, alternative options to the traditional classroom (e.g. on-line courses, MOOCs, etc.), problems associated with the diversity (or lack thereof) of the student body and faculty, relevance of linguistic and cultural competency, college and university rankings, and the globalization of higher education and research. In doing so, it addresses important ethical concerns such as issues of justice and equality (e.g. how do institutions of higher learning treat faculty and staff, students, and other groups?), conflicts of interest (e.g. what is the relationship between the institution and its funders and commercial partners?), honesty and fairness (e.g. how does the institution engage in marketing and admissions?), and academic freedom (e.g. how much flexibility do faculty have in the courses they offer?). Students will learn about the historical contexts of these issues, reflect on the ethical questions associated with them, and examine different cultural attitudes and understandings of higher education.

name: POLS-239
title: Special Topic:InternationalyOrganizations
desc: In this course students will explore the role of international organizations in today's global political landscape.  By exploring the political history of key international organizations (The United Nations, The International Monetary Fund, and the European Union), students will learn about the role of cooperation in today's globalized political and economic systems, as well as explore the limits of cooperation.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic:Comparative EuropeanyWelfare States
desc: This course will introduce students to a comparative and historical approach to the development of European welfare states. We will study both the theoretical underpinnings of welfare states and their particular temporal and spatial manifestations. This will include looking at a variety of European cases, including France, England, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Russia, and Italy, in order to answer questions regarding the who, what, where, why and when of welfare state development. Lectures and secondary source readings will provide students with the contextual foundation to evaluate and discuss primary source readings. These readings will expose students to the multitude of people involved in the creation of public policies and include topics ranging from philanthropy to eugenics.

name: ART-239
title: Special Topic:Introduction to Arts ofyAsia
desc: This course is an introduction to the art of Asia and to the cultures of this region as they relate to the arts.  Special attention will be paid to the historical development of the visual arts, with the aim of understanding objects in relation to culture and building awareness of the concepts that define and distinguish the visual traditions of Asia.

name: REL-264
title: Disaster and Enlightenment: PilgrimagesyIn Japan and China
desc: This course explores traditional and new forms of pilgrimages in China and Japan. In particular, it examines two kinds of pilgrimages: traditional ones to sacred mountains, sanctuaries, and other religious pilgrimage sites, on the one side, and pilgrimages to memorials that commemorate immense natural and human catastrophes in Sendai (3/11 earthquake and tsunami), Hiroshima (dropping of the atomic bomb), and Nanjing (1937/8 massacre), on the other. What connects these two kinds of pilgrimages is the importance attributed to memory, the desire for healing, and the need for reflection. The goal of this course is to investigate the religious and political dimensions of memory, self-cultivation, and contemplation. The course accomplishes this goal by examining questions such as: what is the social dimension of religious pilgrimages, what is the moral dimension of memory, and what is the spiritual dimension of healing and reconciliation? Offered only during January term.

name: AFRS-239
title: ST: Environmental Justice & SustainableyDevelopment in South Africa
desc: In this course, students will explore the environmental, political, and ethical issues raised by both development and conservation projects in South Africa and the competing priorities they reflect. Students will examine the complexities of environmental justice and sustainable development within the context of rapid economic growth in a nation with a legacy of social inequality. The course will cover topics related to energy and water rights, conservation, resource extraction, and urbanization and will include a visit to a wild life reserve as well as a service learning project in a rural community.

name: ENVS-239
title: ST: Environmental Justice & SustainableyDevelopment in South Africa
desc: In this course, students will explore the environmental, political, and ethical issues raised by both development and conservation projects in South Africa and the competing priorities they reflect. Students will examine the complexities of environmental justice and sustainable development within the context of rapid economic growth in a nation with a legacy of social inequality. The course will cover topics related to energy and water rights, conservation, resource extraction, and urbanization and will include a visit to a wild life reserve as well as a service learning project in a rural community.

name: INTS-205
title: Religion and Modernity
desc: Are people less religious today than they were five hundred years ago? Has religion lost much of the influence it once had prior to modernity, or does modernity lead less to religious decline and more to changes in how people understand and practice religion? Why do these questions matter in the modern world, or do they? This Intersections seminar examines the interdisciplinary debate and the various theories concerning the causes of religious decline and change in the modern West. We will discuss those elements of modernity and modernization that are often viewed as culprits in secularization, including industrialization, urbanization, science, technology, economic prosperity, and religious pluralism. And we will grapple with the larger questions of what kind of distinction can be made within the West between a "secular Europe" and a "religious America," and how the West differs from the Global South in terms of the influence of religion. [Rel, Hist]

name: INTS-210
title: It's All Relative
desc: We usually hear the phrase "it's all relative" used as a challenge to the stability of moral truths and the fixity of human understanding. While relativism can be a symptom of intellectual laziness, there is also a long history of thinkers who take relativism seriously, arguing that theorizing the differences in human experience is the only way to truly understand our world. In this course we'll trace the intellectual history of relativism as a serious response to fundamental questions about the limits of human knowledge in the areas of natural science, morality, language, and politics. From the master rhetoricians and sophists of ancient Greece to contemporary post-modernists, this course invites students to critically assess the consequences, both ethical and philosophical, of a relativistic worldview.

name: EDUC-226
title: Introduction to Reading
desc: Based on a synthesis of research identifying characteristics of highly effective reading teachers, this course focuses on seven pillars of effective reading instruction: teacher knowledge, classroom assessment, evidence-based teaching practices, response to intervention (RTI), motivation and engagement, technology and new literacies, and family & community connections. Special attention is paid to oral language acquisition, phonemic awareness, phonics and word identification, fluency, vocabulary, comprehension and reading assessment.

name: EDUC-372
title: Middle School General Music Methods
pre_req: Admission to the Teacher Education Program
desc: Study of the middle school learner and the content, materials, and methods of instruction in the middle school general music classroom. Includes technology and alternative ensembles as well as classroom management. Required of vocal music education minors only.

name: HIST-254
title: Russian History
desc: A general survey of Russian-Soviet history from the founding of Kievan Rus in 862 to the present day. Special emphasis given to the topic of empire, including interactions between people on the periphery and the core, the methods Russian/Soviet rulers used to expand and control territories and peoples, and how this changed over time.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar:American Mysticism:Meditation,yPsychedelics, and the Religion of NoyReligion
desc: In this seminar, students will study the history of the American countercultural religious milieu of the 1950s, 60s and 70s and its significance in the development of what came to be known as the "religion of no religion."  This enigmatic phrase --initially attributed to Frederic Spiegelberg (1897-1994), popularized by Alan Watts (1915-1973), and advanced by Michael Murphy (1930-) and Richard Price (1930-1985)-- was used to describe what some experienced as mystical insight into the unity and interconnectedness of all things.  While looking at this phenomenon, students will examine the ways that Buddhist Tantra and meditation, Daoist practice, Indian Yoga, psychedelic drug use, and Western scientific studies of the paranormal were fused together to create a way of knowing and practicing that could engender liberation, forming what can be called an American mysticism.  Students will also assess the critique levied at intellectuals of this period for merely appropriating Buddhist, Daoist, and Hindu religious and philosophical ideas, texts, and practices for their own personal and political agendas and, as such, engaging in a kind of Orientalist discourse akin to nineteenth and early twentieth century scholarship on East and South Asian traditions.

name: BIO-125
title: Genetics and Society
desc: Genetics plays an ever increasing role in our society, and a basic understanding of this field is vital for making informed decisions on issues that impact our health, safety, and environment. This course aims to connect the concepts and approaches of genetics to societal issues relating to health, diversity, forensics, and evolution. The course will provide basic coverage of the science of genetics, including the structure, expression, and transmission of heritable information and the evolution of populations. Methods and techniques, such as gene cloning and DNA fingerprinting, will be covered to provide information on how scientists use genetic technology to answer questions. Also included will be discussion of some of the ethical and social questions surrounding issues as diverse as screening human embryos for genetic traits, evaluating the genetic basis of aggressive behavior, and creating genetically modified organisms. Lecture and laboratory.

name: HIST-135
title: African-American History
desc: This course is a survey of African-American history from the 15th century to the present. Eras and topics include the trans-Atlantic slave trade, slavery in the Americas, the Civil War and Emancipation, segregation, the Great Migration, the Great Depression and World War II, the modern black freedom struggle, and the post-civil rights era.  The class emphasizes how African Americans constructed individual and collective selves, created livelihoods, formed families, communities, and institutions, fashioned cultures, defined citizenship, and consistently defied notions of a monolithic "black community." Centering African Americans' words, actions, and artistic creations and the ways they interacted with other cultures and peoples within the Americas and abroad, this course investigates how African Americans shaped and were shaped by the many worlds they traversed. (Same as AFRS 135)

name: PHIL-320
title: Value Theory: Tolerance and Toleration
desc: Tolerance and Toleration -  Ethical and political theorists have generally treated the question of tolerance in two ways:  one as a kind of virtue, the other as a kind of action (inaction really) whereby one refrains from interfering with the actions of others.  This course will explore questions about both:  Is tolerance a characteristic of a virtuous person and, if so, what characteristic is it?   What actions by others ought to be tolerated (by individuals, society or the state) and which actions ought not be tolerated?  Is there any relation between political toleration and the virtue of tolerance?  How do these questions apply to contemporary life, particularly in contexts of racial and religious diversity and power?

name: ENG-485
title: Sem: Drama and/in time
pre_req: Take 2 courses from courses ENG-352-354 ENG-361 -368 ENG-251;
desc: Contemporary popular drama increasingly leans towards movie franchises and years-long TV series. There is a rich tradition of sophisticated, complex serial drama stretching back centuries. This course will examine long-form drama, investigating the dramatic features, thematic preoccupations, and narrative structures common to this tradition. Reading multiple play cycles (Aeschylus' Oresteia, Shakespeare's Henry VI plays, and Tony Kushner's Angels in America) and watching one season of a TV show (HBO's Deadwood), we will explore the way in which serial performances lend themselves to questions of time and narrative, history and memory, performativity and representation, justice and religion, and, especially, the construction of community.

name: MUS-491
title: Senior Project in MusicyEducation
desc: This senior project option is open to seniors in the music education program only.  Focus is on creation of a research-based Developing Portfolio.

name: HIST-485
title: African American History in the JazzyAge and the Great Depression
desc: The period between World War I and World War II was a vibrant, violent time in African American History. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) grew exponentially, fighting important legal battles and lobbying the federal government to pass anti-lynching legislation. Harlem, Chicago, Washington DC, and Paris became sites of active black arts communities, filled with jazz and blues musicians, novelists and poets, painters and dancers, and entrepreneur owners of the spaces in which they drank. In the world of athletics, the Negro Leagues developed into important sites for community gathering. Despite such dynamismm, or perhaps because of it, cities across the nation erupted in racial conflict, often over the presence of black veterans returning home from WWI in their uniforms. When the Great Depression struck, African American umemployment hit 50%, a devastating rate above the national average. While contributing to your knowledge of the interwar period in African American history, this course will also explore different types of history, including social, economic, intellectual and cultural, family, and organizational.  But the focus of the course will be on research and writing. By the end of the semester, students will produce a journal-length paper, an exercise that will increase their analytical and writing skills. Along the way, we will collectively analyze the historiographic debates surrounding your topic, discuss your research, and evaluate your progress in research and writing.

name: PHIL-485
title: Sem:Phenomenology
desc: Phenomenology is the philosophical study of experience.  What is its nature and how does it relate to the world?  It began with Edmund Husserl, who, as a mathematician, conceived of phenomenology as the means by which philosophy could become a "rigorous science."  However, this "phenomenological springtime" was short-lived.  Within a generation, this vision fractured into many approaches, each giving conflicting  descriptions of the relationship between the subjectivity of consciousness and the objects presented in it.  This course will explore these philosophically rich views, and pay close attention to the perennial issues raised in them.

name: REL-339
title: Special Topic: Beyond Conversion andyPersuasion:Reinterpreting DominantyBiblical (and Christian) Portrayals ofyConversion
desc: For many Christians, "conversion" is a perennially important topic. With a special emphasis on the Bible and its teachings, evangelical Christianity has championed the need for "conversion" in modern life. What do biblical texts, however actually say about conversion? Is there continuity within and between the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament regarding the role and understanding of conversion? Is conversion a one-time occurrence or an ongoing process? Since conversion is often thought of as personal change or transformation resulting from being effectively persuaded of the need to change, is the model of "conversion" through persuasion the best way to think about personal change and transformation? This course will examine these and other questions. The course will also examine whether persuasion is the only (or most effective) form of rhetoric to bring about change.

name: REL-265
title: Religious Narratives in Japan: Demons,ySex, and Martial Arts
desc: This course examines religious themes in and the religious function of various narrative forms in Japan. The narratives studied in this course assume a spiritual topography that includes demons, ghosts, and gods, probe the gender and sexual identities of their characters, and introduce self-cultivation techniques such as martial arts. In particular, this course will focus on two traditional, narrative forms, Kabuki and No, and two contemporary ones, Manga and Anime. Some Kabuki and No plays function as religious ritual, while some Manga and Anime consciously reflect on moral attitudes and religious beliefs. These forms are also the product of various interactions among Japanese, Chinese, and American cultures. Analyzing these four kinds of cultural and religious expressions, the course examines the role of religious ritual and sacred texts in premodern as well as contemporary Japan. The course introduces students to religious studies methodology, critical theory (including gender and queer studies), and intercultural analysis. It will also deepen the skills in textual and literary criticism introduced in the courses fulfilling the Bible requirement. This course exposes students equally to the study of Japanese culture and the religious phenomenon.

name: HIST-126
title: Human Geography
desc: A survey of world geography combining the regional and topical approaches, the natural factors which shape the environment, such as climate, landforms and resources, will be considered, along with their impact on people, as studied in the fields of political, economic, and cultural geography. The primary focus of the course will be on basic concepts in cultural geography that will be of greatest use for students preparing to teach middle school and high school social studies.

name: ART-222
title: Art and Community:yIntroductory Art Methods & Materials
desc: This seven-week course is designed to introduce students to the dynamic and rapidly changing field of art education, this course will familiarize students with current art education terminology and trends, explore various activities, materials, units, teaching techniques, and methods of art instruction. Practical teaching experiences are included with an emphasis on engaging learners of diverse populations and implementing social justice based curriculum. Required for students seeking K-12 art teaching certification, although open to everyone, this course provides students with a strong foundation in art education content, basic art concepts and methods with an emphasis on developmentally appropriate art education in both public school and community-based settings.

name: HIST-239
title: Africa and the Two World Wars
desc: This course explores the fortunes of African societies during the First and Second World Wars and introduces students to Africa's involvement in those wars. It debunks initial assumptions which regarded both wars as essentially European conflicts. Though the triggers for war originated in Europe, Africa, by dint of its colonial relationship with Europe, could not have escaped the vicissitudes of both global crises. Topics covered include the continent's military contribution in Africa, Europe and Asia, military logistics, and the wider impacts of both wars on African societies. Using selected primary and secondary sources, the course examines the military, socio-economic, political, religious, and public health consequences of both wars on Africa, and investigates the origins of African nationalism after 1945.

name: AFRS-239
title: Africa and the Two World Wars
desc: This course explores the fortunes of African societies during the First and Second World Wars and introduces students to Africa's involvement in those wars. It debunks initial assumptions which regarded both wars as essentially European conflicts. Though the triggers for war originated in Europe, Africa, by dint of its colonial relationship with Europe, could not have escaped the vicissitudes of both global crises. Topics covered include the continent's military contribution in Africa, Europe and Asia, military logistics, and the wider impacts of both wars on African societies. Using selected primary and secondary sources, the course examines the military, socio-economic, political, religious, and public health consequences of both wars on Africa, and investigates the origins of African nationalism after 1945.

name: ANTH-239
title: Special Topic: The Price of Progress:yImpacts of Mining and Tourism onyIndigenous Peoples in the Andes
desc: This course explores the pressures that transnational mining and tourist corporations have on key resources like water in the Atacama Desert in northern Chile.  In particular, we will examine how these pressures affect the sustainability of indigenous peoples that have depended on water for agriculture and pastoralism since time immemorial.  The course will focus on the Atacmeno culture of northern Chile, examining the ways in which Atacamenos of the Loa and San Pedro River basins are adapting to, or in some cases resisting the social, political, economic and environmental conditions that are affecting them.  This course also explores how mining and tourist corporations have adopted the discourse of "corporate social responsibility" in trying to convince the public that they are practicing "green" mining and "green" tourism.

name: COMS-239
title: Special Topic:Communication and Sportyin New Zealand
desc: This course investigates communication and sport in New Zealand with specific focuses on media, history, technology, consumer culture, nation-building, globalization, player-coach relationships, and team/group cohesion.  Information on these subjects will be drawn from lectures, discussions, and interviews, as well as from event attendance and visits to museums, media companies, training locations, and club headquarters.  These undertakings will provide an in-depth framework on the sport ethnography of the country, as well as athletic leadership styles and techniques that are in use and provide structure for sport in New Zealand.  Students that have taken COMS 260 Sport, Media, and Society in New Zealand cannot enroll in this course.

name: PAID-450
title: Entrepreneurship and the Common Good
desc: Entrepreneurship has always been central to the American Dream. New types of entrepreneurs centered in California's "Silicon Valley" are transforming marketing, communications, and the operations of almost every business in society. Home to many of the institutions and corporations that are driving this technological change, the region harbors some of the wealthiest and most powerful people on the planet. At the same time, Silicon Valley contains some of the greatest wealth and income inequality in the nation. Students in this course will have the opportunity to speak with innovators and industry leaders including entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, engineers and marketing professionals. At the same time, students will also speak with civic leaders, policy experts, and various social service providers who help those who are trapped in poverty and lack economic opportunity. Students will wrestle with several ethical questions throughout the course related to the following themes: higher education and civic responsibility; entrepreneurship and the common good; and technology and economic inequality.

name: ANTH-185
title: The Gift of Fire
desc: The ability to control fire represents one of the most important developments in the human saga.  This class will explore the central issues associated with this development ranging from the evidence for the initial use and production of fire, fire's technological functions in pre-industrial societies, and a consideration of its symbolic meaning.  As part of this inquiry students will research and replicate preindustrial fire making techniques.

name: SW-239
title: Our World in 2050:Living with ClimateyChange
desc: This course will assist students in planning the kind of world, community, and family they would like to live in in 2050 and consider ways to create that preferred future. Study will include: effects of climate change and resource depletion, political and economic trends, predictions about the state of the world and community life in 2050, and ways to plan and make ethical choices about the future. This will include looking at how individuals behave and interact within political, economic, or cultural institutions and how this changes over time. The course will also consider ways to create a preferred future community and world such as public policy change, sustainable community development, entrepreneurship, electoral politics, technology, etc. The primary focus will be on global climate change and planetary resource limits as drivers of change although there are, of course, many forces shaping the future.

name: ANTH-209
title: Born to Run
desc: Humans possess a capacity for endurance running that is virtually unmatched in the natural world. Understanding this capacity requires consideration of its biological and cultural dimensions.  The physiology of long distance running can only be understood by studying the larger environmental and behavioral conditions under which it evolved.  Similarly, ethnographic accounts from diverse cultural groups provide essential insights for understanding the meanings of and reasons for running among modern humans.  This course uses each perspective to provide insight into the "how" and "why" of this phenomenon and will examine associated topics such as barefoot running, optimal running speed, and the relationship between genetics, gender, and running performance.

name: SPAN-335
title: Cultural Expressions of the HispanicyWorld
desc: This course studies the Spanish-speaking world through its cultural manifestations: language, literature, film, arts, television, music, and the news media.  Several topics are offered on a rotating basis:  cinema, social revolution and the arts, Hispanics in the U.S., current events, popular music and poetry, Spanish and Latin American civilizations.  May be taken up to two times for credit under different topics.

name: THE-239
title: Special Topic: Washington TheateryExperience (Washington Consortium)
desc: Available only to students participating in the Washington semester program.

name: HIST-239
title: Special Topic:Jews in Germany
desc: Course is offered for students during their Munster study abroad semester.

name: LING-493
title: Senior Honors Project
desc: A year-long independent research project. Applications are completed on the "Honors Program" form available at the registrar's office, requiring the signatures of a faculty supervisor, the department head, the honors program director, and the registrar. Interdisciplinary projects require the signatures of two faculty supervisors. The project must be completed by the due date for senior projects. The completed project is evaluated by a review committee consisting of the faculty supervisor, another faculty member from the major department, and a faculty member from outside the major department. All projects must be presented publicly. Only projects awarded an "A- or A" qualify for "department honors" designation. The honors project fulfills the all-college senior project requirement.

name: PAID-450
title: Cold Wars Then and Now:Germany, CzechyRepublic, and Ukraine
desc: Cold War politics have resurfaced with a vengeance in Europe today. Recent resurgence of Russian nationalism and E.U. economic crises have made it hard to ignore that the Cold War is no longer cold. In this course we'll investigate why the walls of old Cold War conflicts fell and what kinds of new ones are being built today. The course begins in Germany with site visits to Berlin, a city literally divided until 1989, as well as Potsdam and Dresden, locations important to old and new German identities. With Prague we study an early analog for defiance against Soviet control to shed light on the contemporary struggles in Ukraine. In Kyiv (Kiev) we focus on speaking with young Ukrainians, including students active in the country's desire for autonomy. Throughout our travel, we'll study the history, ideologies, and critical responses to different interpretations of justice, freedom, and self-determination in modern society.

name: PAID-450
title: Dao, Mao, Now:Chinese Perspectives onyChange
desc: With the world's largest population and a fast-growing economy, China today is a major global site of change. This study away course invites students to explore the current challenges China faces with first-hand experiences combined with a historical understanding of Chinese ethical systems and structures. Both Daoism and Maoism have played major roles in Chinese society and have been constantly reinvented by the current one-party controlled-market economy model. The course is grounded in Chengdu, capital city of Sichuan, China's most populous province, and home to the Chengdu Giant Panda Base ecological research center. This area provides rich resources to study the origins and legacies of Daoism and Maoism as well as the sea change brought in by post-socialism across the social, environmental, political, and aesthetic spheres. In addition to Chengdu, the course includes site visits to historically vital mountains and temples as well as an encounter with Tibetan culture. Through readings, lectures, site visits, interviews, and individual projects, students will explore ethical frameworks for decision-making past and present that are well outside the Euro-American experience. Specific decision-making arenas engage dynamics between economy and ecology and include urban and agricultural environmental issues, education policies and practice, and the preservation and change of cultural practices such as local teahouse and opera traditions.

name: HIST-185
title: Oral Tradition and the Epic of Sundiata
desc: Sundiata, founder of the ancient kingdom of Mali, is usually remembered for his military prowess, daring, and courageous exploits in war, and for his political acumen in uniting the disparate Mande clans to form the kingdom of Mali. The Epic of Sundiata is important for its portrayal of the rich cultural heritage and the foundations of political, social, and religious systems in medieval Africa. This course will be mainly based on African legends, customs, and mythology, and will introduce students to the role of griots (professional bards or hereditary keepers of oral traditions) in preserving the story of Sundiata, the majesty and mysteries of medieval African kingship, and Sundiata's role in elevating the kingdom of Mali to greatness in medieval times. The course aims to show how oral tradition intersects with other disciplines in the humanities to illuminate part of Africa's pre-colonial past. Through an examination of various oral traditions, cultural interactions, and the human experience, students will be enabled to interrogate Western perceptions and criticisms of oral sources and recorded history in delineating Africa's rich historical past.

name: AFRS-185
title: Oral Tradition and the Epic of Sundiata
desc: Sundiata, founder of the ancient kingdom of Mali, is usually remembered for his military prowess, daring, and courageous exploits in war, and for his political acumen in uniting the disparate Mande clans to form the kingdom of Mali. The Epic of Sundiata is important for its portrayal of the rich cultural heritage and the foundations of political, social, and religious systems in medieval Africa. This course will be mainly based on African legends, customs, and mythology, and will introduce students to the role of griots (professional bards or hereditary keepers of oral traditions) in preserving the story of Sundiata, the majesty and mysteries of medieval African kingship, and Sundiata's role in elevating the kingdom of Mali to greatness in medieval times. The course aims to show how oral tradition intersects with other disciplines in the humanities to illuminate part of Africa's pre-colonial past. Through an examination of various oral traditions, cultural interactions, and the human experience, students will be enabled to interrogate Western perceptions and criticisms of oral sources and recorded history in delineating Africa's rich historical past.

name: AFRS-185
title: James Baldwin and Black AmericanyLgbt History
desc: By examining the provocative writings of James Baldwin (1924-1987), this course will seek to understand America through the eyes of a black gay outcast. From his homes abroad in Paris and Istanbul, Baldwin wrote his way to becoming one of the most insightful voices of the mid-twentieth century. Through his life and words, in addition to scholarship about him, we will gain a distinct vantage point into religion, race, homosexuality, masculinity, American identity and black American identity, and the ways in which these categories overlap, from the Great Depression through the Civil Rights Movement.

name: HIST-185
title: James Baldwin and Black AmericanyLgbt History
desc: By examining the provocative writings of James Baldwin (1924-1987), this course will seek to understand America through the eyes of a black gay outcast. From his homes abroad in Paris and Istanbul, Baldwin wrote his way to becoming one of the most insightful voices of the mid-twentieth century. Through his life and words, in addition to scholarship about him, we will gain a distinct vantage point into religion, race, homosexuality, masculinity, American identity and black American identity, and the ways in which these categories overlap, from the Great Depression through the Civil Rights Movement.

name: WGST-185
title: James Baldwin and Black AmericanyLgbt History
desc: By examining the provocative writings of James Baldwin (1924-1987), this course will seek to understand America through the eyes of a black gay outcast. From his homes abroad in Paris and Istanbul, Baldwin wrote his way to becoming one of the most insightful voices of the mid-twentieth century. Through his life and words, in addition to scholarship about him, we will gain a distinct vantage point into religion, race, homosexuality, masculinity, American identity and black American identity, and the ways in which these categories overlap, from the Great Depression through the Civil Rights Movement.

name: ART-239
title: Special Topics: Modern andyContemporary Chinese Art
desc: This course will explore Chinese art from the Late Qing (mid-19th century) through the present, with particular emphasis on artists, works of art, and the institutional, social, artistic, and theoretical contexts from which they emerged. The course will focus on ways in which Chinese artists of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries have defined modernity and their tradition against the complex background of China's history. The course will also examine how Chinese artists have chosen to adopt Western conventions and the extent to which they have rejected them. Through examining art works in different media, including oil painting, graphic design, woodblock prints, traditional ink-and-color painting, and recent performance, installation and video art, along with theoretical writing, bibliographical and institutional data, and other documentary materials, the course will investigate the most compelling of the multiple realities that Chinese artists have constructed for themselves. By learning about the complexity of modern and contemporary Chinese art, and the historical forces behind them, students will gain fuller understanding of twentieth-century modernism.

name: ART-339
title: Special Topics: Global Currents andyLocal Responses: Art in the 21styCentury
desc: Contemporary art is increasingly recognized as a transnational, global phenomenon. This course will briefly examine historical conditions that laid the foundation for what is recognized today as an international field of contemporary art and explore in depth some of the most critical issues in the field. Even as art-exhibiting practices continue to associate artists with their nationalities, much of contemporary art in the 21st century challenge the dominancy of racial, cultural and national identities as the most salient factors for their understanding. The course will explore how forces of globalization have shaped artistic practice and critical interpretation. More than ever before, artists today are multi-national or multi-cultural, explore global or transnational issues in their art, and exhibit internationally. At the same time that "peripheral" cities (Dubai, Budapest, Johannesburg, Beijing, Havana, etc.) and regions (Asia, Middle East, Latin America, etc.) across the world participate in the production of "contemporary art," certain artists and curators have promoted the development of localized practices and site-specificity as corrective forces for maintaining diversity and growth. This course will focus on a select body of artworks and texts produced by figures within the wide world of contemporary art in order to understand the positions they represent. Embedded within three thematic units will be examinations of specific geographical regions, artists, aesthetic and conceptual currents, as well as larger theoretical frameworks such as post-colonial, postmodern, gender, and diaspora studies.

name: ENG-185
title: Grammar Cops and Criminals
desc: Are you a "grammar criminal"? Do you sometimes use "improper" English because you grew up with a different way of writing or speaking? Or do you sometimes violate grammar, style, or speaking rules on purpose because you prefer the effect of a different choice? If so, you might find yourself busted by a "grammar cop" (or "language cop" or "style cop"). Sometimes, these protectors of the English language get angry when new words are added to the dictionary, or they consider a person unintelligent for speaking with an accent. Sometimes they use language to include, exclude, rank and sort others into groups. Why is this? Why do some people find it important to protect standard English, and why do others choose to rebel against it? In this course, we'll examine these questions while experimenting with standard and non-standard types of written and spoken English. In discussions, presentations, and writings, students will consider the advantages and disadvantages of choosing a "life of crime" when using the English language.

name: CHEM-371
title: Polymer Chemistry
desc: An introduction to polymer science that examines the synthesis, characterization, and properties of macromolecules.  Emphasis is placed upon mechanisms of polymerization, the stereochemistry of monomer enchainment, the determination of molar mass distributions, and the thermal properties of bulk polymers.  Offered alternate years.

name: COMS-295
title: Directed Study
desc: An opportunity to pursue individualized or experiential learning with a faculty member, at the sophomore level or above, either within or outside the major. Only offered during fall, spring and summer terms.

name: ENG-185
title: Africans in America
desc: Some of the most interesting writing published in the United States in recent years is fiction by Africans who have come to this country. In reflecting on their lives in Africa from the perspective of their lives in the U.S., and on their lives in the U.S. from the perspective of being African, these writers provide rich insights into both of their 'home' countries regarding identity, race, gender, politics, and culture, and they do so in prose that is often beautiful, moving, and at times troubling. Among the writers we'll read are Chimamanda Adichie (Nigerian), Dinaw Mengestu (Ethiopian), and NoViolet Bulawayo (Zimbabawean).

name: ENG-239
title: Special Topics: Motionpoems
desc: Take a great contemporary poem, add sound, light, action, image, music-and the result is a short poetic film, a dynamic unfolding poem: a Motionpoem. In this course, the Minnesota poet Todd Boss will guide students as they create their own Motionpoems. Through collaborative and creative work, the students will explore film making techniques, film scoring, visual imagery, and the power of poetry to move and delight us. Class visitors may include artists, musicians,and producers. This course welcomes everyone who is interested in making a wonderful and original flash of art. Todd Boss is the founding Executive and Artistic Director of Motionpoems, the world's only poetry film company. The course will be graded Credit/No-Credit.

name: ENVS-185
title: Mining the Earth: How Long Will It Last?
desc: Stop texting, stop driving, and stop eating. Our phones, computers, cars, and food have just run out. Some predict this could be our future reality if we continue consuming Earth's natural resources at current rates. Competition for metals, oil, and fresh water is growing every day. Where do these resources occur and how long will they last? Are the potential environmental problems associated with acquiring these resources worth the risk? Should we continue to mine the Earth? We will examine these and related questions through in-class discussions, fieldtrips, and by drawing on your individual experiences with resource use in a Lifestyle Project. By the end of this course you will be able to describe the geologic controls on Earth's mineral, energy, and water resources, assess the environmental impact of resource use, and evaluate strategies for minimizing these impacts.

name: GS-185
title: The Examined Life Is Worth Living
desc: The ancient Greek philosopher Socrates, as recorded by Plato in his account of the trial and conviction of his mentor, noted that "the unexamined life is not worth living." In this course we will turn this statement on its head - and will use books, films, & guest speakers to reflect upon some big-life questions including: Who am I? How are others different from me and how am I different from them? What does it mean to live a good life, a happy life, a meaningful life? The course will be taught in a spirit of gentle reflection using various writing, discussion and presentation exercises to process the material. Participants will also learn a variety of tools to help them discern answers to the course's questions. Throughout the course, the emphases will be on self-awareness and self-acceptance, for the purpose of personal growth.

name: MATH-339
title: Special Topics: Combinatorics
pre_req: Take Math-220; Math-240 or consent of instructor.
desc: In this course we will survey a wide variety of topics in combinatorics, an area of mathematics which focuses on understanding arrangements of objects, including things like permutations and combinations, but also more rigid structures like Sudoku grids. We are interested in questions such as how many arrangements of a particular type exist, what sorts of structure those arrangements have, and sometimes whether any such arrangements exist at all. Topics in this course may include: combinations, permutations, the Binomial Theorem, Catalan numbers, the pigeonhole principle, the principle of inclusion and exclusion, derangements, Latin squares, graph theory, Ramsey theory, and design theory.

name: MATH-439
title: Special Topics: Methods of AppliedyMathematics
desc: This course will be devoted to developing mathematical methods useful in the physical sciences. Topics may include dimensional analysis and scaling, perturbation methods, calculus of variations and Hamilton's principle, boundary value problems, Green's functions, and integral equations.

name: PHIL-185
title: The Question of Evil
desc: What is evil, how does it arise, and how should we give an account of it? Does evil arise from some supernatural power, or does it arise from social conditions? Does evil stem from ignorance, or does it emerge from purposeful intentions? In this course, students will analyze some of the classic philosophical approaches to these questions, beginning with Plotinus and ending with Martin Luther King, Jr.'s "The Three Evils of Society."

name: POLS-239
title: Special Topics: Gender, Politics, andyAnd the Iowa Caucuses
desc: Using the Iowa Caucuses as a focal point, this course will explore the role of gender and its impact on the US political system. How does gender influence the process of nominating presidential candidates? We will examine gender in public policy, political activism, political campaigns and advertising, debates, political media coverage, and elections. Class may include direct observations of Iowa Caucus meetings if scheduling permits. As we analyze gender in the caucus system, class will closely follow ongoing caucus related current political events in January 2016.

name: WGST-239
title: Special Topics: Gender, Politics, andyThe Iowa Caucuses
desc: Using the Iowa Caucuses as a focal point, this course will explore the role of gender and its impact on the US political system. How does gender influence the process of nominating presidential candidates? We will examine gender in public policy, political activism, political campaigns and advertising, debates, political media coverage, and elections. Class may include direct observations of Iowa Caucus meetings if scheduling permits. As we analyze gender in the caucus system, class will closely follow ongoing caucus related current political events in January 2016.

name: REL-185
title: Imagining Religion With the Beatles
desc: The music of the Beatles took shape during a revolutionary decade in which old patterns of religious belief and practice were being challenged and new forms of spirituality were emerging. We will examine the philosophical, spiritual, and religious themes in the music and musings of the Beatles in order to gain a better perspective on what was happening to religion in Britain and America during the 1960s and how the Beatles influenced generations of spiritual seekers and skeptics alike.

name: REL-185
title: Darwin, Drugs, and the Divine:yScientific and Religious Approaches toyMental Health
desc: This course will engage students in a critical analysis of the influence of fundamental religious and scientific worldviews on our understanding of the nature of mental illness and its treatment. Can human mental and emotional experience be reduced to the level of brain biochemistry or does it have a reality of its own? Is mental illness primarily a physical phenomenon or does it result from a spiritual crisis? Is it some of both? Can we definitively answer such questions? This course will not seek to provide definitive answers, nor will it be a forum for providing mental health advice. It will rather be an intellectual analysis of how fundamental scientific and religious perspectives help shape how our society constructs its understanding of mental illness and its appropriate treatment along with an ethical reflection on those constructions and the treatments they authorize.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: Eco-Reformation
desc: Protestants in general, and Lutherans in particular, are gearing up to commemorate the 500th anniversary of the Reformation in 2017. A growing number of pastors, laity, theologians, teachers, authors, and activists are emphasizing the critical need today for an Eco-Reformation. They argue the collective impact of human production, consumption, and reproduction is undermining the ecological systems that support human life on Earth. If human beings don't reform their relationship with the planet enormous suffering will befall many-especially the weakest and most vulnerable among all species. Students in this course will read, discuss, and critique books and essays by leading scholars that advocate for an Eco-Reformation and assess proposed means to bring one about.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: Religion and Bioethics
desc: Technological advances in medicine and healthcare often raise new ethical questions even as they create new treatment possibilities. In this course, we will explore the ethical questions prompted by organ transplantation, embryonic stem cell research, assisted reproductive technologies, and other medical advances. We will examine the ways in which the sources of religious traditions have been used to engage these ethical questions, with special attention to writings from the Christian, Jewish, and Muslim traditions.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: Reading the Bible LikeyThe Rabbis: an Introduction to Midrash
desc: This course introduces midrash, a genre of biblical interpretation developed by early Jewish rabbis after the destruction of the Second Temple. Through the examination of examples of midrash (in English), we will consider the types of questions the rabbis asked about the biblical text, as well as the techniques they used and the goals they pursued in crafting midrashic interpretations. Finally, we will explore efforts among Jewish theologians to create new examples of midrash that respond to changing values in contemporary life and culture.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: Genesis, God, and theyPolitics of Creation: A Racial/EthicyAppraisal
desc: The book of Genesis is a foundational text credited with God's creation of the world and everything in it. But this creation raises complex moral and ethical issues that call into question the very nature of the creator and the created. For example, in Genesis 1-3, God creates Adam and Eve and places them in the Garden of Eden. But then he alerts them to a tree called "the tree of the knowledge of good and evil" and warns them not to eat of its fruits least they die. Regardless of the warning, Adam and Eve eat of the fruit, leading to the Adam/Eve "blame game" and God's punishments of the duo that rupture the relationship between Adam and Eve. It transforms the relationship from "bone of my "bones" to "thorn in my flesh." This necessitates a reflection on a number of questions: Did God set Adam/Eve up for failure? Why did God give different punishments? In Genesis 4 God accepts Abel's offering while rejecting that of Cain leading to the first human hatred and murder in the Bible. Why does God favor one offering over and against another (in the process creating good/bad attributes for Cain/Abel)? This course is an exegetical study that seeks to address the politics of creation inherent in Genesis (who is God? Why does he create through differentiation? Who are the winners/losers of God's creative activity?) as the "seeds" for racial/ethnic conflicts in the biblical and contemporary world.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: Constructing IdentityyThrough Archaeology: Israel andyPalestine
desc: Constructing Identity through Archaeology - Israel and Palestine: This course will examine how archaeology in Israel and Palestine influenced and was influenced by Jewish, Muslim, Christian, secular, and nationalistic identities. The course will begin with studies of the 18th century and continue to the present. We will analyze the methodology that underlies competing archaeological narratives in the region as we ask whether a scientific, objective history can be told.

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: The Body of the GodsyIn the Ancient Near East
desc: The way we construct the bodies of the gods affects how we relate to our human bodies. How was a god's body constructed from clay and wood in Mesopotamia and Egypt? Did ancient Israel have a similar concept of their God's body? How was the god's body interwoven into military and political narratives? We will examine critically ancient texts and artifacts from Mesopotamia, Egypt, Israel, and Anatolia to discover how the body of a deity was constructed through rituals and used for political ends.

name: SOC-185
title: Nations Within: Native AmercianyExperiences
desc: This course will examine the historical and contemporary experience, identity, and cultural tradition of Native Americans in the United States and greater North America. The exploration of contemporary issues related to Native Americans will be addressed by exploring several pertinent questions such as: What does it mean to be Native American? What is the historical narrative that informs our current understanding of indigenous peoples? How have external depictions obscured an accurate portrayal of Native American communities? As these questions are asked and investigated, it will lead to a greater appreciation of the Native North American experience.

name: IS-450
title: Global Citizenship
desc: This course is designed for students who have lived or spent a semester or more studying abroad.  It will enable students to reflect on how their immersion in a foreign culture has affected their values and vocation.  By combining practical experiences with scholarly and artistic works, students will a)reflect on the role of culture, b)think about the articulation and application of values in the public sphere, c)explore the relation among politics, economics, culture, and society, and d)develop their own ethical perspectives as "global citizens."  There will be a heavy emphasis on writing, group work, and oral presentations.

name: REL-485
title: Seminar: Religion, Global Violence, &yThe Quest for Peace
pre_req: Take 3 courses in Religion or consent of instructor.
desc: The tragic events of September 11, 2001, engendered increased interest on the relationship between religion and violence as well as religion and peacemaking. This seminar explores the academic and political debates in the post-9/11 West over these relationships with a focus on the following questions. In what ways can religions be instrumentalized for both violence and peace? Do the texts, theologies, and traditions of some religions encourage violence more than others? How do religious ideologies interact with other political, cultural, and historical factors to produce violent acts? What distinguishes religious violence from secular violence, and why might such a distinction matter? How do theories of religion's relationship to violence influence how religious practitioners develop models of peacemaking?

name: REL-239
title: Special Topics: "Black Lives Matter":yA Biblical Theology ofyConfrontation
desc: A new Gallup poll found that the percentage of Americans "satisfied with the way blacks are treated in U.S. society" has dropped to a low not seen in 15 years, falling from 67% in 2013 to 49% in 2015. White Americans are more likely now than in January of 2015 to see the death of a black man at the hands of a white police officer as part of a broader pattern of racism rather than an isolated incident. The "Black Lives Matter" movement raises the hot burning question of the day-In America, Do Black Lives Really Matter? While the debates surrounding the "Black Lives Matter" movement are often heated, this course seeks to explore the theology at the heart of this movement and to compare that theology to various examples of "confrontational theology" within biblical writings that clearly identify specific groups and classes of people as objects of divine concern. In so doing, this course will provide an opportunity to critically examine difficult portions of the biblical text-portions that often do not fit into the peaceful, passive theology dominant in much of Western Christianity-and to explore the numerous confrontational elements of biblical texts in general and the portrayal of Jesus' ministry in particular.

name: AFRS-239
title: Special Topics: "Black Lives Matter":yA Biblical Theology ofyConfrontation
desc: A new Gallup poll found that the percentage of Americans "satisfied with the way blacks are treated in U.S. society" has dropped to a low not seen in 15 years, falling from 67% in 2013 to 49% in 2015. White Americans are more likely now than in January of 2015 to see the death of a black man at the hands of a white police officer as part of a broader pattern of racism rather than an isolated incident. The "Black Lives Matter" movement raises the hot burning question of the day-In America, Do Black Lives Really Matter? While the debates surrounding the "Black Lives Matter" movement are often heated, this course seeks to explore the theology at the heart of this movement and to compare that theology to various examples of "confrontational theology" within biblical writings that clearly identify specific groups and classes of people as objects of divine concern. In so doing, this course will provide an opportunity to critically examine difficult portions of the biblical text-portions that often do not fit into the peaceful, passive theology dominant in much of Western Christianity-and to explore the numerous confrontational elements of biblical texts in general and the portrayal of Jesus' ministry in particular.

name: HIST-171
title: History of Africa to 1880
desc: Survey of African history from the earliest times to roughly about 1880.  The course begins with the historical development of Africa's still-vital cultural, linguistic, social, and economic systems and moves on to examine the Islamic and Christian impact on these systems through the era of the Atlantic slave trade. The course concludes by discussing the ways in which early European colonialism affected the African past. (Same as AFRS 171)

name: POLS-485
title: Seminar: Media and the PoliticalyProcess
desc: This course explores the role of media in the political process. Focusing more directly on traditional media (print and television) but also addressing the rise of social media, students explore in more detail the role language plays in the political process. Through class discussions and the use of content analysis (a well-established methodological tradition in Communication Studies and Political Science), this course encourages students to think deeply about the role media plays in the political process. A major aspect of this course is a research paper where students use content analysis to analyze a specific issue related to media and politics, broadly defined.

name: ENG-130
title: Literary Ventures:Uses of Memory
desc: Writers of all genres call on their memories for material, and in the course we will explore the different tools that memory presents, both in existing literature and in our own writing.  We will explore memory in short stories, graphic novels, essays, and poetry, from James Baldwin to Jhumpa Lahiri and plenty in between.  We'll discover why a writer might employ the same memories in a memoir and a book of poetry, or why someone might switch from nonfiction to fiction smack in the middle of a narrative.  We'll ask whether the line between fiction and nonfiction really matters at all.  We'll even explore the nature of memory.  Can people inherit memory?  Do our senses contain memory?  Can a culture remember?  And what do we do when memory fails?

name: HIST-321
